1 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Nigerian Skipper Confident


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ATHENS, United States (PANA) - Nigeria's under-23 team captain Nwankwo Kanu said he never felt that the team would lose to Brazil, even when they were two goals down with 12 minutes to go in Wednesday's second semi-final of the Olympic soccer tie.

Kanu, the two-goal hero of Nigeria's 4-3 victory against Brazil said his confidence was based on the fact that the south Americans were tired in the second half.

"We saw that the Brazilians were not playing. They were tired and they were missing a lot of chances," Kanu told a packed post-match conference. 

"We believed in ourselves that we were going to do it and by the grace of god, we have done it," the Nigerian forward said.

He challenged a journalist's assertion that he was losing the leadership of the team to more-aggressive players like Emmanuel Amunike or Daniel Amokachi, saying: "I don't think so, I am the leader."

"If you are calling the team leader, I am the team leader, so there is no problem in the team. And I have tried all my best...if I am not a good team leader, we can't be there (in the final)," said Kanu.

On the final match against Argentina on Saturday, Kanu, locked in a salary arbitration battle since June 15 over a proposed multi- million-dollar transfer from Ajax Amsterdam to Internazionale of Italy, promised that his team would work hard for victory.

"Nigeria has never won the trophy, and we have come all out to win," he told the conference, adding "so if Argentina is coming out to play all their best, we are also coming out to play all our best."

Kanu's goal in the 90th minute levelled score for Nigeria at 3-3, and he sent the country to its first-ever Olympic soccer final with a clincher four minutes into the sudden-death extra time.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 1, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
African Soccer Hour Has Arrived, Says Nigeria Coach


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ATHENS, United States (PANA) - Nigerian technical adviser Jo Bonfrere has described the country's 4-3 victory over Brazil in the semi-finals of the Olympic soccer event as a sign of maturity of African football.

Bonfrere told reporters after the match, played in Athens, U.S., that there was no longer any gap between a "good-playing team" like Brazil and a team from Africa.

"Now the gap between the good playing teams and African and Asian teams is very close and it is now a matter of tactic and how the players themselves approach matches," he said. 

The Dutch coach said his team encountered a lot of organisational problems which, he said, disturbed its preparations for the tournament, recalling that five days to the start of the competition, he didn't have all his players in camp.

"But I talked with the team before this game. I told them to forget all the problems for one-and-a-half hours and then, after this game, we can start with new problems," he said.

Bonfrere said that skipper Nwankwo Kanu had not played well in the competition because he reported late to camp, but said that he had decided to forgive him "because he made the final goal today."

With Brazil's lead cut to 3-2 toward the end of the match, Kanu struck in the 90th minute to force the match into extra time. He scored again four minutes later to ensure Nigeria's first-ever qualification for the Olympic soccer final.

Meanwhile, Nigerian sports minister Jim Nwobodo says the players have shown, by Wednesday's victory, that they are indeed a "dream team".

"Only great teams achieve this kind of feat," the minister, emerging from the players' dressing room, said.

He described the match as miraculous, saying "nothing can be better than this."

The chairman of the Nigeria Football Association (NFA), retired air commodore Emeka Omeruah, said the outcome of the match was "like a dream."

Nigerian football authorities had pulled all the necessary strings to motivate the country's Olympic soccer team for Wednesday's semi-final match against Brazil.

Two days to the match, the players were all paid their match-winning bonus (for match against Mexico) of 5,000 U.S. dollars each.

Then the players were moved into a hotel in Athens, venue of the match because the accommodation in the city's Olympic village was said not to be conducive.

The Omeruah promised to do whatever was necessary to put the players in the right frame of mind for clinching the Olympic soccer gold on Saturday, against Argentina at the same venue.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


3 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Brazilian Coach Commends Nigerian Team


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

ATHENS, United States (PANA) - Brazilian coach Mario Zagallo has attributed his team's 3-4 loss to Nigeria in the Olympic soccer semi-final to bad luck and superior play by the west Africans.

"I believe it was bad luck, especially to concede a goal in the last minute, " Zagallo, speaking through an interpreter, said after the match at the Sanford stadium in Athens, U.S.

"But Nigeria played very well and we have to give it to them," added the coach, one of only two men in the world to have ever won the world cup both as a player and a coach.

Zagallo, 64, praised the Nigerian players for their tenacity even when they were two goals down and after they had lost a penalty. 

"The important thing is that Nigeria never lost faith, especially after missing the penalty," he said. "Instead, they were the ones who took over, and it was an incredible game," he added.

"Nigeria has shown today that they have a strong potential. They did not lose strength especially when they were losing. They turned it into a very beautiful game."

Asked what he would have done differently if the match were to be re-played, the Brazilian coach said that it did not matter what he did or did not do, noting: "the match was bound to be tough."

"It will be a very difficult game, just as this one, no matter what," he said.

Commenting on the overall play of his team, Zagallo, member of Brazil's world cup winning teams in 1958 and 1962, indicated that there might have been too much expectation from his players.

"From the beginning I have said that there is no such thing as easy football," he said, adding: "we began the competition by losing to Japan, but now we have also lost to a very good team."

Zagallo, who coached Brazil's 1970 winning team and was assistant coach in 1994, said that he had not lost all hopes of an Olympic medal, promising to go after the bronze in the third-place match against Portugal on Friday at the same venue.

Nigeria, which was 1-3 with 12 minutes to go, cancelled the deficit to send the match into an extra time, where it scored the "golden goal" in the fourth minute to prevail.

A crowd of over 78,000 witnessed the dream team's stunning victory, played under 81 degrees heat and cloudy skies.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996

4 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1996


Zambia;
Party Does U-Turn Over Inter-Party Talks


BYLINE: Sipo Kapumba, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) has back-tracked on its earlier position that it was willing to compromise over the chairmanship of the inter-party talks.

ZDC general secretary Derrick Chitala said in an interview yesterday that the talks could only succeed if they were chaired by a neutral chairman. 

"There is conflict in the nation and arbitration can only be through a neutral chairman,

"During the UNIP days the church and s tudents were called to mediate so why should it be different now?" Chitala said in a statement that appears to contradict his President Dean Mung'omba's statement last week.

"It is in the best interests of the country for us to run away from rigid positions," Mung'omba said in an interview last Tuesday. "If the chairmanship is a rigid position it should be considered from both our side and that of the ruling party."

Chitala denied that ZDC had backed down, he instead said the ruling party should be reasonable in its demands.

"We are dealing with an issue of life and death such as attempts by the government to rig the elections through Nikuv and the constitution which has been rejected by many people," Chitala said.

"If some people are not satisfied with the electoral process they will do everything to wreck this country and we are not prepared to allow Chiluba to lead the country to that."

The ZDC's position further erodes any hope of interparty dialogue taking place as MMD insists that only Chiluba should chair the talks.

Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) chairman Roger Chongwe said in an interview on Tuesday the MMD's rigidity showed the party was not interested in dialogue with the opposition.

5 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1996


Science;
Zambia In Second Round Of Polio Eradication


BYLINE: Goodson Machona and Samson Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - New population projections for children below five years are being worked out in readiness for the second round of the National Immunisation Days (NIDS), Head of the Maternal Child and Family Planning department in the Ministry of Health, Dr Dean Phiri, has disclosed.

According to Phiri, this measure has been taken following a joint meeting held by the Ministry of Health and officials from the Central Statistics Office (CSO) a fortnight ago to find out what led to the running out of vaccines at some posts during the first round of NIDS.

"The Central Statistics Office is working out details to project vaccine requirements for the next round," Dr Phiri disclosed at a press briefing yesterday adding that an additional three million Oral Polio Vaccines (OPV) had been ordered to supplement existing stocks. 

Phiri conceded that during the first round, the NID secretariate underestimated the population figures for children needing immunization resulting in some areas running out of vaccines.

"The distribution of population figures was different from what was expected," Phiri said. "We didn't take into account the movement of the population from rural to urban areas since the last census was done."

He also noted that the declining life expectancy in Zambia has led to a change in the population structure.

"There seems to be an increase in the younger population," he said.

He however noted that the overall response to the first round of NIDS was a success.

"The number of children of 0-5 years immunised throughout the country was over 80 per cent," Dr Phiri said, adding that the remaining 20 per cent will be catered for in routine programmes.

"This is just the first phase towards the eradication of polio," he explained. "The next step is to mop up all remaining pockets of those not immunised through routine programmes."

He, however, complained that financial resources have been depleted.

"Most of the funds went towards putting the logistics in place and there is nothing to pay the volunteers," Phiri moaned.

United Nations International Children's Fund (UNICEF) representative, Grace Kagondo, disclosed that there are over 40 volunteers country-wide and appealed to various service clubs and the business community to "take care of the volunteers".

NID co-ordinator, Mary Kaoma, promised at the same briefing that there would be no shortage of vaccines during the second round of NIDS and urged parents to take their children for the second round of immunisation.

"The second dose is very important as it is a booster and everybody must attend either on August 23 or 24, 1996," Kaoma said.

Deputy director of medical services, Dr Lendy Kasanda, added: "The first round was just but the first step. We can only thank ourselves if we do well in the second round."

UNITRAD representative, Kathryn Mwondela, disclosed that the theme for the eradication of Polio in Africa is "Let's boot it out of Africa".

"So let's boot it out," she said.

Polio toll free number; for any details Telephone 239180 (toll free.)


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996

6 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1996


Business;
Political Stability In Zambia 'A Must' For Investment


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - Political stability is 'a must' for the improvement of the investment climate in Zambia, said Meebelo Mutukwa, Managing Director of Pangaea Associates at a lecture on the Zambian Capital Investment Market at the British Council yesterday.

Mutukwa however, commended the regulations set up for the Lusaka Stock Exchange saying they were more than sufficient to protect the investor.

"But we must create confidence in investors, avoiding abrupt changes and sudden withdrawals in policy and introductions of laws," he told his audience drawn mainly from the business community. 

He pointed out that inconsistencies in policy had adversely affected the investment climate in the country making it difficult for Zambia to generate confidence in the investment market.

"Zambia has done so well in creating an enabling environment through instituting a viable legal framework such as the Banking and Financial Services Act of 1994 and the coming Competition and Fair Trading Act. But the problem is with the Investment Act. In the past four years, we have had so many changes in investment policy," he said.

Mutukwa gave examples of how some investors had been stuck with equipment which they thought was tax free upon ordering it but later discovered they needed to pay duty on it.

"The 1992 budget suspended all incentives in the Investment Act. And after the last budget speech, we now have to pay duty on all equipment. The ability of the government to suspend duty at such short notice might adversely affect investors who had been informed of prior measures," he said.

Speaking on both the macro and micro effects of the economy on the capital market, Mutukwa said there was need to exploit Zambia's comparative advantage: "That is, for Zambians to trade in natural assets such as tourism."

"We have to learn to compete effectively and also to invest in new technology," he said.

Chief Executive Officer of the Securities and Exchange Commission Mumba Kapumba commented that it was the voters' responsibility to ensure that leaders upheld the investment principles in the Investment Act.

General Manager of Cavmont Merchant Bank Limited, Abdul Munshi, earlier commended the installation of the stock exchange but said the public should be patient as the exchange was investment of a long term nature.

"People should not expect the stock exchange to yield huge returns overnight. As long as the laid down macro economic principles are followed, activity will pick up on the market," he said.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996

Africa News


August 1, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Journalists Declare Freedom Of Expression Vital


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The International Federation of Journalists' (IFJ) African Regional Conference has declared that democracy cannot exist without freedom of expression, access to information and independent journalism.

The IFJ has also attacked all government's acts of aggression against journalists and called for African states to provide and secure conditions of service for the survival of the profession. 

According to a press statement from Brussels, released after the conference on the "access to information" in Harare, the African nations were implored to free journalists detained for exercising their professionalism.

"As a first step, all African States should release from prison any journalists detained for exercising their profession and should incorporate into domestic law all international standards of freedom of expression," he said.

The conference attended by Benin, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Mauritius, Namibia, South Africa, Tanzania, Uganda and Zimbabwe urged governments to recognise the right to access to information and to incorporate it in the constitution.

The IFJ recommended that a full review of legislation affecting the media, including penal codes, official secrets acts and civil defamation is required at a national level to remove all legal obstacles to press freedom like criminal defamation.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

8 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1996


Business;
Food Reserve Shortfall Disclosed In Zambia


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - The Food Reserve Agency has disclosed that they will have a shortfall of 250,000 metric tonnes of grain to be purchased for strategic reserves this season.

Speaking in an interview yesterday, director of the reserve agency, Chance Kabaghe, disclosed that the government's limited funding to the purchase of grain for the strategic reserves will result in the acquisition of only 50, 000 metric tonnes of grain instead of the required 300,000. 

"Ideally we are supposed to purchase 300,000 metric tonnes but Parliament only allocated K10 billion for the exercise," Kabaghe said.

Among the grain lined up for purchase besides maize are sorghum and millet although 90 per cent of the grain purchase will be white maize.

Kabaghe further disclosed that the sourcing of the grain for the strategic reserves would however mark the start of the market support for economically disadvantaged areas.

"The grain would be sourced from uneconomic surplus areas where traders least go to because of inaccessibility," he said and named the grain strategic storage points as Isoka, Mwenzo, Kasama, Lundazi and Choma.

Mumbwa warehouse will stock reserve grain for the Western province, a major deficit area.

According to information from the agricultures ministry's Market Information Bulletin, the operational modalities for the purchases and delivery of stocks will be on open tender basis invited by FRA.

The Northern province has however been allocated 50 per cent of the total funds for the purchase as the area had recorded a high surplus.

With the limited budgetary allocation for the restocking of the reserves, a programme has been worked out for the gradual collection of grain until it finally reaches the 300,000 metric tonne mark in storage.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

9 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1996


Business;
Zambian Farmers Facing Food Shortages


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - Farmers in Eastern Province are facing food shortages due to the low maize prices in the 1995/96 marketing season.

Small scale farmers in Chipata's Musanga valley said though they had a surplus of maize initially, necessity had forced them to sell most of their stocks to traders who are exporting the maize and are also suspected of hoarding it in anticipation of higher prices after the elections.

A 90kg bag of maize in neighboring Malawi is being sold at K13,000 while the Zambian farmers are selling at sometimes as low as K5,000 a bag. 

"Does the government have 15 million bags of maize in its food reserves or is it relying on what we are supposed to bring in?" asked John Mbulo, a farmer in Chizongwe area of Chipata.

"If so, then the forecast of a bumper harvest is false because we have sold all our maize to traders who obviously want to export," he said.

About 1, 300 farmers in the valley have to pay back fertiliser loans to marketing agents but though they are expected to repay two bags of fertiliser with 15 bags of maize on the average, some have failed to hold back the maize needed for repayment.

"We have to sell our maize or else the children will starve and not go to school. Neither can we buy clothing, blankets, or travel without money," said Blackson Tembo, another valley farmer.

"The agents also want their share of the maize as per agreement. They gave me two 90kg bags of fertiliser and now they want their maize of which I don't have enough," he said.

Andrew Banda, a maize agent through the Cavmont-SGS Fertiliser Fund, agreed that traders were buying maize from farmers at very low prices even before the fertiliser agents got to their farmers.

"It is sad that these farmers will not have food to last them up to December simply because they have to sell their maize at any price to get some money. The government should not have lifted the ban on exports because unscrupulous traders are now desperate to grab maize from unsuspecting farmers who do not understand the new liberal system," said Banda.

Zambia Association of Chambers of Commerce and Industry Chipata Chairman, Idrisse Mosali, confirmed the low prices of maize saying it would affect the food security of most households in Eastern province.

Zambia National Farmers Union President Ben Kapita lamented the state of the farmers in an interview last Wednesday.

"It is sad that the country should lose the little food the farmers had managed to grow this year in such a manner. It is time for government to fulfill its promises to the farmer, giving him better roads and protection from such injustices," he said.

Farmers in Eastern Province were expecting a yield of 2.9 metric tonnes of maize for the 95/96 season. Statistics collected by the Eastern Province Cooperative Union showed that the expected yield was the highest in the country followed by Central Province with 2.56 metric tonnes.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996

August 1, 1996


Zambia;
British Official To Meet With President


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Lusaka - British Minister for Overseas Development Baroness Lynda Chalker arrives in the country for an official visit today. 

According to ZNBC News last night, Baroness Chalker will hold official discussions with President Frederick Chiluba and other government officials.

Early in June Baroness Chalker told a news conference in Zimbabwe that Britain was not happy with the developments in Zambia concerning the constitution.

"The situation in Zambia is sad. We and other donors are particularly concerned about the recent measures to restrict eligibility of candidates for president," she said then.

Baroness Chalker urged the Zambian government to review the constitution with all the concerned political parties to enhance democracy. -ZNBC

11 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 2, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Nigerians In Festive Mood After Olympic Soccer Victory


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Politics bowed to the unifying influence of sports, as Nigerians celebrated Thursday with fan-fare, their country's 4-3 defeat of world champions, Brazil, in the second semi-final of the Olympic soccer tie at Athens, Georgia in the United States.

Fans in the football-loving west African country warched the crucial encounter glued to television sets or clutching radio sets for live commentaries of the match, which kicked off at 23H00 local time (22H00 GMT).

Lagos, the nation's commercial hub, was electrified with anxiety and great expectation when the match began. 

The city of some six million people was almost turned into a grave yard, as the south Americans led 3-1, until 15 minutes to the end of the tension- soaked encounter.

The deafening ovation that greeted victor Ikpeba's 78th minute goal, putting the scores at 3-2, had hardly subsided, when skipper Kanu Nwankwo drew level one minute to full time.

That crucial goal dragged the match into extra-time, to the frustration of the Brazilians, who had earlier beaten the Nigerians 1-0 in their last group 'D' match a week ago.

Nigerians poured into the street in jubilation, dancing and drumming as if the match had been won. The under-23 team did not disappoint.

Kanu, sporting his usual number 4 jersey, slotted Nigeria's fourth and winning goal in the fourth minute of the "sudden death" extra-time.

That "golden goal" under FIFA's new rule, secured Africa's first ticket for an Olympic final soccer match.

Nwankwo's goal's, which broke a 28-year-old jinx that had haunted Nigeria against Brazil, heralded the actual victory party by the Nigerians.

Guard dogs barked at the reverberating shouts by the jubilant crowds, who drummed, danced and lighted up the skies with fire crackers.

The perpetual fear of armed robbery in Lagos vanished as youths poured into the streets singing "Ose O, O Se O, O Se Baba," thanking God for the victory.

No serious incident had been reported here, although over-excited fans reportedly smashed the windows of two private cars at Mushin, a residential area of Lagos.

The victory became the talk of the town in all nooks and cranies as many workers picked their way late to the office Thursday.

Summarising the jubilant mood of the nation, soccer fan Kasali Adeoye, an accountant with a Lagos based company said, "nobody expected the equalizer, at least, not against Brazil. It is a great achievement for Africa."

To many Nigerian soccer fans, beating Brazil seems a miracle.

The Nigerian media reflected this much in their jubilant analysis of the match.

After transmitting the match, the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria devoted some 30 minutes to what it called "victory conference," taking telephone calls from different parts of the country.

The nation's vibrant press also refused to be outdone.

Although the game continued until one A.M. Nigerian time, most of the national dailies reported the event in their front pages.

The private Concord newspaper called it the 'Miracle of Atlanta '96', while the Guardian said 'Nigeria Shocks Brazil, Goes For Gold'.

Digging into history, the mass circulation semi-official daily times said 'Nigeria Breaks 28-year Jinx', in a reference to the fact that Brazil had always beaten Nigeria in soccer since their first meeting in 1968.

The Nigerian squad will take on Argentina in the final of the Olympic soccer Saturday, for Africa's first silver or gold in Olympics soccer.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 2, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Abacha Commends Nigeria's Olympic Soccer Team


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha has sent a

congratulatory message to the nation's under-23 soccer team for its victory over Brazil.

In the message, Abacha said the team's 4-3 success in the semi-final of the Olympic event was "proof of the Nigerian spirit of determination to success and perseverance against insurmountable odds and obstacles." 

The team's performance, he added "has further reinforced to the whole world that our country will attain its desired goals of greatness in all fields of human endevour."

Abacha expressed his personal pride in the Olympic team.

He assured them of the country's support, saying the entire nation was waiting for them to bring home Africa's first Olympic soccer gold.

Similar messages have come from other eminent Nigerians, including former head of state Gen. Yakubu Gowon.

Meanwhile, donations and pledges have also been pouring in to motivate the Nigerians as they prepare to battle Argentina in the crucial final Saturday.

Africa News


August 2, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Onyali Says Olympic Bronze Is Dream Come True


BYLINE: Mike Mbonye, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ATLANTA, United States (PANA) - African track queen, Mary Onyali-Omagbemi of Nigeria, has said the bronze medal she won in the women's 200 metres at the Atlanta Olympics on Thursday is realisation of an ambition she has been nursing since 1988.

"This is the happiest moment of my life," she said, shortly after returning 22.38 seconds to win her first individual Olympic medal. 

She added: "I thank God for making my dream come true."

Onyali also thanked all Nigerians for standing by her in her athletics career since 1988.

"I am glad that I realised a dream I have been nursing since 1988 and I do not mind even if I stumbled to get it," she said.

Her bronze has moved Nigeria from the 58th to the 50th spot on the medals table.

Falilat Ogunkoya got Nigeria's first bronze in the women's 400 metre race.

Onyali came behind Marie-Jose Perec of France, who won the gold and silver- medalist Marlene Ortey of Jamaica.

Commenting on Onyali's success, Nigerian sports minister Jim Nwobodo said: " I feel that God is with us in this Olympic games. I still have the hope that Nigeria will win the elusive gold medal before the Olympic games end."

He commended Onyali's dedication, hardwork and endurance.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

14 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 2, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Zambia's Matete Snatches Silver


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia Friday clinched her first and only Olympic medal at the on-going Centennial Games in Atlanta, a silver, won by 400 metres hurdles specialist, Samuel Matete.

He finished the race seconds behind gold medalist and long-time rival in the event Derrick Adkins of the United States, who romped home in 47.54 seconds. 

It is Zambia's second Olympic medal in almost 20 years. The country first obtained an Olympic medal at the 1984 Los Engeles games when a boxer, the late Keith "spinks" Mwila, won a bronze.

Matete, a professional runner based in United States, has lost 22 times to Adkins in their 37 meetings in the 400 metres hurdles over the past five years. The Zambian has won 15 of the events.

Zambia had taken a 10-member team, four boxers and six runners to the games. Only Matete offered prospects for a medal and had been widely favoured by pundicts here to lift the gold this time around.

Matete's victory was received with less enthusiasm in Lusaka where soccer is the number one sport.

"Good luck to Matete, the guy should be happy for the silver...but we (Zambians), are looking forward to a gold at the 1998 world cup finals in France," said Chandwe Chibuye, a marketeer at the city's centre market.

His sentiments seemed to wrap up the general lack of particular interest in other sports, other than soccer in Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


15 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 2, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Nigeria Shocks Brazil In Soccer


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Atlanta - Nigeria pulled the biggest upset at this year's Olympic Games beating hot favourites and World Champions Brazil 4-3 in an exciting semifinal football match on Wednesday.

Trailing 3-1 with 18 minutes to go before the end of the match, Nigeria produced an amazing comeback to beat the hot Brazilians in sudden death extra time and shatter the South Americans' hopes of winning a first Olympic soccer gold medal.

In the widely watched match game, played before 78,000 fans and millions of TV viewers, it was Nwanko Kanu who sealed the victory for Nigeria with a left- footed shot to the right corner of the net just four minutes into extra time. 

Kanu had also scored late in the game to make 3-3 in regulation time and force the overtime.

Brazil scored early, with Flavio Conceicao sliding a free kick through the wall in the second minute of play.

But Nigeria refused to succumb and soon Celestine Babayaro broke free, crossing the ball from the end line, where it went off defender Roberto Carlos' foot into his own goal.

Minutes later, Brazil pulled away once again, with World Cup sensation Bebeto scoring off a rebound from the Nigerian goalkeeper. Bebeto then helped make it 3-1 in the 37th minute with a neat pass to Conceicao.

Nigeria squandered a penalty in the 63rd minute when Augustine Okocha's shot was stopped by diving Brazil goalie Dida. Nigeria continued with its assault on the Brazil's goal and Victor Ikepebai made it 3-2 in the 77th minute after a pass from Daniel Amokachi.

With time running out, Taslim Fatusi pushed a ball through a mass of defenders to Kanu, who powered it past Dida in heavy traffic for the equalizer. And four minutes later, Kanu was the hero with the winning goal and end the game. The new extra time rules states that the first team to score in extra time wins.

For Nigeria, the 1994 African champions who pulled out of the 1996 African Nations Cup for political reasons, a victory on Saturday against Argentina would make it the first African team to win a major senior world soccer title.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 2, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Zambian Runner Makes It To Finals


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Atlanta - Now only one man, Samuel Matete, can give Zambia an Olympic medal this year.

Matete is only one race away from the cherished medal after qualifying to the 400 meters hurdles finals at Atlanta's Olympic Stadium on Wednesday.

But teammate Godfrey Siamusiye's chase for gold ended Wednesday after he finished 10th in the second heat of the 3000 steeplechase.

Only the top five finishers and the next best two in time qualify to the finals in steeplechase. 

Fackson Nkandu who was expected to run in the 5000 meters did not participate. The other athletes, Ngozi Mwanamwambwa and Charles Mulinga lost in the preliminary rounds. Three of the four boxers made it to the second round where they lost, leaving Matete as the only Zambian in contention for a medal.

Matete, the former world and commonwealth 400 meters hurdles champion earned a place in the final with lackluster performance in the semifinals, coming third in his heat.

Although he led most of the way, he apparently slowed down and relaxed in the last 10 meters in a move to conserve energy for the finals set for Thursday night at 8.25 p.m. (U.S. Time, which will be Friday 02.25 hours Zambian Time.)

In the 400 meters hurdles, the top four finishers in the two heat qualify to the finals.

Calvin Davis of United States won Matete's heat clocking 47.91 with Everson Teixeira of Brazil coming second (48.28) and Matete clocking 48.28 for the third position.

Matete's biggest challenge for the gold, American Derrick Adkins, also made it to finals by winning his heat easily in 47.76. Others who qualified for the finals include Sven Nylander of Sweden, Fabrizio Mori of Italy, Eronilde de Araujo of Brazil and Rohan Robinson of Australia.

For Siamusiye, who came second in the the first round, the semifinals proved hard and he faltere behind American Marc Davis who won the heat in 8: 26.76. Siamusiye was clocked at 8:37.41.

In other track and field event, Hezekiel Sepeng won silver medal in men's 800 meters, becoming first black from South Africa to get a medal.

After his time of 1 minute, 42.74 seconds shattered the South African record, he draped his nation's flag around his shoulders and paraded around the stadium - the first black person from his country to ever do that.

Sepeng lost to Vebjoern Rodal of Norway, who won the gold in an Olympic- record 1:42.58.

American Michael Johnson put himself in position to make golden history in the 200 meters, after qualifying to the finals.

Johnson cruised through the first two rounds of the 200 meters, the event in which he set a world record here last month.

He won the 400 meters in Olympic record time Monday and can become the only man to win both events in the same Olympics if he triumphs. To do that, he has to beat Frankie Fredericks of Namibia, the only man to have beaten him this year.

Another bid for an Olympic double ended when Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia dropped out before the start of the first round of the men's 5,000 meters with sore feet. Gebrselassie, who won the 10,000 on Monday, had been a favorite in the 5,000.

But American women hot favourites, Gail Devers and Kim Batten, fell short on the track. Devers, winner earlier of the 100 meter dash, finished a fading fourth in the 100-meter hurdles, failing in her bid to double, and world- record holder Batten settled for silver in the 400 hurdles.

Batten couldn't catch Jamaica's Deon Hemmings, who won in 52.82, only a few ticks off Batten's world record of 51.69.

It wasn't a good day for Sergei Bubka, world-record holder in the pole vault. He pulled out of qualifying with an Achilles tendon injury and said, " obviously, the Olympics are not for me."

Bubka, who has set 35 world records, failed to clear a height in Barcelona.

On the tennis courts, Lindsay Davenport defeated fellow American Mary Joe Miami to make the women's singles final. She will meet Spaniard Aranxta Sanchez-Vicario for the gold medal.

Indonesia's Rexy Mainaky and Ricky Subagja rallied to beat Malaysia's Cheah Soon Kit and Yap Kim Hock 5-15, 15-13, 15-12 to win the men's badminton title. Indonesia and Malaysia are badminton powers.

Deng Yaping of China won the women's table tennis singles title, giving her two gold medals for the second consecutive Olympics.

And away from the playing fields, another member of the Olympic family defected. Iraqi weightlifter Raed Ahmed, who carried his national flag in the opening ceremony, ran out of the athletes village, was picked up by an Iraqi opposition group and asked the U.S. Immigration and

Naturalization Service for asylum. Four Cubans have also asked for asylum.

With 188 of 271 events concluded, the Americans led with 72 medals, 27 gold. Russia trailed with 45 medals, 21 gold.

Africa News


August 2, 1996


Zambia;
NGO Highlights Problems Of Poverty In Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia will never develop economically and politically if the vast majority of people continue to live in poverty.

This came to light at the basic human rights tribunal organised by Oxfam at Lusaka International School. 

Oxfam Representative in the country, Ms Lucy Muyoyeta disclosed that 76 per cent of the country's population live in poverty adding that this hinders development.

She said the battle for peace and security would only be won if poverty is eradicated among most of the people.

"You can not expect to create peace and security in the country when most of the people live in poverty," Ms Muyoyeta said.

She charged that poverty is a violation of human rights and called upon the government to join in the campaign against poverty.

Ms Muyoyeta also revealed that Oxfam has embarked on a five year campaign against poverty.

She further disclosed that only 53 per cent of the population in the country have access to safe drinking water and that this has resulted in a number of deaths from preventable diseases.

At the basic rights tribunal women from various provinces testfied that they hardly afford a meal in a day.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

Africa News


August 2, 1996


Science;
Zambia Requested To Airlift Polio Vaccine


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Mongu - The government has been requested to provide a Zambia Air Force chopper for the transportation of polio vaccines to some parts of Lukulu district when the second round exercise resumes before the end of this month throughout the country.

The request was made by the Western Province polio immunisation co- ordinating committee, which met in Mongu yesterday under the chairmanship of the area permanent secretary, Mr Tebuho Muliokela.

A report which was tabled before the committee from Lukulu medical authorities indicated that there is absolute need for the ministry of health to negotiate with the government for the provision of a ZAF chopper to ferry polio vaccines to Lukulu west where roads are impassable. 

In another development, the committee was also saddened to learn that areas of Kaungamashi and Kaunga-Lweti have not been covered in the first immunisation exercise which took place from July 19 t0 21 because of transport problems.

But Mr Muliokela directed Senanga district health management team director to ensure that children in those two areas are vaccinated against polio any time now before the second phase of the campaign starts.

However, according to reports from the six districts of the province, a total number of 135,339 under-five children and slightly over that were immunised but the permanent secretary called for extra hard work to ensure that this figure is exceeded by a wide margin.

Meanwhile, the committee was startled to hear that during the just-ended immunisation campaign, a team of some medical personnel travelled all the way from Mumbwa boma and carried out the exercise at the TBZ's farm number 10 in Kaoma district.

The permanent secretary directed provincial medical officer, Dr Albert Sitali to take up the matter with his counterpart in the central province in order to avoid the already existing confusion.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZIS

Africa News


August 2, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
African Soccer Hour Has Arrived, Says Nigeria Coach


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ATHENS, United States (PANA) - Nigerian technical adviser, Jo Bonfrere, has described the country's 4-3 victory over Brazil in the semi-finals of the olympic soccer event as a sign of maturity of African football.

Bonfrere told reporters after the match, played in Athens, U.S., that there was no longer any gap between a "good-playing team" like Brazil and a team from Africa.

"Now the gap between the good playing teams and African and Asian teams is very close and it is now a matter of tactic and how the players themselves approach matches," he said. 

The Dutch coach said his team encountered a lot of organizational problems which, he said, disturbed its preparations for the tournament, recalling that five days to the start of the competition, he didn't have all his players in camp.

"But I talked with the team before this game. I told them to forget all the problems for one-and-a-half hours and then, after this game, we can start with new problems," he said.

Bonfrere said that skipper Nwankwo Kanu had not played well in the competition because he reported late to camp, but said that he had decided to forgive him "because he made the final goal today."

With Brazil's lead cut to 3-2 toward the end of the match, Kanu struck in the 90th minute to force the match into extra time. He scored again four minutes later to ensure Nigeria's first-ever qualification for the olympic soccer final.

Meanwhile, Nigerian sports minister Jim Nwobodo says the players have shown, by Wednesday's victory, that they are indeed a "dream team".

"Only great teams achieve this kind of feat," the minister, emerging from the players' dressing room, said.

He described the match as miraculous, saying "nothing can be better than this."

The chairman of the Nigeria Football Association (NFA), retired air commodore Emeka Omeruah, said the outcome of the match was "like a dream."

Nigerian football authorities had pulled all the necessary strings to motivate the country's Olympic soccer team for Wednesday's semi-final match against Brazil.

Two days to the match, the players were all paid their match-winning bonus (for match against Mexico) of 5,000 U.S. dollars each.

Then the players were moved into a hotel in Athens, venue of the match because the accommodation in the city's olympic village was said not to be conducive.

The Omeruah promised to do whatever was necessary to put the players in the right frame of mind for clinching the Olympic soccer gold on Saturday, against Argentina at the same venue.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 2, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwean Men Team Up Against Wife Battering


BYLINE: Chemist Mafuba, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - As cases of wife battering continue to hit headlines, some gender-conscious men in Zimbabwe have teamed up to lobby against domestic violence and bring harmony in households.

Men's Forum for Gender, founded in March 1995, has now set up branches in the capital, Harare, and the towns of Bulawayo and Chitungwiza. There are plans to open offices in the midlands city of Gweru soon.

The forum, also known as 'Padare' in Shona and 'Enkundleni' in Ndebele, Zimbabwe main national languages, proposes to offer a counseling service for husbands who do not feel at ease in the presence of strange women. 

National convener Jonah Gokovah says the social system in Zimbabwe benefits men more than women because of attitudes which have not been questioned over the ages.

"As men we have to learn to develop the consciousness that there is something wrong with the way we were brought up and try to change ourselves," he says.

"There are many men who appreciate the situation, but because of cultural pressure they keep their thoughts to themselves. When they are with their families they slide back to their old lifestyles."

Gokovah says that at the group's meetings, members are provided with an environment which enables them to speak about gender issues, and become clearer in their minds about where they stand.

The group held its first public meeting here on July 13, and the next one is scheduled for Chitungwiza. Eventually, the group plans to take the message of gender equality to the rural areas.

In Zimbabwe, gender equality has always been associated with women, and they have since played a very important role in bringing awareness.

Some non-governmental organizations have welcomed the formation of the forum as a step in the right direction.

"If they want to assist, we welcome them," says Eveline Chikovore of the Musasa project that offers a marriage counseling service.

Women's action group director, Selina Mumbengegwi, hailed the group as one of the best contributions men have ever made to the struggle for gender equality.

"It is a group of men which saw that in society men and women should support each other," she says. "Men working together will help each either."

Gracious Women's Fellowship International representative, Idah Chikono, says husbands have since been incorporated into their counseling sessions together with their wives.

"We are attending to something like six couples a day," she says. "At times the queue is so long we hardly break for lunch."

Chikono attributes domestic violence in Zimbabwe to financial hardships and pride which makes women refuse to accept husbands as heads of families.

"Couples start off at the romantic stage and pass on to the realistic stage when each reveals what he or she really is," she says.

"This is the most crucial stage, and once they pass that one they can get on to the creation stage. At this point the two of them have decided to stay together."

Cases of domestic violence are increasing as Musasa project alone has counselled 603 couples in 1994 and 699 in 1995.

Leading the list have been wife beating and forced sex.

Men's forum on gender underplays violence which is perpetrated by women against men.

"We believe men being beaten by women is not a social problem," says Harare coordinating committee member, John Vekris.

"We believe many causes of women attacking men is a response to a history of abuse and oppression. We understand men are the culprits, but there is a possibility for them to change. It is not abnormal to move towards gender consciousness."

With a strong feeling that education plays a crucial part in changing attitudes, members have been addressing schools and colleges on the issue.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 2, 1996


Kenya;
Kenya to Jail HIV Rapists for Life


BYLINE: Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - The Kenya parliament has passed a motion recommending life imprisonment for HIV positive rapists and those convicted of deliberately infecting others with the virus that causes the incurable AIDS.

But the attorney-general, Amos Wako, had to contend with an angry house Wednesday, because a majority of the members of parliament (MPs) had recommended the death sentence. 

The government adviser in law, however, amended the motion to read "life imprisonment", instead of "death sentence", to the disappointment of the law makers.

The MPs were united in their concern about the rapid spread of the AIDS menace and anger at those who deliberately infected others. They also criticized courts for handing out lenient sentences to rapists.

Moving the motion, the MP for the central Kenya constituency of Ndaragwa, Mwangi Gichuki, had sought a mandatory death sentence for rapists proven to carry the HIV virus.

His seconder, John Munyasia, from a western Kenya constituency, said the death sentence would reduce rape from HIV positive rapists. He equated HIV- positive rapists with murderers.

"Aids must be discussed as a national calamity," Munyasia said.

Other MPs urged the attorney-general to consider castration of the HIV rapists. The attorney-general rejected the proposal.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 2, 1996


Sudan;
Sudan Denounces Envisaged Air Embargo


BYLINE: Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan's aviation and survey minister, Gen. Tigani Adam Tahir, has said the proposed imposition of a ban on his country's national carrier, Sudan Airways, would be unfair and unjust.

"Sudan rejects any decision on imposing a ban on the Sudanese air companies, " Tahir said in a statement issued through the official Sudan News Agency (SUNA). 

The ban is reportedly under consideration by the United Nations Security Council.

"Such a resolution would be unjust, biased and unfounded," the agency quoted the as saying Thursday.

Two months ago, the Security Council imposed diplomatic sanctions against the Sudan for its alleged involvement in an attempt to assassinate Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa in June 1995.

The assassination attempt was made as Mubarak arrived in the Ethiopian capital for the annual OAU summit.

It also threatened further sanctions in case Khartoum fails to cooperate with the OAU on the issue.

Sudan defended itself, saying none of the suspects was within its territory.

The Sudanese minister appealed to international aviation organizations to prevent the imposition of an embargo on his country's airline.

He said the Sudan Airways, which was allegedly used by one of the accused to escape from Ethiopia to the Sudan, was not responsible for scrutinizing passengers before they boarded on its planes.

He argued that it was not the mistake of the airline if the suspect managed to pass all the Ethiopian security undetected and was able to fly from Addis Ababa to Sudan.

The airline should not be blamed for the mistake of others, the minister added.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 2, 1996


Benin;
Nigeria, Benin Agree On Demarcating Corridor


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ONIGBOLO, Benin (PANA) - Nigeria and Benin have agreed to create a 30-meter corridor along their border towns with effect from September 15, to minimize frontier disputes between the two west African countries.

A communique issued here Thursday, after a two-day meeting between Nigeria's Minister of Works and Housing, Maj.Gen. Abdulkarim Adisa, and his Benin counterpart, Sahidow Nadey, said the two countries agreed to enumerate and assess all buildings, structures and other properties within the said corridor. 

The two countries share a 770-kilometer (1,232 miles) long land boundary.

The communique said the positions of eight pillars along their common borders were yet to be resolved and that both governments should abide by a 1912 colonial document on the boundary demarcation.

It called on the two nations to equip, fund and provide suitable vehicles urgently, to facilitate the demarcation of the borders.

The traditional rulers of the border communities were urged to sensitize their subjects on the demarcation scheme.

Adisa explained to the border communities that the demarcation scheme was designed to stem border disputes.

"Neither of our two countries is interested in expanding its frontiers to the detriment of the other," he added.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
