72 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Ethiopia;
Bomb Explodes in a Hotel in Addis Ababa


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - One person was killed while 11 other were injured, four of them seriously, when a powerful bomb ripped through the bar and lounge of an Addis Ababa hotel early Monday night.

State radio quoted police as saying the bomb extensively damaged the Wabe Shebelle hotel in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa.

Police immediately cordoned off Ras Abede Argegay street, the main thoroughfare on which the 11-floor, three-star hotel is located, and the adjacent streets. 

Eye witnesses said the explosion occurred when the ground floor bar, lounge and dance floor, were crowded with customers. The explosion caused heavy damage to glass panels of the eastern and northern sections of the ground floor of the hotel and completely shattered the entire bar.

A similar explosion on January 19, at another government-run hotel, the plush Ghion Hotel in downtown Addis Ababa, ripped off the frontal section of the hotel, killing three people and injuring 15 others.

Two weeks later, another explosion, in the eastern town of Dire Dawa, 500 kms (312 miles) from Addis Ababa, also caused extensive damage to the government-owned Ras Hotel, killing one person and injuring four others.

Responsibility for the attacks on the two hotels in Addis Ababa and the one in Dire Dawa, was claimed by an Ethiopian separatist group, Al Itihad, from Mogadishu, Somalia, last month.

Al Itihad seeks secession for the Ethiopian Somali region from the rest of federated Ethiopia. The group also claimed responsibility for the attempt on the life of a senior Ethiopian minister of Somali origin in Addis Ababa early in July.

Abdulmegid Hussein, minister of transport and communications, was shot six times on the arm, shoulder and throat, on July 8 in front of his office as he arrived for work in the morning. His bodyguard and another security officer were killed by the unidentified assailants, who managed to escape.

Hussein was flown the next day to Tel Aviv, Israel, for treatment.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


South Africa;
Opinion Favours Active Defence Role For South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The vast majority of the South African public would support President Nelson Mandela if he opted for the country's participation in peace-keeping operations in Burundi, or anywhere else, according to a survey.

The survey, on national security issues, was conducted by the Institute for Defence Policy and the Human Sciences Research Council, and reported in the Johannesburg newspaper, The Star.

It was released on the eve of a Defence Consultative Conference which will assess the future needs of the South African defence force for the next decade. The conference will determine such elements as force levels, new ships, aircraft and other equipment, part-time forces, and security trends in Southern Africa. 

The survey revealed that the majority of all population groups believed that a strong defence force was either necessary or essential. Only 20 percent of those interviewed felt it was unnecessary.

Another trend to emerge strongly from the survey was the belief that the South African Defence Force had a specific role to play in the Southern African region.

Almost three-quarters of the respondents felt the South African Defence Force should play an active role in maintaining stability in Southern Africa; 63 percent believed it should defend the borders of other countries in the region; 73 percent favored South African training of other military personnel in the region; and 67 percent said South Africa should provide equipment to the other powers in Southern Africa.

A large majority of those questioned (almost two-thirds) believed South Africa should have a peace-keeping force to assist other countries in maintaining peace.

Nearly half were in favour of such a force serving anywhere in the world. Of these, almost half believed the force should always be under South African command, while just over a third felt the force should be prepared to serve under foreign command when required.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


74 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Swaziland;
Swaziland Complains Of Trade Imbalance With South Africa


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Mbabane, Swaziland (PANA) - Criticism voiced at the recent annual general meeting of the South African Sugar Association concerning what its members viewed as unfair competition from imported cheaper Swazi sugar has drawn a sharp reaction from the Swaziland Sugar Association. The South Africans were reported to have complained that the free flow of sugar imports from Swaziland and Zimbabwe at cheaper prices than South African grown sugar presented unfair competition to South African growers.

In an interview here with PANA, the Swaziland Sugar Association general manager, Andy Colhoun, said the South African complaint was totally unjustified considering the imbalance in the total trade situation between the two countries. 

He said Swaziland is a member of the Southern African Common Customs Union along with South Africa, Namibia, Botswana and Lesotho which provides for the fostering of the free flow of goods and services across the borders of these member states. Zimbabwe, as in the case of Mozambique and Angola, is not a member of the union.

There is heavy imbalance of total trade in favour of South Africa which exports a vast range of goods and services to Swaziland everyday, said Colhoun. These include petrol, oil, electricity, wines, fruits and vegetables, among others.

Almost two billion rands (nearly half a billion U.S. dollars) worth of South African goods are imported by Swaziland each year, whereas Swaziland total exports to South Africa amounts to only about 780 million rands (about 173 million dollars).

Colhoun said since sugar is a product in which Swaziland has an advantage due to its good climate and soils, excellent labor resources and a high level of managerial expertise, Swazi sugar locally termed "Swazi gold", helps redress the balance of trade.

It is a simple case of economics, said Colhoun. Swaziland is a small landlocked country with comparatively fewer resources than South Africa and must be allowed to use those resources to its best advantage.

Colhoun said "the whole of the Southern African Common Customs Union is based on a market economy in which competition is inherent."

The South African sugar industry, he added, must be prepared to face competition.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Burundi;
British Minister To Consult Museveni Over Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The British minister of state for foreign and Commonwealth affairs, Baroness Lynda Chalker, is consulting President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda Tuesday over the political situation in Burundi and Rwanda.

"I am consulting the president because he is likely to know far better. All regional leaders condemned Buyoya (the new Burundi leader) and asked him to restore democratic government," Chalker said on arrival Monday at Entebbe airport, 32 km (16 miles) from here.

Chalker, also minister for overseas development, is scheduled to meet Museveni at his country home in Rwakitura, south-western Uganda. She will later visit Rwanda and possibly Burundi.

"From here I am going to Rwanda, and, depending on what President Museveni tells me, I will be in Burundi as well," said Chalker, who arrived from Nairobi, Kenya.

She said her visit is part of a southern and eastern African tour to inspect projects funded by Britain.

Uganda receives over 60 million U.S. dollars from Britain in bilateral aid, in addition to substantial multilateral contribution.

Africa News


August 6, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
National Olympic Committee Makes Pledge to Ethiopian Athletes


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Ethiopian athletics team will return home Thursday with two gold and one bronze medals won at the 26th Atlanta Olympiad, the Ethiopian Sports Commission announced.

Member of the Ethiopian Olympic squad, athlete Fatuma Roba won women's marathon championship, the first record for Ethiopia and Africa while athlete Haile Gebre-Sellassie shattered the record held for eight years by a Moroccan, in the 10,000 meters men's race.

Gete Wami stood third in the women 10,000 meters race to win bronze medal and the Barcelona champion, Derartu Tulu finished fourth in the competition. 

The two gold and one bronze medals Ethiopia clinched stood her 31st in the world and 3rd in Africa next to South Africa and Nigeria.

Haile Gebre-Sellassie due to leg injury could not participate in the 5,000 meters race in which athlete Fita Baissa, bronze medal winner at the Barcelona Olympics 10,000 meters competition finished 10th.

Ethiopian athletes who took part in the marathon competition, Abebe Mekonen, Belayneh Densamo and Turbo Tumo were not lucky.

Yared Wolde-Mechael, a boxer who took part in the 71 kg. category tournament, though had qualified for the first round was later beaten by an Uzbekistan.

Meanwhile, the coordinating committee of the special reception programme to Ethiopian athletes returning from Atlanta has called on sports fans, companies and businessmen to take part in the programme.

The national special reception committee organized by the Shala Advertisement Enterprise said yesterday the activities so far carried out to give colour to the welcome programme and to strengthen the National Olympic committee said many people from all corners of the country are expressing willingness to support its endeavours.

The Committee added that since the victories scored by the athletes are the victories of the Ethiopian people, the support should be consolidated to strengthen sports in all fields in the country and to maintain the achievements.

Financial and material pledge of over 1.6 million birr have been made so far by different companies and entrepreneurs to encourage the athletes and support, the National Olympic Committee said.

August 6, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Ethiopian Medalist to Wed


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The 22-year-old track hero Haile Gebresellasie, wears a wedding ring at a ceremony to be held at Bole International Airport right after alights from the plane he and other members of the Ethiopian athletics squad are boarding.

"I did not want to get married until my plan to win an Olympic gold medal came to fruition. And now, I guess, it is time to get tied to the girl I have chosen some time ago," Haile told Ethiopian Radio sports reporter Demisie Damte in Atlanta. 

"I promised her (his fiancee) that we would get married after my victory at the Olympic games. I gave precedence to the Olympic gold medal. And that is why I held my marriage a secret," he said.

He said he wanted the celebration marking his wedding to kick off right after his arrival at the airport to make it "special" and "memorable."

Haile, who has become the richest national athlete of all times, said flamboyantly that he will now turn his face to meeting his social obligations of helping his family "I will keep running in the meantime," he added.

The gold medal chasing athlete, whose dazzling performance in the 10,000 meter Olympic race, left Ethiopians and people across the world pop-eyed with amazement hopes to receive a warm welcome on arrival.

Asked to comment on whether he expects an elaborate festive at the airport Haile said between laughters, "I warn the airport staff to do their level best to make my betrothal day a success."

It is expected that there would be a massive gathering of fans choking terminal waiting areas to welcome and congratulate the Ethiopian athletics team including Haile, one of the best athletes the world has produced in age.

Haile's victory in the 10,000 meter race has fuelled the excitement generated by the performance of Fatuma Roba who outdistanced her compititors to win the 42,195 km women marathon.

Haile and Fatuma earned Ethiopian two gold medals while athlete Gete Wami won bronze in the 10,000 meter race. Haile could not compete in the 5000 meter because of a wound in his feet.

The Ethiopian athletics squad is scheduled to retain home on the 8th of August.

Africa News


August 6, 1996


Ethiopia;
Court hears charge file of ENPF members


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egiziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Six members of the clandestine and self styled " Ethiopian National Patriots Front (ENPF)" yesterday appeared before the Second Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court and heard to a 3 page charge filed against them by the Prosecutor General's office.

According to the charge, they stand accused of allegedly "establishing an armed underground political organization in which they worked as leader and members with the aim of usurping power from the constitutionally elected government and inciting organized terror and chaos in the country."

Asked if they had any objection to the charge, the defendants including, the former president of the Ethiopian Teachers' Association and now chairman of the said "terrorist gang" Dr. Taye Wolde Semayet - said that they would consult their lawyers before saying anything about the case. They instead appealed to the court to grant them bail, which the Prosecutor General dismissed outright. 

The Prosecutor General objected to making the grant saying: "Since they are accused of grave offences which will entail severe punishment, it is most unlikely that they will reappear once they are granted bail. Moreover, since their collaborators have not yet been arrested, a bail would mean the continuation of their illegal deeds; since, too, the witnesses testifying for the Prosecutor General are individuals selected with utmost care and deserve strict legal protection, the bailing of the defendants will almost certainly mean the elimination or attempted persuasion by the defendants and their collaborators of the witnesses."

The court will decide today on whether to grant or refuse bail.

Before the hearing began defendant number one, Dr. Taye Wolde Semayat, objected to the presence of a press camera crew which the court rejected. He then took off his coat and concealed his face with it only to put it on again following order by the court.

The other defendants included: Ato Kebede Desta, former president of the Veteran Teachers' Association; Ato Gebretsadik Hailemariam, Lt. Chane Tolla; Ato Talegeta Leul (Dagne), and captain Moges Assefa.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


79 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
11,000 Athletes Bid Adieu To Atlanta


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Atlanta - The Centennial Olympic Games closed on Sunday night with fireworks, music, tears and appeals to global brotherhood before a capacity crowd of 85,000 at Olympic Stadium.

At 10:40 pm, the Olympic flame, lit 17 days before, was extinguished minutes after Atlanta Mayor Bill Campbell presented the Olympic flag to Frank Sartor, mayor of Sydney, Australia, site of the 2,000 Summer Games.

The Atlanta Games were the biggest in Olympic history, with 11,000 athletes from 197 countries. 

"Well done, Atlanta," declared Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee. "For 100 years the Olympic Games have inspired great dreams. Today, the dream has come true for Atlanta, which will be forever an Olympic city."

Samaranch praised the competition, but at a press conference earlier on Sunday he criticized the commercialisation of the Atlanta Olympics and mentioned "problems" in "transportation and technology."

Billy Payne, president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, praised Atlanta for rallying in the wake of a July 27 terror bombing at Centennial Olympic Park.

Musicians like Stevie Wonder, Gloria Estefan, B.B. King, Little Richard, Wynton Marsalis and Tito Puente took part in the musical portion of a three- hour event that concluded with thousands of athletes on the field.

The host nation enjoyed two last successes on the athletic front, winning the women's basketball gold medal and a surprise boxing gold. The United States finished atop the medal standings for the first time in a non- boycotted Olympics since 1968, winning 101 medals, 44 gold.

Germany won 65 medals. Russia, competing without athletes from several breakaway Soviet republics, was second in gold with 26. But the days of overwhelming dominance by a few nations are over. A record 197 nations took part and an unprecented 79 won at least one medal. Fifty-three countries got at least one gold.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Science;
The War Against Polio in Malawi


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Lilongwe - Malawi, on July 17, launched a countrywide campaign to immunise over 2,000,000 children against polio. It is estimated that the lives of nearly 300,000 children could be saved each year through the campaign.

The World Health Organisation-funded campaign is targeting children aged between one to five years. The Acting WHO representative in Malawi, Chris Forshaw, hopes that polio will be eradicated by raising coverage of routine immunisation and by supplementary immunisation.

The Malawi government has taken the opportunity to simultaneously administer supplementary oral vitamin A, the deficiency of which is said to be ''very common among Malawian children under 5 year of age.

Issue cover date: July 26, 1996

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 6, 1996


Business;
Malawi to Get First 5-Star Hotel


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lilongwe - Malawi's first five star hotel is to shoot up in sight of the New State House in Lilongwe, which is slated to be turned into an international conference centre.

Cabinet has approved a K780 million (US$52 million) project to be undertaken at the extravagant - K700 million (US 46.67 million) - State House built by former president Kamuzu Banda, in order to convert the presently under-utilised facility into a commercial entity. 

Deputy Chief Economist in the Economic Planning and Development Ministry, Dr Henry Ng'ombe, said a 200-rooms hotel will be built in the complex yard to supplement the tourist facilities being planned for the premises, adding that the present buildings will be commercialised by offering international conference facilities and other recreation services.

Several local companies are lined up ready to participate in this colossal venture with foreign companies also bidding for partnership shares. The project is expected to start before the end of this year.

Issue cover date: July 26, 1996


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


82 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Malawi;
Malawi News Roundup


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

K200 Million Grant for Power Project In Malawi - The German government is to provide a K200 million (US$13.34 million) grant to Malawi for the country's new hydro-electric scheme, Kapichira, in south Malawi. The signing ceremony for this took place on July 18 in Lilongwe.

Finance Minister, Aleke Banda, who signed the agreement on behalf of the Malawi government, said the Kapichira project would enable the country to supply adequate electricity to the country's urban, peri-urban and rural areas and will provide an alternative source of energy to ease the burden on fuel wood and charcoal.

The Acting German Ambassador to Malawi, Dr Wolfgang Klapper, signing on behalf of his government said the extension of Malawi's present electricity supply was essential for the country's future since demand for electricity would exceed current electricity production by the end of the decade. 

The main financier of the project is the World Bank.

The War Against Polio in Malawi - Malawi, on July 17, launched a countrywide campaign to immunise over 2,000,000 children against polio. It is estimated that the lives of nearly 300,000 children could be saved each year through the campaign.

The World Health Organisation-funded campaign is targeting children aged between one to five years. The Acting WHO representative in Malawi, Chris Forshaw, hopes that polio will be eradicated by raising coverage of routine immunisation and by supplementary immunisation.

The Malawi government has taken the opportunity to simultaneously administer supplementary oral vitamin A, the deficiency of which is said to be ''very common among Malawian children under 5 year of age.

Malawi to Get First 5-Star Hotel - Malawi's first five star hotel is to shoot up in sight of the New State House in Lilongwe, which is slated to be turned into an international conference centre.

Cabinet has approved a K780 million (US$52 million) project to be undertaken at the extravagant - K700 million (US 46.67 million) - State House built by former president Kamuzu Banda, in order to convert the presently under-utilised facility into a commercial entity.

Deputy Chief Economist in the Economic Planning and Development Ministry, Dr Henry Ng'ombe, said a 200-rooms hotel will be built in the complex yard to supplement the tourist facilities being planned for the premises, adding that the present buildings will be commercialised by offering international conference facilities and other recreation services.

Several local companies are lined up ready to participate in this colossal venture with foreign companies also bidding for partnership shares. The project is expected to start before the end of this year.

Government Must Retrench Or Perish - The World Bank Resident representative in Malawi, Arif Zulfiqar, said July 18 that the government could choose to retrench some civil servants and succeed with the civil service reform programme, or avoid retrenchment and perish by perpetuating inefficiency and unnecessary public spending.

Zulfiqar said that the World Bank could not make the decisions for the government though the bank was committed to assisting the Malawi government in its reform programme.

He was reacting to the Secretary to the President and cabinet Alfred Upindi's recent statement that government had shelved the retrenchment programme due to financial problems.

Zulfiqar said that if the government decides not to retrench, it should be prepared to face problems like strikes for salary increases, since it is not possible to offer attractive wages to the present oversized civil service. He also said that any improperly planned salary increases now would result in a budget deficit and possibly a rise in inflation.

Prisoners Plea for Clemency - Prisoners serving various sentences in Malawi's jails still face problems communicating with the outside world despite claims of transparency and reforms.

Several inmates had to secretly smuggle letters out of Zomba Central Prison during a visit there recently by a group of human rights activists.

Several letters, one of which is believed to have been written by ex-army Colonel James Njoloma and addressed to President Bakili Muluzi asking for clemency, were passed on to the visitors.

Njoloma is serving a 14-year sentence after a court martial found him guilty of organising a mutiny. He is kept in the section of the prison reserved for prisoners awaiting capital punishment.

Prison authorities said, however, that they were surprised that prisoners had to secretly send letters out of prison. They said the system was open. A member of the prison authorities did, however, confirm that all letters from prisoners are opened by the prison authorities and vetted before they are sent out.

Malawi Polytechnic Closes Down - The Malawi Polytechnic, a constituent college of the University of Malawi, was closed indefinitely on July 18 until the authorities concerned address demands by lecturers for salary increments.

The closure has resulted in students not being able to take their examinations. The students were advised to vacate the campus on July 19 and wait until the salary issue is resolved.

Issue cover date: July 26, 1996


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


83 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Malawi;
Hell In Malawi's Prisons


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lilongwe - Life in Malawi's prisons is turning out to be hell, report human rights activists who visited the country's biggest central prison in Zomba, south Malawi.

Although government is making an effort to reform the institution - largely due to the prodding of international organisations like the Red Cross and Amnesty International - Malawi's prisons remain death traps.

Executive Director of Malawi Democratic Institute of Economic Affairs, Shyley Kondowe, leading a delegation that visited the maximum security prison in Zomba, said that statistics on the health of inmates and their general welfare are chilling. Kondowe said, referring to the health of inmates, that there is a high prevalence of diseases such as tuberculosis and scabies. 

He said that between January and June this year, 26.4% of the inmates at the prison were suffering from TB and in addition, 58.8% of them had TB/HIV related complications with 17.6% of prisoners having full-blown AIDS.

What is even more pathetic is that medication for the patients is almost non-existent. "There were cases where some prisoners who have TB were being given aspirin because drugs are not available,'' said Kondowe. Apart from the lack of drugs, Kondowe said, the prison's medical system is greatly undermined by lack of personnel and equipment. The incidence of disease is exacerbated by the diet, which Kondowe described as ''extremely low.'' Prisoners are still served only one meal a day which makes it even more difficult for inmates suffering from TB to recuperate.

Kondowe said his group encountered a case where nsima (the local staple food - a thick porridge), that had been prepared some two days earlier, was still being served to the inmates. "The beans that served with nsima are rotten," Kondowe said. He said this results in a high rate of deaths, a rate always on the increase inside the prison walls.

Kondowe said eight people had died during the past two weeks at Zomba Central Prison alone, representing a death rate of one person every two days. ''We saw a number of sick prisoners sleeping out on the floor, left for dead, and uncared for. They were in a very pathetic situation because nobody was attending to them.''

Most prisoners have no blankets and there is overcrowding in the cells, some of which house as many as 20 inmates when they are obviously designed for far fewer people. Prisons Public Relations Officer Winston Manyela bemoaned the situation and blamed the lack of facilities like blankets, uniforms and other basic equipment for prisoners on the meagre financial allocations made by the government.

Kondowe also commented on the fact that some 800 remandees on homicide cases have not been taken to court. Director of Public Prosecutions, Kamudoni Nyasulu, also blamed this on the inadequate funding by the government.

Given enough funds, he said, he would hire lawyers in private practice to deal with the cases adding that unless there is an adequate cash injection into public prosecution, trial of the 800 remandees held in the various prisons would not be completed within the next two years. He said his department currently needs US$500,000 to prosecute the homicide remandees, some of whom have already spent two years in waiting in prison.

Some human rights organisations are recommending the establishment of a special tribunal to examine the cases and grant the remandees bail. But, Nyasulu said, the setting up of a tribunal would not solve the problem. For a tribunal to operate, he said, it needs the involvement of legal aid, the judiciary and the prosecution. "If there is money, why not give it to these three sections?" he queried.

Kondowe also said that torture equipment, such as straight jackets, was still being kept in the prison. He said this was a violation of human rights, adding that some prison authorities might be tempted to use them on the inmates. He recommended that they be taken to a museum.

Issue cover date: July 26, 1996


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


84 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Tunisia;
President Highlights Commitment To Mideast Peace Process


BYLINE: Tunisian Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Tunis - President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali reiterated Tunisia's commitment to the Middle East Peace Process and its support of the "land for peace" formula as one of the principles agreed upon in the peace accords.

Speaking Thursday at the closing session of the annual Conference of Ambassadors and Chiefs of Consular Missions, the President said "our major concern is to see that the interests of the Palestinian people prevail, and to confirm their rights and those of all Arab parties, in a framework of respect of international law and of the principles set forth in the Oslo, Madrid, Washington and Cairo agreements, particularly the principle of "land for peace." He added, "as we note certain recent indications that seem to favor resumption of the peace process, we reiterate our confidence that the two co-sponsors of the peace process, and particularly the United States, will work to stimulate this process, to encourage all parties to respect the agreements reached and to prevent any regression or attempt to create a new fait accompli that might endanger future security and stability in the region. " 

The President emphasized Tunisia's principled stand against extremism and terrorism. He said that the resurgence of this phenomenon "is now endangering security and stability in numerous countries of both North and South." But he noted "the evolution that has occurred, albeit somewhat late, within the international community in its perception of the seriousness of this phenomenon, and curtailing its effects."

The President said that the international community "must go beyond simple considerations of security" in trying to find solutions to extremism and terrorism, but rather "give real impetus to cooperation and solidarity in favor of the development and the economic expansion of Third World countries, with the adoption of social policies designed to prevent poverty, marginalization and exclusion within different societies, in such a way as to eliminate the factors that feed this phenomenon and favor its expansion."

Ben Ali addressed also in his speech Tunisia's relations with other countries. He said "we will continue our attempts to strengthen relations with our traditional partners in our Arab, European and Mediterranean environment, and to intensify dialogue and concerted effort with the countries of the European Union, in a manner that will serve our mutual interests and develop partnership and cooperation in all fields." He mentioned his recent to Japan as an example of Tunisia's outreach to other parts of the world as "dictated by the imperatives of economic globalization and by the necessity for opening the broadest possible horizons for our country, which has undertaken to meet the challenge of openness and progress."

Full text of speech is available on the Tunisia Online website (http://www. TunisiaOnline.com/news/news.html).


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


85 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 6, 1996


Nigeria;
Politicians Show The Colour of Desperation


BYLINE: Amos Esele, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

Lagos - They're supposed to be in Abuja, the nation's capital, for the brain-racking and energy-sapping process of meeting the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria's guidelines for the registration of parties. But for most politicians, the trip to Abuja is just another opportunity to attempt to kill two birds with a stone. Barely a month to the end of the third quarter of the year, set aside for the state and local government creation exercise, politicians, whose future fortunes will be affected by who gets what state and how, have intensified lobby on behalf of their anticipated future electorate. They are equally concerned, Theweek has learnt, with how government goes about the state and local government creation exercise, in order to enable them map out appropriate strategies for coming elections.

No doubt, the politicians are already campaigning by another means and will return during electioneering to claim their reward from the ever gullible electorate. But theirs is just a part of last-minute moves by Nigerians desperate to realise their dreams of getting new states and local government areas. 

Before now, desperation on the part of the agitators has peaked in the last days of the Committee on State and Local Government Creation and Boundary Adjustment. There are allegations that some state agitators had sought to help their case by giving money to some members of the committee. The collection of "mobilisation fee," as it was called by some state champions claiming to be acting in the interest of their people, reportedly went on till July 1. On that day Arthur Mbanefo, chairman of the committee had dismissed allegations of bribery against committee members and challenged those with evidence to the contrary to publish names of those who collected money from them. Mbanefo threw the challenge shortly after he submitted the report of the committee to Sani Abacha, the head of state. He insisted that the committee received gifts from state governments but not from agitators for states and local governments.

Hundreds of Nigerians from a minority ethnic group who gathered in a hall in Surulere, Lagos, around the time the committee submitted its report, would be the last to take up Mbanefo's challenge, as that would amount to betraying one of their sons. The meeting, held under the auspices of the Lagos chapter of a national social club headquartered in a state the agitators want to split into two, hit a climax when the club president intimated members with a juicy directive from the parent body. He announced that members of the club nationwide were required to make financial contribution towards a N4 million fund. The money, according to the parent body, was to be used to bribe the members of the committee on State Creation. For the avoidance of doubt, members were told that a prominent indigene who, incidentally, was a member of the State Creation Committee, advised on this course of action. A sense of urgency dawned on the meeting and members agreed to act quickly.

In the northern parts of the country, the money was also evident. A source simply described it as forced taxation. He disclosed that some prominent persons were even blackmailed into making substantial financial contributions to a fund. In the case of the New Kaduna State Movement, well-to-do Zaria sons were made to pay to a fund as proof that they were not against the creation of the dream state fully supported by Shehu Idris, the Emir of Zaria. The money, said the collectors, was needed for transportation to Abuja, lodging and secretariat costs.

Theweek could, however, not confirm if money actually changed hands between state movement organisers and the state creation committee members. Investigations showed that some smart members of the movements scattered all over the country might have helped themselves to the money collected under the pretext that it would be used to bribe members of the Mbanefo committee.

Meanwhile, campaigners for new states and local governments are seeking to make maximum use of their contacts in government. The Paul Zakka and Bashir Ikara group which also want a state from Kaduna are said to be looking up to Jerry Useni, minister of the federal capital territory, whom they expect to protect the interests of the Middle Belt.

For the citizens of Ifelodun local government in Kwara State, their dream for a local government to be known as Ifesowapo is said to be as good as realised. Rahim Oladimeji, a businessman who donated N5 million at the state launch of the Family Support Programme, is said to have concluded the lobby for the creation of the said local government, with his home town Igbaja as the proposed headquarters. Oladipo Diya, the Chief of General Staff, has reportedly assured his Ijebu kith and kin that an Ijebu State would not elude them this time. His only demand is that his town, Odogbolu, be made the capital.

For some agitators, money and contacts are not enough. In this category are members of the Itai State Movement in Akwa Ibom State. For some time now they have been holding special prayer sessions in furtherance of their cause. Shortly before the State Creation Committee concluded its 30-state tour during which it received requests and statistical data from agitators, Itai Movement called on its members to pray to God to touch the heart of Mbanefo and his committee members so that their Itai State would be recommended and subsequently created. Seeking to warm its way into Abacha's heart, the group had earlier bought space in some national dailies to condole the head of state on the death of his son, Ibrahim, in the January 17 fatal plane crash near kano.

Simple as its tactics are, Itai State Movement has by its tenacity and publicity made the proposed state to look like a reality, at least in its immediate vicinity. The Akwa Ibom State government is said to be so scared stiff of a possible Itai State that it is trying to frustrate the movements efforts. The state polytechnic at Ikot Osurua, Ikot Ekpene, possible capital of the proposed Itai State, is allegedly being starved of funds by the government. Ikot Ekpene, the second biggest town in Akwa Ibom, after Uyo, is said to have been gratefully excluded from any official investment in the current efforts by the state government to give major towns in the state a face-lift.

The same non-investment mentality reigns supreme among the Izon of Rivers State, although self-imposed. The fourth largest ethnic group in the country and presently shared among several states, the Izon are said to be so sure of at least a state that they have heeded calls by some of their leaders not to invest a kobo in Rivers State until the state creation exercise takes place.

At the other extreme, the New Delta State movement appears to have given up the struggle. But it may not have totally lost out. The Delta State capital, Theweek learnt, may be moved from Asaba to a neutral ground between Isoko and Ukwani.

While some who are campaigning for new states are acting out of ethnic or patriotic sentiments, others like Mamman Nasir, Transition Implementation Committee chairman, may be doing so for other considerations. On retirement from the Bench in 1992, the former president of the Appeal Court was turbaned the district head of Malumfashi with an eye to the emirship of Katsina. Sources say he was not the choice of the Emir of Zaria. The dissolved National Republican Convention which was then in charge in the state was said to have set up a machinery to create more emirates to accommodate Nasir, but was stopped by the legislature controlled by the defunct Social Democratic Party. The scrapping of the political structures almost dashed Nasir's hopes. Still nursing the ambition of becoming Emir, Nasir is said to have thrown his weight behind the campaign for the creation of Kaduna State out of Katsina despite the recommendation against it by a committee set up to look into the potentiality of the envisaged state. Kaduna, if created, would comprise Bakori, Daya, Funtua, Mutaza and other fertile and industrialised areas of southern Katsina.

The ball is obviously in the court of the committee set up by the federal government to study and review Mbanefo's committee recommendations. The Mbanefo committee is said to have recommended that rather than create new state that would depend on the federation account for survival, existing ones should be restructured to make them economically viable. Hot on the heels of the submission of the committee's report came speculations that some areas like Lagos State might be dropped.

Alarmed by this possibility, Lagos State obas, chiefs and senior indigenes met last week and called on the federal government to discard the idea. Lagos State, the committee, known as the Eminent Persons Group, argued remains the most viable state in the federation. The committee was particularly irked by the alleged plans to merge parts of the state with parts of Ogun to create Ijebu State.

Olagunsoye Oyinlola, the Lagos military administrator, later dismissed the speculations. But to some, that is not reassuring enough. Indeed, until new states and local governments are eventually created, the lobbying is bound to continue on different planes.

With Sani Yaro, Ademola Adedoyin, Emmanuel Ado, Akaninyene Esiere, Mfon Uyeh, and Rufina Nsofor.

Issue cover date: August 12, 1996

Africa News


August 6, 1996


Ghana;
Travails Of Ghanaian Image Laundering


BYLINE: Theo Nicol, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Lagos - Disloyal government officials provide the Ghanaian opposition the ammunition with which to fight Jerry Rawlings, incumbent president and front- runner in the December presidential elections.

The Heat is on, as president Jerry Rawlings and his National Democratic Coalition could testify. As the December presidential election approaches, the opposition is making every effort to paint the president in bad light by exposing what it considers his wasteful spending of tax payers' money.

Just recently, the opposition hit town with the story that sources at the Ghanaian embassy in Washington, have revealed that President Rawlings, through Ekwow Spio-Garbar, Ghana's ambassador to the USA, spent about half a million dollars in the past nine months to shore up his image in America. 

The opposition has it that about 400,00 dollars was paid to Burston- Masteller, a public relations firm, between October last year and now, to help make Rawlings look like an angel in the eyes of American congressmen and officials so that they could support Rawlings in the December polls.

It is also alleged that Ambassador Spio-Garbar signed an agreement with Mickel H. Williams, the PR firm's administrative officer, providing for the firm to be paid 40,000 dollars per month plus out-of-pocket expenses, in return for publicity for President Rawlings. The contract was for an initial three months period, but subject to renewal for the same sum of 40,00 dollars monthly as retainer fees, excluding out-of-pocket expenses.

According to sources, the payment to Burston-Masteller was made via bank transfer to account Number 890-022954, ABA NO. 021-000-18, Bank of New York.

The opposition claims that money expended on public relations for Ghana and Rawlings is a big waste as Rawlings himself has helped to erase whatever gains that could have come from the PR campaign. By the end of last January, the initial expiratory period for the contract, Rawlings had had problems with Kow Arkaah, his vice-president, which resulted in a physical attack on Arkaah by the president.

A government spy called Frank Bennen, who was working at the Ghana UN Mission in Geneva, Switzerland, had also put Rawlings in an embarrassing situation. He was arrested for drug dealing and later revealed "too many things" which were not in the government's favour.

To worsen matters for Rawlings, Samuel Okine, a government spy attached to the Ghana High Commission in London, had problems with the police and defected to the USA, where his public utterances caused a lot of damage to Rawlings' image.

Although these events were a big blow to Burston-Marsteller's efforts, Ambassador Spio-Garba was undaunted. Apparently with government's support, he has renewed the PR contract with the American firm and has paid at least another 100,000 dollars to Burston-Marsteller. Details of the new contract are yet to be made public.

As of last week, the presidency and the ruling NDC were yet to officially deny the allegations by the opposition parties.

A source at the presidency who spoke to Theweek however, dismissed the allegations as one of the ploys by the opposition to discredit President Rawlings. "Look, my friend," do you take these people seriously?" asked the source. "They are jokers." Is there any government that does not spend money on public relations? Don't bother about them. They are just being petty."

Asked why so much money was paid to a firm for public relations when the government has its own information and PR unit at the Ghana Mission in the USA, the official explained that the job of publicity is always better handled by an independent, professional firm. "The Mission may be too busy doing other things," he told Theweek. "What is wrong with giving the job to professionals? Doesn't the Nigerian government do the same?"

Africa News


August 6, 1996


Burundi;
A Big Leap Backward For Burundi


BYLINE: Amos Esele, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Lagos - For months before his ouster last Thursday by the military, President Sylvester Ntibantunganya of Burundi would not hear of the idea, let alone tolerate the suggestion of foreign military intervention in his war- torn country. Six months ago he fell back on the vague notion of territorial sovereignty to rebuff a United Nation's planned peace keeping force. He would equally not cooperate with an African peace initiative of ex-President Julius Nyerere of Tanzania.

Last week, Ntibantunganya and his fragile coalition government, badly shaken by events that followed the murder of over 304 Tutsi civilians by Hutu rebels, made a sharp U-turn. He echoed more forcefully the call of his prime minister, Antoine Nduwayo, who agreed June 28 to support a plan for an African peace keeping force. 

But before any help could come its way, the beleaguered regime was sacked by the Burundian Army, which swiftly installed Pierre Buyoya, the country's former military leader from 1987 to 1993, as the new head of state.

During their brief and controversial reign, Nitbantunganya and Nduwayo's hands were filled by bloodshed. A day before the prime minister's turn-around, 1,000 civilian Hutus had been slaughtered at Cibitoke, a refugee camp northwest of Burundi. Rwandan Tutsi soldiers who are said to be allied with their counterparts in neighbouring Burundi, were implicated in the killings. Three weeks later on July 20, Hutu rebels took a revenge. Wielding knives, machetes and guns, the rebels numbering about 1,000, descended on the central Burundian town of Giteg in the early morning of that Saturday. They attacked the military guards, women and children and then burnt some of the over 304 dead bodies.

At the burial ceremony for the deceased last Tuesday, aggrieved Tutsis assaulted their president. They rained stone on him, forcing him to flee to safety in the residence of the American ambassador to Burundi. From his hide- out, Ntibantunganya made a broadcast to his people, appealing for calm and peace. The military which defied strong international warnings not to re-take power, late last week advised him to voluntarily surrender himself to the new regime.

Before it fell, the panic-stricken government had stared expelling about 3, 000 Rwandan Hutus who had been taking refuge in Burundi since the outbreak of violence in their own country in 1994. The United Nations High Commission for Refugees condemned the forced repatriation. Even before the coup, the crisis had taken a toll on politics. Unity for National Progress, the main opposition party, a coalition partner to the government, was badly rattled by the latest bloodletting. As the main opposition in government, UPRONA was represented by Nduwayo, in the government. Following the unending crisis, the opposition party threatened to pull out of the government.

American, Belgian and French soldiers are considering armed evacuation of their people, 900 of whom are said to be leaving Bujumbura every month. Their home countries had earlier cut off aid to Burundi following the no- intervention order of the former government. With dwindling revenue for the coffee-producing Central African country, pay for the civil service and the army has not been forthcoming. This has affected the morale of the army and made the war against the Hutu rebels a no-win situation. Burundi's problem lies in the ethnic imbalance in power sharing. Made up of 85 per cent Hutus and 15 per cent Tutsis, the country under Ntibantunganya, was ruled by a minority Tutsi government. It came to power following the 1993 Tutsi- organised coup in which Melchior Ndadaye, a Hutu and Burundi's first democratically elected president was assassinated. This stirred massacres in which up to about 200,000 persons died. Today, Tutsi hard-liners run the army, the gendarmerie, the security service and the main Tutsi party, UPRONA. The Tutsis had always feared a change in the status quo which would lead to loss of power and wealth.

At the organisation of African Unity heads of state meeting in Cameroun, July 8, Salim Ahmed Salim OAU secretary-general, had called on the Burundian leadership to accept the Arusha peace agenda, which calls for power-sharing between the majority Hutus and minority Tutsis. He indicated that an African peace keeping force would be sent to restore peace in Burundi. Last week's coup, swiftly rejected by the United Nations, could make that a remote possibility.

Issue cover date: August 12, 1996

August 7, 1996


Nigeria;
Mandela Receives Nigerian Envoy


BYLINE: Adamu Lawal Toro , PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

PRETORIA, South Africa (PANA) - Nigeria's new High Commissioner to South Africa, Shehu Malami, has presented his credentials to President Nelson Mandela, who described the appointment as "timely."

"You are the right man for this job here," the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) Wednesday, quoted Mandela as telling Malami. 

He is Nigeria's first high commissioner to Pretoria since the restoration of diplomatic relations between the two countries following the 1994 all-race elections that ended apartheid.

"Nigeria is a leading African country that we would like it to take its rightful position," said Mandela. "We can work together in rebuilding Africa."

Referring to the troubled diplomatic relations between Abuja and Pretoria over the November 1995 execution of nine Nigerian minority rights leaders, the South African leader said he hoped to work closely with Malami in solving some of the "nagging differences" between the two countries.

He said he would never forget the support Nigeria gave to the liberation movements in Africa and to South Africans in particular.

Africa News


August 7, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Soccer Gold Improves Nigerian Image


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi , PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

NEW YORK, United States (PANA) - Nigeria's Olympic soccer victory is still reverberating in the American media, four days after the country's under-23 team beat Argentina 3-2 to clinch the gold medal.

In an article titled 'A Victory For The World To See,' the New York Times said Wednesday that Nigeria's gold medal, more than a simple victory for one country, had become the occasion for some chest-beating around Africa, "even in neighboring countries that have long considered themselves Nigeria's rivals."

"Now all over Africa, people are wildly celebrating an event that, more than any other, made the summer Olympics a resounding success for an often- beleaguered continent: the gold medal victory of Nigeria," the paper wrote.

It quoted the president of the African Football Confederation, Issa Hayatou of Cameroon, as saying: "those who are surprised by our progress will continue to be surprised, because those are people who refuse to see the progress Africa is making." 

It also quoted an Ivorian woman, Marie-Therese Apouteh, as saying that though Africa won a lot of medals (34 medals altogether to record its best games ever), "none shines as brightly as the soccer players' gold. I still get goose bumps at the thought of it."

The write-up is spiced with a photograph of four Nigerian players, their shirts pulled off, revelling after the victory in the match.

The article is a continuation of the unparalleled coverage given to Nigeria's "Dream Team" in Athens Daily News in a front-page story titled " Cinderella Strikes Gold: Underdog Nigerians Turn Back Argentina. The Nigerian Eagles have landed -- On the Olympic Gold Medal Stand."

The paper said "Capping off a brilliant tournament performance in which they often came from behind to win, the Nigerian men's soccer team beat Argentina 3-2, scoring a goal moments before the end of regulation play.".

At least six different photographs of the team, including a full-color front page photograph of skipper Nwankwo Kanu carried shoulder-high by two of his teammates on a victory lap, were splashed on the newspaper's pages.

Other photographs include that of a Nigerian soccer fan, clad in green 'Danshiki' (national dress) with white embroidery, doing a 'bata' dance -- a favorite of the American fans who thronged the stadium to support the so- called "Cinderellas."

In general, the soccer gold won by Nigeria may have helped to enhance the country's image, particularly in the U.S., but a scene at the Hartsfield airport in Atlanta on Monday was perhaps the most pleasurably stimulating since the victory.

On one of the busiest days at the airport, with thousands of people converging there on their way out of the Olympic city, an American boy wearing a white T-shirt emblazoned with the Nigerian flag and the words 'Atlanta' and 'Nigeria' was an indication of how much things have changed since the victory.

"I got it at the soccer finals in Athens, where I supported the Nigerian team," the 10-year-old white American boy proudly told a PANA Correspondent at one end of the airport's concourse D, before continuing his long walk to the other end.

The picture is a sharp departure from the situation some days earlier, when the Nigerian contingent was "blacked out" of the opening ceremonies by NBC TV, and Nigerian taxi drivers in Atlanta would rather introduce themselves as " Africans" rather than as Nigerians.

A barrage of negative articles about Nigeria in the American media, as a result of its political situation and the involvement of a few Nigerians in various vices, had dented the country's image tremendously.

Under that situation, a T-shirt with the Nigerian colors on it may not go beyond the seller's shop.

But, thanks to the exploits of the team referred to as "Cinderella," the situation may have changed.

On the day of the match, several fans -- Nigerians, Africans and Americans - - wore T-shirts with such inscriptions as "the dream team goes for gold" and " I support Nigeria."

And even on the day after the match, several people in Athens were still flying the Nigerian flag on their cars while some decked their shops with it.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

August 7, 1996


Zambia;
Thieves Ransack Zambian Graves


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya , PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian police in the northern regional headquarters of Ndola have detained three suspected grave thieves thought to be part of a syndicate specialized in exhuming corpses and stealing bedding, clothing and other valuables in the graves for sale.

The government-owned Times of Zambia newspaper reported Wednesday that the three were arrested Sunday night after a tip-off. 

The suspects are said to have led security officers to various houses within the town and retrieved blankets and clothing. They are reported to have confessed to the police that they mainly targeted corpses buried in coffins.

The syndicate used to send one emissary to patrol cemeteries everyday for " body-viewing" along with genuine mourners to determine possible targets.

The police were also reported to have recovered more than 26 pairs of underwear allegedly stolen from the coffins which the suspects said were for their personal use, because nobody would be interested to buy used underwear.

A young lady, identified as the wife of one of the suspects, was reported to have openly wept at the police station after learning, for the first time, of her husband's "weird career."

She complained bitterly that the scandal now explained her mysterious dreams about ghosts and sharing a bed with a corpse every night.

"It is difficult to believe this, but I now understand why I have had these strange dreams. At times I dream that I am sleeping with a dead person." she wailed.

Africa News


August 7, 1996


Arts;
Brazzaville Prepares For Pan-African Festival


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Over 2,000 artists from about 20 countries in

Africa and the black diaspora are expected to participate in a Pan-African Music Festival (FESPAM) to be held in Brazzaville, capital of Congo from August 9 to 16, official sources said Wednesday.

According to Congolese culture minister, Gabriel Matsiona, the Central African delegation is already in Brazzaville while musicians and personalities from Latin America, the Pacific, West Indies and West Africa have also confirmed their participation in the event, aimed at uplifting the standard of African music. 

Among the well known artistes expected at the festival are Aicha Kone of Cote d'Ivoire, Senegal's Ismael Lo and Youssou Ndour, Gabonese Pierre Akendengue and Pierre Claver Zing. Several female artistes, such as Mbilia Bell of Zaire, Angelique Kidjo of Togo, Amy Koita of Mali, as well as Monique Seka, a Congolese star based in Cote d'Ivoire, will also take part.

Other musicians, such as Papa Wemba, who is based in France, and Zairean Koffi Olomide, are also said to have expressed a desire to participate in the festival.

South Africa's Yvonne Chaka and Myriam Makeba are also billed to perform at FESPAM, according to organizers.

The artists selected for the competition will perform in places such as the parliamentary palace and the French cultural center, among other venues. Simultaneous performances will also take place in public places.

A carnival is being organized Wednesday in the Congolese capital as a prelude to FESPAM.
