Africa News


August 7, 1996


Science;
Tropical Fruits Ward Off Cancer, Heart Diseases


BYLINE: Peter Masebu , PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The consumption of tropical fruits and vegetables could go a long way to reduce the risk of certain chronic diseases including cancer and heart diseases.

This view is contained in a document entitled "Nutritional Benefits of Tropical Fruits" circulated at an international consultation on tropical fruits, which was held in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia from July 15 to 19.

The meeting was called to promote, among other things, more transparent import procedures for tropical fruits, particularly tariffication and harmonization of sanitary and phytosanitary measures.

"Studies in various parts of the world show that people who consume diets with plenty of plant foods - including tropical fruits - have lower risk of developing heart disease, in particular arteriosclerosis, cancer and other chronic diseases," says the document. 

Ample consumption of tropical fruits can also be an integral part of effective weight control programmes, it says. The nutritious fruits listed were avocado, durian, guava, lime, lychee, mango, mangosteen, papaya, passion fruit, pineapple, starfruit, apple and orange.

These also provide useful amounts of dietary fibre which help to lower the levels of certain fats (or lipids) in the blood, adds the FAO document.

Consumption of some fruits, including tropical fruits and certain vegetables also decreases susceptibility to cancers, in particular those of the digestive and respiratory tracts.

Dark green and orange fruits and vegetables, mangoes and papayas are particularly mentioned as good sources of vitamin A, known as carotenoid, whose low intake raises the risk of some cancers.

Vitamin A is also necessary for normal growth and skeletal development, the health of the skin, eyes and fighting infections.

Many tropical fruits are also good sources of potassium, whose daily intake may reduce the risk of hypertension and stroke.

"Stroke, a hemorrhage of important blood vessels in the brain, is a major cause of death among older adults world-wide. In industrial countries, stroke is usually third among causes of death behind heart diseases and cancer," FAO says.

In addition, tropical fruits are also important sources of vitamin C, which is known to prevent scurvy and also serves as an antioxidant both within the gut where it can enhance the absorption of dietary iron," and within the body's tissues where it may have a protective effect against a number of degenerative processes.

FAO said that fruit and vegetable consumption was picking up in developed countries after declining in the 1950s. Their intake has particularly picked up in the United States thanks to a government-funded campaign to encourage consumers to eat at least five services of fruit or vegetables a day.

In the tropical countries, where a wide variety of fruit are available, consumption is based "on taste and cultural dietary practices, coupled with availability and affordability of the fruit."

One common problem in these countries however is that most of the fruits are seasonal. Due to their abundance during certain months of the year and lack of canning capacity, up to half the fruits available are normally left to waste.

It is for this reason that the international consultation in Kuala Lumpur discussed measures of easing procedures for the export and import of tropical fruits.

Due to tough phytosanitary regulations imposed on canned fruits under the World Trade Organization (WTO), only Kenya and South Africa were listed as major exporters of canned pineapple between 1990 and 1994.

One of the core documents presented at the consultation in Malaysia encouraged exporting countries, including those in Africa, "to adapt to these changes and introduce appropriate mechanisms, including investment in new treatment plants."

If this is done, the thousands of tons of fruits which are wasted each year on the continent could enter the tropical fruit market, whose volume is expected to rise to 1.6 million tons by the year 2000.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


93 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 7, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa In Major African Anti-Malaria Project


BYLINE: Lionel Williams , PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa is playing an active role in a multi-million-dollar project aimed at reducing the incidence of malaria on the African continent.

The Republic's Medical Research Council (MRC) is co-ordinating the project, which is attempting to plot the geographic occurrence of malaria throughout the African continent. 

The co-ordinator of the project dubbed 'Mapping Malaria Risk in Africa (MARA)', Dr. Dave le Sueur, says documenting the geographical occurrence of the disease and its severity will make it easier to implement appropriate and cost-effective intervention.

MARA will also concentrate on such issues as drug resistance, mosquito species and climate, he added. A team of five investigators would integrate the data into a geographical information system.

The MRC will maintain the project database, and ensure that the information is regularly updated and relevant. Maps will be made available on the Internet, and on a Worldwide Web site now being constructed. This means that people planning to travel anywhere in Africa will be able to access the Web site for information on necessary precautions to take when planning to visit malaria-infected areas.

Le Sueur says more than 300 million people are at risk in terms of contracting malaria, mainly in sub-Saharan Africa. "Last year was the worst in South Africa since the 1930s," he said, "with over 20,000 cases and 124 deaths.

Zimbabwe had more than 1.4 million cases by May this year, and more than 2, 000 deaths, despite active control efforts," Le Sueur added.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


94 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 7, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwean Modern and Traditional Healers Collaborate


BYLINE: Tambayi Nyika , PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - In one corner, a trained medical doctor exchanges diagnostic notes with a black-robed traditional healer, clutching a cow-horn tobacco pouch stuffed with brown snuff, which he regularly sniffs up his sooty nostrils.

The next moment the healer takes off his crown of feathers head gear, sits down on a reed mat legs crossed, and goes into a trance, casting bones like dice on the bare floor.

In an adjacent room, a faith healer recites a prayer, invoking the Holy Spirit to drive out demons. Outside, a long queue of desperate patients await their turn in the hope that their health problems will finally be solved. 

The above-scenario is replicated daily at a local clinic in Zimbabwe's second city of Bulawayo, where a 15-year old experiment that combines traditional, medical and faith healing is underway, despite criticism and prejudice from the world of science and modern medicine.

"When we started out, we were not given a chance. Everybody thought we were a joke, cheats out to take advantage of people's desperation. But prejudice has since turned into confidence," says Barbara Sibanda, cofounder of the clinic, located right in the city center.

The traditional medical clinic, which has since opened a maternity wing manned by both traditional and medical midwives and a rural outpost, recently celebrated its 15th anniversary as a model for Southern African countries in an era of complicated diseases that have even defied modern scientific research.

Research shows that despite the advent of modern medicine a century ago, up to 80 percent of the people in Africa believe in the efficacy of traditional herbal treatment.

"The success of the clinic does not lie in the hundreds of patients seeking alternative treatment methods every month but also in the success rate that has been achieved so far," says Dr Theo-Ewart Harvey, a medical doctor who works closely with traditional healer, Dumezweni Sidambe, midwife Elita Mlilo and faith healer, Harriet Ndlovu.

Records show that the number of patients at the Bulawayo clinic has risen from a mere 500 in 1981 to over 25,000 in 1995, some of them from surrounding rural areas, and neighboring Zambia.

Sibanda says patients visit the clinic either out of faith in traditional medicine or as a last resort after the failure of modern practice. She adds that patients are given a choice between the three methods. In the event of one of them failing, the patient is given an option to try the next alternative.

The doctor or traditional healer may also recommend the option most likely to succeed, which the patient is free to accept or reject.

"This has given our patients a wider choice. Some kind of revolution in the health delivery system," says Sibanda, who adds that the bias over the years is increasingly tilting toward traditional herbal remedies for ailments like infertility, mental illness, epilepsy, asthma and sexually transmitted diseases resistant to anti-biotics.

"This clinic is particularly proud of the traditional remedies to infertility which has helped hundreds of women conceive after years of trying medical methods. Most of them prefer to give birth at our maternity wing which we opened for that purpose," says Sibanda.

Recognition for the clinic which previously experienced "terrible prejudice" was evident during the anniversary when Zimbabwe's health minister, Timothy Stamps, and representatives of traditional healers organizations from Ghana, Nigeria, Malawi and host country, Zimbabwe attended.

At that anniversary, the secretary general of the international organisation of traditional and medical practitioners, Rodwell Zongo of Zambia, traced the history of traditional medicine and criticized scientific prejudice to a system that has been around since the beginning of time.

"Traditional medicine has proved beyond doubt that it is as good, if not better in some cases, than Western medicine. African governments should now seriously consider funding further research in African medicine for complicated diseases like AIDS," he says.

The president of the 40,000-strong Zimbabwe National Traditional Healers Association (ZINATHA), Gordon Chavunduka, says because of ignorance, modern medicine continues to deny that traditional practitioners have concluded a lot of basic research and that many of the herbs used are correct even when judged by scientists.

He says in the last 15 years, ZINATHA collected 125 samples of traditional medicines for sampling by the drug control laboratory in Harare, 119 of which proved safe and useful while the rest were useless.

"Modern scientists from universities and other research centers will not discover anything new in the field of traditional medicine," he says. What is required, he adds, is collaboration, not condemnation of efforts to improve the country's health delivery system.

Stamps, who has been severely criticized for his indifferent attitude to traditional medicine, had the last say when he called for more cooperation between the two sides. Observers see this call as an acknowledgment that traditional medicine is here to stay.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


95 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 7, 1996


Burundi;
World Food Programme on Burundi sanctions


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The United Nations World Food Programme (WFP)

Tuesday expressed concern at the sanctions imposed on Burundi by neighboring states.

In a statement to PANA in Dakar from its Rome headquarters, WFP said the sanctions were blocking emergency food supplies to the needy in the country. 

"Unless key neighboring countries allow emergency supplies to enter, then the situation is likely to worsen," spokesman Trevor Rowe said. "This will force WFP to find other, more costly alternatives to delivering food."

The organization estimated there was currently a stockpile of one month's emergency food supplies in the country for some 300,000 people.

"A key problem is that once transport operations are shut down, it requires a long time to restart them. Trucks and drivers must be found again and contracts renegotiated," the WFP said.

Seven neighboring states, at a summit last week in Arusha, Tanzania, imposed sanctions against Burundi to protest a military coup on July 25 by former leader Maj. Pierre Buyoya.

Buyoya says he would assuage the ethnic rivalry between his minority Tutsi and the majority Hutu ethnic groups which have claimed some 200,000 lives since 1994.

But the neighboring states rejected his argument saying it does not bode well for sustainable peace in the central African country. Uganda and neighboring Rwanda, which has the same ethnic profile as Burundi, have said they would not join the embargo against Bujumbura.

Meanwhile, WFP on Tuesday also protested the Kenyan government's banning of its King Air passenger flights from Kenya to Burundi.

"The move is expected to make it more difficult for WFP personnel and cargo to transit in and out of Burundi," it said.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


96 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 7, 1996


Ethiopia;
Bank Of Abyssinia Reopens After 60 Years


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos , PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The first private bank in Africa, the Bank of Abyssinia, has re-opened for business after 60 years in oblivion, with a capital of more than 25 million birr (about four million U.S. dollars).

The bank, wholly owned by Ethiopian shareholders, is the third private bank to be floated since the marxist regime of former President Mengistu Haile Mariam was ousted in May 1991. 

It opened its doors for business here over the weekend. The Bank of Abyssinia, which was founded in 1905 during the reign of Emperor Menelik II, was nationalized in 1930.

Its new managing director is Tekalign Gedamu, former vice president of the Abidjan-based African Development Bank.

The man behind the revival of the defunct bank is Debebe Habte-Yohannes, founder and managing director of Addis Ababa Bank, the second private-owned bank in the country, established in 1965.

The National Grindleys Bank of England was the minority share-holder of the Addis Ababa bank before it was nationalized 10 years later by the Mengistu regime.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


97 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 8, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigerian Sultan Exonerated


BYLINE: Emmanuel Ado, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Lagos - A government probe panel exonerated Ibrahim Dasuki of alleged financial sins, paving the way for secret negotiations between the Abacha regime and the family of the deposed Sultan.

For the family of Ibrahim Dasuki, deposed Sultan of Sokoto, the decision to take the Sani Abacha government to court over Dasuki's continued detention was not a simple one. Conservative elements within the family had argued that the move would further anger the government. The argument was, however, roundly defeated by other family members who cited the various hostile acts of government against the family. 

Family sources revealed that contrary to claims by Yakubu Muazu, the Sokoto State military administrator, Dasuki's accounts were indeed frozen following his deposition. The family was also said to be irked that Dasuki's family members, lawyers and personal physician, had been denied access to him after he was deposed on April 20.

According to family sources, what finally proved a decisive factor was the revelation by a mutual friend of the Dasukis and the Abachas, that the head of state had "feigned ignorance" when he was requested to allow Dasuki family access to the ex-Sultan.

In the circumstance, the family reasoned that by going to court, it would help the government tidy up the mess in which it has found itself over the Dasuki affair. Once the decision was taken, Chimezie Ikeazor, a senior advocate, was contacted to file a suit on behalf of Dasuki, asking for N500 million for illegal detention. An early sign of victory came when Tajudeen Odunowo, justice of the Federal High Court Lagos, granted Dasuki leave to enforce his fundamental rights to the dignity of his person, personal liberty and freedom of movement.

In the substantive application Dasuki asked the court to declare as illegal, null and void his continued detention in Zing or any other place by the Sokoto or Taraba State government or security agents acting for, and on behalf of the said governments for periods of over two and a half months without trial or be informed of the offense for which he is being detained. He also asked for an order releasing him from detention.

There are strong indications that the governments wants the matter amicably resolved. Sources confirmed to Theweek that shortly after the application was filed by Ikeazor, government started to mount tremendous pressure on Dasuki's family to withdraw the suit. The government, according to sources, has reportedly argued that Dasuki - if he got to know of his family's line of action - would not support it, but that as a good Muslim, he would accept his predicament as the will of Allah. The family reportedly described the government's new point an insulting, resulting in the hardening, rather than the weakening of its resolve. The family, in effect, adopted the attitude that "he who is down, has no fear of a fall."

The confidence of the family might have been informed by some favourable developments in the last few weeks. In a landmark decision, Mukiliu Ope-Agbe, chairman of Lagos zone of the Failed Banks Tribunal, had declared that it was illegal for the Nigerian Deposit Insurance Corporation to have joined directors of debtor companies as parties in suits against debtor firms. The judge ruled that actions filed by NDIC could only indirectly affect the directors during the execution of the tribunal's judgment. Going by Ope Agbe's judgment, joining the directors of debtor companies as parties is contrary to section 290 of the Companies and Allied Matters Decree of 1990.

The judgment removed a major plank on which Muazu, the Sokoto military administrator, had based the removal of Dasuki. Worse for the government, the Garba Gummie panel set up to audit the account of the Sokoto Emirate Council from 1988 to 1990, had exonerated Dasuki of any wrong doing while in office as Sultan. According to the report of the panel, the deposed Sultan had banked N2 million, part of foreign grants for the propagation of Islam, with the Bank of the North, Sokoto branch. The investigators found the record of expenditure of the foreign grants convincing enough. They also found that the deposed Sultan was using his personal resources to run the Emirate council, which is said to be bankrupt.

The panel also discovered that as a result of Dasuki's foresight, the Emirate Council has acquired property in Abuja worth millions of naira and that the decision to acquire the property was approved by the Sokoto State government. Dasuki was also found to have divided his salary amongst Islamic teachers and Hajia Amina, wife of Ahmadu Bello, the late premier of the defunct Northern Region.

The vindication of Dasuki might have informed government's change of attitude towards him. Last week, top government officials surprised the family, when they presented them with passes to Zing. The family members were expected to visit Dasuki last Friday. It would be the first contact between Dasuki and members of his family since April when he was unceremoniously removed from office.

Theweek gathered that the government's gesture was aimed at cajoling the Dasuki family to withdraw the suit it filed against the government. Government reportedly gave indications that if the suit was withdrawn, Dasuki would be released. By last Wednesday, the family appeared to have backpedalled from its position that government should first release Dasuki unconditionally, before the suit instituted June 11, could be withdrawn. On that day Ikeazor, counsel to Dasuki, informed Odunowo of his willingness to withdraw the suit following a change of heart by government, which, he revealed, recently allowed him access to his client. The move was not challenged by the defendants, paving the way for Odunowo to accordingly strike out the suit as requested by Ikeazor. Secret negotiations are continuing between both parties. If every thing goes well, Dasuki may end up being exiled to Yola, as he has requested.

Issue cover date: August 12, 1996

August 8, 1996


Zambia;
'Token' Amount Raised For Women Candidates


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The National Women's Lobby Group campaign fund project has only raised K500,000, an amount which falls far short of the needs of women candidates.

Treasurer of the campaign fund project Ms. Honorine Muyoyeta announced that the money that has been raised so far is not enough to support most the women candidates. She was speaking during a live debate on the challenges of women candidates in the presidential and general elections.

Ms Muyoyeta whose project embarked on the fundraising campaign last month made a fresh appeal to the general public to donate for the women's cause. She, however, did not mention the amount needed to support the women candidates who would be approved by the various political parties.

Speaking at the function MMD representative Professor Nkandu Luo urged women candidates to identfy campaign issues in order to win support from the electorate. She said women should market themselves and show what they can offer from the grassroot levels.

Prof Luo also said women are the custodians of traditional values and hence have an advantage over the male candidates.

She further urged women who are fighting to be part of the electoral process to be committed to their parties and show that they can work side by side with men.

And UNIP representative, Mrs Mary Fulano said women should be given a chance to compete favourably with men because they are equals.

August 8, 1996


Zambia;
Students Protest Cancellation Of Former President's Talk


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - An invitation of former president Kenneth Kaunda by the University of Zambia Political and Administrative Students' Association (UNZAPSA) to address students last evening was cancelled by the university administration.

But students did not take kindly to the cancellation and accused the government of trying to silence intellectual reasoning and debate at the University of Zambia (UNZA).

"We feel disappointed and betrayed by the move to abort the meeting because all we wanted was to have first hand information about the current political and economic situation from the voice of wisdom," final year law school student Robinson Malipenga said in an interview last night. 

And at UNZA's Great Road campus last night, UNIP and UNZAPASA officials pleaded with angry students not to resort to violence, as hundreds of them, chanting anti-MMD slogans marched to Kalundu where Kaunda addressed them.

At Kalundu, former president Kaunda told the students he was very "hurt and disappointed that this has happened".

"I hope it is not the beginning of autocracy at UNZA," former president Kaunda carped. "Students at the highest institution of learning must be free to meet and discuss with anyone they want."

President Kaunda added: "Revolution can never die when there are active youths like you. Zambia shall be free gain."

But the students insisted that he should go with them to UNZA and address their meeting.

"I am a 24 hours free man and if you invite me tomorrow I will come," Kaunda said in an impromptu address.

Students demanded to shake hands with him before dispersing.

Earlier a letter from the acting registrar announced the cancellation of the meeting, the second following one in March this year organised by the banned University of Zambia political Association.

"I am compelled to cancel the meeting forthwith and to direct you, through the office of the Dean of Students, to re-schedule the meeting," reads part of the letter from the acting registrar Peter Pande.

Africa News


August 8, 1996


Business;
Plans To Hike Zambian Fuel Levy Criticised


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The government's plans to hike the fuel levy are not justified as the current levels of revenue collected for the roads maintenance programme was sufficient to sustain the exercise, said Chartered Institute of Transport (CIT) national chairman, Henry Chipewo in an interview yesterday.

"The K15 billion collected for the roads maintenance programme is quite sufficient but because of over pricing by the road contractors the funds seem to be little to sustain the exercise," Chipewo said.

Chipewo, however, called on the government and the National Roads Board to work towards standardising the pricing of road works and avoid overcharging by unscrupulous contractors. 

"Just how does one arrive at K200 million per kilometre, when he uses very little money for crushed stones and whatever he needs to rehabilitate the roads?" Chipewo asked. "The government should not just jump onto the innocent tax payers and impose huge levies on them after failing to control bad contractors."

Works and supply deputy minister, Celestino Chibamba, recently said government was planning to hike the fuel levy.

"The increment will have ill effects on the people, buses and other fuel users will also increase their fares," Chipewo said.

And Chipewo advised the government to halt the "raiding" of funds collected for the roads rehabilitation exercise if the programmes was to succeed.

But the director of budget at the finance ministry, Elesani Njobvu, denied that government has been sourcing revenue from the roads fund.

"The fuel levy is collected as part of excise duty and we only know the percentage of fuel levy after returns are submitted every after 10 days. So it is wrong to say that we are sourcing government revenue from the fuel levy, "Njobvu said.

Njovu, however, confirmed that about K400 million of fuel levy had not yet been paid to the Roads Board.

But Roads Board chairman, Raymond Jhala, earlier accused Chipewo of " playing to the gallery".

"Chipewo as chairman of CIT sits on the Roads Board and knows the facts fully. No money is being diverted,"Jhala said. "The levy is just not enough to cover the reconstruction work that needs to be done on the roads."

August 9, 1996


South Africa;
New South African Crackdown on Crime


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

JOHANNESBURG (PANA) - President Nelson Mandela of South Africa has announced tough new measures to crack down on the disturbing crime rate in the country, giving the assurance that the public will see the impact of the new initiative within a matter of days.

An average of 50 people are killed in violence and crime-related incidents in the country each day, making it one of the most dangerous places to live in the world.

General crime levels in South Africa -- underlined this past week by the " war" between drug gangs and vigilante groups in Cape Town -- are causing increasing public and business concern. 

Earlier this week, the South African Chamber of Business said that its monthly business confidence index had dropped to its lowest level in almost a year.

Addressing a media conference at his Cape Town official residence Thursday, Mandela said: "The question of violence is one we are dealing with. I am in contact with the minister of safety and security as well as the minister of defense on the matter, and we are taking the necessary precautions."

"In a couple of days," he added, "every body will see that the government is taking very strong measures to crack down on all forms of crime in the country, especially in the Western Cape and Johannesburg".

Referring to drug-trafficking in South Africa, Mandela said it was clear that the country was dealing with some very powerful syndicates which had links beyond its borders.

"That's a matter of common knowledge," he added, "and that is why we have established a regional organization which includes all the members of the Southern African Development Community (SADC), who are dealing with questions of security generally."

The Johannesburg daily, 'The Citizen', reported Friday that the South African police force, backed by units of the national defense force, are poised for what could be the single most visible anti-crime offensive undertaken in the country.

This follows urgent meetings earlier this week between safety and security minister, Sydney Mufamadi, and justice minister Dullah Omar, with defense minister Joe Modise promising full military backing for the planned exercise.

In Pretoria Thursday, former cabinet minister Pik Botha called on Mandela and other South African leaders to hold a national convention on crime.

South Africa, he said, needed to prove to the world that it had the will to eradicate crime and make the country truly free and a justified target for foreign investment.

Africa News


August 9, 1996


Kenya;
New Sugarcane Variety Developed in Kenya


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

KISUMU, Kenya (PANA) - The Muhoroni Sugar Company in western Kenya

has developed a new sugarcane variety which matures faster than the existing types.

The company's agronomist, Simon Kibet, said the new variety dubbed H35-198, is currently undergoing final tests and will soon be submitted to the Kobos sugar research station for authentication. 

After being tested at the Kibos sugar research station, the new sugarcane will be subjected to tests by all sugar factories in Kenya.

Speaking to journalists at the start of the 1996 Kisumu agricultural show, in western Kenya, Kibet said H35-198 is expected to mature in 17 months instead of 20.

The agronomist said the crop, developed from sugar seed imported from Hawaii, will be self-stripping, adding that research has shown it was suitable and could do well in the Nyanza sugar belt's soil in western Kenya.

The new variety will be submitted to the national co-ordination of varieties board for trials by other shareholders in the sugar industry.

Kibet said at Mohoroni Sugar Company, H35-198 had been tried against the conventional breeds for germination, stock count and juice analysis.

"Its juice quality compared favorably against conventional types such as Co 421 and Co617, which are currently widely planted in our estates in Mohoroni," he said.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 9, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Growing Pains For New Zimbabwe University


BYLINE: Joshua Munthali, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - No beds or matresses for the prospective students.

Worse still, no desks or chairs and no laboratory facilities for the under- graduates. Just a few academics waiting to dispense higher education to the first crop of aspiring science education teachers. 

Such was the gloomy scenario when Zimbabwe's latest institution of higher learning, Bindura University College of Science Education (BUCSE), in the provincial capital of Mashonaland central, opened doors of its empty buildings to the first intake of students in April 1996.

The birth of the college follows the government's decision in 1995 to relocate the Zimbabwe-Cuba science teacher education programme to Zimbabwe.

With the United States economic blockade imposed on Cuba biting hard, living conditions for Zimbabwean students studying in the Carribean island had worsened due to reduced stipends.

The Fidel Castro government, as a show of solidarity with this southern African nation dating back to Zimbabwe's armed liberation struggle, had sponsored the programme since independence in 1980. But Cuba later indicated it could no longer sustain it because of the debilitating economic embargo.

However, some 600 students are still studying in Cuba.

Originally a government public service training centre offering courses in craftwork, domestic science and secretarial work, the Bindura college, 80 km north-east of Harare, has now been transformed into a university with an initial intake of 125 students, 10 of them female.

As if logistical problems were not enough, the embryonic university has been granted a paltry one million U.S. dollars by the government, a far cry from the three million dollars actually needed.

"During the first week, students had to make do without furniture as most of the furniture and equipment had not yet been delivered," says James Chitauro, pro-vice chancellor of the college, which is affiliated to the University of Zimbabwe in Harare.

He says the college has been promised three million dollars for recurrent expenditure but needs in excess of two million dollars to start constructing laboratories and other essential facilities.

Students at the college study for a four-year bachelor of science with education degree, majoring in general science, biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics.

Education, curriculum development, pedagogics and teaching practice are also taught.

"We also envision expansion in other areas of science, including computer science, soil sciences and mining sciences," Chitauro says.

"All these projections of course depend on demand, resource base and capacity of the college to deliver the programme to prescribed standards."

The college has capacity for an intake of 1,000 students when fully operational in about five years with the first graduation in the year 2000.

The college has 15 staff members recruited locally and five Cuban nationals.

Chitauro says staff recruitment was largely successful although there were a few hitches with some offers not being taken up. "The last seven months had been devoted to recruitment of staff. We recruited five."

The college official is anxious that more experienced professors, associate professors, senior lecturers and lecturers teaching at the University of Zimbabwe should assist in the successful implementation of the Bindura programme.

One believes that given all the necessary support, growing pains will not be that much for the nascent university.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


104 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 9, 1996


Business;
Zambian Tariff Structure To Be Modified


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - The government is considering integrating the five per cent charged under the Import Declaration Form (IDF) into the customs tariff structure, reports Business Line, the ZACCI newsletter, of August 6.

The IDF is a form required to be filled out and 5 per cent of the cost of whatever import declared must be paid to the state before the form is handed over.

"The government plans to do this in 1997 when the customs tariff structure is modified to a two rate tariff structure only," read the business newsletter. 

Government promised to eliminate the IDF by the end of last year but nothing has been done about the levy up to now.

Speaking in an interview in Lusaka yesterday, finance minister Ronald Penza said government will be raising revenue fairly by installing uniform rates of tariffs.

"The IDF is a good way of raising revenue for the government. But we are just trying to make it easier and fair for everybody with the new tariffs," he said.

ZACCI reported that the government intends to integrate the IDF into one of the two tariff rates of 10 per cent and 25 per cent respectively.

The 10 per cent band will cater for both raw materials and intermediate goods while the 25 per cent will be for finished goods only.

The danger in the move is that imports of finished goods from the COMESA region, which currently attract duty at six to eight per cent, will have a debilitating effect on Zambian industry because they will be much cheaper than locally produced goods which have been manufactured using raw materials imported at 10 per cent duty.

ZACCI has on numerous occasions raised concern at government's mode of policy restructuring, asking that government consult the private sector before jumping into decisions.

Chairman of Stanbic Bank and member of ZACCI, David Phiri, on Tuesday urged Penza to the clarify government's policy to the people so as to avoid misunderstandings.

"If people knew what was going on and policies were made clearer then the business sector might have more confidence in the market," Phiri said.

But the minister said the perceptions of politicians and the private sector were different. It was enough indication to the private sector that politicians were fully behind the structural economic reforms, Penza said.

ZACCI suggests a five per cent levy on raw materials, 15 per cent for intermediate goods and 25 per cent for finished goods.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 9, 1996


Zambia and Zaire;
Zambia-Zaire Border Temporarily Closed


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Mansa - The Zambia-Zaire border at Chembe-Mwenda crossing was temporarily closed on Thursday by Zairean soldiers following an alleged refusal by a Zambian driver to give money which they demanded on flimsy grounds.

The temporary closure meant that most of the transporters from the Copperbelt could not be allowed through for many hours until around 17.00 hours when some transporters made donations towards the demands of the soldiers that was when the border was re-opened. 

One of the passengers who suffered the inconvenience was Mr. Peter Kasompe, a vice chairman of Mwaiseni branch of the MMD in Mansa Central Constituency.

He said that the driver who works for Katebe Katoto company was uncompromising with the solders who man the border gates, and argued with them volubly using one of the Zairean languages. This infuriated the soldiers as they thought he was an ex-Zairean soldier or simply a turn-coat out to destroy their lucrative source of easy income.

And Mansa central constituency MMD acting chairman Paul Kalwa has appealed to the government to intervene in such sensitive issues and deal firmly with trouble markers," he said.

Zambia;
Foundation Sets Program To Empower Zambian Women


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Ndola - The Ndola branch of the HOPE foundation is to draw a programme of empowerment for women in shanty compounds to enable them achieve self reliance.

Newly elected chair-person of the branch, Judith Chama, said she would work towards empowering women in shanty compounds to rely on their own instead of depending on their husbands entirely. 

"We need to educate mothers to fight on their own and achieve success," she said.

Mrs Chama scooped the post of chairperson in a by-election of the Ndola branch of the Hope Foundation to fill the vacancy left by Anne Nsuluka who left for Lusaka after the transfer of her husband.

The new chairperson polled 23 votes and beat Mary Zambezi who was acting in the position but trailed behind with 19 votes.

Mrs. Chama said one of the projects her executive would work on was the completion of the childcare centre in Mushili.

The project is at roof level and will also offer training facilities for women in various skills.

August 9, 1996


Zambia;
Election Monitors Coming To Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Luanshya - The government will invite international monitors to observe this year's presidential and parliamentary elections to forstall cries of rigging by opposition parties.

Addressing a meeting of constituency and brach officials in Mikomfwa Hall yesterday, Defence Minister Benjamin Mwila, said that the two monitoring groups of Forum for Democratic Process (FODEP) and the Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) could not be relied upon because they were biased and partisan to the opposition parties. 

Mr Mwila said that the two groups in the country had lost direction and tended to side with the opposition.

He charged that FODEP and ZIMT were political parties masquarading as non governmental organisations when in fact they had different agendas.

Mr Mwila said that even the leaders of the two groups were 'fake Zambians' who had not interest at heart of this country.

He said that some opposition parties had continued to cry foul over the contracting of Nikuv to update the voters registers because they had registered in more polling stations.

He said they thought they would cheat the computers but they were fished out.

Mr Mwila, who is also member of parliament for Luanshya constituency said that they were crying over the shoulders of the international community when the MMD fought it out inside the country without anybody's help.

He said that the MMD only invited the international community at a later stage when it was asked to explain its policies.

Mr Mwila also said that the 'black mambas' have been firmly dealth with and the elections will go on peacefully.

He said that despite Dr Kaunda's rantings that he would release some of the suspected leaders of the group, this could not be done because 'it was mere cheap propaganda.'

108 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 9, 1996


Zambia;
Agro-Party Formed By Zambian Farmers


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Ndola - Two prominent Zambian farmers today announced the formation of a political party whose platform will entirely rest on the agricultural plank.

Former Agricultural Minister and Mpika Member of Parliament, Dr Guy Scott, joined President of the Zambia National Union of Farmers (ZNUF) Ben Kapita to announce formation of the new party.

Consequently Dr Scott has resigned from Movement for Multi-Party Democracy to form the National Lima Party (NPL) and Mr Kapita is equally expected to resign from the farmers union. 

The new party, dubbed the great one by its founders, is not interested in the presidency but wil contest this year's elections and seek representation of farmers in parliament. The party was registered with the Registrar of Societies on August 9 but names of other founding committee members were not given during the brief chaired by both Dr Scott and Mr Kapita.

A statement by the two helmsmen of the new party who will be co-chairmen until a convention is held said NLP wanted duly elected farmers representatives to be in the house to provide balance and oblige the executive to take interest of the rural sector more seriously than they have done in the past. The statement read by Dr Scott said whatever the differences of approach by the former UNIP government and MMD, a single striking miner is of more political significance than 1000 desperate village farmers.

"It is basically this bias away from the villages that has resulted in our former federal partners Zimbabwe and Malawi outstripping us in agricultural production many times over," the statement added.

The NLP aims to correct the state of affairs in parliament.

But the NLP may also decide to support candidates who belong to other parties but have independent thoughts and a bias towards farmers.

The statement said the new party wanted to usher in the concept of political representation based on economic interest groups rather than idealogy, tribe or narrow individual interest in the Zambian democracy.

Earlier Mr Kapita who said he would relinquish his post in the farmers union observed that Zambia was one of the few countries with surplus arable land but every year asked for food aid from nations which are even smaller in size because it has not utilized its potential.

"For 32 years we have talked about agricultural potential but we have not created wealth from this," he said. He noted that out of 60 million hectares of arable land in Zambia, only nine million is being utilized and the problem was that the representatives in parliament did not understand agriculture.

The government should be serious about putting agriculture in its right place.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA
