Africa News


August 10, 1996


Ethiopia;
Youth - Ethiopia's Future (editorial)


BYLINE: Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Addis Ababa - In 1995, the Ethiopian youth population (i.e. persons aged 15 - 24 years) are estimated to be 12 million. By the year 2020, young people will number 31 million. 

The difficulties faced by the general population is exacerbated for the young by the lack of adequate opportunities for education and training, unemployment, juvenile delinquency, poor health facilities and services, etc. This situation is doubly detrimental in that young people constitute the major human resource for development; they are, in many sectors, the key agents for social change and technological innovations.

Trapped in a vice of poverty, young people are deprived of access to opportunities which could contribute not only to their own development but also to that of societies in which they live. Young people are frequently the last to benefit directly from general progress. Living without basic resources curtails the participation of youth in the lives of their communities and nations. In Ethiopia, faced with too many demands and too few resources, the needs of the youth go unanswered to the long term detriment of development.

Young people need support if they are to play a central role in society. As a recent United Nations paper recommended "...reviewing and assessing the situation of youth; evaluating and improving existing policies for youth; developing new policies and programs where necessary; mobilizing resources for the implementation of these policies and programs" is necessary.

Issue cover date: August 2


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


147 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 10, 1996


Ethiopia;
End of "free" imports to bring changes


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2054 words


 

Addis Ababa - Effective as of August 3, 1996 for new goods and September 30, 1996 for used (or second-hand) merchandise, imports into Ethiopia on a franco valuta basis will be banned.

The term "franco valuta" is not one that can easily be found in a dictionary. If it is found at all, the two component words appear separately: "Franco" means "free of charge" and "valuta" may be broadly defined as " foreign exchange". So, literally, "franco valuta" would mean "free of charge in foreign exchange". Practically, franco valuta imports in Ethiopia are those goods which enter the country without the use of foreign exchange held within the domestic banking system, which comprises the National Bank of Ethiopia and other banks. 

There are three ways in which imports enter the country and these are: by using the country's own foreign exchange resources; through gifts and grants and through foreign loans. Imports which are purchased by using official foreign exchange (i.e. foreign exchange in the banking system) and foreign exchange recourses of the private sector. But at this point the question of where the private sector obtains its foreign exchange may arise, considering the fact that the holding of foreign exchange by the private sector with the exception of the recently introduced foreign currency accounts for exporters is illegal. Principally, the private sector gets its foreign exchange through the following major avenues all of which, of course, are illegal under present legislation:

* Foreign exchange remittances from abroad converted into domestic currency on the black market or through special arrangements;

* Foreign exchange conversions from foreign tourists and other travelers in Ethiopia;

* Receipts from contraband trade in exports;

* Underinvoicing of exports and overinvoicing of imports;

* Foreign exchange earned by rendering certain services to foreigners;

It is therefore with the foreign exchange obtained from these sources that the private sector finances its franco valuta imports.

With the banning of franco valuta imports, the supply of foreign exchange to the black market and the latter's demand for foreign exchange are expected to decrease. This is likely to lead to a decline in the black-market birr/dollar rate, bringing it closer to what may be called the official rate on the foreign exchange auction market. A good part of the foreign exchange demand on the black market may shift to the auction market, raising the birr/dollar rate here. The remaining portion of the foreign exchange demand on the black market could find an outlet in an increase in contraband imports. In other words, what used to finance legal franco valuta imports would now in part finance illegal, tax-evading goods smuggled into the country. So, the banning of legal franco valuta imports may well encourage contraband imports. One reason why this may be expected is that importing through the official foreign exchange auction market involves several eligibility conditions including the possession of a valid import trade license and an expiry date for the utilization of foreign exchange.

On the other hand, will the previous supply of foreign exchange to the black market now shift to the official foreign exchange market? The answer would be, yes. But not all of it would switch to official channels. Part of it would remain on the black market, financing, as indicated, an increase in smuggled goods.

Hence, the final upshot may be (a) a shift in the foreign exchange supply from the black market to official channels; (b) an increase in contraband (tax-evading) imports because of the banning of legal franco valuta imports; (c) a rise in the foreign exchange auction market birr/dollar rate because of the expected higher rise in demand than in supply; and (d) a decline in the black-market birr/dollar rate because of the anticipated higher decrease in demand associated with the banning of franco valuta imports than the possible rise in demand for contraband imports.

From the on-going process of foreign exchange liberalization, is the forthcoming banning of franco valuta imports by the private sector a step forward or backward? Franco valuta imports are legal. The government gets quite a substantial amount of revenue from customs duties levied on these imports. In fact, one other effect of the prohibition imposed on these imports is likely to be a decline in government revenue as the shift in imports from a franco valuta basis to the auction (or Letter of Credit) basis is not expected to compensate for the loss in revenue. On the other hand, some of the financing methods used for franco valuta imports are quite illegal, namely contraband exports destined for financing tax-evading, contraband imports and under-and over-invoicing of exports and imports.

By contrast, the conversion of foreign exchange from foreign tourists and other travelers by private foreign exchange dealers is in keeping with the basic objective of eventually creating a free market for foreign exchange. The same observation applies to foreign remittances being converted into domestic currency by the private sector. Hasn't the government promised that over the next three years exports, public or private, will be allowed to retain one hundred percent of their foreign exchange earnings to do with them as they please, with the possible exception of depositing them abroad? Is it not the wish of the IMF and World Bank, the government's economic and financial mentors, to see the flourishing of private foreign exchange bureaus? Why then discourage some of the foreign exchange dealings on the so- called black-market which are sooner or later destined to be officially recognized and be made legal?

The irony is that the banning of franco valuta imports is likely to lead to a rise in an activity that is truly illegal: that of importing goods without paying taxes due to the government. On the other hand, thousands of Ethiopians receive bona fide gifts in the form of second-hand cars, new TV sets, second-hand or new capital goods and many other items every year from relatives and friends abroad on a franco valuta basis. Why should this free flow of resources be stopped? How are goods brought in by Ethiopians after a relatively short stay abroad going to be treated?

Will they be banned or will they be allowed in, duty-free into the bargain, as promised by the Ministry of Finance without mentioning whether a minimum period of stay abroad is required?

All in all, the rationale behind the forthcoming banning of franco valuta imports does not seem to be convincingly clear. There appears to be no good reason to take a measure with such far-reaching consequences on the simple pretext of controlling the foreign exchange black-market when most of the activities of this market are in fact poised to be legalized in the on going foreign exchange liberalization reforms. Tax-busting contraband imports could be controlled only through reducing customs taxation or through tightening border patrol. The same goes for contraband exports destined for financing contraband imports. On the other hand, some of the foreign exchange dealings on the black-market are ones that could be tolerated in view of the fact that the government's foreign exchange liberalization measures themselves are heading that way. At any rate, some of the major anticipated effects of the ban on franco valuta imports may be summarized as follows:

* A loss of a free flow of resources in the form of bona fide gifts and grants from abroad;

* The concentration of imports in the hands of a relatively few traders, limiting free competition and possibly raising prices;

* A shift in demand for foreign exchange from the black-market to the auction market, pushing upwards the birr/dollar rate on the latter market and downwards on the former;

* A net loss of government revenue from customs taxation as the shift from franco valuta to regular (LC) imports is not expected to compensate for the total loss on customs revenue on franco valuta imports;

* A rise in contraband imports, especially used clothes which cannot now be imported on both franco valuta and LC bases, contraband imports may increase as a result of possible, attractive import price rises which may be brought about by restricted availability in the wake of the ban on franco valuta imports and red-tape in the alternative LC channel;

Further, it is argued that it would be difficult for LC importers to present fake invoices, which are deliberately low-priced for taxation purposes, as has been the case with franco valuta importers, the reason being that if an importer produces a low-price invoice to evade full taxation, he would have to lower the amount of foreign exchange he bids for on the auction market, which may not cover the full cost of the goods to be imported. In other words, a low-price invoice to evade full taxation would automatically translate into a low foreign exchange entitlement on the auction market, which may not cover the full cost of the goods to be imported.

But what if the LC importer buys part of the foreign exchange on the auction market and part on the black market. Assume the true price of a second-hand car to be imported from some west European country is 3000 US dollars. Suppose an LC importer manages to produce a 1500-USD invoice and buys this amount of foreign exchange from the auction market and the remainder from the black market. Is he not going to be taxed on the basis of the 1500-USD invoice rather than on the basis of the true price of the car which is 3000-USD?

Well, it seems the effects of the ban on franco valuta imports do not look like they are going to be positive on balance. What we may get in return for the benefit of a proper registration and licensing of importers may be a lot more of the usual government red-tape, import price inflation and a rise in contraband imports besides a number of other negative effects.

Let us just hope that our predictions prove wrong! By the way, we are not talking here about something insignificant. Private sector franco valuta (FV) imports in 1994/95 amounted to well over 900 million birr. As would be expected, the major FV import goods are vehicles, vehicle spare parts, textiles including used clothes (which are difficult to so identify), electronic goods and machinery and equipment. Let us wait and see whether the LC system alone can deliver as much and as effectively without the parallel FV mechanism!

Issue cover date: August 2


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


148 of 455 DOCUMENTS

Ethiopia and Burundi;
Ethiopia Cuts Air Links With Burundi


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopia said it has cut air links with Burundi as part of sanctions imposed by leaders of East and central African countries on Major Paul Buyoya's government that seized power in a military coup last month.

A spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said the Ethiopian Airlines suspended flights to Bujumbura on Tuesday. 

The spokesman said Ethiopia along with other states will try hard to prevent from happening of carnage on the level of Rwandan genocide in Burundi and to restore peace in the central African country.

The East and Central African countries have imposed sanctions on Burundi at their recent meeting in Arusha, Tanzania in an attempt to restore that country's constitutional government ousted in a military coup.

Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda have so far imposed sanctions on Burundi.

149 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 10, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Ethiopia's Participation In The Olympic Games


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopia had won 16 medals in her 40 years participation in the Olympic games in addition to registering a number of records in various races. Following is the historical record in the Olympiads in chronological order.

The Ethiopian Olympic squad appeared in the Olympic arena for the first time in 1956 after flying for solid 16 days in a military aircraft to land in Melbourne but no victory was registered either in cycling or athletics competitions in which it took part. 

1960 - The legendary Abebe Bikila, bare-footed, broke the marathon record in Rome clocking 2hrs. 15 mts. and 16.2 seconds to win the first gold medal for Ethiopia and Africa.

1964 - Abebe Bikila broke his own record to finish the marathon race in 2 hrs. 12 mts and 11 seconds in Tokyo.

1968 - Abebe Bikila interrupted the race in Mexico after a muscular strain but Mamo Wolde took in his feet and won the gold medal in marathon there by embalming Ethiopia become the only country to win the Olympic marathon thrice in a row. Besides his victory in the marathon, Mamo won silver in the 10,000 meters race.

1972 - Mamo stood third in marathon in the Munich Olympics with the upcoming Mirutse Yifter clinching a bronze medal in 10,000 meters event.

1976 - Ethiopia boycotted the Montreal Olympic games along with African countries in protest against the participation of the apartheid South African regime.

1980 - Gear Shifter-Mirutse Yifter clinched gold medals in both the 10,000 and 5,000 meters competitions in Moscow. His teammates Mohammed Kedir and Eshetu Tura won bronze medals in 10,000 meters and 3,000 meters steeplechase respectively.

1984 - 1988 Ethiopia boycotted for political reasons the Los Angeles and Seoul Olympiads.

1992 - Derartu Tulu won a gold medal in the 10,000 event in Barcelona while Fita Bayisa and Addis Abebe snatched bronze medals in the 5,000 and 10,000 competitions respectively.

1996 - Fatuma Roba clocked 2:06:04 to win the first gold medal for Ethiopia and Africa in the marathon in the recently held Atlanta Olympics. Haile Gebreselassie, holder of four world records, has clinched gold medal in the Atlanta 10,000 meters event to add up another record to his victories. Gete Wami stood third in the women's 10,000 meters event.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

August 10, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Ethiopian Medalists Decorated With Military Ranks


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Federal Police and Prison Administration Commission

yesterday decorated the Atlanta Olympic good and bronze medalists with

military ranks, the Ethiopian Radio reported.

Accordingly, World and Olympic 10,000 meter record holder Captain Haile Gebre- Sellassie and the women's marathon gold medalist, Master Sergent Fatuma Roba were promoted to the rank of a Major. The radio said women's 10, 000 meter bronze medalist, corporal Gete Wami was promoted to the rank of Lieutenant.

The radio quoted the commission as saying that the appointment was made in recognition to their outstanding performance during the 26th Atlanta Olympiad.

Meanwhile, the Ethiopian athletics squad left Atlanta and arrived in Frankfurt, Germany on a transit flight for home.

According to the Ethiopian Radio sports reporter Demissie Damte, the athletes were accorded a hero's welcome by Ethiopians residing in Frankfurt and the employees of the Ethiopian Airlines.

Africa News


August 12, 1996


Mauritania;
Six Tons of Heroin Impounded In Mauritania


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania - Some 6,750 Kg (13,500 pounds) of heroin were seized Sunday morning at the Port of Nouakchott aboard a ship impounded by the navy. 

The ship was impounded after an alert from Interpol, the international police.

A navy spokesman refused to state the ship's exact destination but said it come from a European port and was headed for an African country.

Sources, however, said the ship could have been headed for the Gambia after several stops in Europe.

The vessel is German-owned but flies under the Dutch flag.

It was also carrying cargo destined for Mauritania.

Africa News


August 12, 1996


Zambia;
Zambian Treason Detainees Plead Not Guilty


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Eight Zambian opposition figures facing treason and murder charges Monday pleaded not guilty, when they appeared for plea in the Lusaka High Court.

They were appearing in court for the first time after they were committed to the higher court by a magistrate on July 15. Trial is expected to start this Thursday. 

The eight, all members of the United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former president Kenneth Kaunda, have been in detention since June 4, charged with two counts of treason and murder.

They include UNIP vice-president Inyambo Yeta, UNIP central committee member Rabison Chongo, Kaunda's press assistant, Muhabi Lungu and Kaunda's head of security, Moyce Kalung'ombe.

The four have also been charged with conspiring to procure, by force, the alteration of the new constitution of Zambia.

Others are retired army Generals Joseph Chintomfwa and Nicholas Zulu, Capt. Selemani Mpangulu and UNIP central committee member, Patrick Goma, who have also been charged with murder.

The four are alleged to have murdered Gordon Banda who died in a bomb blast at Lusaka international airport in May.

The eight have also been charged with writing offensive graffiti carrying messages against members of parliament and government leaders, in an effort to force government to withdraw the new constitution of Zambia. The constitution bars Kaunda from contesting the presidency because he had Malawian parents.

Defence lawyer, Daniel Lisulo, Monday submitted that both the defence and state lawyers had agreed that trial should begin Thursday.

Kaunda, who attended Monday's court session, later appealed to UNIP supporters and sympathizers to be calm and avoid confronting policemen deployed at the court.

He said it was not the fault of the police that they were carrying out " unlawful orders".

"I want to beg you not to be violent towards the police.

"...They are merely carrying out unlawful orders from the government," said Kaunda.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


153 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 12, 1996


Business;
Growing Concern About South African Economy


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Growing concern about South Africa's faltering economic situation has sparked off intensified pressure on the government to implement key elements of its new macro-economic strategy.

The authoritative Johannesburg Business Times reported Sunday that failure by the South African government to implement its macro-economic strategy has prompted economists to call on finance minister, Trevor Manuel, to end policy stagnation and boost investor sentiment.

Earlier last week, the department of Trade and Industry did announce a tax holiday package for investors. The report says however, that economists still insist that only a firm announcement on a timetable for lifting exchange controls, or for privatization, can stem recent large outflows of capital from South Africa. 

Market nervousness reached a peak on Thursday, with the South African Rand dropping to 4.53 to the U.S. dollar and 7.01 against the British pound. Currently the country's foreign reserves have dropped to 2.5 billion dollars, and it is running a current account deficit of close to 2.7 billion dollars.

It will take time, said Reserve Bank governor Chris Stals, to give foreign investors the confidence they need. "We are committed to phasing out the controls and must perhaps give further confirmation," he said. "We must certainly implement the economic strategy."

But the country's economists painted a bleaker picture, according to Business Times. Stals has his back against the wall, said one economist. "The Bank is trying to keep the currency at a certain level and there is no ammunition to do so."

Since South Africa's economic strategy was announced, there has been a noticeable absence of measures to implement it, says Sunday's report. Apart from relaxing exchange controls, investors are also looking for moves on the privatization front. But there is little evidence to suggest that sectoral task groups are anywhere near finalizing restructuring plans for parastatals.

Another cornerstone of the macro-economic plan -- fiscal stringency -- is proving difficult to implement. Central Statistical Service figures last week showed that employment by the South African government increased from 572,000 in December 1995 to 587,000 in March 1996.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 12, 1996


Uganda;
Ugandan Rebels Over 300 Killed in Two Weeks of Fighting


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda - At least 327 people, including government soldiers and rebels, have been killed in two-and-a-half weeks of fighting in the northern Ugandan district of Gulu.

The number includes 255 civilians, 40 Ugandan soldiers and 32 rebels, including two top commanders, according to casualty figures published in the local press between July 25 and August 10.

The commanders are Lt. Col. Beba Beba Alias Oola and Chief Signal Officer, Capt. Ojok of Joseph Kony's Lord's Resistance Army (LRA). About 37 people, including 23 students at a local college, were abducted over the same period. Some later escaped from captivity. 

The killings were probably aimed at enforcing rebels demands that people move at least eight kilometers (5 miles) away from all major roads.

They repeated the warning in two letters posted at Layibi Onang, eight kilometers south west of Gulu a week ago.

The rebels also gave civilians four days to join them and vacate Gulu town.

In the latest incident, 14 people were killed and 30 injured in two separate rebel ambushes on Friday. Two of the dead were killed when the rebels showered bullets on a Kampala bound bus at Bobi, 24 kilometers (15 miles) from the Gulu highway. On the same day, 12 people were killed when a vehicle they were travelling in hit a land mine at "For-God" village, west of Gulu town.

At Ongako trading center, along the Gulu-Pakwach road, LRA rebels also Friday killed six people and burnt scores of huts. The next day, they raided the villages of Labwoch and Payaya in Koro sub-county. They herded several civilians together before murdering 11 people, abducting five youths and burning 56 huts.

But the most horrendous killings occurred on July 22 when the rebels massacred 60 people in Parabongo, Pabo, and Palwong villages. They accused the civilians of reporting their presence to the state and selling their land mines to the Ugandan army. The government pays some 200 U.S. dollars to any civilian who hands in a land mine.

Witnesses say some of the victims were chopped to death with hoes, a method increasingly preferred by the rebels.

Last week, the rebels vowed to capture and kill all journalists, local and foreign, who report on the battles going on in the north. The rebels accused the journalists of telling lies about their operations and calling them killers.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Mauritania;
Mauritania in Rare Archeological Find


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 133 words


 

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania (Pana) - A piece of metal believed to date back to the era of the Ghana Kingdom in the 11th and 12th centuries has been unearthed at an archaeological site of Coumbi Saleh in Mauritania by a team of archaeologists from the Mauritanian Scientific Research Institute (IMRS).

The official Mauritanian news agency said the discovery was a rare metal of an exceptional quality.

The institute has been carrying out excavations and other research activity at sites in Hodh Charghi and Aoudaghost as part of a national programme for the conservation of ancient cities and archaeological sites.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 12, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi Women call for lifting of sanctions


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Some 20 Burundian women's associations and international humanitarian organizations on Sunday in Bujumbura, called for the immediate lifting of sanctions against Burundi.

The sanctions were decided on by the Arusha (northern Tanzania) summit of neighboring states on July 13, in an effort to return the country to legal rule following the July 25 coup led by former military leader, Maj. Pierre Buyoya. 

A statement issued by the associations described the sanctions as "a disturbing step taken against a country whose only wrong is to strive and try to solve its own problem."

Copies of the statement were sent to leaders of the region.

"The embargo will only worsen a situation which is already precarious by starving the poor and war-affected people to death," it said.

The embargo against Burundi was decided on by a summit of Ethiopia, Zaire, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda and Tanzania. Implementation was initiated by Tanzania on August 1. Other countries have followed suit.

The embargo includes the cancelling of air and land traffic and freight with neighboring countries.

Ethiopia;
Ethiopia's Offensive Against Terrorist Group


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopia says it successfully carried out "a limited counter-offensive" late last week against a "multi-national terrorist group" along its south-eastern border with Somalia.

A government statement released in Addis Ababa on Saturday, said the group, whose name it did not state, had been engaged in terrorist activity for some time. 

The foreign affairs ministry Friday said a contingent of Ethiopian defence forces was engaged in hot pursuit of the terrorist group.

It said the objective of the operation "was essentially aimed at destroying the base and sanctuaries" of the multi-national terrorist group.

The statement said the operation was concluded after achieving its objectives and that Ethiopian defence forces will continue to remain vigilant, "ready to take similar action in the future to ensure that the terrorist provocations are brought to an end and until the threats posed by the multi- national terrorist groups are fully removed from the area." The group was vaguely described as "dangerous" and "multi-national". The statement said its major "goal is to spread terror and to lead the sub-region into chaos..."

Ethiopia has in the past accused the separatist Al Itihad Moslem fundamentalist group that has over the past three years been involved in hit- and-run operations in the vast Ogaden area, of responsibility for the incursions.

Al Itihad has in the past claimed responsibility for bomb attacks on government hotels in Addis Ababa and the eastern city of Dire Dawa.

The group, in July, also claimed responsibility for the attempt on the life of a senior Ethiopian minister of Somali origin.

Africa News


August 12, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Zambian Runner Beats US Rival


BYLINE: Samson Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's Atlanta Olympics silver medalist Samuel Matete last Saturday pulled through in the 400m hurdles in Monaco, France to beat his greatest rival, United States' gold medalist Derrick Adkins.

Matete scored a time of 47. 83 seconds, a time worse than his Atlanta Olympics performance where he recorded 47.78 seconds. 

Dressed in yellow, with tag 84, Matete looked composed. At the crack of the gun he went on, slowly increasing his speed to the last hurdle.

Sensing defeat as the count increased, Adkins tried to double his speed but bashed his second last hurdle in the third lane while Matete crashed through the thin air in the fifth lane to victory.

Adkins could not dispute the outcome of the race. He was the first to congratulate his rival Matete.

Before the contest, while the commentators were announcing the names of the participants in the order of their lanes - Matete already had the face of the winner.

The two last met at the just ended Atlanta Olympics in which the American won the gold medal with a time of 47.54 seconds while the Zambian star managed second position at 47.78 seconds, settling for a historical silver medal for Zambia at the Olympics.

LANGUAGE: English

159 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 12, 1996


Zambia;
Law Group Condemns Constitution


BYLINE: Bright Mwape and Sipo Kapumba, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Lusaka - Ten key clauses of the amended Constitution of Zambia were on Saturday condemned by the Law Association of Zambia's (LAZ) Extra-ordinary General Meeting at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Centre as " discriminatory, contentious and unacceptable".

LAZ fell short of rejecting the entire recently amended Constitution and shut up lands minister Lumizu Shimaponda for attempting to talk fellow lawyers down.

According to resolutions released at the end of the meeting, Zambian lawyers by a vote of 38 to 19 declared ten clauses in the amended Constitution as "discriminatory, contentious and unacceptable".

The identification of the clauses came after one Lusaka lawyer advised the meeting against universal condemnation of the constitution because technically there was no new Constitution in Zambia. 

The lawyer argued that what has been floated was a Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Act which has altered the 1991 Constitution. And in the circumstances it is the amendments in it which should be isolated.

The condemned clauses include the preamble declaration of Zambia as a Christian nation which lawyers argued was discriminatory against other religions and violated the 1991 Constitution on freedom of conscience.

The citizenship and domicile clause was also dismissed as discriminatory, especially that they classify "citizens into categories of second and third generation".

And according to the lawyers, a presidential candidate should only be declared winner if he has votes amounting to over 50 per cent of the total votes cast as provided for in the 1991 Constitution and not any simple majority as article 34 (8) in the 1996 Constitution demands.

"It is inconceivable how a president who fails to marshall more than 50 per cent of valid votes cast can have legitimacy to govern," the resolution read.

Part (iii) of the Constitution (Bill of Rights), LAZ argues has been altered without a referendum as required by the 1991 Constitution. One alteration, the lawyers noted, was that giving individuals non hindrance "in the enjoyment of their right of assembly and association ... and in particular to form or belong to any political party, trade union or other association of his interest".

This right in part (iii), the lawyers said, has now been altered by article 129 in the 1996 Constitution which says "a person shall not while remaining a chief join or participate in partisan politics".

They say the clause that empowers Parliament to make laws retrospectively is dangerous and can be abused to settle vendettas and political scores and want the impeachment procedure for an incapable president to be less cumbersome.

The lawyers have also opposed the clause which says the law and custom of the Parliament of England shall apply to the Zambian Parliament because this clause "fails to recognise that while in England Parliament is supreme, in Zambia the Constitution is supreme as per article 1(3)".

"Laws cannot be imported into a country without due regard to our own constitutional peculiarities,'" LAZ says.

LAZ also wants a 75 per cent majority to be sufficient to waive the immunity of an ex-president before he can be prosecuted for any criminal offences and not the new demand of simple majority to "safeguard against possible political vendettas".

The lawyers want individuals right to bail restored and the protection of the judiciary from political attacks.

After a protracted debate these resolutions were adopted 38-19 but not after Shimaponda had been severely lashed at.

Shimaponda stirred trouble for himself when he told fellow lawyers they were wasting time debating the Constitution because his government would "not renege on its stand".

"The only way lawyers would change the Constitution is if MMD lost this year's elections " which it will unfortunately win," Shimaponda said.

But he was cut half way by a barrage of statements from irate lawyers who felt Shimaponda had no right to tell LAZ not to make a stand when his party and government had made one.

Shimaponda was advised by, among others Richard Mukelabai, Lucy Sichone and Daniel Lisulo, that LAZ was an independent organisation whose position cannot depend on that of the government.

The lawyers said they would take a stand whether or not government listens.

"It will be noted that LAZ took a stand," one lawyer said. "That it was government which did not listen not that no one advised."

By the time the meeting was closing Shimaponda and several government lawyers had walked out with a statement discrediting the LAZ meeting immediately following from President Frederick Chiluba's public relations and press assistant, Richard Sakala.

Sakala claimed the LAZ resolutions were political and "not driven by consensus but majority rule"


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 12, 1996


Zambia;
New Party Launched


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, Sipo Kapumba and Elias Kamanga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) president Ben Kapita and ruling MMD Mpika member of parliament, former agriculture minister, Guy Scott, have formed a political party known as the National Lima Party (NLP) which they co-chair.

The party which was registered two weeks ago was officially announced at a press briefing in Ndola yesterday attended by Scott but it will be based in Lusaka.

Kapita, in an interview yesterday, said he would resign his position as ZNFU president later this month.

Kapita said the party was formed to redress the problems facing Zambian agriculture which had remained undeveloped for a long time. 

"Our aim is it to bring the right people to the National Assembly so that the 100 rural constituencies can have a dominant agricultural voice," Kapita said. "Time has come for committed farmers, agricultural input suppliers and others interested in agriculture and who have good programmes to occupy rural constituencies ."

Kapita said he had been lobbying for agriculture for 20 years and now time had come for him to lobby from Parliament.

"I must do the second phase of agriculture lobby which means you must have someone doing something from inside," he said.

Kapita said his party would be a national one because it would also appeal to retrenchees and school drop outs whose only alternative for survival was agriculture.

"Our party is not restricted to farmers," Kapita said. "It emphasises sectors that create wealth and wealth creation comes from rural areas."

Kapita said he expected to get support from small, medium and large scale commercial farmers in addition to others who may want to join the party.

Kapita said his party would not field candidates in all the 150 constituencies, but only where it felt someone committed to agriculture was needed.

Kapita said Scott in his statement at the press conference said he was aware that he would be expelled from MMD for being associated with the formation of another party.

According to sources, Kapita and had initially entered into negotiations with Rodger Chongwe with intentions of joining the Liberal Progressive Front(LPF).

"I was first approached in April and then the last approach was made to our national secretary sometime last week. But then they have decided to form their own party," Chongwe said in an interview on Friday.

Kapita also admitted having approached LPF but declined to comment on the outcome of the negotiations.

"Our objective is not State House. There is only one position for President in Zambia. But of the 150 parliamentary seats 100 of them are rural constituencies and agriculture should have been well advanced in this country, which is not the case," Kapita said. "We are not carrying thieves with us like has always been but we are only fielding those people who have an interest of the people at heart."

He refuted reports that the NLP was being backed by the ZNFU.

"ZNFU is a non-partisan organisation which has nothing to do with the party. I have already informed the executive of my resignation since I have decided to be partisan," Kapita said.

Scott also announced at a press briefing at Kapita's farm in Ndola yesterday that he had resigned from the ruling MMD.

"I have automatically resigned from MMD. I have failed to realise my dream in the MMD because most of my colleagues have their own priorities and interests," Scott said.

Scott said the party's priority would be "to empower and address the suffering of the rural population".

Kapita, however, indicated that the NLP would enter into alliances with other political parties with the same interests.

Lusaka Province MMD chairman, Christopher Chawinga, said in an interview that he was not surprised about Kapita's move since he has always been critical of government.

"Just because he has been president of the farmers union does not mean he can be Zambia's president," Chawinga said. "The party is a non-starter."

And on Scott's involvement he said it was not surprising either.

"We have always known Scott, that is why he was suspended from MMD for three months some time ago," he said. "Don't forget he was fired from his ministerial post by the President for reasons some of us know but which we can't reveal."


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 12, 1996


Zambia;
The Diary: Peace Based On Injustice


BYLINE: Fred M'membe, Column, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Lusaka - On Saturday some Copperbelt representatives of the country's major political parties were organised by the Committee for Clean Campaign(CCC) to hold the Holy Bible and pledge to promote peace and social justice during the campaign.

Symbolically, it was a good demonstration of political will in the quest for peaceful politics. Beyond being symbolic I don't think there was much in the CCC peace act or show.

I think we need to be candid with each other, in order to rectify an unjust political set up that threaten not only the democratic process in this country but peace itself. 

We must deal with the causes the real issues that threaten peace in this country, rather than do damage control.

We need vision, courage, determination and the political will to change the course of events.

When the CCC and others 'concerned' about political instability in the country it is usually as if this emerged from a vacuum. There is a context.

What we need is the vision to deal with the causes in ways that would transform the realities on the ground rather than mere verbal exercises - with Bibles in hand.

The only way to remove political threats to peace in this country is through a just constitution and a credible a electoral process -- that addresses causes of political instability.

Zambia's march to political instability began with signing of the Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Bill on May 28, 1996 by President Frederick Chiluba. The Bill was opposed by all major political parties and NGOs, including the country's donors, with support only coming from the ruling MMD.

Peace is no accident of history. It is a systematic and deliberate process, which requires the vision of architects, the mastery of craftsmen and the patience of wise men and women. In the words of a famous philosopher: "It takes men to make war, but great men to make peace."

The biggest threat to peace in Zambia today the unjust constitutional, and clearly fraudulent Nikuv electoral, arrangements. These fraudulent arrangements cannot be tolerated, accepted or justified.

President Chiluba, the sponsor of these arrangements, and his supporters must be shown how humanity deals with inhumanity. Peace is something we not only preach and practice, but also protect. Peace cannot built on injustice as President Chiluba is deceptively trying to do. Peace means building a society in which democracy, freedom of expression and the pursuit of happiness are available to all without discrimination.

Peddling costly lies

It seems State House officials, like President Chiluba, have seriously problems telling the truth.

On Wednesday deputy minister in the Office of the President, Lusaka lawyer Eric Silwamba, representing President Chiluba's press aide, Richard Sakala, in a contempt of court case, told magistrate Brian Simango that his client could not attend court because he was in South Africa for a medical review.

But Sakala had on Monday told Post journalist Masautso Phiri, in a telephone interview from Johannesburg's Carlton Hotel that he was in the country on his "own business".

And Tuesday Sakala told South African journalists that he was in their country to try and correct their misconceptions about Zambia that have created by the "gutter" press.

What is the truth?

Did Silwamba lie to the court? Can he honestly claim ignorance about the real mission of Sakala that made him miss court?

Well, Sakala's lie is established, what remains is who paid for trip. Anyway I don't think even that is a big problem considering President Chiluba's deep pockets -- on Friday my good friend Evaristo Mutale, the President's aide, was sent to withdraw K35 million from the 'oldman's' Long Acres bank account.

These may appear to be 'small' lies but spoke volumes about the credibility of the presidency.

I was, however, delighted that Sakala had the opportunity to see for himself how almost impossible it is to sell lies abroad. Despite high expenditure on public relations consultants, Sakala failed miserably to convince any section of the South African press about 'correctness' of the Zambian Constitution and the government's lack of seriously commitment to press freedom.

Business Day, in an editorial comment on Thursday, correctly summed up Sakala's futile efforts.

'Zambia should know better than to try to sell a flawed constitution in a country whose previous government spent most of this century extolling the democratic virtues of patently undemocratic arrangements.

As South Africans know only too well, glib explanations do not change the facts.

President Frederick Chiluba has sent a senior emissary here to persuade the South African public that Zambia is a model democracy. Chiluba would have us believe that constitutional amendments which bar former president Kenneth Kaunda from standing in the October elections were not aimed at Kaunda and anyway are the wish of the Zambian people; he tries to tell us that Western donors who suspended aid to Zambia do not understand the situation.

Many countries, likes Zambia now, limit presidents to two consecutive terms, but hardly any prevent a two term president from standing again. Many countries require their presidents to be born in the country, but few require their parents to be born there too. It is these restrictions which will keep Kaunda out of the October elections, asking the world to believe this is not the intention mimics the honeyed deceptions of apartheid's propagandists.

If Zambians hate Kaunda, as well they might given his autocratic excesses, then they will not vote for him.

If Chiluba is the democrat and civil rights reformer he started as, he will let Kaunda stand and stop bullying local newspapers. If he is no better than his predecessor, a charm offensive will change nothing.'

Angel Chiluba

The MMD government has problems admitting mistakes.

I don't believe there is anyone looking for government of angels that makes nor errors of judgment.

The government has made many mistakes -- some of them fundamental. The declaration of a state of emergency in 1993, the handling of the Gabon Zambia Air Force plane crash in which the country's national soccer squad perished, amendments to the country's constitution, the detention of eight opposition UNIP leaders and members on stupid and fake treason charges, the Nikuv Computers Limited contract to update the voters' register.

All humans make mistakes, but they to be corrected.

But this government never wants to accept mistakes and let alone correct them.

This places a very high responsibility on citizens to pressurise the government to correct mistakes. But some citizens, especially those who are in one way or another directly benefitting from President Chiluba's corrupt regime, behave as if the country is being governed by angels.

We have no angels in government -- we have sinful, selfish, greedy and corrupt little men and women. They need to be constantly checked and corrected. Zambia knows no single genius -- there can only be a collective genius.

Let's, therefore, put pressure on our government to 'correct' the constitution, the electoral process and to release the Gabon report.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 12, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia's Image Abroad Dented


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - The international community's perception of Zambia is very negative because its image has been heavily dented, disclosed President Frederick Chiluba's public relations and press assistant, Richard Sakala, at a State House press briefing yesterday.

Sakala said that the country's image abroad was negative and worrying and called upon Zambians to sell their country positively. 

Sakala said the task of correcting Zambia's image abroad was not only for the people in public relations but for all citizens.

"Every Zambian should sell our country positively abroad and not leave this job to us people in the public relations and information sector alone, as a country we have a duty to correct the situation," Sakala appealed.

Sakala, who recently returned from South Africa where he went to "portray a correct picture" of Zambia told journalists that it was their duty to inform the international community that there was no crisis or anarchy in the country.

"It is our task to tell the world that there is no crisis in this country and that there is also no anarchy as has been portrayed so far," Sakala said.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 13, 1996


Kenya;
Kenya Agriculture Threatened by Dumping


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenyan grain farmers have experienced big income losses since 1994 because of dumping, a study has revealed.

The sugar industry has also declined because of destructive price competition with imported sugar. 

The study, by Germany's Bread for the World Organization, says the grain losses are attributed to competition by subsidized wheat from the European Union and maize imports from the United States and South Africa.

The looming sugar decline is due to the years-long competition from sugar imports from the European Union and Brazil.

The study, titled "The negative effects of EU subsidized agricultural exports on the agriculture and food security in Kenya and Ethiopia," also attributes the crises to mismanagement, among other factors.

It says the losses to Kenya maize farmers amounted to an estimated 439 million U.S. dollars in 1994/95.

The fall in income reduces the farmers chances of buying production inputs and making the necessary operational investment for the coming farming season, the report adds.

Meanwhile, the Kenya National Union of Farmers has said that the country will face a maize deficit before the November harvest due to bad weather, high cost of inputs and loss of guaranteed markets and prices.

The Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) representative in Kenya, Harold Norton, recently said Kenya needs to increase its food production by 75 percent over the next 30 years.

The annual national maize consumption of three million tons is expected to increase by four percent.

If market liberalization continues and the food markets are further swamped with dumping imports, and no counter-measures or support are forthcoming from the government, Kenya's already marginalized agricultural households can only be expected to become yet more impoverished, the study further notes.

It adds that food insecurity will increase in many areas of Kenya.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 13, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Academics To Assess New Information Highway


BYLINE: Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - How to help poor countries reap the benefits of the phenomenal expansion in global communication will be one of the issues to be discussed at the upcoming Executive Board Meeting of UNESCO, its president, Prof. Nureini Tidjani-Serpos, has said.

Issues surrounding the 'New Information Super highway' will dominate the 'Intellectual Forum' which is being institutionalized at the periodical meeting at the organization's Paris headquarters in October, Tidjani-Serpos told PANA in an interview in Dakar.

"Intellectuals from across the globe will be expected to give their views on the importance and use of new information technologies during the Paris meeting," he said. 

Participants at the Forum, which will include top communication experts, will also examine how small and poor countries can be helped to gain full access to modern global communication.

They will also discuss content and ethics --- how to protect young people from exposure to violence and pornography on Internet.

Tidjani-Serpos, 50, arrived in the Senegalese capital on Sunday.

He is touring UNESCO bureaux and offices in West Africa to discuss ongoing decentralization activities with officials. He has already held talks with President Abdou Diouf and senior government officials and staff at the UNESCO Bureau for Education in Africa (BREDA), one of the organization's 58 major representations worldwide.

He will also visit Cote d'Ivoire, Benin, Togo and Nigeria during the four- day tour.

Decentralization is top most on the agenda launched by Director-General Federico Mayor soon after he assumed office in 1987.

"The ultimate goal is to bring the civil society to take charge of a wide rage of issues which touch on their daily lives," Tidjani-Serpos said.

UNESCO's role as an advocate for peace, he said, has even become more relevant in the unipolar world as wars, ethnic cleansing, terrorism, marginalization and other forms of social strife continue to wreak havoc on humanity.

Tidjani-Serpos, a Beninese national, was elected president of the 58-nation executive board, the second highest decision-making body of UNESCO, at its general conference in November 1995.

He previously held the chair of Francophone African Literature at the University of Benin, Benin-City in Nigeria from 1980 to 1988 and at the National University of Benin, in Cotonou.

He was later appointed ambassador and head of his country's delegation to UNESCO in Paris.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 13, 1996


United States and Africa;
Rawlings,Discusses Liberia Conflict with U.S. Official


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Accra, Ghana - President Jerry Rawlings has held discussions here with Howard Jeter, a special envoy of U.S. President Bill Clinton to Liberia.

Foreign Ministry sources said discussions on Monday centered on the conflict in Liberia which is in its seventh year and has claimed more than 150,000 lives. 

Several peace agreements have been signed by the warring factions, the latest being the Abuja Peace Accord of August, 1995, under which a Council of State was installed in Monrovia.

The accord spelled out disarmament, encampment of fighters and elections in September 1996 as key goals. Brutal fighting, however, erupted in April and threw the accord out of gear.

The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), now under the chairmanship of Nigeria, is making fresh attempts to rekindle the Liberian peace process.

The sources said Jeter briefed Rawlings, immediate past chairman of the 16- member sub-regional economic grouping, on efforts the U.S. is making to achieve peace in Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 13, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi in Fuel Rationing


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Burundi's new military regime has announced fuel rationing starting Tuesday, 10 days after economic sanctions imposed by neighboring Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, Tanzania and Zaire.

To implement the rationing, fuel coupons were being distributed at the Bujumbura Football Stadium in the city center.

An initial rush by motorists eased off as the day wore on. 

Private cars are being allowed 20 liters (5.2 gallons), minibuses 40 liters ( 10.4 gallons) jeeps 30 liters (7.8 gallons), trucks 400 liters (104 gallons) , trailers 600 liters (156 gallons) and motorbikes six liters (1.56 gallons) per month.

According to Nicodeme Nimenya, director general at the internal trade ministry, the rationing operation is aimed at stretching available fuel supplies for as long as possible.

Sources at the ministry said if the rationing is strictly implemented, current stocks should last over five months.

However, most motorists see the government measure as a "polite invitation" for citizens to walk.

Others said that the 10 liters (2.6 gallons) allowed taxis cabs would only prevent their tanks from gathering rust.

The new ruler, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, came back to power for a second time through a military coup that toppled the democratically-elected government of President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya on July 25.

The coup sparked off an embargo imposed by neighboring countries to force the new junta to restore democracy in the country.

Burundi is now isolated from the rest of the world. Its air, land and water links have been cut. The Belgian airline, SABENA, which still maintains flights to the country will wind up soon.

Meanwhile, the Executive Director of the World Food Programme (WFP), Catherine Bertini, has welcomed Tanzania's decision to allow humanitarian aid deliveries to reach Burundi.

"We hope the same spirit of cooperation will prevail among the other countries of the region to ensure that humanitarian relief operations are not derailed as a result of sanctions," Ms. Bertini is quoted as saying in a press release received by PANA in Dakar.

She praised the Tanzanian government for demonstrating a spirit of cooperation and respect for humanitarian aid.

The UN food agency estimated that 300,000 people in Burundi depended on its relief efforts.

It said over one month of food supplies remained inside Burundi. However, WFP officials said the fuel situation was even more critical.

Currently, about 2,000 tons of WFP humanitarian aid have been blocked at Kigoma port, on the shore of Lake Tanganyika. This aid was destined for refugee camps in eastern Zaire, as well as refugees and the internally displaced in Burundi. An additional 3,000 tons of WFP aid were delayed in Dar es Salaam and Isaka, a depot township on the Tabora-Mwanza railway.

Tanzania's decision means that some WFP humanitarian aid can begin moving almost immediately. Under contingency plans, WFP pre-positioned six trucks of aid at Isaka, about 350 kilometers (219 miles) from the border with Burundi. They are not expected to enter Burundi until Tuesday afternoon. INL002 from SSS.069 (960813-17:19) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG068G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA(2) WFP however, expressed concern over the decision by the Government of Kenya not to allow WFP to fly its King Air passenger aircraft to and from Burundi.

Africa News


August 13, 1996


Angola;
Angola Deports Illegal Immigrants


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUANDA, Angola - A total of 223 Malians, 83 Senegalese and 43 Lebanese were deported Monday from Angola to their countries, for "illegal immigration" or " illegal business activities."

Those deported were ferried on a national carrier, 'TAAG', plane chartered for the purpose. The plane, which took off from Luanda, was to make its first stop in the Malian capital Bamako, before continuing to Dakar, Senegal.

The Lebanese were, however, put on board a 'SABENA' flight bound for Brussels, Belgium, from where they were expected to connect to Lebanon.

One of the Malians resisted the forced deportation because, he said, he wanted to travel with his Angolan wife and son.

Angola's immigration director, Carlos Burity da Silva, said the Malian's wife would not be prevented from joining her husband in future if she wanted to.

The operation, code-named 'Cancer II', was launched last week by police in Luanda. It led to the arrest of 748 illegal immigrants from 28 countries in the Angolan capital.

It will be extended to other provinces.

Carlos Burity said those deported had violated Angola's immigration laws.

He said measures were also being carried out to guard against their re- entry into the country.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 13, 1996


Sudan;
Sudanese Floods Destroy over 300 Houses


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Floods have destroyed some 326 houses and left thousands homeless in Sudan's Kitaina province, some 60 kms (38 Miles) south of Khartoum, following two days of heavy rain at the weekend.

The official daily 'Al Sudan Al Hadeith' (Modern Sudan) said the floods, which devastated nine villages, also destroyed schools, government buildings, medical centers and water pumping stations. A large number of livestock was also killed.

The Sudanese government has appealed to the international community for food and medical assistance to the affected people.

The deputy commissioner for humanitarian assistance, Fatih Al Rahman Al Gadi, was quoted by the daily as calling on NGOs and the United Nations agencies to provide emergency relief assistance to the needy.

Food, medicines, tents and tarpaulins are reported to be in short supply in the area.

The paper said relief workers had been sent to the area to assess the damage and emergency needs. It said further threats of flooding were looming as the level of the river Nile has been rising continuously.

The UN Security Council is currently considering sanctions against Khartoum which accused of sponsoring terrorism.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 13, 1996


Zambia;
Zambian Grave Robbers Sent to Prison


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - A Zambian court in the northern copper belt town of Ndola Monday sentenced three grave robbers to two years in prison, with hard labor, after they had admitted to exhuming bodies and stealing bedding and clothing from the dead at the town's cemeteries.

The trio were in addition fined 100,000 kwacha (100 U.S. dollars) each for the offence which the prosecution recorded as "trespass" on the cemeteries. This is classified as a "misdemeanor" under Zambian laws. 

The men, arrested last week, were said to have confessed to the police that they robbed more than 10 graves and stole bedding and clothing which they later sold as second-hand clothing, popularly known as "salaula."

Police recovered some of the items from the suspects and members of the public who voluntarily surrendered them in disgust.

Ndola principal resident magistrate, Roydah Kaoma, who sentenced the trio, said that their action was "repulsive" and that they did not deserve leniency from the courts.

"We all want our beloved deceased relatives to lie in peace. I do not feel that you deserve any pity from the court," she told the convicts, who were reported to be wearing some of the clothes stolen from the graves.

Meanwhile, trading in second-hand has slumped as news of the incident spread across the county.

"Yes, business has been tough since last week...many customers have been turning a blind eye to our wares...and have instead started teasing us of being "grave-robbers," said 24-year-old Evaristo Mwape.

Mwape, whose Salaula stall at the city center market boasts of some of the " latest" fashions in ladies and mens' wear, said that he had only sold one dress since last Tuesday to "an old lady" who, he said, appeared not to have heard the story.

Several salaula vendors who previously made up to 100,000 kwacha (about 100 U.S.dollars) on average per week from sales of the items, said Tuesday that this had dropped drastically in the wake of current "ghostly gossip" among potential customers about their merchandise.

Certain people in Ndola last week surrendered stacks of salaula clothing and bedding to the police after three men, who have since been jailed, confessed that they plundered local cemeteries for salaula for sale.

Their wares included men's, women's and children's clothing, bedding and other valuables "grabbed" from corpses.

Police found more than 26 pairs of mens' underwear on the suspects who said that they had kept them for their own use. According to them, not many people were interested in buying used underwear.

Zambia has a roaring business in old clothing from Europe, Asia, the Americas, some of which are sold in neighboring Zaire.

Zambian textile manufacturers have since been demanding that government impose a levy on salaula to protect their business which they say has been adversely affected by the more popular and cheaper old clothing from abroad.

Neighboring Zimbabwe taxes second-hand wares from Zambian traders who are said to be doing good business, mainly in that country's capital, Harare.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


170 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 13, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia Transformed Into A Zaire


BYLINE: Masautso Phiri, Column, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Lusaka - My Dear Readers,

Owen Sichone, writing out of South Africa, has talked about the Zaireanisation of Zambia. This charge is of serious concern for a country that was developed on the British system of government. Its deterioration came into focus recently during the Mushota tribunal. The tribunal proceedings brought out the conflict between civil servants and politicians.

To support Sichone's assertion, there is a big difference in the manner Northern Rhodesia and Belgian Congo developed during the colonial period. In Northern Rhodesia a proper civil service was developed which despite the changes over the years has continued until now. 

The system has entailed the development of controls on how public funds are handled under well defined government financial regulations. Simply, parliament votes funds for ministries and permanent secretaries are the controlling officers and not ministers

But in Zaire to retain power in perpetuity, President Mobutu Sese Seko has made himself chief pay master and chief banker of the country. Mobutu decides what denomination to issue, how many and who keeps the money. He also decides when to pay, who and how much. In turn when his functionaries receive the money from the chief paymaster they too have to decide who and when to pay. This process filters down to all other functionaries across the line - army commanders, heads of diplomatic missions, regional governors, every one plays his role in handling government funds. In Zaire it is normal for a boss to treat government funds as his own until he decides to whom and how much he should pay. Thus it is not surprising for civil servants in Zaire to be unpaid for several months. That is normal practice.

When President Chiluba came to power in 1991 his politics towards Zaire were rather confused. Perhaps he was merely being careful. A meeting between Chiluba and Mobutu at Gbadolite changed that and from then he began emulating his new mentor, the Zairean dictator on how to survive donor pressure. Thus Chiluba has learnt to transform himself from a poor trade unionist to a rich paymaster, controlling the purse of the country.

It is not surprising therefore that the President's role in the Third Republic has grown as chief banker and paymaster with the approach of this year's elections. Suddenly Zambians have to look to Chiluba for money. The president has taken the role of deciding and approving projects and their budgets. Now President Chiluba through his gifts decides what is good for the electorate. Thus to keep this image the President has travelled across the country giving gifts of K20m here, K30m there, inspecting this school or that community for a bridge or hospital building and in his benevolence he dreams the amounts. Hence like his Zairean brother Chiluba has changed the presidency and transformed it into the main budgetary control centre. Somehow, Chiluba is effectively the chief paymaster and the banker.

I am aware, for instance, the President now keeps billions of Kwacha and several millions in various currencies within his State House central bank. Unfortunately, Bank of Zambia governor Jacob Mwanza is aware of this fact but he is powerless despite the fact that it is a violation of the country's laws.

There is no doubt the Zairenisation of Zambia starts with the control of government funds and that President Chiluba is at the centre of it. His ministers, Mushota included have been trying to emulate their master. But to keep donor confidence, they have maintained laws relating to financial regulations though they are continuously violating them. For instance early in the MMD term MPs were benefiaries of this approach to government funds.

It is for the sake of the Zaireanisation process that during his first visit to Arakan Barracks after being appointed minister of defence, Ben Mwila told officers to make money because their salaries were inadequate. The officers have taken him on his word and gone to town to make money from the institution they are serving. They and their wives have become the chief suppliers to the defence force. I chuckled the other day when I saw a news item in the government owned Zambia Daily Mail announcing a donation of K4m by wife of airforce commander Ronnie Shikapwasha to wives of officers based in Mbala. I chuckled not only because there is no constitutional basis for her benevolence but because by the simple logic - where can an ordinary officer's wife get that kind of money other than the fact that the whole defence structure has become rotten.

Thus rather than ending, the Zaireanisation process of Zambia is on track. And like all processes it feeds on itself. We will see more donations from the "father" of the nation - the chief banker and paymaster - President Frederick Titus Jacob Chiluba.

I love you all, Masautso

Issue Date: August 7, 1996


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 13, 1996


Zambia;
Party Chief Calls For Voter Register Corrections


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Chipata - National Party President Humphrey Mulemba says the ruling MMD government should urgently rectify mistakes in the current voters registers to help prevent a national crisis.

Mr Mulemba said government should treat this matter with the urgency it deserved because it would risk retarding the development of Zambia's new and fragile democracy. 

He told ZANA in Chipata today that the anomalies that had been found in the registers would make some people not to cast their votes in the forthcoming parliamentary and presidential elections if government did not take action to address them.

''There is a crisis in this country in regard to the verification of voters registers and many concerned stakeholders in the election process are still guessing what will happen next if government did not rectify the anomalies,'' he said.

Mr Mulemba also advised government to respond favourably to opposition demands that were tabled before it during the inter-party talks to create an enabling environment during the the forthcoming general elections.

He said the new constitutional ammendment bill was hazy and discriminatory and for that reason government should sort out its differences with the opposition political parties, churches and non-governmental organisations to ensure a fair and free elections this year.

Above all, he urged the government to create an independent electoral commission because the current one was not free as it was operating at the whims of the ruling party.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

Africa News


August 13, 1996


Business;
Border Delays Hamper Travel


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwodela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - Local travel agents last Friday expressed displeasure at the lengthy border formalities between Zambia and Zimbabwe.

"Most of our clients end up missing their connecting flights simply because of being made to queue up endlessly," carped a Lubi Travel representative. " There must be provisions made by the Zimbabwe customs officials for connecting passengers so as to serve the interests of both parties."

The agents made their views known at a trade promotional event hosted by Carribean Bay Hotel at Intercontinental Hotel. Carribea is situated in the Zimbabwean border town of Kariba.

Sales manager of the Carribea, Lionel Sivule, assured the Zambian agents that the region was working towards smoothening border relations and Zimbabwe would not be left behind.

"It would not serve both the interests of Zambia and Zimbabwe if border procedures were left as they are," Sivule said. "I am sure the authorities are working on it."

And Zimbabwe High Commissioner to Zambia, Tirivafi Kangai, dismissed claims that they were taking eight days to clear visas for Asian tourists.

"The most we take is three days. We understand that whereas before, the region's emphasis was on politics, on apartheid, it is now on investment and trade," High Commissioner Kangai said. " We do not desire to jeopardise any investment opportunities."

The Zambian travel agencies had complained of loss of business because some tourist parties had changed their minds after waiting an inordinate amount of time for their visas. They also complained of the Zimbabweans' slow response to customer demands from the Zambian side.

The event was attended by about seven travel agencies from Lusaka and Ndola.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 13, 1996


Business;
$12 Million Needed For Grain Silos in Zambia


BYLINE: Cecilia Banda, Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - Government needs about 12 million United States dollars to rehabilitate the six major national silos if it is to store all of this year's bumber grain harvest.

Agriculture, Food and Fisheries permanent secretary, Dr Austin Sichinga said today a feasibility study on the exercise has already been done by a German consulting firm. 

Dr Sichinga said government is still waiting for a response from the German government on when the repair works will commnence.

The German government had insisted on a food reserve agency to be put in place before the rehabilitation exercise is started.

Dr Sichinga said his ministry has fulfilled the condition and that the agency is already in place but the Germans have not responded yet.

He said two of the silos are however beyond repair and will not be part of the rehabilitation exercise.

The six silos are situated in Kitwe, Kabwe, Lusaka, Choma and Monze.

Dr Sichinga also revealed that the 350 small storage bins have already been rehabilitated and let-out to the private sector.

The storage capacity of the small bins is estimated at 55,000 metric tons.

August 13, 1996


Business;
Southern African Trade Talks Stall


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Trade talks between Zambian and Zimbabwean manufacturers and exporters have stalled.

Matters came to a standstill after the Zambia Association of Manufacturers (ZAM) disagreed with the Zimbabwean proposals. 

"The main issue we have to agree on is the duty structure," ZAM chairman Mark O'Donnell disclosed in an interview yesterday.

"We want to see equity. The first draft of the agreement was too favourable to Zimbabwe."

Apparently, the Zimbabwean market had been protected with slightly higher import tariffs.

O'Donnell said a meeting between the Zambian commerce ministry officials and the members of ZAM agreed that some points had to be modified.

ZAM, however, hopes that the government will not make other alterations in the nation's economic policies to upset the imminent agreement with Zimbabwe.

According to O'Donnell, the 1997 budget and tariff structures must be carefully constructed to fully protect the Zambian producer.

"I will be very surprised if this government causes more damage to industry, " O'Donnell said. "The last thing we need is for the government to go back on its word."

But acting permanent secretary in the Ministry of Commerce, Oliver Sikufweba, said the onus was now on the Zambian manufacturers to organise themselves.

"The problem lies with our manufacturers here to work out the structures they want," Sikufweba said in an interview yesterday.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 13, 1996


Business;
Prioritise Tobacco, Zambian Government Urged


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The government has been urged to prioritise tobacco production in its crop diversification programme.

Tobacco Association of Zambia (TAZ) executive director, Graham Wallace, in an interview yesterday said it was among the most profitable crops and has a high potential as a foreign exchange earner. 

And Wallace advised local farmers to venture into tobacco production if the agro sector was to be a major foreign exchange earner as was the case in Zimbabwe and Malawi.

"Generally they talk about food security and once this is satisfied, as is the case, the government should also start prioritising high income earning cash crops like tobacco," Wallace said.

Wallace disclosed that research carried out by his organisation had placed Zambia as having better conditions for tobacco farming compared to other countries in the region, such as Zimbabwe and Malawi, which had been raking in over US$600 million and US$200 million in annual tobacco exports respectively.

"We have great potential, imagine Malawi gets 70 per cent of its foreign exchange earnings from tobacco and has nearly the same population as Zambia," Wallace said. " We are at an advantage in that our climatic conditions here are better than the other countries' for tobacco production."

And with the current meagre 160 farmers registered under TAZ, Zambia expects to raise over US$10 million in tobacco exports this year.

Tobacco, compared to maize production, has however enjoyed vast assistance from TAZ through extension facilities to farmers, credit facilities and sound marketing which is entirely handled by the association on behalf of the farmers.

Wallace's sentiments follow ZNFU executive director, George Gray's, calls on farmers last week to venture into other crops as the prices for maize had continued to drop.
