Sports - Soccer;
France And Portugal Reject Zambian Soccer Invitation


BYLINE: Celani Shongwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - France and Portugal have turned down a Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) request for preparatory international games against the national team.

According to FAZ acting general secretary, Julio Chiluba, France could not accommodate the friendly game against Zambia because of their busy schedule this year while Portugal were said to be overhauling their coaching staff and team. 

However, Chiluba announced that the soccer body had now set their eyes on Estonia and Kenya to help the squad prepare for the World Cup.

"Because of the negative responses from France and Portugal, we have invited Kenya for a friendly match. We have also received a request from Estonia, if we finalise the deal with the two countries the games would be played at Independence Stadium," Chiluba said.

He added: "I can safely say that a lot of ground has been covered in as far as the game against Estonia is concerned, we have set a tentative date for the friendly but I will announce it later."

The acting FAZ chief also said his association was waiting for China to respond to their proposal. He assured the nation that the squad will play some friendly matches before the 1998 Africa Cup opener against Mozambique in October.

Meanwhile Chiluba has announced that the senior national team will go into camp next Monday at a venue to be announced before the end of the week.

Sports - General;
Zambians Hoopsters Invited To Tour Malawi


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Basketball Association (ZBA) has been invited by Malawi for a five-match tour that will start on August 23.

According to ZBA general secretary, Mwemba Kaona, the all expenses-paid invitation to tour Malawi was faxed to Zambia by that country's national coach, Adolf Onions, who is keen to have a feel of the Zambian style of basketball. 

The Zambians will have to play the African Bible College squad on August 23, in the Malawian captial of Lilongwe and clash with a full strength Malawi national team the following day before taking a trip to the remote town of Zomba for a tie against a select University side on August 27.

On August 27, the Zambian squad will play The Falcons in the commercial capital of Blantyre, where the second match against the Malawi national side will also be played, with the last match, pitting the two national teams set for Lilongwe again.

And veteran basketball player Mateyo Nkana of Premium Hawks is among the 19 players that have been picked for the Malawi trip while the women's team is yet to be selected.

Others are Joel Chibanga, Sam Kalenga, Alex Makai and Mwamba Ngandwe (Heroes), Juba Banda, Lombe Chitambala, Kadipa Kasapatu, Mashekwa Mundia and Nkana (Premium Hawks), Jerry Nkandu (Green Buffaloes), Levi Ngulube and Sydney Maki (Pioneers).

And joining the provisional side from the Copperbelt are Fabby Basili, Cornell Kandala (Premium Baskets), Malama Mwansa (Nchanga Haulpacks) and Vernon Siputuma (Celtics).

Sports - General;
Zambian Government Adopts New Sports Strategy


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - Government has pledged it's committment to provide resources so as to tap sports talent in young people throughout the country.

Permanent Secretary - Ministry of Youth, Sport and Child Development - Arthur Yoyo, made the pledge when he toured the Chawama sport for all sector today. 

Yoyo admitted that there is a lot of potential in the Zambian youth but lack of resources hinders their progress.

He said apart from providing resources government would ensure that skilled adminstrators are employed to drill the young people in various sports discplines.

Yoyo also disclosed that the upcoming "vision 2000'' sport for all conference shows government's committment to the development of sport in the country.

The conference which opens in Lusaka on Friday aims at identifying the best strategies in involving the comminities in planning and executing community sports activities, without looking for sustenance from the outside community.

Yoyo said the hosting of the conference responds to the MMD's 1996 manifesto which entails that sports would be developed by the year 2000.

Africa News


August 13, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Football Association To Assist New Coaches


BYLINE: Celani Shongwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has made a commitment to offer its undivided assistance to the new national squad coaches in order for them to execute their duties effectively.

FAZ acting secretary general, Julio Chiluba said they want the country to maintain its status of being one of the leading countries in Africa. 

Chiluba said this before releasing the names of the coaches who will lead the country's three squads in their forthcoming international games.

At a press conference held at his office yesterday, Chiluba said the Under 17 team will be under the tutelage of Fighton Simukonda as head coach while his assistants are Keagan Mumba and Frederick Kashimoto.

Their first assignment will be against Nambia on the 25th of this month.

Lusaka Dynamos coach, Patrick Phiri has been appointed head-coach for the Under 20 squad. His assistants are Lewis Shambulo and Wezlie Mondi.

Chiluba said senior squad coach, Roald Poulsen would be assisted by Ashios Melu and Konkola Blades German trained coach, Benjamin Bwalya.

"Part of the appointments especially in the junior squads were based on the results of the FIFA course held recently. The coaches who have been appointed to these positions scored high marks," Chiluba clarified.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


180 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 14, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe Sells Tobacco Worth 400 Million Dollars


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe- Flue-cured tobacco worth about 400 million U.S. dollars has been sold at Harare's auction floors since sales started April 23 this year.

According to statistics from the Tobacco Marketing Board, more than 136 million kg (299 pounds) of tobacco had been sold during the period. 

A spokesman for the board told the Zimbabwe News Agency (ZIANA) that the market for the crop was firm, with no signs to suggest that deliveries were tailing off.

"Up to the end of trading on Tuesday, more than 136.3 kilograms of tobacco had been traded at the floors at an average price of 28.52 zd (2.85 U.S. dollars)" per kilo, he said.

"We expect the volumes to continue firm. As you are aware we operate on a quota system which ensures the same quantity is maintained throughout the marketing season," the official said.

Total tobacco output for this year was estimated at over 200 million kg (440 million pounds), up from 190 million kg (418 pounds) last year which fetched 320 million U.S. dollars at the floors.

The crop is expected to earn farmers more than 700 million U.S. dollars following the expected increase in world tobacco prices caused by the damage to the American crop by a storm.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

August 14, 1996


Gambia;
Angola Deports 107 Gambians


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

LUANDA, Angola - The Angolan government has deported 107 Gambians, two Senegalese and three Lebanese its said were residing in the country illegally. 

The deportations were carried out Tuesday under an operation code-named 'Cancer-II' which was launched by the police almost a week ago, the national news agency, ANGOP, said.

Meanwhile, the Angolan immigration department reported that two Guinean immigrants also turned up at Luanda international airport for voluntary repatriation. The two had evaded the police swoop that caught the other West Africans.

On Monday, some 249 foreigners, mainly Malian and Senegalese nationals, were repatriated aboard three flights.

Africa News


August 14, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi To Introduce New Working Hours


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Burundi is to introduce new working hours following the economic embargo imposed against the country.

"A general consensus has been reached for the introduction of new working hours" designed to save fuel in Burundi, according to a statement released Wednesday in Bujumbura at the end of a meeting between government officials and civil society representatives. 

The hours, to be announced, are designed to reduce commuting during the working day and help Burundi, which has been hit by an embargo by neighboring states, save fuel.

The meeting was attended by representatives of the ministries of labor, crafts, vocational training and public service on the one hand, and representatives of the Burundi Employers' Association and major trade unions in the country on the other.

According to the statement, the new working hours will be introduced "in public, parastatal and private sectors due to the difficult situation brought about by the economic embargo imposed against Burundi" since August 1.

This is the second major change that has resulted from the economic embargo imposed on Burundi by its neighbors to force the new regime in Bujumbura, which took power in a military coup on July 25, to restore constitutional order in the country.

On Tuesday, the government decided to ration fuel, with very limited quotas for private vehicles and taxis, which can only get 20 liters (5.2 gallons) each per month.

Observers, meanwhile, noted that Burundi had been cut off from the rest of the world since Tuesday, when the last flight of the Belgian airline, SABENA, took off from Bujumbura. The country is also facing an international air embargo.

The military regime in Burundi has intensified diplomatic efforts to have the embargo lifted.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 14, 1996


Zambia;
Interpol Recovers Stolen Zambian Mask


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

LIVINGSTONE, Zambia - A Zambian 'Makishi' mask stolen from the Livingstone Museum in the south of the country in 1989, has been recovered in Brussels by the International Police Organization, Interpol.

Livingstone National Museum director, Vincent Katanekwa, said Wednesday that the famous mask, called "Nalindele" and used by Luvale ethnic group during boys' initiation ceremonies, had been found but his office does not have the money to collect it from Brussels. 

He said many other pieces stolen from the museum had been found in South African museums but had not been collected because of a lack of funds for the necessary travel.

Katanekwa said the recovery of the mask has cheered workers at the institution which is going through financial difficulties.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 14, 1996


South Africa;
Beef Cow Lung Disease Threatens Beef Industry


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - A cow lung disease which has been diagnosed in Botswana poses a serious threat to the entire cattle population of Southern Africa.

If it goes unchecked, the disease, which has so far destroyed 250,000 heads of cattle, could have far-reaching consequences for the beef industries in Sub-Saharan Africa. 

It has been confirmed that cow lung disease is already spreading southward from Botswana.

South Africa's Northern Province Red Meat Producers' Organization chairman, Gert Roets, says the rapidly spreading disease poses a bigger threat to Pretoria's meat industry than mad cow disease, which recently resulted in the banning of British beef here.

He pointed out that a campaign to test cattle entering South Africa was impractical, as there was no real control of animals crossing the country's borders.

If the government could not effectively control the borders, it would have to consider deploying South African National Defense Force personnel to do so, he added.

Transvaal Agricultural Union president, Dries Bruwer, says if unchecked, the disease has the potential of destroying the cattle industries of South Africa's neighbors, where few preventive measures are taken against infectious diseases.

Bruwer's union has already called on the South African agricultural union to demand that all member-countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) inoculate their herds against the disease.

"Unless drastic steps are taken to force SADC member countries to use available South African technology and vaccine to eradicate the disease," Bruwer said, "the South African red meat industry could be harmed for a very long period, and suffer losses amounting to million of Rands."

Cow lung disease was eradicated in South Africa 50 years ago, but officials believe that a new outbreak could prove fatal to the provinces, and the country as a whole.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 14, 1996


Science;
Zambia Discovers Useful Medicinal Plant


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

CHILILAMBOMBWE, Zambia - Zambia's National Council for Scientific Research (NCSR) has announced the discovery of a local plant whose active substance is effective in family planning, controlling malaria, bilharzia and livestock diseases. It also has a vital ingredient required in the making of detergents. A specialist in tropical public health at the Kitwe NCSR office, Dr Mohammed Shehata told the Zambia News Agency (ZANA) recently it took his team ten years to discover what he termed "the wonder plant." which grows naturally in various parts of Zambia. Shehata said the plant is commonly known in Zambia as 'endod'. Its scientific name is 'phytolacco'. 

He said the plant which is also available in Ethiopia, the United States and in the Middle East, grows naturally near sources of water like rivers, streams and lakes.

Shehata said his research findings show that berries produced by the plant contain about 25 percent of saponin, an active substance which is effective in killing snails which carry the bilharzia parasite and larvae of anopheles mosquitos, the malaria-causing vector.

"Saponin is effective in controlling malaria as it kills mosquito larvae when sprayed in areas infested with the insects, eliminates worms which affect the liver in cattle while saponin foam is an active ingredient in making detergents.

Saponin also kills sperms and can be used as a compound for birth control," the Egyptian scientist told ZANA.

He and his team, have over the years developed a technology of extracting the substance from endod berries.

Shehata said local pharmaceutical companies are free to approach the NCSR with a view to acquiring the technology of extracting saponin from the plant for use in manufacturing various products including veterinary ones.

"The 20 percent saponin content in a berries of endod is the highest compared to plants found in Ethiopia, the United States or the Middle East," said Shehata who holds a doctorate in tropical public health.

Since he was recruited by the NCSR to develop an effective drug against bilharzia in 1985, Shehata has established a six- hectare plantation of endod in Ichimpe in Kitwe in the northern Copper belt province, where he harvests about five tons of berries a year.

He collected the plants from Luapula, northern, central, western and southern provinces for comparison purposes.

"The plant found in Nchelenge in Luapula province have highest potency of saponin and yields of berries compared with those from other parts of Zambia," he added.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Mumbwa - Former Member of Parliament for Mumbwa Constituency, Stanford Hlazo, has welcomed the formation of the National Lima Party saying this shall resurrect the doomed farmers if properly utilised.

Mr Hlazo congratualted both Zambia Farmers Union President Ben Kapita and former Agriculture Minister and Mpika Member of Parliament, Dr Guy Scott for being courageous enough to form up a political party that would enhance the agricultural industry in the country. 

Mr Hlazo who was speaking in interview with ZIS from his L.S. Hacienda hotel in Mumbwa today said the formation of the National Lima Party has been over due since farmers have suffered for too long without any help from the government.

He criticised the MMD policy for allegedly sidelining the farmers whom he said have received no or little help from government in terms of securing inputs and as well as marketing of agricultural produce.

Mr Hlazo claimed that one of the reasons that forced him to resign from MMD is the idea of giving farmers promissory notes adding that some of the farmers' promissory notes have not been honoured up to date.

He appealed to farmers and the general public to support the National Lima Party saying that if agriculture policies improved, many people especially the non employed and retirees shall have somewhere to go to and earn a living.

Mr Hlazo also accused the government for not advertising enough the tourism potential Zambia has saying the country could be earning a lot of foreign exchange brought in by the would be tourists.

He said that the government should work hard to exploit all the avenues that could contribute torwards the growth of national economy.

Africa News


August 14, 1996


United States and Africa;
Libya Denounces US Bill


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Libya has reacted sharply to the United States' assent of the Bill that will punish foreign companies that will continue to do business with Libya and Iran.

Despite objections from Washington's closest allies in Europe, US President Bill Clinton on Monday signed the Iran and Libya Sanctions Act of 1996 which imposes sanctions on foreign countries that invest in those two country's energy sectors. 

In a statement released in Lusaka yesterday, Libyan ambassador

to Zambia, Mustapha Braid, said "the the law was unjust as it opposes and contradicts the international laws and Accords, particularly the United Nations Charter that prevents the use of economic sanctions for the benefit of political objectives".

The statement further states that Libya had cooperated with with the international community in the Lockerbie issue and proved its good intentions and accepted by presenting its two suspected nationals for trial in an independent country.

The bill also received a sharp reaction from the European Union. The European Commission released a statement by EU trade commissioner, Sir Leone Brittan, on Monday recalling that "EU had already said it would act to defend its rights and interests if they are jeopardised by this legislation".

The statement further alleged "that the reason for the sanctions was an election campaign pressure on the United States President and growing uneasiness on the part of American petroleum companies on their vital interests in Libya and Iran"

Africa News


August 14, 1996


Zambia;
Zambian Law Association Resolution Supported


BYLINE: Mukalya Nampito, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition political parties and the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace (CCJP) have come out in full support of the Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) condemnation of 10 key clauses of the amended Constitution of Zambia.

The Liberal Progressive Front (LPF), UNIP and the National Party, in separate interviews yesterday, said LAZ had done well to highlight the objectionable clauses.

But ruling MMD Mandevu member of parliament Patrick Katyoka, said LAZ has been hijacked by some political elements within the association. 

LPF chairman, Roger Chongwe, said lawyers in Zambia have always been consistent on issues of the Constitution. He said they were consistent in 1964, 1973 and in 1991.

"What they have highlighted and resolved is supported by all the people of Zambia," Chongwe said, asking: " Why should the president win the elections on a minority vote?"

LAZ resolved that a presidential candidate should only be declared winner if he has votes amounting to over 50 per cent of the total votes cast as provided for in the 1991 Constitution and not any simple majority as provided for in article 34 (8) of the 1996 Constitution.

Chongwe said this amendment was not even in the Government White paper or in the Constitution Amendment Bill. He said it was introduced at the Committee Stage so that they would hoodwink members of parliament.

But Katyoka said the professionalism of LAZ has to be called into question because of the political elements.

"You have the same people talking about consensus on the issue of the Constitution but they go ahead and pass resolutions by way of vote," Katyoka carped in an interview yesterday. "That is why we in MMD have decided to let the people decide, if they think we enacted a wrong constitution, they will vote us out."

CCJP's Fr. Joe Komakoma said they felt encouraged that an influential group like LAZ has come up with this position.

"It just shows how many groups are not happy with the Constitution," Fr. Komakoma said.

UNIP administrative secretary, Basil Kabwe, said this government has in the most subtle manner altered the fundamental human rights provided under Part 3 of the 1991 Constitution without calling for a referendum.

"In some countries, this alone would precipitate a very nasty situation in the land. UNIP has always maintained that the Constitution has not been amended according to the law but has been hijacked by the MMD," Kabwe said in an interview yesterday.

Amongst the 10 clauses condemned by LAZ are the preamble declaring Zambia a Christian nation which lawyers argued was discriminatory against other religions and violated the 1991 Constitution on freedom of conscience.

The citizenship and domicile clauses were also dismissed as discriminatory, especially that they classify citizens into categories of second and third generation.

National Party spokesman, Sam Chipungu, said his party wanted this Constitution to be adopted through a Constituent Assembly so that a consensus emerges out of it.

"What LAZ has done is merely what we have always been speaking about. We would have loved the Constitution to be discussed. We have been very consistent on the issue of the Constitution," Chipungu said in an interview. " We were the ones leading the discussion on issues of the Constitution."


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 14, 1996


Science;
Zambian Drug Shortage Fears Allayed


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - There are adequate funds to secure the nation enough drugs to run up to December this year, health minister Katele Kalumba assured in Lusaka yesterday.

Kalumba, receiving a donation of drugs from the World Health Organisation (WHO), said "the World Bank has agreed to support a drugs revolving fund to be operational in 1997".

Allaying fears of a serious national drug shortage, Kalumba said he did not want to be involved in cheap politics but would rather work "quietly" to the best of his ability. 

Kalumba advised the nation that the drug situation in the country requires careful management.

"What we found on the ground when I took over office in June was that we had run out of money," Kalumba disclosed. "The 1996 budget had provided K6 billion for the Ministry of Health which was only enough to clear the outstanding debts owed to a number of suppliers."

The health minister revealed that "in spite of the crisis we have had with the Constitution, our partners came through with K3 billion at the end of June and the government managed to secure an extra K1 billion.

"These funds will secure us enough drugs to run up to December this year," Kalumba assured.

Kalumba, who insisted that "transparent" procedures had been followed in tender processes concerning donor funds, announced that cabinet had also approved the restructuring of Medical Stores, a state owned and controlled drug procurement and supply company.

"The cabinet also approved our decision to start a drug revolving fund. This requires careful planning and not dramatics," Kalumba said. "Nobody should jump over me to go to State House or see some finance minister. You have to wait until I'm ready to see you because I'm also busy negotiating with our partners."

Kalumba added: "It is time we sat down to examine why we need a second survival plan for Medical stores. We are restructuring management to reduce the cost on tax payers' money."

And chairman of the Medical Stores Board of Directors, Bwalya Chiti, confirmed that the company was owed over K1 billion by the government.

According to Chiti, Medical Stores was in a "serious financial position" and something ought to be done soon to avert its possible collapse.

But despite being on the verge of collapse, Medical Stores on Monday donated drugs and protein supplements worth K2 million to first lady Vera Chiluba's Hope Foundation.

"Medical Stores sees in this donation an element of support to Hope Foundation," managing director Violet Kabwe said, probably 'hoping' the donation will halt 'unfavourable' restructuring of Medical Stores.

Sports - Soccer;
Coach Dropped From Zambian National Team

LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - Power Dynamos charismatic stand-in coach, Aggrey Chiyangi, has been dropped from the squad which goes to camp next week Monday.

National soccer team coach, Roald Poulsen, explained that Chiyangi has been sidelined because of his commitments at Power Dynamos. 

Chiyangi was appointed acting coach after the team fired Webby Chilufya for allegedly failing to execute his duties.

Said Poulsen:"I explained to Chiyangi why he could not be with the squad. We didn't want to interfere with his role at Power.

"Chiyangi is a good player but if included in the squad, he would not be with the team Power and yet his services are greatly needed by the team."

The coach said there was still room for Chiyangi if he could maintain his present form and the situation at Power is normalised.

Power has contributed three players to the national team, Jones Mwewa, Mwape Miti and Douglas Chiwaya.

Africa News


August 14, 1996


Zambia;
ZAMBIA'S BAD IMAGE . . .Kaunda blames it on corrupt govt


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala and Mukalya Nampito, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has lost her respect and integrity abroad because of poor leadership, corruption, insincerity and other vices in President Frederick Chiluba's government, charged former president Kenneth Kaunda at the University of Zambia's (UNZA) Great East Road campus in Lusaka on Monday.

President Kaunda told more than 2,000 UNZA students on Monday night that Zambia's dented image abroad had nothing to do with anybody else but the government itself.

But chief government spokesman, information and broadcasting minister Amusaa Mwana-mwambwa, who is also a ruling MMD National Executive Committee (NEC) member, said that the UNIP president was speaking as a politician "and so the best people to answer that are his fellow politicians - MMD national secretary, minister without portfolio Michael Sata and party national chairman, Sikota Wina.

The UNIP president, invited by University of Zambia Political and Administrative Studies Association (UNZAPASA) to discuss the political and economic situation in the country accused President Chiluba of "dodging" important regional summits because he could not defend his unacceptable misgovernance to other nations. 

"Zambia has lost out because since he came to power in 1991 Chiluba has been shunning to attend all crucial regional meetings where a lot of important issues are discussed. How can you have a President like that?" the former president asked, amid shouts of "Kaunda mwaume" (Kaunda is a man) by UNZA students.

President Kaunda further charged that the MMD had a ruthless machinery which had brought lots of misery to the people.

"There has been economic decline and all that Zambians worked for in 27 years has been reversed. MMD has shortened the life expectancy of Zambians," Kaunda told a packed lecture theatre. "The present climate is not conducive for economic development because there is rampant corruption and little morality in the ruling party which is affecting progress."

He challenged UNZA students to assist in restoring good governance and to fight injustice of any kind.

And University of Zambia Student's Union (UNZASU) presidential aspirant, Brian Yuyi, took the occasion to condemn UNZA administration officials, who were present at the meeting, for allowing MMD cadres to form a branch at the institution, saying it was not healthy for the university.

Yuyi, greeted with applause from the audience, challenged Dean of Students, Bizwell Phiri, and UNZA registrar, Peter Mphande, to state the administration's position on the matter.

"From the time the cadres announced the formation of an MMD branch here, the administration has been quiet," Yuyi observed, asking Phiri and Mphande: " Can we know why there has been this silence now?"

Yuyi accused the administration of being indecisive and of supporting the pro-MMD students and lecturers who in June marched to State House in support of the despised constitution.

Tembo said the students would resist any efforts to form a political party at the campus because it was supposed to be a non-partisan institution.

Phiri and Mpande exculpated themselves.

"When I heard about the formation of the branch here, I immediately telephoned the registrar, the vice-chancellor and the students union to find out what was happening," Phiri said. "The administration will take a decision in consultation with the students union."

Students shouted down the two officials and demanded that the culprit lecturers and students be expelled or the "Burning Youth" (the students who last June burnt the property of their colleagues who had marched to State House in support of the Chiluba sponsored constitution) pounces on them.

And UNZASU president, Emmanuel Tembo, has sued the state over his " abduction".

His lawyer, Law Association of Zambia chairman, George Kunda, confirmed the suit.

Tembo is suing for damages, "false imprisonment, inhuman treatment and intimidation".

"We have already written the letter of demand to the state. The writ of summons was filed in the Ndola High Court yesterday," Kunda said in an interview yesterday.

Tembo said he was on July 15 dragged and taken behind UNZA hostels where a policeman pointed a gun at him threatening to shoot him if he did not cooperate. At the time of his "abduction" he did not know who had taken him.

He was taken to Chelstone Police Station where he spent the night in cells and was later moved to Lusaka Central Police for interrogation.

"I refused to answer questions at Central Police because of the way I was treated. I was not prepared to say anything ," Tembo said in an interview on July 16 after he was released without being charged.

Tembo blamed his abduction on the 15 pro-MMD students who had marched to State House and feared that they may endanger the lives of many other fellow students.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Zambia;
Parties Vie For Student Allegiance


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Lusaka - Lusaka Province Chairman for Movement for Multi-Party Democracy, Christopher Chawinga, has challenged the University of Zambia administration to ban the United National Independence Party branch which also exists at the institution.

Reacting to press reports that the administration has banned his party's branch which he launched on Saturday, Mr Chawinga said he was aware that a UNIP branch existed.

He said this is why Dr Kenneth Kaunda is always addressing meetings at the campus. 

Mr Chawinga also accussed the administration of maintaining double standards saying while they allowed UNIP activities to be conducted at the campus, they were so much against the MMD activities.

"When Kaunda goes to address students at the campus, the lecturers are silent but when MMD forms a branch they cry foul," Mr Chawinga said.

He also cited a recent incident in which some MMD students had their property burnt by UNIP activists and the administration did not take any action.

"We are aware that some senior lecturers are pro-UNIP and I challenge them to come in the open.," he said.

He urged the students to remain calm adding that MMD will always support them despite the ban.

Last Saturday Mr Chawinga launced an MMD branch for the university at Chainama Hills Hotel to which the UNZA administartion is against.

Students at the University of Zambia (UNZA) Great East Road campus have given the authorities there up to today evening to explain their stand on the reported existance of an MMD branch at the institution.

The ultimatum was issued yesterday evening when students stormed the office of the dean of students to seek an explanation why they maintained double stands by condenming political involvement of UNZA staff and students while at the same time allowing the formation of a political party at the institution.

Sources at the institution revealed that some members of the administration were almost manhandled by the irate students over the saga yesterday.

The community relations manager, Mulife Malambo, declined to comment on the matter and refered all queries to the registrar.

Mr. Malambo said the administration was still holding consultative meetings at high level after which a statement will be issued on the situation.

A number of students interviewed denied the existance of such a political branch adding that if it at all the reported branch did exist the student body would vehemently oppose it.

"We shall never allow the formation of any political party at UNZA because it will bring chaos at the institution. The university is a mirror of society and should remain neutral but, individuals have the right to belong to a political party of their choice," said one student who declined to be named.

Other students have expressed worry that politicising the institution will just spark violence similar to what happened recently when some students had their property burnt and others failed to right their examinations due to political involvement.

Lusaka MMD provincial chairman was yesterday reported to have launched an MMD branch at the campus at Chainama Hotel and pledged support by the ruling party.

LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

194 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 14, 1996


Business;
Better Days Coming For Zambian Farmers


BYLINE: Cecilia Banda, Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - The prices of local maize will remain stable between now and December when the major commercial producersare expected to off-load their harvest on the market.

The Agricultural Commodity Exchange (ACE) predicts that the maize prices will be pegged between K18,000 and K20,000 per 90 kilogram bag in December because by then all the maize from the small traders will have been consumed.

ACE General Manager Andrew Fletcher said in Lusaka today the current maize market is characterised by low liquidity, limited buyers and lots of sellers because of the bumper harvest. 

Mr Fletcher said there is a lot of maize available on the market mostly coming in from the smaller farmers although some of them are not prepared to sell it at the prevailing warehouse prices.

The current maize prices are pegged between K11,000 and K13,000 depending on the terms being offered by the market players and this trend is expected to go on until December when the stocks for the small growers run-out.

Mr Fletcher said the highest price prediction for this year's harvest is K25,000 and that this is also expected to compete favourably with the maize coming-in from neighbouring Zimbabwe between January and the next harvest.

The prices will move-upward depending on the flow of maize from the high consumption areas like Lusaka. More maize is expected to come on the market by October to supplement the supply by the small farmers.

Mr Fletcher said there is still a lot of maize being collected in rural areas and that the commodity exchange is busy buying on cash basis from the farmers willing to sell at the prevailing warehouse prices.

He also pointed-out that the slow mealie_meal sales have contributed to low liquidity on the maize market because millers are only buying enough maize to produce mealie-meal at the current demand levels.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 14, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Zambian Medalist Won't Be Rewarded Yet


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's star athlete Samuel Matete won't be rewarded yet as the government is still waiting for a report on his performance at the Atlanta Olympics.

Responding to queries on whether or not the sports ministry would award Matete following his outstanding performance at the just-ended Olympic Games in Atlanta, permanent secretary Arthur Yoyo said it was the prerogative of the President, Frederick Chiluba to decide on the awards to give out to deserving sportsmen.

"I wish to advise that my ministry has not yet received a full report on the performance of not only Samuel Matete but the entire Zambian team that participated at the recent Olympics in the USA," reads part of Yoyo's response. 

But the decision to await a performance report from the Zambia Olympics Commonwealth and All Africa Games Association (ZOCAGA) has been attacked by some sports administrators who feel Matete deserves some rewards.

"It is rather surprising that Matete cannot be rewarded for his job when we all know that he is the only one that managed to win a medal for this country. I do not think there is any need to await any reports," said an administrator who sought anonymity.

But according to Yoyo, even the issuing of the diplomatic passport to Zambia national soccer team skipper, Kalusha Bwalya, did not come from the sports ministry but State House.

"It will be too early for me to start commenting on rewards and awards for every sportsman that excels like Matete. You might recall that the diplomatic passport issued to Kalusha Bwalya was the prerogative of the Republican president and not my ministry. I would therefore advise you to wait until I receive that report from ZOCAGA," said Yoyo.

And efforts to get comments from the Zambia Amatuer Athletics Association (ZAAA) failed as the general secretary, Phiri Kuombela was out of office.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 14, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
New Players Join Zambian World Cup Squad


BYLINE: Celani Shongwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - National soccer team coach, Roald Poulsen, has recalled former Zambian centre forward Maybin M'gaiwa and utility Evans Sakala in his 28-man squad announced yesterday for the Africa and World Cup preparations.

M'gaiwa, the Kabwe Warriors striker who last played for the national team in an Africa Cup qualifier against Zimbabwe in Harare in 1993, joins the team after his long stay in Morocco where he was playing professional soccer, while Sakala, a member of the 1994 silver-medal Zambian squad at the Africa Cup of nations in Tunisia, is attempting to win back a regular place after a long spell of injuries forced him out.

New faces in the squad that has seen the return of two Zamsure players, Arthur Lungu and Kingsley Musabula, are teenage Lusaka Dynamos midfielder, Perry Mutapa, and first division Garden Stars striker, Beston Mwansa. 

Others coming back into the side include Mufulira Wanderers striker, Bilton Musonda, Zamsure defender, Sidney Mambwe and Chambishi football club midfielder, Emmanuel Siwale.

Others that will start camping on Monday are goalkeepers, Davies Phiri(Kabwe Warriors), James Phiri (Zanaco) Collins Mbulo (Wanderers) defenders, Hillary Makasa (Roan United), Jones Mwewa (Power Dynamos), Mordon Malitoli (Nkana) Martin Chola (Wanderers)Hector Chilombo (City of Lusaka) and Allan Kamwanga (Wanderers)

Midfielders include Douglas Chiwaya (Power Dynamos), Vincent Mutale (Wanderers), Alex Namazaba (Lusaka Dynamos), Limbi Mbewe (Rumlex)and John Lungu (Roan), while strikers Andrew Tembo, Shy Kumwenda(Zamsure), Kenneth Malitoli (Nkana) Paul Chellah (Wanderers), Mwape Miti, (Power Dynamos) Cosmas Banda(Rumlex) and Edward Kangwa from Zanaco.

In his announcement, Poulsen also requested the four professional players who are pursuing their careers in Saudi Arabia but are in the country for a holiday to join the rest of the players in camp.

Saudi-based players not named at yesterday's press conference are Harrison Chongo and Elijah Litana. "This is not the final squad, their stay in the team will depend on their performance in the camp and at club level.

"We can still ask some players to leave the camp and bring new ones," Poulsen said.

The squad will be training every Monday to Wednesday until the game against Mozambique on October 6. The coach asked Lusaka based players to assembly at Anchor House for transport to Kitwe.

Africa News


August 15, 1996


Science;
Zambian Scientists Discover New Coagulant


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Kitwe - The National Council for Scientific Research in Kitwe has discovered a water coagulant known as 'moringa seed' which could replace aluminium sulphate being used by councils in the treatment of water.

The discovery came to light today when Minister of Science Technology and Vocational Training, Dr. Kabunda Kayongo, toured the centre. 

Acting head of the tree improvement centre, William Chishimba, told the minister that the main objective was to develop low cost water treatment technology using moringa seeds and also to demonstrate the developed technology at urban and rural level.

He explained that the efficiency of moringa seed in water treatment whas already been demonstrated by Kitwe City Council water plant and it proved very satisfactory.

Mr. Chishimba also said the project was being carried out in conjunctioin with water resources research unit based at the national council and scientific research headquarters.

The acting head further added thirteen essential oil samples from exotic and indigenous plants have been established and were gradually being expanded in a nursery form.

He added the centre also intends to establish a pilot distillation plant for essential oils and offer service in form of consultancy to farmers and small scale distillers in Zambia.

Later Dr. Kayongo praised the staff for their iniative and innovativeness towards research and development in the country despite facing a lot of constraints.

She said what they had embarked upon was a breakthrough in the field of science and technology.

The minister told them that given a better working environment with laboratories with equipment, their performance at the centre would be exemplary.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZIS

198 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 15, 1996


Ethiopia;
Economic Bonanza for Returning Ethiopians


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Addis Ababa - Effective as of July 8, 1996, Ethiopians returning home from abroad are allowed to bring in goods considered as personal effects duty-free

What types of Ethiopian returnees are going to benefit from the tax exemption? Included in the tax privilege category are Ethiopians serving in the Ethiopian diplomatic missions and embassies abroad; those on foreign scholarships and on business trips abroad and returning Ethiopian refugees. So, on the face of it, that sounds like practically every Ethiopian who is coming back home after a stay abroad of some duration.

But the duration of the stay is important. However, it has not yet been made explicit. Would Ethiopians who have been abroad for a week be allowed to take advantage of the tax break? Further, the types of goods to receive the tax exemption have not yet been specified. Are cars, TV sets, tape-recorders, video-recorders, refrigerators and washing machines included? Definitely a tax exemption on second-hand cars (these being the ones that are most affordable by aspirants of car ownership) is a big bonus, amounting to as much as 15,000 birr for a medium-sized car with a manufacturing date in the mid-1980's. Another question is whether Ethiopians can benefit from the tax relief as frequently as they have been abroad. In other words, would someone who has been abroad three times in a year be allowed to bring in three cars duty free? 

At any rate, scholarships and tours abroad on government business for state employees are going to be at a higher premium than before, thanks to the tax exemption privilege! Competition for such travel abroad among civil servants is expected to be stiff. High-ranking government officials may reserve such travel opportunities for themselves.

When they do pass them on to subordinates, they may use them as a means of dispensing favors to gain or maintain political loyalty.

The timing of the announcement of the special tax exemption privilege to coincide with the ban on franco valuta imports, particularly by the private sector, appears to have been designed at least as a partial antidote to the anticipated widespread uproar over the latter measure. Whether the project will succeed remains to be seen.

At least in principle, the government could use the duty-free privilege as an interim incentive to induce professionals to remain in the civil service where low pay is forcing experienced employees to seek work in the higher- paying private sector. Such labour market pressures have already motivated state-owned banks to consider granting substantial pay increments to their staff.

In this vein, to make the incentive impact of the tax break well felt, it is recommended that the following specifics be considered in its implementation.

* Include the major desirable items such as cars, TV sets, video-recorders and refrigerators in the list of goods to be allowed in duty-free;

* Make the required duration of stay abroad for eligibility as short as possible;

* Allow at least three occasions before a returnee's duty-free privilege is withdrawn;

* Permit the sale of items brought in under the tax exemption privilege;

* See to it that scholarships and other travel opportunities are granted to deserving and appropriate individuals.

However, one ought not to have the impression that the duty-free privilege is going to be anything like a substitute for an upward revision of the salary scale for the civil service. Revisions so far made are not adequate and even those are not being implemented. The government would be well- advised to appreciate that once the private sector is allowed to take off by removing the investment obstacles that bedevil it at present, the civil service may find it difficult to retain even a single top-notch technocrat outside the inner circle of political loyalists. As a whole, the recently announced duty-free privilege for returning Ethiopians is a welcome measure provided it is implemented equitably. However, one should not labour under the delusion that it would in any way ameliorate the unpopularity of the ban on franco valuta imports announced almost simultaneously. People are bound to ask: "Why should we in Ethiopia be denied the right of receiving bona fide gifts of second-hand cars from our friends and relatives living abroad while returning Ethiopians are allowed to bring in such gifts duty-free. What's more, we pay taxes on the gifts we receive!"

Humorists may retort: "If the gifts cannot come to you, go to them!"


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


199 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 15, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

Addis Ababa - First Direct Shipment of Ethiopian Coffee Destined for South Africa: The first direct shipment of Ethiopian coffee to South Africa is being loaded in Assab. The coffee is destined for Johannesburg via Durban and is being imported by a South African coffee roaster, caf Rossini. According to S.A. Bagersh Coffee, the company who is exporting the coffee to South Africa, this first containerized shipment weights in at 17,100 kg. Ethiopian coffee was in the past imported from European trading houses.

Mr. Ajay Bramdeo, a First Secretary at the South African Embassy in Addis Ababa responsible for trade matters, said that this first coffee shipment is significant as it is symbolic of the ever increasing bilateral trade between Ethiopia and South Africa. He indicated that trade between the two countries had already grown from approximately US$ 3 million in 1993 to US$ 19 million in 1995 and is steadily increasing 

Source: South African Embassy press release, 8 August

Bomb Blast at Wabe Shebele Hotel raises Unanswered Questions

On Monday at 7:10 p.m. a bomb blast at the Wabe Shebelle Hotel in Addis killed, according to the Region 14 Police Commisioner, one person and injured eleven others. Those injured were taken to Zewditu hospital, Black Lion, and one to Gebrial Hospital. ENA reported that there was only minor property damage. Frequent efforts made by Addis Tribune have failed to discover who is in charge of the investigation.

This is the third incident of its kind this year. The first was at the Ghion Hotel in Addis on 18 January. The other was at the Ras Hotel in Dire Dawa on 2 February. It is not known whether a link exists between the latest bombing and the two previous ones or even between it and the assassination attempt on the life of Dr. Abdulmejid Hussein, Minister of Transport and Communications on 8 July.

Ethiopian Airline's Financial Troubles

The financial situation of Ethiopian Airlines (EAL) has received much coverage of late. In a report in the biweekly newsletter, dated August 2, more is added to the matter.

Net profit before tax during the first ten months of EAL's fiscal year, fell by 71.5 per cent to 42.6 million birr, down from 150 million last year. Profits for March were 5.8 million birr compared with six million in the same month last year.

These figures were allegedly obtained from the Airlines internal financial document, known as the 'green book', said the article's writer, Tamene.

Reasons for the loss vary, the report continues. Many believe the 1995 net profit exaggerates its current loss. The airline posted 186 million birr profit last year, some find this unattainable. The management's competency and its failure to control costs was another reason mentioned.

There are indications that EAL's Chief, Dr. Ahmed may step aside and run the new Harari Bank, the report states. In addition to this, the Amharic publication, Tobia, claims that the Internal Revenue have asked Ethiopian Airlines to pay taxes owing.

Addis Tribune contacted EAL to see if there was any comment to the reports but our call was not returned.

Food Security Assessment For June

Heavy rains continued in most agricultural areas of the country throughout June as the 'belg' season progresses. Last month the USAID Famine Early Warning System (FEWS), and the EU Food Security Unit (EU-FSU) estimated that this could be one of the best 'belg' production harvests in recent years.

An assessment team visited the field and preliminary findings confirm the previous forecast.The short 'meher' rainy season agricultural activities are underway around the country. They are reported to be following regular patterns and substantial rainfall in some regions has radically improved water and pasture availability, ensuring that there will be more than enough for the coming dry season.

Citizens Permitted Use Of Wide Range Of Communication Equipment

The Ministry of Transport and Communications issued a statement indicating that Ethiopians can now import and use communication equipment including Television Receive Only (TVRO). The new law went into effect on Wednesday 7 August. ENA reported that telephone apparatus, cellular telephones, fax machines, modems and intercoms could also be imported by individuals and organizations.

It was however said that using TVRO for commercial purposes is prohibited. The ministry also warned that legal action would be taken against those who without due authorization redistribute a program and receive authorized schedules, move the TVRO from one place to another. Those with licenses could sell and maintain telephone apparatus, cellular telephone, fax machine, data modems and intercom. ENA also reported that in two months time, the internet service might be made available.

The ICRC Is Acting With Discretion

In response to three articles appearing in a private newspaper on 23 and 30 July 1996, and on 6 August 1996, and subsequently reprinted in an English language weekly publication, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) Delegation in Ethiopia would like to clarify the following points.

The ICRC is a neutral, impartial and independent humanitarian organization, born more than one hundred years ago.

As custodian of International Humanitarian Law, the ICRC has been mandated by the international community to monitor respect of the four Geneva Conventions of 1949 and their two Additional Protocols of 1977.

Hence, and through different tasks, ICRC delegates in Ethiopia visit detainees held in connection with the change of regime or for state security reasons throughout the country, including military camps, police stations, and government prisons.

During and after visits, the ICRC endeavors to obtain commitments from authorities concerned to improve conditions of detention, in particular to assume greater responsibility for the health of detainees, and, where necessary, to ensure that they are afforded correct treatment.

The reports drawn up by the ICRC following visits to places of detention are confidential, and, as such, they are handed over to the detaining authorities only. This policy of discretion is not always properly understood by the public, which would often prefer to see the ICRC point an accusing finger at certain governments or at the perpetrators of certain inhuman acts. Yet, over a century of experience has convinced the ICRC that its humanitarian mission is best accomplished through persuasion devoid of all publicity.

These considerations do not prevent the ICRC from providing regular information to all those who wish to keep up to date on the institution's activities, but this information is limited to a description of the work carried out by the ICRC, and refrains from revealing what its delegates see or find out in the course of their duty.

The ICRC Delegation in Ethiopia hopes that the above-mentioned classifications will eradicate any misunderstanding which could have arisen on the part of those who might have read the articles referring to the ICRC, published in the last three issues of Urji. The first article was written solely on the basis of the personal interpretation of a reporter unknown to the ICRC, who, moreover, has never met with ICRC representatives.

Source: ICRC Press Release


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996

Zaire and Zambia;
Talks Slated On Copperbelt Regional Commission


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Ndola - The 'on-off' Zambia-Zaire regional permanent commission talks are expected to be held in Lubumbashi in two weeks time.

Copperbelt Deputy Minister, Charles Museba, said today that Zairean authorities have finally responded to reminders for them to host the 17th session of the Zambia-Zaire joint permanent commission meeting and they indicated that it could be held between now and next month. 

Mr Museba said the Zambian side, however, would like the meeting to take place in the last week of this month.

The meeting was originally scheduled to take place in the first quarter of this year but Zairean authorities were not ready to host the talks at that time.

The Zambian side has been anxious to meet the Zaireans to iron out a number of pressing issues.

Some of the issues which the Zambian side is likely to table for discussion is the harrassment of Zambian travelers on the 'pedicle road' and the armed theft of vehicles which are later driven into Zaire.

Sports - Soccer;
No Government Money For Zambian Soccer Association


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - Government has urged the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) to try and raise the K1.2 billion on their own as government has no money to bail them out.

Deputy Minister of Youth, Sport and Child Development Reverend Peter Chintala said in Lusaka today that FAZ must try to raise the money needed to cover the three national soccer teams involved in the World, Africa and CAF cup competitions. 

"The situation is very critical as government has no money, hence FAZ must engage in various fundraising ventures to raise the required amount," he said.

Rev Chintala, however, disclosed that with the availability of funds, government would meet the shortfall.

"We are prepared as a government to meet the shortfall if we raise a bit of money, but we can't help them all the way," he said.

FAZ Treasurer Musa Kasonka announced in Lusaka that the association is short of the amount by almost three quaters.

He said FAZ needs money for the players' allowances, training and camping allowances.

Kasonka further disclosed that his association would source funds from government, private donors and through the government appointed fundraising committee.

Sports - Soccer;
Mozambican Squad Prepares For Africa Cup


BYLINE: Celani Shongwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The Mozambican national squad, alias the "Black Mamba", is looking beyond the Zambian national team in the Africa Cup qualifying game to be played at Lusaka's Independence Stadium on October 6.

In an exclusive telephone interview yesterday the secretary general of the Mozambique Football Association (MFA), Anthony Karavano said they have played a number of international games in preparation for the game against Zambia. 

Karavano said they had also received an invitation from the South African Football Association (SAFA) to participate in the Four Nations tournament next month.

"We are looking forward to blotting Zambia's image, they are not invincible. We want to prove that we are an upcoming soccer giant in the region.

"Our participation in the Four Nation's Cup will be the final dress rehearsal before we take on Zambia in October," Karavano said .

He said their Portugal born coach, Arnado Salvador has assembled a crack squad which would shock Zambia in October.

Karavano said they would recall four of their internationals who are pursuing their career in Portugal. Among the players are the nimble-footed, Matthews "Chaka Chaka" Mandlazi who is playing for Stabudal.

Mozambique were booted out in the early rounds of the Africa Nation's Cup which was eventually won by the hosts, South Africa early this year.

Meanwhile, the Zambian national soccer coach, Roald Poulsen has indicated that he would need a full house of the professional players for the game against Mozambique.

Business;
Zambian Sugar Shares Sweet But Dear


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The minimum share price in the Zambia Sugar PLC floatation is too high, carped Securities and Exchange Commission chief executive, Mumba Kapumpa, yesterday.

Addressing a seminar for curriculum developers at Lusaka's Hotel Intercontinental yesterday, Kapumpa said "the price of K11 per share is alright, but the required block minimum amount of 10,000 shares is too much." 

"Fifty or K60,000 block minimum would have been better because it would have allowed more people to participate in the floatation," Kapumpa suggested. "Our aim right now is to get as many people as possible to participate in the market."

Mumba said he had anticipated more players on the Stock Exchange market with the floatation of Zambia Sugar but the block minimum amount would ensure only a few Zambians' participation.

And representative from InterAfrica Equities and Securities Limited, Zoran Zuze, said the price of Zambia Sugar shares was too high in relation to what people can afford to pay.

"The average Zambian salary is K390,000 annually. When you take this into consideration, K110,000 minimum block share is too much for the ordinary Zambians," Zuze said.

The Zambia Sugar PLC price was set by the Zambia Privatisation Trust Fund.

The seminar was for the Schools Education Project on Capital Markets. And the Curriculum Development Centre (CDC) will try to integrate the subject in school syllabuses.

SEC chairman Brian Musonda said the seminar was specifically aimed at the CDC trainers so that information about the stock exchange would be disseminated in schools.

"This forum is crucial because the more children and adults we can reach through you, the more people we will have interested enough in the market to participate," he told the trainers.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


204 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 15, 1996


Zambia;
Charges 'Shaky' Against Post Editors


BYLINE: Samson Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Lusaka - For the second time yesterday the state could not come up with the correct charge under the State Security Act against three Post editors.

Lusaka High Court justice Peter Chitengi had to intervene and guide the prosecution to rephrase their charge and make it clearer.

"This charge was not properly drafted," Justice Chitengi told state advocate Emelia Phiri and Chalwe Muchenga. "You were just fishing so that if they were missed by one charge they would be caught by another. That can put these people in jeopardy." 

Justice Chitengi said this after Phiri applied to amend the charge from " receiving document, article or information while knowing or having reasonable grounds to believe at the time that the same document, article or information were communicated or received in contravention of the State Security Act".

"The people would like to amend the charges by way of deletion of the word document, article ... ," Phiri said.

But justice Chitengi said the charge would still not be clear as it gave an impression that the state would want to catch the three on either "being communicated to or if that fails receiving classified information".

"These people are charged with a criminal offense and their liberty is at stake," justice Chitengi said. " We can't say if we miss them on this charge we will catch them on this."

And with justice Chitengi's help the state then dropped receiving and left the charge to read: "receiving information while knowing or having reasonable ground to believe that the same was communicated in contravention of the State Security Act."

Then the three accused persons, Post editor-in chief and managing director Fred M'membe, managing editor Bright Mwape and special projects editor Masautso Phiri, later took a plea of "not guilty".

But earlier M'membe, who is representing himself, told justice Chitengi that he was shocked by the careless manner in which the state was handling such a serious case.

"My lord, it is a bit shocking that a case of this nature can be handled in such a careless manner by the state. This case can alter the course of my professional, life and indeed my whole life. I can go to jail for up to 25 years," M'membe said. "My job involves receiving information, seeking the views of other people, blending them and transmitting them everyday."

And when asked if he understood the charge against him to take a plea, M'membe said: "I don't understand the charge because it has just been read to me now, I haven't had time to look at it. I have not been served with depositions. But from what has been read to me, I have great difficulties in understanding who should be charged - whether it is me or the government which should be here to answer charges."

M'membe only took plea after justice Chitengi assured him of court's protection.

"Mr M'membe you are protected. Feel safe," justice Chitengi assured. "That is why I was raising the peculiarities in the charge, the role of the court is to ensure that even though you are representing yourself the state does no abuse your rights."

Chitengi then directed the state to make available depositions from the 21 state witnesses.

The case comes up for trial on October 18, 29, 30 and 31, 1996.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Business;
Zambian Brewery Announces Changes


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia Breweries Plc yesterday launched new packaging for their Mosi lager. The company also announced changes in its management.

A new chief executive, Roger Smith, has 'traded' places with former managing director, Mick Marriot, who takes up a similar position in Lesotho left by Smith. 

"I am looking forward to the challenge that a competitive beer industry in Zambia will bring and will be relying on team effort from all staff members at Zambian Breweries," said Smith.

Zambia Breweries distribution director, Morris McClurg, said the company had raised their marketing budget from K200 million to K500 million this year.

"Quality will always remain a prerequisite for us, not just in beer ingredients and brewing processes but also in marketing, sales, distribution, and interaction with all stakeholders," McClurg said. "Our initial feedback two years ago was that our product quality was inconsistent and that our label for Mosi lager was outdated."

McClurg, however, assured that "the unacceptable standards of manufacture, hygiene, efficiency, and housekeeping of two years ago have all been done away with".

"Over the past twelve months, Zambia Breweries had conducted an extensive market research through its agents," McClurg said. "The results of this research is the new label and crown that you see."

Zambia;
President Reveals Government Spending On Poor


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - Six hundred million kwacha of government funds have been spent on the poor and the marginalised every year since 1992, disclosed President Frederick Chiluba in Lusaka yesterday.

Opening the Extensions to the Mother Theresa Home for the Terminally ill in Mtendere yesterday, President Chiluba said through the Public Welfare Assistance Scheme, aimed at cushioning them from the impact of the economic policies, the government has spent K600 million annually on the poor and the marginalised. 

"The poor are always with us, and it is up to us to take care of them. Most of us may not find the time nor inclination to care for the destitute, and we are grateful to the Missionaries of Charity for the good they are doing for the people," President Chiluba said. "Mother Theresa was an epitome of humility."

The President disclosed that the government was also in the process of establishing a vulnerability criteria to assess eligibility in accessing Public Welfare resources.

Mother Theresa's representative, Sister Regina, asked President Chiluba to help them in the matter of import duties and taxes.

"The Home had no home to pay these charges," Sister Regina told the President. "

Benefactors were ready to help them with food, medicine and clothing but they could not afford to pay the import duty."

Sister Regina also said the Home for Malnourished Children in Zambia has 60 children at the moment and the Outdoor Clinic which opens once a week caters for 220 patients on average.

"Our home for the terminally ill was started in a shed in January 1995 from that day till today 594 were admitted, 335 discharged, 140 died," Sister Regina disclosed to President Chiluba. "At present we have 38 patients. In addition to these activities, we visit poor families and help them in their needs."

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


207 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 15, 1996


Business;
Zambian Farmers Should Concentrate On Profitable Crops


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) executive director, George Gray, on Tuesday said his organisation would encourage its members to concentrate on profitable crops such as tobacco, as the maize prices had continued to fall.

"It's sad that the prices are still low and they continue to be falling, which will make repayment of loans very difficult," Gray said in an interview yesterday.

And according to the latest week's figures from the Agricultural Commodity Exchange (ACE) maize was trading at K12,500 per 90 kg bag. 

ACE, however, forecasts the same price to continue due to limited liquidity on the market.

And despite having close to six million bags in its hands, the Food Reserve Agency (FRA) has disclosed that the grain bag shortage is still being experienced in the country.

FRA director, Chance Kabaghe, disclosed that there was a deficit of close to over five million bags needed for this years anticipated 15.6 million bag harvest.

"There is a substantial shortage of grain bags in the country. In addition to the two million bags carry overs we got from last year's stock, we imported about three million for the strategic grain reserves," Kabaghe said in an interview last Thursday adding: "With the current stock in the private sector we have about 8-10 million bags in the country which means there is a shortfall of five million plus bags."

Kabaghe however hailed private institutions which had taken the initiative of joining in grain bag trading as they are working in line with the liberalisation of the agro-sector by the government.

And the grain bag traders' concentration on urban areas in distribution of the currently scarce empty grain bags has created shortages in the rural areas in the country.

According to the agricultural ministry's Bullentin, traders have concentrated their distribution of grain bags in the urban areas.

"There are, however, pronounced shortages of bags in rural areas. Most of the available bags are concentrated in urban areas," the report said.

The distribution has further been affected by the generally tight liquidity on the market and the prices of the bags which the farmers feel is rather high.

"Grain traders have limited funds to pay for empty grain bags let alone the maize itself, very few small scale farmers can afford the bags," the bulletin further explained.

The same view was shared by the Peasant Farmers Union of Zambia chairman, Patrick Kayeka, who disclosed that the K2,000 average price at which traders were selling the empty grain bags was too high.

"The farmers have obligations such as the clearing of their farming loans and in addition to that, have to pay very high prices for grain bags while the maize prices are still low," Kayeka said in an interview last Saturday. " Most of them simply cannot afford."


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 15, 1996


Ethiopia;
Case Against Alleged Underground Organization Adjourned


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Second Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court will re- commence hearing the case against Dr. Taye Woldesemayat, President of the Ethiopian Teachers' Association (ETA), on 14 October. Five others also stand accused of allegedly forming an illegal underground organization presumably under the name "Ethiopian National Patriots Front". The other five were named by the government English daily newspaper the Ethiopian Herald as Ato Kebede Desta, former president of the Veteran Teachers' Association, Ato Gebretsadik Hailemariam, Lt. Chane Tolla, Ato Talegeta Leul (Dagne), and Captain Moges Assefa. Ato Seleshi Berhane, cited in the statement issued by the Police Force Central Bureau's Investigation Co-ordination department, as one of the organisers of the underground organisation was not among the defendants. 

On Monday 5 August, the six defendants heard the charges brought against them. All of them decided to consult with their lawyers before making any comments. A reporter from a government newspaper noted that the ETA president objected to the presence of a press camera crew at the hearing. It was said that Dr. Taye took his coat and covered his face and only put it on again after the court ordered him to. The six defendants were appealed for the court to grant them bail. The Prosecutor General objected to this by saying that the defendants were charged with grave offences that call for sever punishments, and so there was all likelihood of them jumping bail. The granting of bail, said the Prosecutor General, " Will almost certainly mean the elimination or attempted persuasion by the defendants and their collaborators of the witnesses". On Tuesday, the court denied all six of the defendants bail.

Dr. Taye Woldesemayat was arrested on 30 May 1996, at the Bole International Airport on his return from a working visit of Europe. The Ethiopian Human Rights Council has issued a report noting dissatisfaction with the way Dr. Taye was being treated in prison and called for his case to be handled " in accordance with the law". On 26 June 1996, the executive committee of ETA held a press conference where they said that "Atrocities committed against ETA members have reached a dangerous point". The committee called the accusation put forward against its president as " Nothing more than an attempt to poison public opinion against ETA and to divert attention from the grievances of Ethiopian teachers which is beginning to arouse national and international interest."

Sports - Olympics;
Ethiopia: Four Years Behind Us and Looking Ahead, Editorial


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - The 1996 Summer Olympic games are over. The glory of the Olympics has filled our TV in the past weeks and tomorrow, we will celebrate the return of OLYMPIC HEROES; FATUMA ROBA, HAILE GEBRE SELASSIE AND GETE WAMI to Addis Ababa. Here at the Addis Tribune, we also have another celebration, the 4th Anniversary of Addis Tribune.

Four years may not seem such a big deal in the life of a newspaper but we are spirited and happy to be around. It is not easy but we wish to excel like our Olympic heroes in our endeavor.

Once again, we would like to renew our commitment to our readers that we will do everything possible to give accurate reports in their proper context and without distortions. The Addis Tribune will continue to be a forum for discussions on our country's politics, economics and culture.

We take advantage of this special occasion to congratulate FATUMA ROBA, HAILE GEBRE SELASSIE AND GETE WAMI for their superb achievement at the Atlanta Olympics. We would also like to congratulate the Olympic Committee, the coaches and all involved on an excellent job in preparing our athletes. Finally, we sincerely thank our readers and advertisers for your continued support.
