Africa News


August 19, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Moves Against Boutros-Ghali Resisted


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

NEW YORK - The United States' plan to find a replacement for the United Nations secretary-general, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, before the American presidential elections in November, may be facing some resistance in the Security Council, a U.S. newspaper has reported.

The influential New York Times reported Monday that the council, on whose recommendation the appointment of the secretary-general is made by the General Assembly, was not as keen as the U.S. to discuss the issue now.

"When Tono Eitel, Germany's representative at the UN and this month's security council president, polled delegations in recent days, he found only one, the American, that wanted to schedule a debate on the issue any time soon," the newspaper reported. 

It added that the consensus among the 14 other members of the council was that there was no urgency to act, "in part because a secretary-general has usually been chosen later in the year and in part because the Clinton administration, with its record of policy shifts, may change its mind after the elections."

Boutros-Ghali has said he will seek re-election when his current five-year term expires on Dec. 31, but the U.S., which accuses him of not having carried out enough reform at the UN, has promised to veto his candidacy.

"The U.S. has made its position clear, and therefore people who think that we might change our minds are wrong," the paper quoted the U.S. permanent representative at the UN, Madeleine Albright, as saying.

Albright said that countries that insisted on supporting Boutros-Ghali, " rather than working to find a candidate who is somebody who will have the general confidence not only of the U.S. but others, should understand that the American decision is irrevocable."

"One of the reasons we made the decision when we did was to allow other candidates to come forward," she said, adding: "I think that it is a little bit irresponsible not to be more active for other council members in terms of trying to figure out how the process ought to work."

The New York Times reported that the U.S. government's efforts to belittle Boutros-Ghali's achievements, and its warning to UN staff members not to use their positions to campaign for his re-election, had generated new sympathy for the secretary-general.

The Organisation of African Unity, the League of Arab nations and China, among others, have also expressed their support for the secretary-general's re-election.

The 73-year-old Egyptian diplomat is the first African UN secretary-general.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 19, 1996


Swaziland;
Swazi Communities Fear For Ancestors in Dam Excavation


BYLINE: Tom Hollaway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland - Swazi communities living in the construction site for a dam have expressed fear that the bones of their deceased relatives may be stolen and used for ritual purposes, when the graves are moved.

The graves will be moved as part of a resettlement programme to give way for the Maguga dam in north-west Swaziland. 

At a meeting held at Timphisini at the weekend, ministry of agriculture officials explained that the resettlement of communities to be affected by the Maguga dam and the enlargement of the Driekopis dam on the South African side of the border was necessary to prevent eventual spill-overs during floods.

The concerned villagers have called on the government to provide police protection during the exhumations as well as sacrificial beasts to be slaughtered by the affected families to appease the dead, the Times of Swaziland reported Monday.

The Maguga and Driekopis dams projects are part of a billion rand (over a quarter million U.S. dollars) Komati River basin development scheme which will open up large areas in northern Swaziland and across the South African border for agricultural and agro-industrial development.

The two governments will share the costs of the project with South Africa, providing three-fifths and Swaziland two-fifths.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 19, 1996


South Africa;
South African Airline Considers Clipping Its Wings


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa's national airline is reportedly giving serious consideration to halting some of its regular international routes. South African Airways (SAA), one of the continent's top air transport companies, is said to be moving into the red this year in the face of stiff foreign competition. The Senior Public Relations Manager, Leon Els, has confirmed that a drop of up to 10 percent this year in passenger numbers has led to an investigation into the airline's less profitable international routes.

He said no decision had been taken as yet on which routes might be discontinued, but he did confirm that 30 of the airline's pilots had been contracted out to far eastern airlines. More pilots may be contracted out in the future, he added.

The airline is also believed to be considering the possibility of cutting back on the nine new aircraft it ordered from Boeing in 1995, or at least postponing the acquisition of some of the aircraft.

SAA sources have indicated that the number of aircraft could be cut, or some of them could be leased rather than purchased, as a result of the current tight financial situation in which the airline finds itself.

A major reason for this situation is the fact that the South African Rand has lost 25 percent of its value against the American dollar in the past six months.

This means that the ordered aircraft would cost SAA considerably more than the 3.5 billion South African Rand budgeted for early in 1995.

In addition, much stronger international competition has pushed SAA into a loss situation for the first quarter of 1996.

There has been no official confirmation of the extent of the loss, but some unofficial estimates claim it could be as much as 23 million U.S dollars.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 19, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe Collects 244,000 Dollars For Solar Summit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe had by last Friday raised the

equivalent of 244,000 U.S dollars locally for the World Solar Summit scheduled to be held in Harare on September 16 and 17 this year.

The summit, whose goal is to promote worldwide utilization of solar energy and other renewable sources of energy to generate electricity, is expected to cost 9.4 million dollars. 

The World Solar Summit fund-raising committee's chairman, Peter Pamire, said the amount was contributed by several local companies and unnamed donors.

He said that some foreign donors -- Saudi Arabia, Spain, the European Union, Indonesia, Austria and Denmark -- have pledged a total of 750,000 dollars.

The Zimbabwe government still needs to raise an additional 4.1 million dollars to host the summit.

It will spend about 4.3 million dollars to purchase vehicles for the summit.

Pamire urged Zimbabweans and other people to donate towards the summit to ensure it is a success.

"The summit is...about handing over a usable environment for our future generations. I want to re-emphasize that it is small monies that make the big monies, so I would like to appeal to people to donate whatever amounts they can afford," he said.

More than 200 heads of state and government and heads of international organizations and institutions have been invited to attend the summit being co-organized with the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO).

United States and Africa;
South Africa Slams U.S. Action On Cuba


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa has come out strongly against the latest United States government action against Cuba.

Deputy Foreign Minister, Aziz Pahad, has criticized United States legislation tightening the economic embargo against Fidel Castro's regime, underlining the fact that Cuba offers excellent business opportunities for South African companies. 

President Nelson Mandela has gone on record in the past, saying that South Africa would not abandon its old friends to suit American wishes.

He pointed out that Cuba was one of the few countries to support his African National Congress during its armed struggle against Pretoria's apartheid regime.

The South African leader has issued an invitation to his Cuban counterpart to pay an official state visit to South Africa.

Pahad said South Africa has discussed the new anti-Cuban legislation with European and Latin-American countries. "We agree with the general position," he added, "that this is a bad law, and we have expressed our opposition."

It was announced earlier this week that another large group of Cuban doctors is scheduled to arrive in South Africa later this month to assist with health care in the rural areas of the country.

This will be the second group of Cuban doctors to work in South Africa in terms of a special agreement with Cuba.

The first team of about 100 doctors reported for duty in February.

Africa News


August 19, 1996


Science;
Villagers Deal With Unruly Elephants


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Luangwa - Villagers in Janeiro area of Chief Mpuka's area in Luangwa, have resorted to killing some elephants after growing tired of sending reports about the unruly beasts to the department of wildlife without who, however, failed to impose any control measures.

One such elephant was today found dead, about a hundred metres away from Chamitondo wildlife camp after being shot in the chest once by unknown people the previous night.

Chimitondo camp officer in charge, Green Mundia, that the animal had been shot at night and they had tried to trek its foot prints to establish where it had been shot from but could not come up with any results as many elephants had stampeded the area during the night. 

''We had heard three gun shots in the night, around 01:00 hours and in the morning a boy who was going to cut poles reported to us that he had found an elephant sleeping just near the camp. But when we went there we discovered that it was actually dead'', explained Scout Mundia.

He said he had sent a report to the ranger in charge of the area and was waiting for orders to dispose off the meat since villagers were up in arms with them for not controlling the animals.

Village headman Janeiro, flanked by three other headmen, Mbilisau, Kaombo and Chaulu said their subjects had suffered enough and would not go on with it like that without any action from the officers responsible.

The headmen lamented that they were not happy that their subjects had resorted to such action as killing the animals themselves without permission from the government but however appealed to the government to urgently look into their plight.

''We have stopped going to our fields now because of this same problem as the hunter that was sent here has now taken to drinking only,'' he moaned.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZIS

Africa News


August 19, 1996


Zambia;
Government Launches Book Policy


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - Government has pledged to support the book industry in the country to further enhance educational levels, education permanent, secretary Dr Sichalwe Kasanda said today.

Dr Kasanda said at the national book policy symposium that the ministry of education is fully committed to support useful developments that contribute to strenghthening of the educational system. 

The two-day symposium is being held at the Mulungushi International Conference Centre under the auspices of the Zambia Commission for UNESCO and will pave way for the formation of a national policy and the book development council of Zambia.

Officially opening the symposium, Dr Kasanda said the formation of a national book policy in Zambia is long overdue and that the ministry has taken due care to embrace all the needs of the stakeholders in order to come- up with the policy.

Dr Kasanda regretted however that Zambia is currently under a moribund state as regards the book industry which has kept the country in a state of intellectual isolation from the rest of the world, a situation he described as unfortunate.

And the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) has commended Zambia for the strides it has taken in formultaing a national book policy.

UNESCO programme specialist in education Dr Mauno Mbamba from Harare said Zambia is the first country among the five in the sub-region that participated in a study for textbook provision in 1993 which has formulated a national book policy to further develop the book industry.

The other countries are Zimbabwe, Namibia, Malawi and Bostwana.

Dr Mbamba appealed to the stakeholders to ensure that all essential elements of a national book policy including the collection of baseline data, research, interests of authors, publishers and printers are addressed so that the policy is a success.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

259 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Business;
Ezports Only Way Forward For Zambian Economy


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - The liberalisation of the economy and opening up of the market to free competition has forced many companies to look towards exporting as a way of survival and increasing capacity utilisation.

Export Board of Zambia (EBZ) chairman, Mr Kambidima Wotela, said this in Lusaka today when he officially opened an eight-month integrated export management training programme to take place for the first time in Zambia.

Mr Wotela who expressed sadness at the little attention paid in Zambia to specialised and practical training in export management said exporting had more challenges than selling on the domestic market. 

"There is usually lack of knowledge on the market and consumer behaviour while there is stiff competition from all over the world. The further one is from the market place, therefore, the more complex the marketing problems," he said.

He said it was for this reason that the EBZ approached the European Union for assistance in establishing a training programme which would look at the practical side of exporting.

He said the board has in the past run short courses in some aspects of export market and has worked closely with the human resource development project under USAID in undertaking management training programme for small scale business enterprises.

"This export management training programme has been designed after extensive consultation with Zambia's export companies and potential exporters. The programme is, therefore, a true reflection of the training needs of Zambian companies," he said.

And speaking at the same function, EBZ acting executive director, Mr Johnson Mwenya said the training programme was necessary because more rapid expansion of non-traditional exports which the Zambian economy needs to support its development objectives required high quality export and business skills.

He said in regional and wider international markets competition was intense and exporters must be sufficiently skilled to cope with the competition.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


AUGUST 19, 1996


South Africa;
Mandela Confirms He Will Step Down


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 705 words


 

JOHANNESBURG (PANA) - President Nelson Mandela of South Africa has confirmed that he will step down as president of the African National Congress (ANC) in 1997, and as the country's leader in 1999.

During the course of the weekend, Mandela informed the ANC's national executive committee that he would not make himself available for another term as the party's leader in December 1997, when elections are held for the next three-year term of office for office bearers. 

The committee, the highest decision making body of the ANC, also confirmed that in addition Mandela had formally announced that he would not be available for re-election as president of South Africa. His term of office expires in 1999, when the next democratic general elections are to be held.

The committee said that it respected Mandela's decision, and also expressed its profound appreciation for the sterling service he had rendered to both the party and the country in a lifetime of struggle.

Informed ANC sources are of the opinion that Mandela's decision is likely to open the door to deputy president Thabo Mbeki to take over as president of the party in 1997, and possibly become the country's leader in 1999.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


AUGUST 19, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Moves Against Boutros-Ghali Resisted


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

NEW YORK (PANA) - The United States' plan to find a replacement for the United Nations secretary-general, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, before the American presidential elections in November, may be facing some resistance in the Security Council, a U.S. newspaper has reported.

The influential New York Times reported Monday that the council, on whose recommendation the appointment of the secretary-general is made by the General Assembly, was not as keen as the U.S. to discuss the issue now.

"When Tono Eitel, Germany's representative at the UN and this month's security council president, polled delegations in recent days, he found only one, the American, that wanted to schedule a debate on the issue any time soon," the newspaper reported. 

It added that the consensus among the 14 other members of the council was that there was no urgency to act, "in part because a secretary-general has usually been chosen later in the year and in part because the Clinton administration, with its record of policy shifts, may change its mind after the elections."

Boutros-Ghali has said he will seek re-election when his current five-year term expires on Dec. 31, but the U.S., which accuses him of not having carried out enough reform at the UN, has promised to veto his candidacy.

"The U.S. has made its position clear, and therefore people who think that we might change our minds are wrong," the paper quoted the U.S. permanent representative at the UN, Madeleine Albright, as saying.

Albright said that countries that insisted on supporting Boutros-Ghali, " rather than working to find a candidate who is somebody who will have the general confidence not only of the U.S. but others, should understand that the American decision is irrevocable."

"One of the reasons we made the decision when we did was to allow other candidates to come forward," she said, adding: "I think that it is a little bit irresponsible not to be more active for other council members in terms of trying to figure out how the process ought to work."

The New York Times reported that the U.S. government's efforts to belittle Boutros-Ghali's achievements, and its warning to UN staff members not to use their positions to campaign for his re-election, had generated new sympathy for the secretary-general.

The Organisation of African Unity, the League of Arab nations and China, among others, have also expressed their support for the secretary-general's re-election.

The 73-year-old Egyptian diplomat is the first African UN secretary-general.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


AUGUST 19, 1996


Swaziland;
Swazi Communities Fear For Ancestors in Dam Excavation


BYLINE: Tom Hollaway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - Swazi communities living in the construction site for a dam have expressed fear that the bones of their deceased relatives may be stolen and used for ritual purposes, when the graves are moved.

The graves will be moved as part of a resettlement programme to give way for the Maguga dam in north-west Swaziland. 

At a meeting held at Timphisini at the weekend, ministry of agriculture officials explained that the resettlement of communities to be affected by the Maguga dam and the enlargement of the Driekopis dam on the South African side of the border was necessary to prevent eventual spill-overs during floods.

The concerned villagers have called on the government to provide police protection during the exhumations as well as sacrificial beasts to be slaughtered by the affected families to appease the dead, the Times of Swaziland reported Monday.

The Maguga and Driekopis dams projects are part of a billion rand (over a quarter million U.S. dollars) Komati River basin development scheme which will open up large areas in northern Swaziland and across the South African border for agricultural and agro-industrial development.

The two governments will share the costs of the project with South Africa, providing three-fifths and Swaziland two-fifths.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


AUGUST 19, 1996


South Africa;
South African Airline Considers Clipping Its Wings


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's national airline is reportedly giving serious consideration to halting some of its regular international routes. South African Airways (SAA), one of the continent's top air transport companies, is said to be moving into the red this year in the face of stiff foreign competition. The Senior Public Relations Manager, Leon Els, has confirmed that a drop of up to 10 percent this year in passenger numbers has led to an investigation into the airline's less profitable international routes. 

He said no decision had been taken as yet on which routes might be discontinued, but he did confirm that 30 of the airline's pilots had been contracted out to far eastern airlines. More pilots may be contracted out in the future, he added.

The airline is also believed to be considering the possibility of cutting back on the nine new aircraft it ordered from Boeing in 1995, or at least postponing the acquisition of some of the aircraft.

SAA sources have indicated that the number of aircraft could be cut, or some of them could be leased rather than purchased, as a result of the current tight financial situation in which the airline finds itself.

A major reason for this situation is the fact that the South African Rand has lost 25 percent of its value against the American dollar in the past six months.

This means that the ordered aircraft would cost SAA considerably more than the 3.5 billion South African Rand budgeted for early in 1995.

In addition, much stronger international competition has pushed SAA into a loss situation for the first quarter of 1996.

There has been no official confirmation of the extent of the loss, but some unofficial estimates claim it could be as much as 23 million U.S dollars.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


AUGUST 19, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe Collects 244,000 Dollars For Solar Summit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe had by last Friday raised the

equivalent of 244,000 U.S dollars locally for the World Solar Summit scheduled to be held in Harare on September 16 and 17 this year.

The summit, whose goal is to promote worldwide utilization of solar energy and other renewable sources of energy to generate electricity, is expected to cost 9.4 million dollars. 

The World Solar Summit fund-raising committee's chairman, Peter Pamire, said the amount was contributed by several local companies and unnamed donors.

He said that some foreign donors -- Saudi Arabia, Spain, the European Union, Indonesia, Austria and Denmark -- have pledged a total of 750,000 dollars.

The Zimbabwe government still needs to raise an additional 4.1 million dollars to host the summit.

It will spend about 4.3 million dollars to purchase vehicles for the summit.

Pamire urged Zimbabweans and other people to donate towards the summit to ensure it is a success.

"The summit is...about handing over a usable environment for our future generations. I want to re-emphasize that it is small monies that make the big monies, so I would like to appeal to people to donate whatever amounts they can afford," he said.

More than 200 heads of state and government and heads of international organizations and institutions have been invited to attend the summit being co-organized with the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO).

AUGUST 19, 1996


United States and Africa;
South Africa Slams U.S. Action On Cuba


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa has come out strongly against the latest United States government action against Cuba.

Deputy Foreign Minister, Aziz Pahad, has criticized United States legislation tightening the economic embargo against Fidel Castro's regime, underlining the fact that Cuba offers excellent business opportunities for South African companies. 

President Nelson Mandela has gone on record in the past, saying that South Africa would not abandon its old friends to suit American wishes.

He pointed out that Cuba was one of the few countries to support his African National Congress during its armed struggle against Pretoria's apartheid regime.

The South African leader has issued an invitation to his Cuban counterpart to pay an official state visit to South Africa.

Pahad said South Africa has discussed the new anti-Cuban legislation with European and Latin-American countries. "We agree with the general position," he added, "that this is a bad law, and we have expressed our opposition."

It was announced earlier this week that another large group of Cuban doctors is scheduled to arrive in South Africa later this month to assist with health care in the rural areas of the country.

This will be the second group of Cuban doctors to work in South Africa in terms of a special agreement with Cuba.

The first team of about 100 doctors reported for duty in February.

LANGUAGE: English
