266 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Business;
Nigerian Capital Market Not the Elixir


BYLINE: Akaninyene Esiere, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Lagos - Despite concerted efforts to lure more patrons, Nigeria's capital market remains unattractive to many firms and of limited benefit to listed companies.

All over the world, the capital market is known for the big boast it gives listed firms which, in turn, entices others to rush to enlist on the stock exchange. Nigeria might as well be an exception. After more thatn 30 years of its operation, the Nigerian Stock Exchange has listed just 183 companies in the primary and secondary markets. Worse, a chunk of these firms are Nigerian subsidiaries of traditional institutions. 

The listing of indigenous firms on The Exchange is grindingly low. Compared to what obtains in other developing economies, Nigeria's is yet to register its mark. For example, there are well over 500 quoted firms in the South African Stock Exchange with a market capitalization of about $300 billion while Chile's capitalization is above the $100 billion mark. In comparisoon, Nigeria's 183 quoted firms' capitalization is straggling at less than $2 billion, the equivalent of just one medium-sized firm in a developed economy.

An illustration of how slowly Nigerians are taking their companies to the capital market could be seen in the fact that for all of this year, just two firms -- Lonman Publishers and African Paints -- have been listed on The Exchange. Even to chronic optimist, the figure is baffling, considering that the repeal of the much vilified Exchanged Control Act of 1962 in January of last year and the promulgation of the supposedly private sector-friendly Investment Promotion Commission Decree eight months later was expected to literally force company owners to take their firms to the public. Thinking was that quoted firms would benefit tremedously from foreign investment funds.

Two major reasons have been adduced for this disappointingly low patronage of the Exchange by Nigerian enterprises, of which Corporate Affairs Commission says it has already registered a little over a million. Many argue that it costs a fortune to source for funds in the capital market. African Paints, Plc, one of the latest entrants into the market, discovered this as soon as it got listed. On July 30 when the shares of the company were formally listed, Gbenga Akinnawo, chairman and chief executive of the company, said he coughed out a staggering N15 million of the N75 million he went to raise as sundry charges. He lamented that "the capital market which is supposed to be a source for cheap funds is having its funds priced above the money market rate."

The various charges go to the Securities and the Exchange Commission, the Nigerian Stock Exchange, brokerage firms, issuing houses and other third parties such as solicitors and accounting firms. This is in addition to the mandatory stamp duty of .00025 per cent of total share value. It is probably due to this outcry that SEC has begun a campaign for the reduction of the percentage of the charges. May 20, SEC reduced its percentage charge on securities worth N500 million and below from 1.5 per cent to one per cent. The George Akamiokhor-led SEC said the reduction was "targeted at the small and medium-scale industries with a view to attracting them to seek quotation on The Nigerian Stock Exchange."

The commission is also currently negotiating with the Chartered Institute of Stockbrokers with a view to reducing the brokers fee from the current three per cent of the total value sought. It is hoped that this wil entice more firms to the capital market.

However, many analyst still argue that in the long run, it is still cheaper to source funds from the capital market than from the money market. Abiodun Akinsola, managing partner of Bond Consulting, a financial consultancy, argues that funds from the capital market are for long term investments. He maintains that "the advantage to the borrower (company) is that the lender (shareholder) has a stake in the company," and that fees paid in the process are once and for all while "interest" is paid in the form of dividend only when the company makes profit. In contrast, profit or not, interest on funds from the money market must still be paid along with the principal. What this means, says Akinsola, is that the money market advantageous for short term purposes. Akinsola traced Nigerians' slow dance to the capital market to their reluctance to give up control of their firms no matter their financial state. "Nigerians," he said, "rebuff economics of scale due to our basic orientation to business which is that we prefer to have absolute control of the businesss. The saying that Nigerians would rather rule in hell than serve in heaven is pointedly true of our businessmen."

Perhaps, the country's business tycoons need to carefully read the stories of their foreign counterparts before deciding to embrace the bitter-sweet pill of capitalism.

Issue Date: August 26, 1996


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


267 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Nigeria;
A New Twist For Political Parties


BYLINE: Yusuph Olaniyonu, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1747 words


 

Lagos - The disruption of the party registration exercise and moves to make politicians start afresh heighten tension in political circles and create doubts about what the designs of the government are.

It came too sudden and too soon. Barely five days inot the much-awaited verifcation of the claims submitted by the 18 political associations seeking registration as parties, an order from the headquarters of the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria suddenly halted the exercise. According to reports, the order came from Sumner Dagogo-Jack, NECON chairman, directing state administrative secretaries to recall all the field officers back to the state headquarters for a reverification of data so far obtained by them.

Since no definite reason was given for the suspension, speculations soon started making the rounds. One report had it that the order to suspend the exercise originated from the presidency, which was purportedly irked abut reports from security agents indicting NECON officials at the local government level fro allegedly extorting money from politicians so as to present favourable reports of their claims. Another suggested that the verification exercise ran into a storm as NECON officials found out that " some mistakes were discovered in the sorting and distribution of claims of political associations." The temporary suspension would, therefore, enable the electoral body to correct the mistakes discovered in the field. The latter report was credited to Steve Osemeke, NECON chief spokesman. 

More conflicting information was to come from the commission last week. In one of the several reactions from the headquarters in Abuja, Ibrahim Biu, the deputy director of public affairs, denied that the verifiation exercise was ever suspended. He said: "As far as we are concerned, our men are still on the field. You can see for yourself, the commission's (office) is still empty. " The drama got to a height on Monday when Dagogo-Jack and the seven national sommissioners in charge of the zones held a four-hour meeting with officials of the presidency in Abuja. The meeting continued on Tuesday, with the Transition Implementation Committee holding yet another meeting the following day.

Theweek, however, gathered that the suspension was at the instance of the government. A top government official whose portfolio is related to security matters is said to be the motivator of the events that led to the suspension of the verification exercise. The man credited to be the brain behind the emergence of the United National Congress, UNC, which is now the behemoth among the political associations, was eventually able to convince Sani Abacha, the head of state, that security reports had indicated that the verification exercisie by NECON would end in stalemate.

To win over Abacha, the smooth operator claimed that only the UNCP has the spread and machinery to scale the registration hurdles. This reality, he said, would finally lead government having no option than to dismiss the entire registration process and then resort to creating parties fiat as was done in the Babangida era. He suggested that the head of state should order NECON to halt the registration exercise and then call for a review of the NECON guidelines with provisions for the 18 associations to merge and create "very few broad-based political groups."

After listening to the security chief, Abacha summoned Mamman Nasir, chairman of the TLC, Dagogo-Jack, Hammas, the political adviser to the head of state, and Didado Idris, secretary to the government of the federation, to a meeting on Friday, August 9. At the meeting, the security chief eas told to present his argument before everyone. After he had done that, Nasir picked a hole in the argument that only UNCP would meet the NECON guidelines and therefore should be a model for other associations to copy. The TIC chief argued that there is no legal basis for the recognition of any group known as UNCP as its constituent groups submitted registration materials on individual basis.

It was at this point that the head of state recommended that the presidency, NECON and TIC should harmonise their positions and make recommendations to the government. But before last Monday when the meeting was scheduled to hold, the security chief had instigated NECON to produce a position paper supporting his views. The NECOn paper predicated its recommendations on the preliminary reports of its field officers and then argued that only a merger plan would save the registration exercise. It was the NECON paper that formed the nucleus of deliberations at last Monday's meeting which also extended till the following day.

Theweek learnt that by Wednesday when TIC met to ratify the new decisions with presidency officials, it had been agreed that the registration exercise would start afresh.

The reviewed guidelines announced last Thursday by Dagogo-Jack gives all the associations 14 days to go and merge along similarity of ideology and programme of action. The merging groups will then have to submit the name of their new association, the manifesto, constitution and symbols to NECON.

They are also expected to furnish NECON with the names of all the officers at the national, state and local government levels. All the materials are to get to NECON by August 29. NECON will announce the approved mergers between August 30 and 31. The verification exercise would commence on September 2 and end on the 17th. The announcement on which parties to be registered will be made in October.

The proposal on merger at the instance of government confirmed earlier reports by Theweek that the government is at the head of the current drive by many political associations to fuse for the purpose of creating braod-based political associations. Sources disclosed that the government is instigating groups with similar ideological coloration and whose sponsors have had long- time association to come together. It is as a result of this effort of government that the United Nigerian Congress, the United Nigeria Party and the Soldiarity Group of Nigeria and the Grassroots Democratic Movement have also merged. That the government is interested on this alliance is not in doubt. Sources say that government officials have mounted pressure on Umaru Shinkafi, a chieftain of the All Nigeria Congress, to join the DPN. Part of the calculation of this lobby is that the ANC will not be registered since its sponsors have not been responding to calls for them to merger with groups.

Theweek learnt that government is already suggesting that promoters of the People's Progressive Party should merge with their colleagues in the Social Progressive Party and the Progressive Party of Nigeria. The suggestion has not borne fruit because of the schism among top members of the associations based on their conflicting roles in the events following the annulled June 12, 1993 presidential elections.

The ultimate aim of the government is that three broad-based parties representing the left, right and centre of the political spectrum should emerge. Government is already thinking that a minimum of three parties and a maximum of five should be announced, possibly in the presidential broadcast of Ocotober 1.

Reactions of politicians on the various manoeuvres on the registration exercise differ. Chris Okolie of the Committee for National Consensus feigned ignorance of the suspension of the verification exercise. He said last week that reports from the northeast and northwest zones of the party indicated that "if anything, NECON officials have not only visited local government headquarters, they have also extended the exercise up to the wards, thereby make it more rigorous." Okolie, however, insisted that the new attempt at reviewing the guidelines is belated and bound to lead to more confusion. " Merger groups was not part of the guidelines that NECON gave us, " said he. " Parties have worked to satisfy current and subsisting guidelines."

Olorunfunmi Bashorun, Okolie's opposite number in People's Consensus Party, was more vociferous in his rejection of the new efforts of government. He fumed: "If it is true that there is such proposal, then the government can be rightly said to be sponsoring associations because there is no justification for a second guideline if there is no plan to assist weak associations."

Jimmy Imo of the PPP spoke in the same vein. He likened the new scenario to a teacher resetting the examination question after the students had submitted their answer scripts to await the result. "Are they saying they are going to change the rule of the game in the middle of the game?" he asked.

But Kenny Martins of the Nation Builders Congress would rather "wait and let NECON make clarifications on what is happening before making logical deductions."

The "clarifications" have finally come, and much earlier than expected. For already stretched politicians who now have to return to the drawing board against their wish, that is naother reason to be sad.

With Emmanuel Ado

Issue Date: August 26, 1996


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Nigeria;
Hemlock in Academia


BYLINE: Ademola Adedoyin and Peter Akpona, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1640 words


 

Lagos - The administration proposes to sack all striking lecturers and close down the universities for one academic year. Who will flunk this test of wills?

At first it looked like a joke. It had all started last March 25 when the Academic Staff Union of Universities, exasperated by government's rebuff of their campaign for implementation of the 1992 agreement with ASUU, embarked on a series of warning strikes to force the authorities to the roundtable. Ignored by Mohammed Liman, the Minister of Education, the lecturers went on a full blown strike April 9. Rather than negotiate the September 3, 1992 agreement, scheduled to be reviewed after three years, the government chose to repudiate it. More than that, it refused to enter into any dialogue on the issues of autonomy for, and better funding of, the universities, as demanded by ASUU.

ASUU, on its part, ignored government orders to return to work. Withdrawal of recognition from the national ASUU did not compel the lecturers to heed government's instruction to negotiated locally with the various univeristy governing councils. Not even moves by vice-chancellors to stop the pay of the striking lecturers as directed by government could do the trick. While some lecturers reportedly indicatd interest in returning to work, a majority continued to reaffirm confidence in the ASUU national executive led by Asisi Asobie, insisting that government should negotiate with it. 

Last weeek, there were hints that the administration might have exhausted its patience. Top-level sources told Theweek that government had made up its mind to come down hard on the "recalcitrant" lecturers. The sources said that government was considering a mass sack of the lecturers and closure of the country's 39 universities for one academic session.

Sources at the Federal Ministry of Education disclosed to Theweek that but for the last minute effort of Iyabo Anisulowo, minister of state in the ministry, the government by last Thursday would have announce the sack. She was said to have prevailed on Aso Rock to consider the initiative of a group of professors acting under the aegis of the All Professor Conference of Nigeria, APCON, who have promised to thaw the ice of confrontation between ASUU and the government. By the end of the week, however, it was obvious that the initiative had collapsed. The all-professor conference could not hold. Some of the professors not only disassociate themselves from the conference, they joined ranks with ASUU in condemning what they described as the strike- breaking antics of APCON.

With the collapse of the apparently last initiative, the government seems set to wield the stick. Sources at the federal ministry say the government will soon brief the committee of vice-chancellors on the draconinan measures it intends to take so that they could make security arrangements on the campuses when the sack hammer descends.

As if to stoke the already volatile situations, angry students are warming up to join the fray. Fear that the nation might witness another students' unrest similar to the 'Ali must go' demonstrations of the 1970s rose sharply last week following a seven-day ultimatum which the National Association of Nigerian students, gave to the federal government to restore normalcy to the nation's univerisity system. The ultimatum came through a statement issued by Sylvester Onoja, national mobilisation officer of NANS.

Investigations revealed that before the student's ultimatium, issued in Jos, NANS had discussed extensively the ongoing strike by ASUU, and the subsequent banning of the union by the federal government. Until now, NANS had maintained a studied silence which it says was borne out of a "matured and disciplined students unionism," and the resolve by the students' leaders to "allow an employer-employee dispute to be resolved without interference."

But, after watching the gladiators for the fourth month running and seeing no solution to the dispute, the students have become militant. As Onoja puts it, "we have been watching with melancholy, the criminal scuttling and frustration of the aspiration of Nigeria Students occasioned by the failure of government and ASUU to reach a compromise in the face-off" and warned that: "The high degree of patience being exercised by students union leaders in universities across the country should not be mistaken for lack of courage to act." NANS, through the statement, directed students union leaders in universities across the country to report on campus if they have not already done so.

At the University of Lagos, Theweek found that a number of students had arrived the campus apparently in keeping with the NANS directive. The students, however, maintained that their presence on campus had nothing to do with the impending showdown with the authorities. They said that students were on campus to pursue their private studies in the hope that the lecturers would decide to go back to the classrooms.

At the Bayero University, Kano, which officially re-opened July 16, normal academic activities are yet to resume. By last week, the few lecturers who have agreed to return to classes were engaged in a game of wits with those who have vowed to continue with the strike. Theweek found that even though the school has re-opened, academic activities were episodic, a situation that has prompted some of the final year students to express their doubts to Heads of Department. Theweek learnt that the students were assured that in the event of the lingering strike being called off soon, a crash programme will be organised to graduate them on schedule. But if the strike continued, all courses that could not be offered as a result would be regarded as carry-over courses.

To worsen the problem of the Bayero University, those lecturers who volunteered to return to the classroom have been less than enthusiastic. Some of them merely wrote their names down as willing to teach in order to collect their pay after which they absconded. To confounded the situation, the population of the returning students is minimal. The bulk of the university students, as indeed, their colleague elsewhere have decided to watch the face- off from the safety of their homes. In desperation, the authorities of Bayero University have resorted to threats to rusticate students who fail to show up. In the meantime, the local ASUU at BUK is unimpressed by any form of threat. In one of its numerous meetings last week, the union strenghtened its resolve to continue with the strike even though salaries had been stopped. Ibrahim Lawal, chairman of the local chapters says that as long as the national ASUU is on strike, BUK lecturers will continue to stay out of the classroom. "No retreat, no surrender until our demands are met," he affirmed.

Lecturers elsewhere equally seem uncompromising. Rather, they are surprised about reports that the government has called for a list of vocal and militant lecturers for punishment, and the purported dismissal of some 100 lecturers at the University of Nigeria, Nsukka. Similar reports have also been received from the University of Ilorin and the Federal University of Technology, Owerri.

Such arm-twisting appears to have been in vain. From Edo State University, Ekpoma, for example, the ASUU branch under the chairmanship of Clement Edokpayi has stated that only peace brokered through discussions with ASUU as a national body can get them back to the classroom. The local ASUU there has described as a false claim, the information published by the university authority in its bulletin of July 4, to the effect that 12 per cent of the lecturers have agreed to return to work.

At the University of Ilorin, reports have it that the ASUU branch there has washed its hands off the school authority's on-going search for a successor for the out-going vice-chancellor. According to a statement signed by B. Lawal and Kola Joseph, chairman and secretary respectively, lecturers are on strike and cannot take part in the search for a new vice-chancellor. This action casts doubts on the claim by the university authority that over 60 per cent of the lecturers in the institution have signified their readiness to resume work.

Perhaps it was an indication of the way matters might turn in the days ahead that at the Univeristy of Lagos, mobile policemen in armoured personnel carrier have been stationed at the gate, a situation which the students on campus say they do not find funny. Of course, nobody does.

With Dan Sule


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Nigeria;
Politicians Wait As Commission Registers Parties


BYLINE: Yuseph Olaniyonu, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Lagos - Politicians remain restless even as NECON commences verification of claims by the 18 associations seeking registration as political parties.

As part of the preparation for a press briefing on the readiness of his association for the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria's verification exercise, Chris Okolie, spokesman of the Committee for National Consensus, decided to arm himself with first hand information from the party's secretariats in all the states. He physically visited some state capitals while in other cases he collected information through the telephone and correspondence with state chairmen and secretaries.

"From what I gathered, our people are ready for NECON officials and the national secretariat has sent instructions to the state secretariats for the necessary officials to remain at their duty posts during the period of the verification exercise," Okolie later told reporters. 

Okolie's anxiety to ensure that nothing goes wrong in the CNC gives a fair idea of the frantic efforts being made by politicians to ensure that their associations survive the current exercise to register parties for the new political dispensation. Two weeks after the submission of registration materials, top officers of the 18 associations are still busy putting finishing touches to their plans to meet the NECON verification team. Most of the associations are hiring offices to serve as secretariats while those who already have offices are seeking to make them functional.

On August 3, members of the national executive committee of the Nation Builders Congress were in Ilorin to launch the Kwara State chapter on Abdul Aziz Atta Road. The launch came a few days after a similar ceremoney was performed to commence the use of the Abuja secretariat in Asokoro district.

For some other groups, the major assignment is to provide directions that would make the secretariats easily indentifiable to NECON officials. The People's Consensus Party recently installed a signboard in front of its office in Ogba, Lagos. Another imposing signboard, glowing with its multi- color paints, has sprouted up on Adeniyi Jones Street indicating that the United Nigeria Congress, the All Nigeria Congress, the Nigeria Center Party and the United Nigerian Party have acquired offices in very strategic locations for their state and local government chapters. The four parties have also not rested their mobilisation campaigns for new members.

The rush to establish offices and make them conspicuous for NECON verifiers is predicted on the directive given to NECON officials by the headquarters of the commission on August 1. In a 27-page checklist handed over to the zonal coordinators of the exercise, NECON insisted that its officers would not waste time on associations whose claims could not be easily ascertained and authenticated. As part of the verification, NECON officers were instructed not to condone any execuse for the absence of persons charged with the responsibility of furnishing them with membership cards. The verifiers are also to check members' faces against the photographs in their party forms submitted to NECON.

NECON officials are also to take special notice of a situation where a party member could not be located at the given address. Where a member is properly located, he will be expected to answer questions on how he was recruited, what dues he paid to join and names of his ward leaders.

Sumner Dagogo-Jack, NECON chairman, who briefed the six zonal co-ordinators, warned that "the claims to be verified are clearly defined" and that they (the officials) "should not be influenced by any other factors or consideration."

Theweek, however, learnt that NECON's verification team is not the only cause of anxiety among the political groups. The involvement of personnel of the State Security Services and the National Orientation Agency in the verification exercise is getting the politicians more worried. The security agents are said to be working independently to interrogate members of the national and state executives of the associations on their source of funds, sponsors, political antecedents and assets. As at last week, state officers of the PCP in Abia and Kebbi states had been visited by security agents. In some instances, the security agents were said to have made repeated calls to demand more facts from the affected politicians.

As soon as information reached the national headquarters of the PCP on the exercise by the SSS, it called a meeting of the national executive committee of the association. Olorunfunmi Bashorun, the publicity secretary, said the meeting held in Abuja last Thursday amd attended by state chairmen and secretaries of the association, was convened to take progress report on the verification exercise and to give appropriate instructions to the state party leaders. "We realised that NECON concentrated on state and local government secretariats of the associations. We had to meet and discuss the developments with respect to the registration exercise," said Bashorun.

Reports, however, indicate that the information sought by the SSS officials are not entirely different from the ones sought by NECON officials. At the Lagos State office of PCP, the chairman, Rahman Owokoniran played host to NECON officials last Tuesday. He said he was asked questions bordering on how the group acquired its office, the identity of the sponsors, the source of the funds, qualifications of its staff and the membership spread of the party.

Apart from making efforts to meet the immediate requirements of NECON, the People's Progressive Party has sent word to its state and local government officials to continue the weekly meetings at the state and ward levels. The idea, according to Chukwuemeka Ezeife, PPP secretary and former governor of Anambara State, is to attract more members. "We have not closed registration as we expect new members to join us," he said.

Like the PPP, the CNC, Okolie disclosed last week, is using the period of the verification exercise to further spread its tentacles to the grassroots and popularise its "centrist, consensus oriented ideology."


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Kenya;
State Reacts Sharply To Churches' Call For Reforms


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

Nairobi - As expected, the government of Kenya has reacted sharply to calls by churches in the country for wide ranging review of the Constitution ahead of General Elections due before December 1997.

Office of the President Minister Kipkalya Kones charged that the Catholic church and the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK), an umbrella body comprising 35 protestant churches, eight associate members and seven fraternal members, were working in league with the Opposition and foreigners to agitate for a boycott of the forthcoming election and "create mayhem through civil disobedience."

His strongly worded statement came 48 hours after the country's 22 Catholic bishops and the NCCK separately issued calls for urgent political reforms in Kenya.

And the Secretary General of the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party Mr. Joseph Kamotho, who is also the Minister for Education, described the churches' call "as another revolutionary idea of overthrowing the Constitution which has served us well since independence."

But the new pro-Nuncio in Nairobi, barely two months old in office, urged Kenya's politicians critical of the churches' stand to stop being emotional " and take time to read and analyze carefully the contents of the bishops' Pastoral Letter before criticising it." 

He said Pope John Paul II fully backed the call by the Catholic bishops for a review of the Constitution and an all-party dialogue on the composition of a new Electoral Commission. Archbishop Tonucci reiterated: "I say the recent Pastoral Letter issued by the Kenyan bishops has the backing of the Holy Father."

In their hard hitting statements, the Kenyan churches cautioned the government that unless it was willing to initiate wide-ranging political reforms as well as an all-party dialogue on the composition of a new Electoral Commission, they would have no alternative but to call on their followers to boycott the General Election due next year. The term of validity of the current Electoral Commission, headed by Justice (Rtd.) Zacchaeus Chesoni expires this November.

The Pastoral Letter of the Catholic bishops was entitled, Our Social Responsibility while the NCCK presented the council's concerns in a statement sub-titled, Our Common Future, drawn from the outcome of the 53rd General Assembly held in the coastal town of Mombasa late July.

Both Catholics and Protestants particularly want the Constitution amended so that the successful presidential candidate is one who wins more than 50 per cent of the popular vote, rather than the stipulated 25 per cent in five provinces.

The NCCK pointed out that on New Year's Eve (January 1, 1995) President Moi promised to initiate a review process but this has never happened. And the Chairman of the Kenya Episcopal Conference Archbishop Zacheus Okoth, told a news conference soon after the release of the Pastoral Letter on August 6, that "the homework has been done. Kenyans are ready and in some areas only two days are required for the review process."

Both the NCCK and Catholics are unhappy that under the current provisions, the Electoral Commission "is appointed solely by the Head of State and lacks true independence."

They proposed that in order to achieve a balance, the opposition and other civic bodies like the Law Society of Kenya (LSK) be involved. Individual nominees would then elect the head of the commission.

In their letter, the Catholic bishops lamented the breakdown in the provision of health, education and transport services. They also questioned the motive behind the establishment of a bullet factory at Eldoret, in Kenya's Rift Valley Province which the government says is for the country's military.

The on-going construction of an airport in Eldoret, some 270 kilometres north-west of Nairobi, the third major airport in Kenya after Nairobi's Jomo Kenyatta International Airport and Mombasa's Moi International Airport, was another issue that raised nationwide controversy particularly in 1994. A cross section of Kenyans, notably the opposition, outspoken individuals and civic groups, generally expressed concern that a third airport was not a priority development project.

They were of the opinion that Kenyan roads, which among other transport needs serve as the only means of transporting farm produce for the ordinary person, were in poor shape and needed more urgent attention than the airport project in the Rift Valley Province town. But the government has gone ahead with the project whose approval earlier on, passed through the normal parliamentary procedures. President Moi comes from the Rift Valley region.

Lately this year, news about the construction of the bullet factory in the same town became a subject of much speculation and debate, particularly among opposition legislators who questioned the motive behind such a factory.

Another issue that worries many Kenyans is the land grabbing mania, wherein the politically correct are rewarded with parcels of public land ("plots"), sometimes without regard to the future. Graveyards, public toilets, and children's playgrounds have become easy prey for the plot grabbers.

Although President Daniel arap Moi recently intervened to stop land related malpractices, the move was generally viewed as coming too late.

The Catholic bishops in their latest appeal said the Small Christian Communities (SCCs), which are dynamic neighbourhood social action and prayer groups would be used to raise public awareness of the evils of vote buying and election rigging.

The Catholic clergy were at pains to stress non-violent agitation for change "even when provoked." The head of the Catholic Church in Kenya Maurice Cardinal Otunga noted that the churches "had played their role by pointing out injustices. God will take up whips and punish those who failed to heed this message."

In their press conference the same day, Protestant churches, through the Chairman of the NCCK Bishop Joseph Wesonga and General Secretary Pastor Mutava Musyimi called for "basic reforms" to be implemented before Kenyans should accept to participate in the next general elections.

The NCCK letter to Christians also lamented that more than 30 years after independence, Kenyans were still subject to repressive colonial laws introduced by the British in the 40s and 50s as a measure to curtail the activities of the pre-independence Mau Mau freedom fighters.

They also cited among what they called "anti-people laws" the Chief's Authority Act and various sedition and treason provisions of the Penal Code of Kenya.

They called for a new system of grassroots administration, preferably based on the concept of electing leaders. A similar process is in operation in Uganda and Tanzania through Resistance Committees (RCs) and Local Committees (LCs) respectively.

The NCCK also called for full freedom for the public media in Kenya, and the freeing of airwaves by the government.

Other issues covered by the churches include the provision of national identity cards to all eligible persons over 18 years of age and the financing of the forthcoming general election. In the last General Election, KANU, then being the only ruling party, had access to state funds. In a multi-party state, all political parties should have access to government funds, in preparation for general elections.

Meanwhile, Mr. Njenga Mungai, outspoken Member of Parliament for Molo constituency in Nakuru District, and a strong critic of the government's inability to effectively end the 1991 to 1994 ethnic land clashes which seriously affected his area, says he fears the rush to review the Constitution could throw the country into turmoil. He instead calls for a gradual process of change.

Addressing a press conference in the Rift Valley Province town of Nakuru, some 160 kilometres north-west of Nairobi on August 13, the Opposition Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (FORD-Asili) legislator asked the opposition not to put pressure on President Daniel arap Moi with their quest for constitutional reforms.

He warned that if reforms were implemented in a random manner, Kenya faced the risk of being plunged into chaos as has happened in Zaire and Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


271 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Publishers Concerned About Pricing Of Books and Censorship


BYLINE: Tim Chigodo, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1734 words


 

Nairobi - For the second time in as many years, the annual Zimbabwe International Book Fair (ZIBF) was eclipsed by the row over the presence of the Gays and Lesbians Association of Zimbabwe (GALZ), a group whose activities would not be discussed in public according to indigenous tradition of the majority Zimbabweans.

Before the official close of business, initially set for 6 pm on August 3, exhibitors whose turnout was 25 per cent higher than previous years, had packed away their wares.

Despite the significant growth in the number of exhibitors, the fair appeared to have been losing its glory in the eyes of the public over the last two years, if attendance figures are anything to go by.

Most stands resembled the empty symbolic GALZ stand, whose members were missing for the third day since winning their July 31 court battle to be allowed to man a stand. Although GALZ had the right to exhibit pamphlets and the like for the two days of the fair, the group not only failed to exhibit but had no one manning their stand. 

Last year, 31,000 people visited the book fair, about 2,000 less than the record 33,000 figure in 1994. It was during the 1995 event that GALZ was granted permission to exhibit at the fair, although the decision was reversed at the request of the Zimbabwean government.

Organisers were silent on the GALZ issue and attributed the decline to the absence of school children. "The event did not fall on any of the school holidays, hence the decline in attendance," said the spokesman.

At the 1995 ZIBF, the banning of GALZ from exhibiting was accentuated by Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe's strong stance thus; "If we accept homosexuality as a right, as is being argued by the association of sodomites and sexual perverts, what moral fibre shall our society ever have to deny organized drug addicts or even those given to bestiality, the rights they might claim and allege they possess under the rubrics of 'individual freedom' and 'human rights', including the freedom of the press to write ...on them?"

But for GALZ Administrator, Keith Groddard, the association's participation at the "1996 ZIBF represents strong advances in the battle for freedom of expression and cultural diversity in Zimbabwe."

In a statement, Groddard noted that culture belonged to all in Zimbabwe and dictations from politicians that all persons within a nation shall conform to a single set of cultural norms is loathsome in the extreme and to be challenged forcefully at every time."

Zimbabwe's censorship board had banned GALZ organisation from participating at this and any other fair in the country, a decision which was later nullified by the High Court.

One exhibitor who sought anonymity expressed concern about security at the event saying; "There have been a lot of threats against some aspects of this event. Nothing has taken place so far and we cannot take chances," he added, as he stored away books long before closing time.

Most parents and schools would not allow their children to visit the fair, for fear that their young ones would get the wrong message from the exhibitors, it was established.

In 1995, some 50,000 visitors were expected at the annual exhibition. Entrance fees were introduced in 1994 and these have been in place since, despite calls to accord visitors free entry to the exhibition, whose theme this year was Books for Business.

About $100,000 worth of books were sold at the fair's bookshop, a figure which fell short of last year's figure. The shortfall was attributed to a 10 to 15 per cent increase on sales tax.

A fruitful writer's workshop ran as a parallel event to the book fair. This forum attempted to address problems facing today's authors, publishers, and more so the readership on the African continent.

Also at the book fair was a large selection of cultural displays, art, dance, and drama which helped keep visitors entertained. These were sub- contracted to the Harare Polytechnic Fine Arts Department who ran the programme as part of their marketing strategy for the Harare International Fine Arts festival scheduled for 1997.

Meanwhile, the Frankfurt Book Fair - the world's largest - is reviewing its relationship with the Zimbabwe International Book Fair after the government's repeated interference with the right of participants to attend.

This action was prompted by the controversy surrounding the GALZ group and their right to exhibit at the ZIBF.

In a protest handed to the Zimbabwe embassy in Bonn, Frankfurt Book Fair Director Peter Weidhaas said, he was afraid the exclusion of GALZ on direct orders from the government could mark the end of the Zimbabwe International Book Fair as the main commercial and cultural publishing event of sub-Saharan Africa.

Weidhaas' remarks were echoed by the representative of the Frankfurt Book Fair at the Zimbabwe fair, Peter Ripken, who said his organization would have to reconsider its future attendance given what he called "the climate of intimidation and censorship."

The government was damaging the reputation of the fair, he said, and " Zimbabwe would soon become a pariah state like Nigeria if they go on like this. "Why come when our books may be banned, when our stalls will not be protected from government-instigated mobs?" he asked. Ripken said as a German, he fully understood the dangers of persecuting a minority.

South African publishers were equally forthright. The controversy surrounding the right of GALZ to exhibit would have a negative effect on future participation by South African publishers, said representative Gavin Cutler.

It (the attempt to bar GALZ) represented "an abnormal abuse of Zimbabwe's host status," said Cutler, pointing out that freedom of expression was essential to the success of the fair.

Francois McHardy of the Witwatersrand University Press said it was "absurd and short-sighted of the government not to allow a group to participate because of their sexual orientation."

He pointed out that the fair was a big boost for Harare's economy with all the main hotels full. "How would the curio craftsmen and traders feel if the book fair were to fail?" posed McHardy. "People have to realise that intolerance is going to affect them economically."

Meanwhile, the government's stance came under fire from human rights group Amnesty International. "Although police protection was formally requested for GALZ, there was no official response, while law endorsement officials have said gays and lesbians have no right to help from police if they are attacked, " an Amnesty statement pointed out. "Government inaction to protect GALZ members would amount to condoning such abuse," the AI statement added, referring to threats from Sangano Munhumutapa, a tribalist grouping and some legislators.

"Freedom of expression and freedom of association are the rights that make it possible to discuss, meet and organise around the defence of human rights, including rights related to a person's sexual orientation," Amnesty said.

At the same time, publishers of educational materials have been urged to " price for the market" when selling textbooks in developing countries so as to make books easily available and help promote a reading culture. "Textbooks must be easily available to students. It is important to look at your market and make the books affordable. This will help empower students and create a greater readership base," said Ms May Bowden, a sales executive with Britain's John Wiley publishers.

A participant at the ZIBF, Bowden noted that most publishers were simply converting prices set for developed countries when selling the same texts to developing country students.

"One should take into consideration the buying power of people you are dealing with. It is also important to compare the two currencies involved before arriving at a price," Bowden stressed.

Judged as the best publisher in the United Kingdom in 1996, John Wiley specializes in scientific and technical textbooks, especially for tertiary institutions.

Bowden said her company was committed to the education system in Southern Africa and worked in close co-operation with local institutions.

"We also publish general interest books and scientific journals. We are committed to supporting a book culture within the region," she said.

"Most publishers are from the developed world. A uniform pricing system would disadvantage students from developing countries and it is for this reason that we employ a policy of market pricing," Bowden added.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


272 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Somalia;
Somali Clan Militia Resumes Battle After Ceasefire Collapse


BYLINE: APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

Nairobi - A truce declared by Somali factional leader Ali Mahdi Mohamed following the death of rival strongman Mohamed Farah Aideed on August 1 collapsed on August 10 as the two sides' militias fought for a strategic air base west of the capital, Mogadishu.

Fighting was also reported in villages between the Ballidogle base and the town of Afgoye, 30 kilometres south of the capital, according to militia field radios monitored in the Somali capital.

They said the battle for the Ballidogle base, built by the Soviet Union for Somalia's air force in the 1970s, began at noon (0900 GMT) on August 10 and by mid-afternoon, the casualty toll on both sides had reached 11 dead and 19 wounded, with the fighting continuing.

Ali Mahdi told journalists at his stronghold in north Mogadishu that his militiamen had captured the base, which is 90 kilometres west of Mogadishu, but that claim could not be independently confirmed.

The base is difficult to hold, as it is surrounded by dense bush in which militiamen armed with anti-aircraft rockets can take cover and attack aircraft as they land or take off. Ali Mahdi told reporters late the previous week that his militiamen in the bush would shoot down any aircraft attempting to land there. 

The two sides were using 106mm recoilless rifles, anti-aircraft rockets, 75mm anti-tank ordinance, and heavy and light machine-guns, according to the reports reaching Mogadishu.

On August 11, fighting was also reported to have flared between the two rival Somali factions on the strategic road leading to Ballidogle airport, which had been cut off the previous day. At least 12 people were reported killed and a dozen others injured in the clashes.

Sporadic fighting also flickekered in the Medina neighbourhood of south Mogadishu on the morning of August 11, while other reports reaching Mogadishu detailed heavy fighting between the rival militia in Balad district, north of Mogadishu. The number of casualties from the fighting was not yet available, but eyewitnesses said that a number of people had either been killed or wounded and hundreds of families displaced by the fighting.

Somalis were also bracing since August 7 for a battle for Baidoa, the main centre of the fertile Juba River valley. The Raharwein clan announced on August 4 that they had recaptured the town of Hoddur, 350 kilometres north- west of

Mogadishu and close to Baidoa, at the cost of 66 deaths and 91 wounded among their own militiamen

and those of the Aideed faction, who had taken the town last February.

Hussein Aideed categorically denied on August 6, without giving details, that the Rahanwein Resistance Army (RRA) had recaptured Hoddur.

Its fall was confirmed by travellers from the area, but they were unable to confirm the casualty toll. Hoddur lies in an open plain which provides no cover for attackers.

Militia sources said militiamen from the two factions were converging on Baidoa, which General Aideed captured from the RRA last September at the head of a column of 600 men.

"The battle will start within 24 hours," one Somali analyst predicted on the morning of August 7.

The capital, where about 150 people were killed in battles last month, remained tense following a declaration by Hussein Aideed that he would " eliminate all internal and external enemies."

Two rivals to Aideed -- the self-styled Somali interim president Ali Mahdi Mohammed, who controls north Mogadishu, and Osman Hassan Ali "Atto," one-time Aideed financier-turned bitter political foe, whose United Somali Congress (USC)/ Somali National Alliance (SNA) faction controls part of the south of the capital, have both put their militiamen on high alert and threatened to cancel ceasefires they declared after General Aideed's death.

It was the first reported factional fighting in Somalia since Aideed died here on August 1 from gunshot wounds he received a week earlier in fighting in Medina, and the replacement of the general at the head of the USC/SNA faction by his 34-year-old son, Hussein Mohamed, a former United States marine.

Political observers in the Somali capital believe that the resumption of fighting now threatened to plunge Somalia, which has been ruled by feuding groups since the overthrow of dictator Mohamed Siad Barre in 1991 after a bloody civil war, further into a political abyss that could drag on much longer.

According to analysts, the faction headed by former US marine Hussein Aideed after his father, who died after being shot in the chest, stomach and leg while leading an attack on a south Mogadishu enclave, was already showing signs that it may disintegrate soon.

The election on August 4 of the inexperienced 34-year-old to replace his slain father was seen here as an attempt to keep the south Mogadishu-based faction together. Hussein Aideed has spent virtually all his adult life in the United States, where he went as a teenager, returning briefly in 1993 as a marine with a US intervention force battling his father's militias.

A reservist, he was sent back to America as his father's militias dragged the bodies of slain US troops through the streets of Mogadishu.

He came back again last year, married, and became head of the faction's security committee, helping his father to secure the strategic town of Baidoa, 240 kilometres north-west of Mogadishu and the main centre of the fertile Juba River Valley.

With his muscular build -- unusual among Somalis, who are generally slim -- and his marine swagger, he became popular with the faction's unpaid and unkempt militiamen. But the ability to keep a faction together in this Horn of Africa nation where clan politics make those of Byzantium appear simple, depends on years of experience.

The powerful figures in each clan, sub-clan and additional sub- clans, are frequently not those put forward as leaders, and the alliances shift almost daily.

Aideed, who tried to appear "presidential" during an interview on August 6, wearing slacks, jacket and tie, and speaking so quietly as to be almost inaudible, was flanked then by General Jama Mohamed

Ghalib, the hard-line "Foreign Minister" in the unrecognised "government of Somalia" his father set up last June.

Ghalib, a northern Issak, was close to General Aideed, a member of the Saad sub-clan of the Habr Gedir sub-clan of central Somalia's Hawiye, because the two men thought the same way, according to Somalis who knew them both.

It was clear during the interview that Ghalib was in charge, since he fielded the tricky questions.

Somali analysts also say that Aideed was given the top job because the alternatives, such as Abdul Rahman Ali "Tuur," another Issak, and the first president of breakaway Somaliland in the north-west, would have divided the alliance immediately.

With the general gone, the power of the Issaks in the alliance is seen as residual, as they do not have militias of their own, and the power behind the throne is up for grabs, the analysts say.

Feelers from various clan groupings within the faction began to go out as soon as Hussein Aideed was nominated and accepted without dissent by the faction's leadership on August 4, they said.

Those soundings are being made through third parties, and are thus deniable. Aideed's "Interior Minister," Mohamed Qanyare Afrah was reported to have told diplomats the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, that Aideed's accession was a " coup."

Qanyare Afrah, a member of the southern Murusade clan, was formerly allied with the Abgal clan of north Mogadishu strongman Ali Mahdi Mohamed, but defected to General Aideed in 1994.

His hard line as an Aideed minister means that he has burnt his bridges with Ali Mahdi, whom he accused of lusting for power.

Other leaders within the faction are putting out feelers to see if they can rejoin factions they abandoned to ride on General Aideed's coat-tails when he was humiliating US and United Nations forces and capturing territory from other factions.

That peak has gone, with the faction's militiamen spread thin, defending those parts of south Mogadishu that they hold, Baidoa, and positions in the lower Shabelle River valley, south of the capital.

Ali Mahdi has, meanwhile, told Aideed to remove his militiamen from the south Mogadishu enclave of Medina, where General Aideed was shot on July 25, warning that he was likely to revoke the ceasefire he declared then if Hussein Aideed did not pull his men out.

Analysts say that Osman Hassan Ali "Atto," former financier to General Aideed but now an Ali Mahdi ally, could well do the same.

Medina is held primarily by members of Ali Mahdi's Abgal clan under the command of a former businessman, Musa Sude Yalahow.

Somalia is in the throw of another bloody clan struggle for control of the country.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


273 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Clergy, Government Differ On Resettling Displaced People


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Nakuru, Kenya - An outspoken Kenyan Catholic bishop says the resettling of victims of politically motivated land clashes that affected parts of the country between 1991 and 1994, is a prerequisite for genuine peace and development in those areas.

Speaking here some 160 kilometres north-west of the capital Nairobi, outgoing diocesan bishop Ndingi Mwana a' Nzeki said, the prevailing state of fear and apprehension among the residents of Molo and Olenguruone in Nakuru district has rendered impractical efforts by the Catholic church to implement medical and education services in the interior for the benefit of the locals.

Bishop Ndingi, whom Pope John Paul II appointed coadjutor Archbishop of the Nairobi Archdiocese on June 27, said it was the responsibility of the government to resettle the displaced people and to initiate moves towards reconciling them as soon as possible, instead of "trying to create a false impression that peace has returned to the area."

The prevailing tension, he explained, has made local residents become suspicious of any visitor who tours the area, as "witnessed in the threats that meet the church staff sent to assess development initiatives." 

But reacting to Bishop Ndingi's statement, local District Commissioner John Abduba said the government had already re-settled the victims of the land clashes, contrary to the bishop's claims.

"It is not true that the Government has not yet resettled the victims of the land clashes and that an atmosphere of apprehension and fear prevailed in the area as claimed by Bishop Ndingi," the government administrator was quoted in a report, carried by the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party daily, Kenya Times.

The DC observed that Bishop Ndingi's remarks could stir fear and tension by reminding the people of the unfortunate past, and urged the bishop and other clergy to assist the government in advocating reconciliation and good neighbourliness.

The district administrator said some of those displaced during the clashes in 1992 failed to return to their farms, not because of insecurity but as a result of incitement and misleading stories by some individuals.

But according to Mr. Ernest Murimi, the Nakuru Catholic Diocese Executive Secretary for Justice and Peace Commission, "most of the victims of the land clashes are still under the care of the church, among other non-governmental organizations, because the government is yet to come out with a workable system of resettling them."

Mr. Murimi said it is important that the government provides facts and figures to suppoort what the DC said. He told APS; ..."It would have been fair for Mr. Abduba to tell us where victims have been resettled, their numbers and when they were resettled."

A report sent to APS by the Nakuru Diocese Justice and Peace Commission says the displacement of 30,000 people from Enosupukia in Narok District in mid-October, 1993 and camps at Maela trading centre in the Nakuru Diocese, almost doubled the workload of the office.

And while many of the victims slowly drifted to other areas in Kenya, seeking housing and support from family members and relatives located elsewhere, over 10,000 displaced persons remained at Maela and the surroundings, 450 at Elburgon town, two at Molo town, 250 at Kamwaura Catholic Mission, 3,000 at Nakuru town, 200 at Thessalia and 50 at Kerisoi centre, says the report.

According to the report, a proposed resettlement programme, which was to be undertaken jointly by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the Kenya government did not take off, "despite the fact that UNDP spent Kshs.40 million (about US$714,000) in preparation for rehabilitation."

It further says the Catholic diocese of Nakuru spent Kshs 36 million (US$642,000) to provide food, clothing and health care among other services for the displaced people.

Only 200 families (1,250 out of 30,000 people) were resettled at Moi Ndabi on government-owned land, says the Nakuru Diocese report, adding..."the rest were left hanging at Maela Trading Centre."

Asked what steps the Catholic diocese was taking towards resettling the victims, who were still under their care, Murimi told APS; "We intend to resettle the land clashes' victims, who are still living in the centres of Maela, Elburgon and Kamwaura. These people, are apparently not able to find any other alternative. Their living conditions have deteriorated as they have been abandoned by both the Government and UNDP."

Most of the NGOs and churches, according to Murimi, seem to have given up on the issue of resettlement. "However, with the past experience on the resettlement programme for needy families, we are confident that resettlement even on a small scale can be carried out successfully," he added.

But the Justice and Peace Commission office expressed concern about reports pointing to the resurgence of similar skirmishes.

He was referring to claims made by Bishop Ndingi last April that residents living around forest areas in Molo within the Nakuru Diocese, were apprehensive about an outbreak of fresh "ethnic clashes," following the entry of three lorries full of unknown people into the forests of Molo and Njoro.

The Catholic prelate had also claimed that locals had begun to flee in fear of attacks on peasant farmers and incidences of cattle rustling had increased. But these claims were denied by the local authorities, with one of them referring to Bishop Ndingi as a "liar".

According to a comprehensive report that was compiled by a parliamentary commission headed by MP Kennedy Kiliku at the height of the 1991/1992 land clashes, more than 500 people were reported to have lost their lives while 1, 000 were said to have been displaced.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


274 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Burundi;
New Ruler Offers Dialogue As Burundi's Isolation Persists


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Bujumbura - Burundi's new junta ruler Major Pierre Buyoya has offered to talk to Hutu extremists fighting the Tutsi-led military government in a last- ditch effort to find a way out of the political imbroglio in his country, completely cut off from the outside world on August 4.

In a national broadcast setting out a three-year transitional programme, Buyoya, who ousted President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya in a bloodless coup on July 25, also went on to warn that "dialogue with armed factions" would only be possible if they first laid down their arms and rejected "destructive ideologies of extermination and genocide."

Buyoya last month justified his July 25 coup saying he had stepped in to haul the country back from the abyss after three years of civil strife, during which tens of thousands of rival Tutsis and Hutus massacred each other.

Last week's broadcast text set out a four-point plan for the war- torn tiny Central African state, which included talks with armed factions, national debate, political and social reconstruction, and rebuilding state structures. 

The process of national reconciliation "should start in October 1996, if the conditions are right," Buyoya said, holding out the prospect of approving the resumption of party political activity, suspended since the current change in leadership.

"We confirm the transitional nature of the regime in place since July 25 and set a three-year transition period," Buyoya said.

During the transitional period, the country would be governed by a " transitional national assembly" which is to be created shortly from the national assembly disbanded following the coup, and leading members of the civil society.

Buyoya will also be advised by a "council of wise men," according to his speech, which also appealed to the international community to lift economic sanctions imposed by regional African states to punish his seizure of power.

The broadcast came only hours after the departure of the last two international commercial flights from landlocked Burundi, whose borders were sealed last week under an embargo prompted by a military coup last month, signalling its complete isolation.

Two jets of the Belgian airline Sabena, left on August 13 night carrying some 400 people. The company said the flights would be the last "for several weeks."

The flights were the last two commercial departures to be authorized by Burundi's African neighbours who imposed the embargo to back their demand that major Pierre Buyoya, who seized power in a bloodless coup on July 25, return the country to "constitutional order."

Among the passengers was Pascasie Minani, wife of president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya who fled to the US embassy two days before the takeover by the army which is dominated by the Tutsi ethnic minority, and still remains there.

She was preceded by the wife of Melchior Ndadaye, the country's first elected Hutu president who was assassinated in October 1993 in an abortive army coup, only a few months after taking office. Ndadaye's widow had been staying at the Belgian embassy since July 23.

The Burundian authorities also sanctioned the departure of former Finance Minister Salvator Toyi, a member of Ntibantunganya's Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU), who had taken refuge at the European Union mission in the capital.

However, reliable sources said several other senior officials of the former regime, believed to include Ntibantunganya himself, had been denied permission to leave.

All embassies in Bujumbura urged their nationals to leave Burundi if they had no essential reason for staying, but no evacuation was planned.

However, Washington said 23 United States officials would remain in Bujumbura. Burundi's neighbours, including Rwanda which has the same volatile ethnic mix of 85 per cent Hutus and 14 per cent Tutsis, decreed an embargo against Burundi on July 31 following the military takeover by Buyoya, who ruled Burundi from 1987 to 1993 when he was defeated in elections by Ndadaye.

The embargo has been implemented by Tanzania, which handles most of Burundi's imports and exports, Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, Rwanda, Zaire and Cameroon and has already created a shortage of petrol which is now rationed.

But Tanzania and Kenya have since agreed to be more flexible and a convoy of 210 tonnes of food from the World Food Programme (WFP) was expected to cross the border from Tanzania, after aid organizations said the embargo would deprive refugees and vulnerable people of vital food stuffs.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 19, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa Cracks Down On Islamic Militants


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Cape Town - South African police said on August 13 that they had arrested a prominent Islamic militant in connection with the mob lynching on August 4 of gang leader, Rashaad Staggie on the troubled Cape Flats.

A police spokesman said a 37-year-old alleged leader of the People Against Gangsterism and Drugs (PAGAD) was arrested on charges of sedition and murder and more arrests could follow.

Police said they had also searched a number of houses in the Cape Flats, a vast network of mixed-race townships that are home to many of the city's gangsters and their opponents in the Muslim-based anti-gang movement. 

The area has been tense since Staggie, the leader of the "Hard Livings" gang, was shot several times and then burnt alive after a pitched gun battle between 2,000 PAGAD supporters and gangsters outside Staggie's home.

The arrest comes after PAGAD early last week extended their earlier threats of armed action against gangsters, to the government, for failing to prevent crime.

PAGAD spokesman Farook Jaffer threatened a "Jihad (holy war)" if the government did not eliminate drug dealing within 14 days, or if gangsters do not consent to end their illegal business.

On August 11, nine people were injured -- including three by police birdshots when about 1,000 PAGAD members and police clashed after a PAGAD rally, prompting the Western Cape provincial government to call on President Nelson Mandela to impose a state of emergency in the city.

Police said they had used teargas, rubber bullets and birdshots on the PAGAD demonstrators after they rampaged through the streets brandishing weapons in contravention of an earlier undertaking they had given national police commissioner George Fivaz, that they would not carry weapons.

After the incident, police said they seized 12 handguns and 221 rounds of ammunition.

In the rally, before the clash with police, an unnamed PAGAD leader had told supporters not to be afraid of dying for their cause.

"True followers of Allah (God) can't wait to die as then they will meet Allah himself," said the leader, hiding his identity behind a Palestinian- style scarf.

Accusing police and the government of siding with known criminals, Jaffer told the South African Press Agency (SAPA) that PAGAD might turn to radical armed Islamic groups in the Middle East, including Lebanon's Hezbollah, for aid.

"If this (war against drugs) is going to carry on and police continue to entertain the criminals, then we will have to call them (Hezbollah and other groups) in, "Jaffer said.

PAGAD's campaign has generated interest in the alleged activities of Islamic militants in South Africa.

Police have been under pressure to prevent mob rule following the August 4 lynching of Staggie, in which he was shot and then set alight outside his home after a pitched gun battle between gangsters and about 2,000 masked PAGAD members.

PAGAD's campaign, amid claims by one of its leaders that he received military training in Libya, has generated interest in the alleged activities of Islamic militants.

According to a secret police report that was leaked to the press last week, members of 11 South African "Muslim extremist fundamentalist" groups have received military training in Libya, Afghanistan and Iran.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 19, 1996


Science;
Phoney Anti-Meningitis Vaccines Sent To Niger


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Niamey - Niger's Health Ministry has admitted that some of the more than five million anti-meningitis vaccines distributed in the country against an epidemic last year did not work.

Reacting to reports in France that thousands of phoney vaccines were handed out to fight an outbreak of meningitis that claimed more than 3,000 lives in the impoverished West African nation last year, the ministry said there were several possible reasons why some were ineffective.

In a radio statement on August 10, the Health Ministry said vaccines were issued throughout the country without undergoing any prior quality control, but that in two regions they appeared to have no effect. 

"Our concern was the urgent protection of the population given the severity of the epidemic," it added.

"However, it was noted in two regions of the country that the epidemic was persisting despite all the vaccination efforts."

Niger's Health Ministry however said there were several possible reasons why the vaccines did not work, including their quality and storage or handling mistakes.

The two affected areas were given new vaccines and those which were doubtful were destroyed, it added.

The ministry made no mention of ongoing fraud inquiries into the phoney vaccines which were ordered last year but have so far produced no result. Neither has anyone been charged.

The Paris business newspaper Le Echos said in a report published from the French city of Lyons on August 9 that the thousands of phoney vaccines were among a consignment of 60,000 vaccines doses, officially provided by Nigeria at the height of the Niger epidemic in the spring of 1995.

But a spokesman of the pharmaceuticals company, Pasteur Merieux, said his company had despatched a vaccine consignment to Niger at the request of the World Health Organization (WHO).

The spokesman said the international aid agency, Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) - Doctors without Borders had warned that company that drugs without any potent effect, counterfeits of the vaccine sent by the company, had been in use in Niger, but declined to give further details because of the ongoing legal investigation.

Legal sources said enquiries had so far been unable to reveal the exact number of false vaccines used.

Two international enquiry teams ordered into Niger and Nigeria by the magistrate in charge of the investigation, had so far produced no results, informed sources said.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


277 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigerian Security Thwart Export Of Child Slave Labour


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lagos - Nigerian immigration officials have seized two boats which were about to smuggle out 78 Nigerian children to Gabon and Cameroon, allegedly for slave labour and prostitution, a press report said here on August 13.

The boats were seized in the border town of Oron, in the south- eastern state of Akwa Ibom independent, newspaper, The Guardian said.

The children - 40 girls and 38 boys - aged between 11 and 17 years, were paraded at the immigration headquarters in Uyo, the state capital by the agency's spokesman, Okey Ezugwu, according to the report. 

Most of the children said that they were paid 10,000 CFA francs (US dollars 20) each as transport fare to go and work in farms and beaches in Gabon and Cameroon during the holidays.

Due to financial hardships, the practice of exporting teenagers to Gabon, Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea and Zaire for forced labour has been on the increase in the past few years, especially in Nigeria's south-eastern states of Abia, Akwa Ibom, Cross River and Imo.

The authorities in those states have launched a campaign against such practices and have arrested some parents, guardians and suspected members of a smuggling "syndicate."

Most of Nigeria's illegal immigrants expelled in the last two years from Gabon were children who had been smuggled in as slave labour or for sexual exploitation.

The reports came only hours after United Nations findings released in Geneva, painted a horrifying picture of modern slavery, with half a million juvenile prostitutes in Sao Paulo, Brazil, 50 million cases of Indian child labour, and entire Nepalese families held in slavery for generations.

The report, made public on August 13, is based on lengthy investigations by parliamentary deputies and organizations in some 20 countries, and as it appeared, 250 young Indians aged six to 12 demonstrated in New Delhi against child slavery.

An Asian group quoted by the UN report said more than 55 million Indian children are "kept in servitude" although slave labour was officially abolished 20 years ago.

In Africa, similar charges have been levelled against Sudan, which has been accused recently of capturing black children both in southern Sudan and northern Uganda to sell them as slaves to rich Arabs in the Gulf region.

The accusations have come from human rights groups, churches and the southern rebels who have been battling Khartoum since 1983 to end domination of the mainly Christian and animist south by the Arabised, Muslim north.

The bloody civil war has left at least one million people dead and forced millions of others to either become displaced internally or to flee into exile in neighbouring countries.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 19, 1996


Sudan;
Sudanese Catholic Bishops Query Nuba Peace Pact


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Nairobi - Catholic bishop of El Obeid, the Rt. Rev. Macram Gasis, is seeking clarification over a peace pact on the problem of the Sudanese Nuba Mountains people.

Bishop Gasis wants to know whether the people of the Nuba mountains were consulted when a group of rebels from the area, jointly with the Khartoum government signed on July 31 a "Peace Charter"

outlining a "declaration of principles," with a view to resolving "the Nuba mountains problem" in a peaceful and democratic manner.

The bishop observes that the international community had condemned the present regime, isolated and punished it through sanctions, because of widespread abuses and violations of human rights, particularly against African ethnic groups and non-Muslims. 

The bishop, whose diocese incorporates the Nuba mountains, also reiterates that slavery continues in the area today and "it is well documented."

He warns the signatories to the charter that "history and their God will judge them." The signatory rebel group had withdrawn from key military posts in Col. John Garang's Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

Bishop Macram wonders if "these people think they are going to be credible with the regime when they move from one side to another."

Bishop Macram spoke to APS on August 10 at the ordination of Rev. Remijo Lominong William as a priest of the Catholic Church in Sudan. He becomes the sixth Sudanese priest to be ordained in exile but will return to work in Sudan.

Among the rebels who signed the "declaration of principles" - in effect the Sudanese Government's initiated "Peace Charter," are Commander Mohamed Haroun Kafi, Chairman of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army Nuba Mountains Central Committee and Engineer Abdelbagi Hamdan Kabeir, the committee's secretary for Foreign Affairs.

The Sudanese government delegation was led by Brigadier Hamad Abdel Karim Elsaid, Minister for Finance South Kordofan State, in which the Nuba Mountains is situated.

The two parties recognised that there had been a long-standing problem in the Nuba Mountains "which led to the armed struggle since 1984."

Further, they acknowledged "the unity of Sudan with its geographical and political borders in 1956."

Observers noted that while the defections could damage the fortunes of the SPLA in the Nuba Mountains, a key rebel leader, Youssif Kawa, was not among the signatories.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
