Africa News


August 19, 1996


Rwanda;
Draft Law Approved To Try Genocide Suspects


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Kigali - Rwandan parliamentarians have approved a draft legislation that will be used to punish suspects in the ethnic genocide which culminated in the massacre of between 500,000 and one million people in 1994.

The draft law will allow the first trials of those accused of ethnic massacres to begin, Rwandan national radio reported here on August 10.

The legislation, approved on August 9, covered organization of judicial inquiries into breaches of the law which constitute genocide or other crimes against humanity, committed in Rwanda between October 1, 1990, and December 31, 1994. This period covers the civil war in Rwanda which preceded the genocide which took place between April and July 1994. 

October 1, 1990 was the date on which the civil war in Rwanda began. The official radio station did not provide any further details on the text of the new law.

Under discussion since June, the draft law was sent before commissions because of differences of opinion between the parliament and the government, despite the fact both are dominated by the mainly Tutsi Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) which has been in power since July 1994.

It was adopted on by 47 votes in favour, with one against and five abstentions, according to Radio Rwanda.

Now the legislation must be put before the constitutional court before it is promulgated by Hutu President Pasteur Bizimungu.

More than 80,000 Hutus, most of them accused of taking part in the 1994 genocide, are festering in overcrowded prisons, provoking repeated criticism of conditions from international observers.

Joshua Amselmo, spokesman of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) said in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, that the Red Cross had registered 80,259 prisoners in 255 detention centres in Rwanda.

More than 54,000 of them were being kept in the country's 14 jails, and more than 25,000 in temporary holding centres.

The Rwandan judicial apparatus was decimated by the 1994 killings and has only been rebuilt very gradually.

As yet, none of those presumed guilty of the genocide has been tried either in Rwanda or by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda which is based in Arusha, northern Tanzania.

According to a statement read on Radio Rwanda, the Rwanda government is " very satisfied" with the passing of the legislation.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


280 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Communicators Asked To Help African Churches


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Nairobi - The General Secretary of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) Rev. Jose Chipenda has challenged trained Christian communicators to help the Church in Africa communicate the Christian message effectively.

Knowledge acquired by Christian communicators should speed up the use of mass media by churches on the continent, said the AACC head.

The Angolan clergy noted that unlike in the past, today's church in Africa must rely on the use of mass media-print and electronic - hence the need for trained Christian communicators to help churches incorporate mass media usage. 

Rev. Chipenda was speaking at the graduation ceremony here for the 1996 Media Production Course, organized and conducted by the AACC Communication Training Centre (CTC) for 19 participants from seven African countries.

Graduands at the 14th graduation ceremony of the AACC/CTC included seven women. Countries represented were Kenya, Uganda, Sudan, Ethiopia, Cote D'Ivoire, Botswana, and Angola.

According to Rev. Chipenda, professional training for Christian communicators is as vital as equipping communication centres, therefore churches should take the challenges posed by these needs.

The AACC General Secretary also called on the course participants to return to their respective countries fully prepared to exploit the knowledge they had acquired during the six-month-media course at the centre.

During the six-months period, participants were exposed to various aspects of mass media production such as photography, news reporting, script writing and studio techniques.

Addressing the same gathering after judging photographs displayed by the students, renowned Kenyan photo-journalist Mohamed Amin, commended the high standard of creativity displayed through the pictures.

"Some of the creativity displayed here is outside what I have witnessed in my 40 years experience in photography. It challenges churches, among other institutions to exploit them (students) for the betterment of mother Africa," he said.

Mr. Amin, who told the gathering that he has taken up assignments in dangerous situations during his career spanning four decades cautioned, " photo-journalism can be both exciting and dangerous."

Amin, who is the managing director of the Nairobi-based Camerapix, lost his hand in 1991 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, while covering the volatile aftermath of the fall of President Mengistu Haile Mariam.

In his address, the CTC communication consultant, Mr. Polycarp Omolo Ochilo, hailed churches for showing interest in training both men and women in mass media.

"The fact that we are today graduating men and women is a clear indication that the church is concerned about gender sensitivity," he said.

In his remarks, photo editor for the independent Nation Group of Newspapers,

Mr. Sam Ouma, who conducted the AACC/CTC photography course, expressed concern that "there are very few female photographers in the media.

"At Nation (Kenya's mass circulation daily) for example, we have only one female photographer in the male-dominated area," he said, adding that "women should be encouraged to venture into photography."

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

August 19, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia News Roundup


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Addis Ababa - Council Approves Loan Agreements

The Council of Ministers of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia yesterday approved two loan agreements with the Kuwait and OPEC funds for the expansion project of the Addis Ababa Airport.

During its 21st regular meeting yesterdays, the council approved the loans planned to partially finance the Addis Ababa Airport expansion project designed to make the Airport meet the standards of the International Civil Aviation Organization and accommodate the air traffic forecasted for the coming two decades.

The loan bills will be submitted to the House of Peoples' Representatives for final enactment.

Commission Dispatches Aid To Flood Victims

The Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission said it has dispatched 19,000 quintals of relief aid to thousands of needy people affected by the recurrent flooding. 

In a statement it issued here, the commission said the aid was distributed in Afar, Somali, Ogaden and Gambella regions where major rivers had burst their banks and rendered thousands homeless.

It said it has finalised preparations to dispatch emergency aid to 33,000 needy people in Amhara region who were affected by recent flooding.

So far, no flooding was reported in the Afar region, the Commission said adding it has send 200 quintals of biscut and 2,000 blankets and plastic nets as a security reserve to the region.

Awash River Threatens Cotton:

Dubti - the Awash River which diverted its normal course near Dubti, would threaten unless prompt measures are taken to maintain its usual route, an official of the plantation warned.

Dr. Tefera-Work Haile, representative of the Tendaho Agricultural Development Enterprise, said unless the flow of the Awash River that diverted from its normal route around Feriti locality in Dubti woreda maintained its usual direction, the cotton plantation on 2485 hectares of land should be damaged in about two weeks time.

Dr. Tefera-Work estimated the ensuing damage at 62 million birr.

He said similar diversion in the flow of the river damaged 336 hectares of cotton plantation in Detbahri area early last month.

The representative added that workers of the enterprise, hard pressed by shortage of potable water, have appealed to abandon the area after the effort to redirect the flow of the river ended up in failure.

Another 2,500 hectares of cotton plantation cultivated by investors and farmers in Detabahri area is also exposed to disastrous condition, be sides the passing of the sowing period for a further 5000 hectares of land prepared for cotton plantation, the representatives explained.

Asked about the problem, Ato Kidane Asefa, head of the hydrology department under the Ministry of Water Resources and other experts in the office told ENA that the implementation of the design that included the digging of a 500 metre canal to reverse the flow of the river to its previous direction began yesterday.

He said the effort to seek solutions to the problem has continued.

International Travellers Need To Bear Health Certificate

The Ministry of Health announced yesterday that international travellers are required to bear health certificates indicating vaccation against major communicable diseases including malaria.

The ministry said in a statment a vaccination centre located on the premises of the Black Lion Hospital is administering yellow fever vaccines for overseas travellers.

The ministry said travellers are often seen coming to the centre to get certified only two days ahead of their scheduled travel but, it said, entertaining such demands are incompatible with the objectives of the vaccination and cannot help the user either.

For the vaccination to be more effective and save travellers the inconvenience they suffer to get it due to time limitation, travellers are required to get immunised 10 days before their travel programme, the ministry said.

The Ministry said it is checking on the entry of diseases labelled communicable internationally at hygiene and quarantine stations set up at major air and land outlets.

Being a member of the World Health Organization (WHO) , Ethiopia adheres to laws, regulations and directives given by WHO and makes health controll in incomint passengers, goods, transportation and corpses, the ministry said.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Sports - Olympics;
Medalist From Zambia Loses Out On $50,000


BYLINE: A Correspondent, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 120 words


 

Lusaka - Samuel Matete, Zambia's Olympic 400 metres hurdles Silver Medalist, came third in the Zurich Grand Prix athletics meeting on Wednesday night. 

Metete, however, missed out on the big money for winners and record beaters.

The Zurich meeting is one of the richest in the World Athletics with $50, 000 for a win plus a kilo of gold ingots if a World record is broken on top of the appearance money.

Matete seems to be performing below his own high standards when it comes to big tournaments.

Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


283 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Business;
Debt Relief Only For Deserving Zambian Farmers


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - Farmers who will be found by Lima Bank to be unworthy of debt relief will not be protected by the government, the Ministry of Agriculture has warned.

In a letter of July 19, agriculture deputy minister Matthias Mpande advised Lima Bank to give debt relief only to those who deserve it.

"Base your loan recoveries on a case by case basis," Mpande directed Lima Bank managing director, Venus Kasapatu. "Ministry officials are being requested to assist you fulfill your loan recoveries programme." 

Mpande assured Lima Bank the ministry will not interfere in any loan recoveries.

But the government's position has not gone well with many farmers.

"We thought that our debts would be repaid by the government through the scheme but these agents are coming to us to repay the 1994/95 loans which we failed to pay because of the drought," complained Lydia Mbewe of Chipata in an interview. "My name appears on the list of loanees in the debt relief scheme but I was told by the agent here that the scheme would no longer apply to my case."

But things have not progressed as to expectations since President Frederick Chiluba's announcement of the debt relief to farmers over a year ago.

"We have not been able to fully implement the scheme due to the fact that the memorandum of understanding has not been executed," Lima Bank managing director Kasapato explained the delay to his branch managers in a circular July 16.

And in an interview on Friday Kasapato said he had been assured of the government's commitment to debt relief.

"I am assuring you that the memorandum of understanding will be processed soon," assured agriculture deputy minister W.C Matutu in a letter of July 10 to Lima bank. " I am appealing to your organisation to stop harassing the farmers and taking them to court until the issue is resolved."

Kasapato, however, said Lima Bank has lists of farmers who are deserving. " But other farmers engaged in poultry, for example, also signed up saying they could not repay because of the drought," Kasapato carped. " We shall not accept such reasons. That is why the government has decided that we go through the lists and take them case by case."


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


284 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Malawi;
Malawi News Roundup


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2067 words


 

Blantyre - Jury System Simplified

The Malawi judiciary has come up with a cost-cutting means of speeding up trials for the 800 outstanding murder cases. It is to start engaging jurors who commute from their homes.

Deputy High Court Registrar, Bikitu Qoto, said the new system, which will also apply to jurors on treason cases, will cut hotel accommodation expenses for the jurors who will, however, continue to be provided with security and other services such as food and sitting allowances.

Qoto said trial by jury, which is required by the country's constitution, is too costly for the judiciary which depends on government subventions affected by the cash-budget system. He cited the year long murder trial of several MCP officials, including former president Kamuzu Banda, which cost Malawi K3 million (US 200,000). 

Parliament has already passed the bill and it is now awaiting presidential approval. The bill allows any juror to sit for murder or treason trials. Previously jurors were required to come from the accused's district of origin.

Some lawyers, however, argue that the jury system should be dispensed with because it delays trial and pending cases. They say that its introduction was ill-timed and wrongly prioritised for the marginally poor Malawi, which is the only country using the system in the SADC region. They argue that the country would benefit more by investing in the training of lawyers.

Malawi To Discuss Deportees With South Africa

The Malawi Human Rights Commission has been meeting with South African human rights organisations to find ways of easing the suffering of Malawian deportees.

Ombudsman James Chirwa, who co-chairs the commission with Law Commissioner Elton

Singini, said in an interview that the commission had collected names of some of the Malawians due for repatriation and would raise their plight at the meeting with South African human rights bodies.

South Africa has in recent months gone on a spree repatriating Malawians with dubious residence permits. Those repatriated usually leave without their assets and are thus subjected to undue hardships during the repatriation.

Chirwa and Singini are also linking up with their South African counterparts on the setting up of the offices of the Ombudsman, Law Commissioner and the Human Rights Commission.

South African High Commissioner, Llewelyn Crewe-Brown, said his government would not change its repatriation policies and would continue to repatriate people without proper travel documents.

He said those who complain about leaving their assets can always arrange to pick them up with their lawyers. He also said that it was difficult to release those found without proper travel documents so they could organise their assets because of the risk of their running away.

He did, however, dismiss allegations that South Africa might be treating Malawians with a heavy hand because of the Malawi government's stand during the apartheid era. Malawi was one of very few countries in Africa which openly allied with the white-led apartheid government. Malawi was also not supportive of countries and organisations such as the ANC which were fighting to dismantle the system.

Bureau To Probe Corruption

The newly launched Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB), has said it will review all reports of enquiries into alleged corruption, such as the Fieldyork notebook scam involving Malawi's ex-minister of education, Sam Mpasu.

The mysterious fire that gutted the offices of the Petroleum Control Commission, destroying vital information into the diverting of funds to private use by some officers, will also be screened, the bureau's director Gilton Chiwaula said on August 2.

Chiwaula said the bureau was empowered to review all enquiries into allegations of corruption made by other institutions to find out how serious they are for possible prosecution of culprits.

Asked on whether the bureau would specifically investigate the Fieldyork notebook scandal, involving the procurement of notebooks by Sam Mpasu in 1994, Chiwaula said that there was no doubt that they would do this, "especially now the public are demanding that we do so".

Mpasuwho, who by-passed all government procedures in the purchase of the notebooks, is alleged to have received hefty kickbacks from the deal with a UK-based company. Mpasu denies the charge. President Bakili Muluzi, bowing to public pressure and keen to clear his government from corruption charges, replaced Mpasu as education minister and then later dropped him completely from the cabinet, but gave him the party portfolio of Secretary General.

Chiwaula said the bureau would also review fraud enquiry reports into the PCC, the Development of Malawian Trust, whose general manager and a senior officer are on suspension, and into the Lilongwe city council.

Lack Of Burial Space Brings Problems

Christians of the Church of Central Africa Presbyterian (CCAP), in the Blantyre synod, may as well get used to the idea of having their bodies cremated when they die.

The church's general secretary, Rev Misanjo Kansilanga, is convinced that this is the only solution to the problem of a shortage of burial space in Blantyre's cemeteries.

Kansilanga said the public should shed the belief that cremation of bodies was not compatible with African beliefs and traditions. He said the large numbers of burials being conducted at the church's cemetery in Blantyre, which is nearly full, had prompted the synod to restrict further burials to its church members only. He said the synod had written to the City of Blantyre to come to the rescue of the church but, up to now, there had been no response.

In fact the city is also facing the same problem. It has already closed a number of its own cemeteries in the city because they are full.

Kansilanga said there was a need to start teaching people to accept the idea of cremation, acknowledging that he was aware of the resistance the suggestion would meet due to deep- rooted African beliefs and traditions.

K160 Million In Unpaid Taxes

Companies, government departments and the general public are depriving the government of K160 million (US 10.06 million) in unpaid tax.

In order to redress this situation and improve the situation of the government coffers, the department of income tax has threatened to confiscate the property of all companies and individuals who fail to honour their tax obligations.

Income Tax is the second biggest revenue generating department for the government, after Customs and Excise.

Most of the unpaid tax is due to tax evasion while a considerable part is also played by employers who deliberately delay remitting the taxes deducted from their employers, giving preference to other commitments, said Yvensio Chimombo, Commissioner of Taxes.

Included among those owing the department money after deducting 'pay as you earn' (PAYE)funds from their employees, are some government departments.

Chimombo said the time was up for tax defaulters. His department could no longer sit back while some unscrupulous people and organisations swindled the government of its much-needed revenue. He said that the law would take its course against culprits by confiscating their property which they could redeem upon payment of their tax dues.

Opposition Retains Seats

The opposition Malawi Congress Party and Alliance for Democracy retained their parliamentary seats in a by-election held on July 29 in Nsanje, south Malawi, and Nkhata-Bay, in the north.

MCP won by a small margin the hotly contested Nsanje Lalanje seat vacated due to the death of Chimalizeni Sabola in March this year.MCP's candidate, Sylvestor Vazhi, scooped 3090 votes against 2795 votes for United Democratic Front's Ibrahim Phoso.

In Nkhata-Bay Aford's Austin Mwenda overwhelmingly beat his contenders by 4470 votes against 1475 for his runner up katantha Banda of the MCP.

Both polls were characterised by voter apathy with less than 33% of registered voters polling in both by-elections.

The ruling UDF has protested against the results of both the polls alleging electoral fraud and has called for a re-run. The Electoral Commission is withholding the results following the protest and has since started investigations into the alleged irregularities.

Street Drug Vendors Challenge President

Street vendors selling unprescribed drugs in the city of Blantyre have challenged president Bakili Muluzi, who on July 31 ordered police to assist in cracking down on the illegal business.

Muluzi said that apart from being illegal, the drugs were being stolen from government hospitals. This, he said, was one of the reasons for the shortage of drugs in these hospitals.

The vendors, however, who sell anything from aspirin to drugs for treating tuberculosis, are unmoved by the threat, and have challenged the president to prove to them that the drugs are being stolen from hospitals. The vendors have also challenged the police to arrest them saying the law on the sale of drugs is very weak.

Hospital authorities say theft of drugs by health personnel is rampant and contributes to the shortage of medicines in the hospitals.

Government Considering Value Added Tax

The Malawi government is considering the introduction of value added tax, to replace the surtax system that is currently in force on manufactured goods and services.

Controller of Customs and Excise, Ernest Mtingwi, and Commissioner for Tax, Yvensio Chimombo, said studies would be conducted on how best to introduce the new tax as one way of boosting government's revenue.

Mtingwi said the VAT system was already working in many countries, such as South Africa and neighbouring Zambia, and said there should be no problem introducing it in Malawi. VAT is tax levied on the rise in value of a product at each stage of its manufacture. It is thus expected to earn government more revenue than surtax.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

285 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 19, 1996


Science;
Twins In Pilot HIV Study in Malawi


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Blantyre - About 40 sets of twins have become the focus of a pilot observational study at a special clinic at Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital in Blantyre to determine the effect of HIV infection on twins.

Professor Ronin Broadhead of Malawi College of Medicine, the paediatrician who is leading the research team, said one of the reasons for the two-year study was to find out the degree of risk of HIV infection and the effect of HIV on twins. "For sometime now it has been known that the first twin is much more at risk of developing AIDS than the second twin," he said. 

He said the college, in conjunction with John Hopkins University in the USA, carried out a study to see whether by washing the vaginal canal, HIV transmission could be interrupted.

He said this had not, however, been proved so. It is, however, presumed that contact of the baby with vaginal secretions might have an effect on increasing the risk of HIV infection.

"Our interest in twins continues because their mortality rate is high especially when mothers have big families and have to look after two babies at once." Mothers often find that one baby, the stronger one, dominates over the second, and the survival rate of the second twin is often much less than the single baby, he said. He also said that another objective of the study was to find out whether it was possible to improve the lives of both twins by running regular clinics and monitoring them carefully in the antenatal period and after the birth.

He said the study also looks at different types of the virus as it is now known that HIV is not just a single type. "It changes and replicates itself making 'cousins' which are related but slightly different in their actual form."

Broadhead said that he hopes the clinic will go on indefinitely providing services for mothers with twins. He said that twins always present a challenge and he hopes the study would help improve the outcome for both twins, adding that it was good clinical practice to run a clinic for a certain risk group such as mothers with twins.

The central hospital has several advantages for the study, one being that it has from 13,000 to 14,000 babies delivered annually and it is hoped that the study will be able to gather information on at least 100 pairs of twins each year. The prevalence of HIV in delivering women is over 30% with the perinatal transmission rate established at 28%.

In Sub-Saharan Africa, it is estimated that one in 40 mothers deliver twins, while in Europe it is one to every 80 births. Professor Broadhead said the biological reasons for this difference are not clearly understood.

All twins delivered at QECH are eligible to be enrolled into the study, after informed consent for HIV testing is obtained from parents.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 19, 1996


Business;
Malawi Bemoans Trade Imbalance


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Blantyre - Malawi has said it was not certain if it had benefited from its membership to regional groupings like the Southern African Development Community (SADC), or the Common Market for Eastern Southern Africa (COMESA).

Opening a seminar on a study of economic integration in Southern Africa, Malawi's Deputy Finance Minister Lizzie Lossa lamented that Malawi had not benefited from most of the grouping's programmes and activities put in place to promote socio-economic development in member countries. She said there was presently a big trade imbalance between Malawi and some of its trading partners in the region in favour of other countries.

She said that although Malawi's benefits from such bodies could obviously not benefit those of other countries with bigger economies, like Zimbabwe and South Africa, there was need for the region to aim at greater regional integration and stability.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


287 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 20, 1996


Business;
Poor Book Policy Isolates Zambia


BYLINE: Samsom Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The morbid state of Zambia's national book industry has kept the country in a state of intellectual isolation from the rest of the world, said Ministry of Education permanent secretary, Sichalwe Kasanda, in Lusaka yesterday.

Opening the Symposium on National Book Policy for Zambia at Lusaka's Mulungushi international Conference Centre, Kasanda said "it is a situation that should make us all uncomfortable because it has a direct bearing on the speed of our development as a country, let alone as individuals".

Kasanda, however, assured all these concerns had been finally addressed in the draft National Book Policy. 

"The policy seeks to create a Book Development Council of Zambia under the auspices of the Ministry of Education to execute and bring to fruition the aspirations expressed therein," Kasanda said. "Due care has been taken, as far as practically possible, to embrace the needs of all stakeholders - ranging from the writer who is the originator of the book, through to the reader who is the ultimate beneficiary in the chain."

And Programme Specialist in Education from the UNESCO subregional office for southern Africa in Harare, Mauno Mbamba, said Zambia had taken a leading role in the process of developing a national book policy of the five countries that took part in the launching of the Study on Textbook Provision and the Feasibility of Cooperation among SADC member states.

"Zambia took full advantage of the consultations with other countries in the sub-region, as facilitated by UNESCO, and moved forward to initiating practical measures at the international level for achieving ideal conditions for the provision of textbooks and books in general," Mamba said, adding: " Although Zimbabwe and Namibia have established a national Book Development Council, and Botswana and Malawi have expressed the need to create such an institution, none of these countries has reached the stage where Zambia is today, namely the formulation of a national book policy."


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


288 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 20, 1996


Business;
Lusaka's Rails Need Repair


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - Unless the thin rail tracks are repaired Lusaka's Njanji commuter train will not last over two years unless, warned the company's general manger Peter Muche in an interview yesterday.

Muche said the thin rail tracks which were designed for much lighter trains cannot withstand the heavy equipment now in use.

"When the Njanji Commuter started the equipment used was lighter, but the coaches and locomotives were replaced when people complained that the Mulungushi coaches were of inferior quality," Muche said. 

But according to Muche, the government says it can only repair the rail tracks after this year's presidential and general elections due to budget constraints.

"We have already put this matter before the government but they explained to us that it cannot be financed because of the coming elections," Muche said. "We would appreciate four rail cars and six coaches which would cost over US$5 million but it would be a good investment in the long run because then we could hope to run this service for a long time."

And Ministry of Transport permanent secretary,Ronald Mukuma, in an interview yesterday, said the government was conscious of the importance of the commuter train and that is why it has "kept the fares low on that train because it is a public service".

"The renovations to that train were not included in the budget but we can expect them to be included in the next budget,"Mukuma said.

The fare for the longest distance covered by the Njanji commuter train, Lusaka to Ngwerere or Lusaka to Lilayi, is K200.

But Muche said the commuter train is able to meet all its general costs having collected about K380 million in fares last year.

"It looks like we will do the same this year in spite of stiff competition from mini-bus operators," Muche said.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

August 20, 1996


Zambia;
Zambian Government To Introduce New Gender Policy


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Siavonga - A new policy aimed at improving the portrayal of women in the media is being development by the government, disclosed permanent secretary in the newly established Gender in Development Division (GIDD), Grace Mulapezi, in Siavonga yesterday.

Opening a training workshop for media personnel on Gender, Population and Development in Siavonga yesterday, Mulapezi complained that women issues that are positive are rarely portrayed. 

"Instead negative and scandalous issues make headlines in the media," Mulapezi said. "In line with this apart from the national gender policy that is yet to be considered by cabinet, a media policy that will include gender issues is being developed by the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting."

And speaking at the same function, assistant director at GIDD Edwidge Mutale said "integration of gender aspect in development strategies came as a result of failure of economic development strategies to raise the status of women".

"In some cases, economic growth oriented development left women worse of than they were before," Mutale said.

And demographer at GIDD, Joe Kapembwa, explained that gender is often confused with sex.

"Gender is a social economic valuable used to analyse the roles, responsibilities, contributions and potentials of women and men which gives rise to the social relation between them," Kapembwa said." There is a big difference between the two."

GIDD was established two months ago to replace the former Women In Development (WID) who it was felt had left out women from the mainstream of development.

"Advocates if WID felt that to integrate women in development, there was need to set up women's projects but this left women farther marginalised," Mutale said.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 20, 1996


Business;
Cotton To Earn Eastern Zambian Farmers K6 Billion


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Chipata - Over K6 billion will this year be earned by Eastern Province farmers from cotton sales to South Africa's Clark Cotton Limited which bought Lintco's Chipata branch under the privatisation programme.

Eastern Province farmers are this year expected to produce about 16 million kilogrammes of cotton - almost double that of last season. 

Clark Cotton's ginnery manager, James Chisenga, in an interview in Chipata on Friday, attributed the increase in cotton production to good rains.

"We are expecting between 15 and 16 million Kilogrammes of cotton this season , and at K440 per kilogramme, we will spend quite a lot because we have to make sure we buy all the produce," Chisenga said.

And over 60 per cent of cotton is of excellent quality.

"So far the over 8 million Kilo- grammes we have received, about 69 per cent of it is of A grade, it is of excellent quality," cotton quality controller Andrew Ndjovu said in an interview in Chipata on Friday.

But Njovu was worried about inadequate cotton storage facilities"All the 16 million Kilogrammes of cotton have to be processed before the start of the rain season as the storage facilities are worrying," Njovu carped. "We have to improve on these facilities in future."

Njovu, however, assured that it takes time for cotton to be spoiled, even if it is soaked, so long it is processed.

And according to Eastern Province permanent secretary, Harry Mutonga, the area has done well in the agriculture sector and there are no fears for starvation.

"I think we are very safe this season and we will make sure all the produce is bought as we have plenty of grain bags and there are no marketing problems, " Mtonga said in an interview in Chipata on Friday.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


291 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 20, 1996


Zambia;
Amended Constitution Under Attack


BYLINE: Chilombo Mondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - The government should seriously consider dialogue before going ahead with elections using the amended Constitution, advised the Economics Association of Zambia (EAZ) chairman, Griffin Nyirongo, yesterday.

Nyirongo, in an interview yesterday, said "there is still room for discussion".

"The manner in which the Constitution was adopted was not conclusive," Nyirongo said. "The uncertainty surrounding the constitution has made it difficult for the country to attract investment." 

The government, Nyirongo advised, should "take a conciliatory stand and meet the opposition parties halfway towards the resolution of the current donor freeze".

"Even the suspense over the date of elections needs to be cleared up because the suspicion it creates makes economic agents wary and they tend to be speculative, not committing themselves to any investments,"Nyirongo said.

And EAZ programmes coordinator, Muna Nakalonga, in an interview yesterday, said "the players in the political arena should come together immediately".

"People should stop being proud because there is nothing to be proud about. A whole year has passed by without growth," Nakalonga said. " All the MMD government was required to do was to maintain donor-financed projects but even this might fail simply because the donors will completely cut off aid if we go with this Constitution to next year."

And Zambia Association of Chambers of Commerce and Industry (ZACCI) chairman, David Matongo, at the association's monthly meeting last Wednesday said the country needed "political stability if this economy is to progress".

Speaking on the Stock Market and the Economy last Wednesday, investment consultant, Zoran Zuze, said the political situation in the country was affecting the markets.

"Although there is no crisis in the form of a mass uprising, our government has decided to pass a constitution which on the face of it, appears as though it was designed to curtail opposition and extend its stay in power," Zuze said. "It has also imprisoned opponents on treason charges apparently with no evidence. This has created a lot of uncertainty in the economy especially in the wake of the donor aid withdrawals."

Zuze pointed to the effects of foreign exchange shortages and gave an example of Chilanga Cement Plc's shares which were going at K54 around the announcement of the ZCCM privatisation.

"Since these political developments the shares have fallen to back to K48," Zuze said.

But finance minister Ronald Penza yesterday refused to give a conclusive answer to the requests made by the economists.

"I stand by what I said on Sunday's television programme," Penza maintained.

Penza told the nation on ZNBC television's Open Fire programme on Sunday that the elections would be held with or without donor funding.

August 20, 1996


Zambia;
Procedure For Parliamentary Candidates Announced


BYLINE: Sam Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba yesterday told MMD cadres in Ndola that the adoption of parliamentary candidates for the ruling party would be conducted by three panels.

The President told MMD cadres at the Ndola airport that the first panel would be at constituency level. 

"You will receive application forms from the aspiring candidates and interview them on a given date. After that you will have to send your report to the National Executive Committee (NEC)," President Chiluba said."The NEC will also interview the aspiring candidates. After NEC has scrutinised the aspiring candidates a final panel will get back to the constituencies comprising of NEC members."

President Chiluba also said the NEC would be the final body to adopt the candidates because some would want to bribe the constituency members.

"The NEC is the final body to look at the candidates because some security information that is not available to you is available to us," President Chiluba said.

August 20, 1996


Ethiopia;
Voice Of TPLF Expands Broadcast Coverage


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

MAKALLE - The Voice of TPLF, a radio station of the Tigray People's Liberation Front(TPLF), expands its broadcast coverage after the completion of an improvisation project worth 12 million birr, the manager announced.

Ato Fire Tesfamichael, the manager, said the radio station that used to transmit its programmes within 500 kilometre radius with a one mega watt power, has now expanded its coverage to 1,500 kilometre radius by installing a 10 mega watt power. 

The manager said the weekly seven-hour transmission has also been increased to 22 hours.

He said the radio broadcasts educational, informative and entertaining programme.

Ato Alemseged Gebreamlak, member of the EPRDF executive committee, said at the inaugural ceremony that the radio station had played a vital role in boosting the morale of the public in the fight against the Derg regime.

Ethiopia;
Demonstration In Support 0f Action Against Terrorism


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

JIJIGA - Residents of the Kebribeyah Woreda in Somali Regional State have expressed support to the military action taken by the defence force against terrorists in a demonstration they staged Sunday.

The public took to the streets of Kebribeyah and Hartishek towns and vowed to stand on the side of the defence force to wipe out terrorists bent on distablizing the region. 

Some businessmen among the demonstration said terrorists have been impeding their activities.

The Kebribeyah Woreda Council Chairman Ato Abdi Mohammed, in his address to the demonstrators called on the public to join hands with the defence force in safeguarding the prevalence of peace in the region.

Representative of the defence force in the area on his part said the army will work for sustainable development along side its mission to maintain peace.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


295 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 20, 1996


Ethiopia;
Neighbouring Regions In East Pledge To Work Jointly


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

JIJIGA - Neighbouring regions in East Ethiopia announced that they will endeavour to maintain cultural, economic and historical ties of their peoples.

The regions, in a resolution they passed at the end of their second congress Sunday, pledged to work for mutual development and benefit through the coordinated involvement of the people. 

They also expressed their pride over the measures taken by the defence force against anti-peace elements and commended its actions as a proof to its competence in safeguarding the on-going democratization process.

They called on the public to brace for the translation into practice of the resolution.

On Saturday, the congress approved its statute outlined by the various regional joint committees, following extensive discussion on the draft presented by the committees and making amendments.

The statute gives the congress the authority to draw and approve directives as well as take actions which ensure peace and stability in the region.

The statute empowers the economic affairs committee with the responsibility to monitor contraband trade, balance inter-state trade tariff, fight corruption and protect natural resources.

According to the statute, the social affairs committee coordinates activities which would be done to prevent transcendent natural and man made disasters and facilitate the effective management of training centres.

The security affairs committee is responsible to track down and detain cross- border criminals and solve disputes that might arise along borders between neighbouring regions, the statute states.

Ato Id Tahir, Head of the Somali Region, was elected as chairman of the congress whose members include Somali, Harari, Oromiya and Afar regional states and Dire Dawa administration. The third congress will be held in Dire Dawa.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


296 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 20, 1996


Ethiopia;
Fourth Ethio-Eritrean Joint Meeting Opens


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Addis Ababa - The fourth Ethio-Eritrean joint high ministerial commission meeting opened yesterday here in the capital.

Opening the meeting, deputy Premier Tamirat Layne said Ethiopia and Eritrea have been committed to implementing agreements signed in the political, economic and social sectors.

The two countries have coordinated their efforts to ensure peace and security in the region, he said, adding consultation are under way to further strengthen their cooperation in judicial assistance and extradition of criminals. 

"We should formulate mechanisms to harmonise our various fiscal and monetary polices for implementing the agreements we reached to establish a free trade area last year in Asmara", Ato Tamirat added.

Ato Mohammed Sherifo, Eritrean Interior Minister and head of the delegation, said on his part that the historical ties between Ethiopia and Eritrea is the basis for their achievements.

"Both countries should coordinate their economic and human resources to enable their people live in peace, stability, tranquillity and prosperity," he said.

The meeting would assess the problems faced in implementing the mutual agreements signed between the two countries and is expected to draw a joint communique.

The four-member Eritrean delegation arrived here Sunday. In a brief statement Ato Mohammed gave at Bole International airport he said the objective of the meeting is to review, identify and solve problems encountered during the implementation of the bilateral cooperation agreements between the two neighbouring countries.

He mentioned that the meeting was supposed to take place six months before but has been delayed upto for various reasons.

The minister said satisfactory results have been achieved through the four joint meetings the two countries held so far and added two of the meetings were conducted in Addis Ababa and two others in Asmara.

The delegation was received on arrival at the airport by Ato Tamirat Layne, Deputy Prime Minister and Defence Minister and other senior government officials.

LANGUAGE: English

Ethiopia;
Voice of TPLF expands broadcast coverage

MAKALLE (ENA) - The Voice of TPLF, a radio station of the Tigray People's Liberation Front(TPLF), expands its broadcast coverage after the completion of an improvisation project worth 12 million birr, the manager announced.

Ato Fire Tesfamichael, the manager, said the radio station that used to transmit its programmes within 500 kilometre radius with a one mega watt power, has now expanded its coverage to 1,500 kilometre radius by installing a 10 mega watt power. 

The manager said the weekly seven-hour transmission has also been increased to 22 hours.

He said the radio broadcasts educational, informative and entertaining programme.

Africa News


August 20, 1996


Ethiopia;
Neighbouring regions in East pledge to work jointly


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

JIJIGA (ENA) - Neighbouring regions in East Ethiopia announced that they will endeavour to maintain cultural, economic and historical ties of their peoples.

The regions, in a resolution they passed at the end of their second congress Sunday, pledged to work for mutual development and benefit through the coordinated involvement of the people.

They also expressed their pride over the measures taken by the defence force against anti-peace elements and commended its actions as a proof to its competence in safeguarding the on-going democratization process. 

They called on the public to brace for the translation into practice of the resolution.

On Saturday, the congress approved its statute outlined by the various regional joint committees, following extensive discussion on the draft presented by the committees and making amendments.

The statute gives the congress the authority to draw and approve directives as well as take actions which ensure peace and stability in the region.

The statute empowers the economic affairs committee with the responsibility to monitor contraband trade, balance inter-state trade tariff, fight corruption and protect natural resources.

According to the statute, the social affairs committee coordinates activities which would be done to prevent transcendent natural and man made disasters and facilitate the effective management of training centres.

The security affairs committee is responsible to track down and detain cross- border criminals and solve disputes that might arise along borders between neighbouring regions, the statute states.

Ato Id Tahir, Head of the Somali Region, was elected as chairman of the congress whose members include Somali, Harari, Oromiya and Afar regional states and Dire Dawa administration. The third congress will be held in Dire Dawa.

Demonstration staged in support of military action against terrorist

JIJIGA (ENA) - Residents of the Kebribeyah Woreda in Somali Regional State have expressed support to the military action taken by the defence force against terrorists in a demonstration they staged Sunday.

The public took to the streets of Kebribeyah and Hartishek towns and vowed to stand on the side of the defence force to wipe out terrorists bent on distablizing the region.

Some businessmen among the demonstration said terrorists have been impeding their activities.

The Kebribeyah Woreda Council Chairman Ato Abdi Mohammed, in his address to the demonstrators called on the public to join hands with the defence force in safeguarding the prevalence of peace in the region.

Representative of the defence force in the area on his part said the army will work for sustainable development along side its mission to maintain peace.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


299 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 20, 1996


Ethiopia;
Fourth Ethio-Eritrean joint meeting opens


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The fourth Ethio-Eritrean joint high ministerial commission meeting opened yesterday here in the capital.

Opening the meeting, deputy Premier Tamirat Layne said Ethiopia and Eritrea have been committed to implementing agreements signed in the political, economic and social sectors.

The two countries have coordinated their efforts to ensure peace and security in the region, he said, adding consultation are under way to further strengthen their cooperation in judicial assistance and extradition of criminals. 

"We should formulate mechanisms to harmonise our various fiscal and monetary polices for implementing the agreements we reached to establish a free trade area last year in Asmara", Ato Tamirat added.

Ato Mohammed Sherifo, Eritrean Interior Minister and head of the delegation, said on his part that the historical ties between Ethiopia and Eritrea is the basis for their achievements.

"Both countries should coordinate their economic and human resources to enable their people live in peace, stability, tranquillity and prosperity," he said.

The meeting would assess the problems faced in implementing the mutual agreements signed between the two countries and is expected to draw a joint communique.

The four-member Eritrean delegation arrived here Sunday.

In a brief statement Ato Mohammed gave at Bole International airport he said the objective of the meeting is to review, identify and solve problems encountered during the implementation of the bilateral cooperation agreements between the two neighbouring countries.

He mentioned that the meeting was supposed to take place six months before but has been delayed upto for various reasons.

The minister said satisfactory results have been achieved through the four joint meetings the two countries held so far and added two of the meetings were conducted in Addis Ababa and two others in Asmara.

The delegation was received on arrival at the airport by Ato Tamirat Layne, Deputy Prime Minister and Defence Minister and other senior government officials.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
