Africa News


August 21, 1996


Sudan;
Sudan Arrests More Than 10 People for Subversive Activities


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - The authorities in Sudan have arrested 19

civilians and an unspecified number of military personnel for their alleged involvement in plans to sabotage vital installations at port Sudan on the Red Sea.

The governor of the Red Sea State, Badawi al Khar, said those arrested wanted to sabotage vital utilities at the port in order to "paralyse the country's supply routes." Most of Sudan's imports and exports pass through Port Sudan.

The plotters were planning to take important figures hostage and liquidate them if their plans failed, the government-owned daily Al Engaz Al Watani quoted Khar as saying at a news conference Tuesday.

The Sudanese army Monday announced the arrest of an unspecified number of people for their involvement in a plot to cripple Sudan's international trade in the east.

The military said in a communique that the opposition had tried to use " weak-spirited individuals for implementing their destructive plans."

The statement did not, however, say when the suspects were arrested.

It only said that state security had monitored "the hirelings" closely.

At the news conference, Khar said that those arrested were being interrogated and that "some of the accused were released for lack of evidence. " He did not specify the number of those who were released.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


301 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


Burundi;
Boutros-Ghali Warns Of Possible Genocide In Burundi


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

United Nations - United Nations Secretary-General Boutros-Ghali has warned the international community to be prepared for the possibility of a genocide in Burundi.

In his latest report to the UN Security Council released Wednesday, the secretary-general said while the UN might be willing to help in any contingency plan for a military intervention, it could not carry it out alone.

"The UN is ready to help, within its limited capacity," he said, adding, " But I am convinced that it is a delusion to think that such an operation could be planned, deployed and commanded by the UN as if it were a peace- keeping operation." 

The secretary-general said if the situation in Burundi exploded, "military intervention to save lives might become an inescapable imperative," irrespective of what the government of Burundi, which is opposed to any foreign intervention, might think.

He disclosed that the UN had been pursuing a two-track approach - a possible peace-keeping mission and a multinational force - in its contingency plan for a rapid humanitarian response in the event of widespread violence in Burundi.

But his report also indicated that the approaches had not recorded much success in terms of the number of countries willing to make troops contribution or offer financial, logistic or material assistance.

According to the report, only 14 of 86 countries approached by the UN to indicate what contribution they might be prepared to make to a peace-keeping mission, responded positively.

On the multinational force, the report said, only 10 of the nearly 50 countries contacted by the UN have responded positively, and only three of that number -- Ethiopia, Uganda and Tanzania -- have offered troops.

"The response of member states to the secretariat's efforts... to canvass support for intervention in Burundi has thus not yet matched the urgency and seriousness of the situation in that country," the secretary-general said.

He said in view of the poor response, some member states had suggested that the UN consider planning, organizing and conducting the force, as well as the possibility of its being financed through assessed contribution.

But the secretary-general noted that with the force expected to reach about 50,000, "I have doubts about the willingness of member states to provide troops for an operation on this scale or to finance it."

However, he said the UN had written to 30 potential troop contributors to assess their reactions to the possibility, adding, "It is necessary to leave no stone upturned in the search for ways to help save Burundi from the cataclysm which threatens it."

Burundi has been in turmoil since 1993, when the first democratically- elected president was killed in a failed coup.

Since then, an estimated 150,000 people have been killed in incessant violence.

A July 25 coup in which Maj. Pierre Buyoya replaced President Sylvestre Ntibantungaya has increased the fear of further deterioration in the situation, amid biting sanctions from neighboring countries.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


302 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Nyerere Foundation Established In Tanzania


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - An organisation known as "The Mwalimu Nyerere

Foundation" has been created in Tanzania for the purpose of promoting peace, unity and people-centered development in Africa.

According to a document received by PANA in Dakar Wednesday, the foundation "will seek to fulfill those purposes by encouraging and as necessary organizing dialogues within Africa, among and between governments, peoples, and local institutions."

Formally registered in June 1996, the foundation seeks to perpetuate the local and international efforts of Julius Nyerere, the "Founding Father" of independent Tanganyika, which got its independence from Britain on Dec.9, 1961. 

Nyerere was also "Co-Founding Father" and the first President of Tanzania, which was created by merging Tanganyika and the Indian Ocean islands of Zanzibar in April 1964. He was re-elected four times, refusing to stand in the presidential elections of 1985.

The foundation "will work on the basis that neither peace, unity, nor development can be secure within or between countries unless the attitudes and institutions upholding them are rooted in the people and ultimately under their control."

It has been established as "an intellectually independent body not linked to any political party."

It will initiate, encourage and assist the development of action-oriented proposals based on the sharing of experience, ideas, and knowledge, among governments, non-governmental organizations, and individuals.

"To pursue its own objectives more effectively, the foundation will seek to cooperate with other institutions - within and outside Africa - which have similar purposes, or whose purposes overlap with its own."

While it will be independent of all governments and is separate from academic and other non-governmental institutions, "the Foundation hopes to be able, as appropriate, to work with them, or assist them."

In addition, it will also promote the study of the principles adopted and practiced by Nyerere who introduced a socialist policy known as "Ujamaa" based on the African traditional family and village life.

"To that end, the foundation will collect, analyze, catalogue and care for documents, letters speeches, interviews, reports and other information concerning Nyerere.

The idea of establishing a "Nyerere Center" was first raised in 1986 after his retirement. It resurfaced at different times in the University of Dar es Salaam, among informal discussion groups, and among individuals discussing either the history or the future of Tanzania.

Finally, a group of individuals from government service, from the University, and from the private sector, persuaded Nyerere to allow their ideas to develop in a coherent and co-ordinated manner.

"It is intended that the foundation will be a modest-sized institution, pursuing its objectives economically and without ostentation in conformity with the example set by Mwalimu Nyerere himself throughout his life and work."

The document sent to PANA said a temporary office has been opened in Dar es Salaam's Sokoine Drive, while contributions towards the foundation have already started coming in.

Nyerere is currently chairman of the Geneva-based "South Center" the successor of the South Commission, which was established by the Non-Aligned Movement in 1986 to promote economic dialogue among developing countries.

He was also mediating in the Burundian ethnic conflict before the military takeover by the Tutsi-dominated army in Bujumbura on July 25.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


303 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Measles Defies Immunization In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe has registered an upshot of between

12 to 86 percent in measles cases in the last two months, despite government's immunization programme of children aged five years and below.

A ministry of health and child welfare official said in an interview over the weekend that most of the measle cases were among children over five years old. 

He said government was currently formulating strategies of eliminating measles in Zimbabwe, following a recent outbreak of the disease.

Nearly 5,500 measles cases have been reported in 1996 with 30 deaths, an increase from about 2,500 cases reported at the same time in 1995.

The official said 576 new cases of measles were reported during the week- ending Aug. 4.

"We have been experiencing a sharp increase over the past few weeks and the majority of these cases are among children over five years old. We are looking at how the English-speaking Caribbean has managed to reduce measle cases to almost zero," he said.

On malaria, the official said the national trend surprisingly showed an increase of 18 percent in the number of cases reported during the week-ending Aug. 4.

He said a total of 8,865 cases with eight deaths were reported countrywide during the week under review.

Malaria has so far killed 1,664 people in Zimbabwe in 1996.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


304 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


Angola;
Illegal Immigrants Deported From Angola


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUANDA, Angola - Angola has deported 165 Malian, Sierra Leonian,

Gambian and Lebanese immigrants, Angolan police announced Tuesday.

Aircraft of the Angolan airline, TAAG, were chartered to carry the deportees as part of a police operation code-named "Cancer II", which started on August 8, to track and repatriate foreign nationals involved in illegal practices in the country. 

Last Saturday, about 150 immigrants, mainly Africans, were deported from Angola.

The operation has spread to other parts of the country, especially in the provinces of Lunda-Norte and Lunda-Sul, where 250 immigrants from Zaire, Mali, Gambia and Guinea, accused of illegal diamond deals, have been arrested.

Since the beginning of the operation, one Frenchman, one Lebanese-born North-American, four Indians and one Chinese have been among the deportees, the majority of whom were Africans.

The operation has so far led to the arrest of 748 illegal immigrants from 26 countries.

Meanwhile, Senegal's foreign ministry has said the deportation of several hundred immigrants from West, Central and East Africa is "difficult to accept" .

In a statement released to the Senegalese news agency Tuesday, the ministry regretted that "such measures are taken by African states against African nationals whatever the reasons or justifications given."

"Current negotiations are rather advanced but deportations are continuing," the ministry said, adding that the Senegalese government will make every effort so that a solution based on principles is found and practical modalities adopted to protect African nationals in Angola.

Eighty-six Senegalese deportees arrived in Dakar August 13, on board a Taag plane chartered by Luanda. They were taken care of by the foreign ministry in cooperation with the crisis committee chaired by President Abdou Diouf's chief-of-staff.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


305 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


Togo;
Prime Minister Eyadema Appoints New Prime Minister


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

LOME, Togo - Kwassi Klutse, Togo's Planning and Land Use Minister, was Tuesday appointed Prime Minister by the Togolese Head of State, General Gnassingbe Eyadema, official sources in Lome said. 

The former prime minister, Edem Kodjo, who was from the opposition, handed in his resignation Monday. This was after the opposition lost a crucial parliamentary bye-election Sunday.

In a note explaining the change of prime minister, the Togolese presidency said that the presidential coalition had obtained an absolute majority in parliament after winning Sunday's election.

It now has 43 seats while the opposition has 38 in the 81-member parliament.

Klutse, 51, is a graduate of the Paris Institute for Economic and Social Development Studies.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


306 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


United States and Africa;
Frontline Feminisms Conference Information


BYLINE: The Center For Women In Coalition


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Riverside - The Center for Women in Coalition at the University of California, Riverside is organizing a conference, "Frontline Feminisms: Women, War, and Resistance" to take place on campus January 16-18, 1997. Participants will discuss the forging of new feminisms in the context of militarized situations around the world.

The conference aims to link feminist activist and grass-roots organizers engaged in innovative feminist praxes with a gathering of scholars and policy- makers engaged in theorizing conflict and promoting cooperation.

Featured participants will include women from the Balkans, the Middle East, Central America, South Asia, the Philippines, Africa, and the United States. 

Workshop, film/video, visual art, creative writing and paper proposals are due August 1. All scholars and activists interested in attending are invited to send their mailing and/or e-mail addresses to the organizers for inclusion on the mailing list.

Conference registration will be $30 ($15 for students) and modestly-priced lodging will be available. (Registration and lodging can be waived in case of need.)

1. The conference is international in scope and we are interested in flying activists from different parts of the world. This is of course dependent on funding. We have invited women associated with the politics of the Balkans, South Asia, Central America/Mexico, Israel and Palestine, Iran, and hope to expand our contacts in sub-Saharan Africa, East Asia and South America. However, we are particularly interested in creating linkages between local and national activists and scholars with women from other parts of the world. In southern California, there is a richness of activism among Mexican- American, Native American Asian- American communities and we will be tapping into these regional networks.

Confirmed speakers include: Vasanthi Raman, Senior Fellow, Center for Women's Development Studies, New Delhi; Soona Samsami, Member Foreign Affairs Committee, National Council of Iran; Gila Svirsky, Member and Founder, Women in Black Advisory Council, Israel Women's Network; Rachel Wareham, Activist and Trainer; Motrat Qiriazi-Rural women activists; Kosovo Kemi Oyarzun, Founder, Center for Women's Studies, Santiago, Chile. This list does not include the many academic scholars who have either committed themselves to, or expressed interest in, participating. Also, we are working with the rich network of activist groups in Southern California that are addressing issues such as immigration, political asylum, and labor, which are closely linked with struggles elsewhere.

2. The conversations will not only connect the "global" and the "local" they will also connect the "academic" with the "practical". As such, we are welcoming all sorts of texts and discourses -- papers can follow the conventions of academic conferencing, but they can also include creative writing, photodocumentary essays, installations, film/video. They can and will be bi or tri-lingual and interpreters will be on hand! We hope that conversations are multiple, linking scholars with activists, poets, artists and whatever intersections and permutations of both. There will be panel presentations, workshops and films.

3. We remain open -- in policy -- to any ideas and creative possibilities which we can accomodate within the constraints we have: time and money. So please do get in touch with us -- about people both here and internationally who we could contact. We are already heartened by the enthusiasm which is seeping in from all quarters of global cyber-space and will follow any "lead" you suggest. Please note again that our funding IS limited in terms of being able to pay for air-tickets but we are going to be creative about good but cheap accommodation in Riverside -- and transportation within the area (to and from airports etc).

4. We are also committed to trying to financially assist women who are not connected to any sources of conventional funding (university, foundations etc) and who will be prohibited because of financial inability to pay for train/plane tickets, housing etc.

5. We are also planning to put together an anthology of writing about these issues (again both academic and other kinds of work) which will be published. We intend to archive (both in text and video) the conference.

For more information, write, fax, or e-mail: Piya Chatterjee and Marguerite Waller, Department of Women's Studies, UC Riverside, Riverside, CA 92521. FAX: (909) 787-6386. EMAIL: mwaller@ucrac1.ucr.edu or piya@ucrac1.ucr.edu


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


307 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


Arts;
Planet Africa 1996


BYLINE: Toronto International Film Festival


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2000 words


 

Toronto - Inaugurated in 1995 to both critical and audience acclaim, Planet Africa returns as a regular part of the 1996 Toronto International Film Festival, presenting films from Africa and the African diaspora. Programmed by Cameron Bailey, Planet Africa includes six world premieres in a programme of eight features and five short films.

"We generated a lot of enthusiasm last year with a modest slate of films," says Bailey. "This year we're back with a larger programme including several world premieres and more films from more of the African world. We've covered the continent more broadly with films from southern, northern and western Africa, as well as other parts of the Diaspora. This year establishes Toronto as the place in North America to see new African film each year."

The following are the films featured in this year's Planet Africa. 

WHEN THE STARS MEET THE SEA (QUAND LES ETOILES RENCONTRENT LA MER) - World Premiere

Director: Raymond Rajaonarivelo, Madagascar/France, 1996 Madagascar's pre- eminent filmmaker establishes his place at the forefront of African cinema with this majestic film taking his story from a particularly resonant Malagasy myth. A boy, born on the day of an eclipse in a small village, is believed to possess great and dangerous powers. As a test, he must endure one night alone among the cattle. But a childless young woman rescues him, forever changing his fate. This startlingly beautiful film reveals Madagascar as one of the last magical places on earth.

ARISTOTLE'S PLOT - World Premiere

Director: Jean-Pierre Bekolo, Zimbabwe/France, 1996 ARISTOTLE'S PLOT began as the African entry in the British Film Institute's commemoration of the centenary of cinema. Instead of a respectful documentary like Martin Scorsese's US contribution, Bekolo serves up a wild hybrid that's half meditation on the trials of African moviemaking, half action movie send-up. In a southern African town, a group of wannabe gangsters hangs out at the Cinema Africa, megadosing on the latest actionfest while assuming the names of their screen gods: Van Damme, Bruce Lee, Nikita, Saddam, and the leader, Cinema. Enter an earnest cineaste, trying in vain to enlist the government's help in cleansing the Cinema Africa of Hollywood contamination, replacing Schwarzenegger with Ousmane Sembene. Taking matters into his own hands, he becomes a vigilante for a home-grown film culture.

EVERYONE'S CHILD - World Premiere

Director: Tsitsi Dangarembga, Zimbabwe, 1996. In her debut feature, Commonwealth Writer's Prize-winning playwright and novelist Tsitsi Dangarembga distills the statistics of the millions of African children orphaned because of AIDS. When their parents die suddenly, Tamari and her brother Itai must fend for both themselves and their younger siblings. Itai heads to Harare, where local hoods take him in and train him in the ways of the street. Back in the village, Tamari accepts the advances of a lecherous shopkeeper. As she tries to use his gifts to pay for her siblings' schooling, the village women suggest she leave, to keep the village safe for their husbands.

JOHN HENRIK CLARKE: A GREAT AND MIGHTY WALK - World Premiere

Director: St. Clair Bourne, USA, 1996. African-American historian John Henrik Clarke is a legend among scholars. Born into sharecropping, self- taught long before he entered academia, he possesses an astounding knowledge of the roots and branches of African history. He's also a great talker. Veteran documentarian St. Clair Bourne (MAKING DO THE RIGHT THING) lets the man do just that in this remarkable documentary, weaving Clarke's words into a mix of archival treasures and image manipulation. From ancient Egypt, we move through the Mediterranean, Africa's great empires, the slave trade, and African American history right up to the Million Man March. Though now blind, Clarke has lost none of his razor-sharp edge. "If you lose your eyesight," he says, "increase your insight." Narrated and executive produced by Wesley Snipes.

A SUMMER IN LA GOULETTE (UN ETE A LA GOULETTE) - North American Premiere

Director: Ferid Boughedir, Tunisia/France/Belgium, 1995 Ferid Boughedir's first film since his acclaimed HALFAOUINE is a sly comedy full of warmth, wit and exuberance, as he crafts a glorious portrait of a Tunisian resort neighbourhood where Muslims, Christians and Jews live side by side. It's the summer of 1967, and three teenage girls vow to lose their virginity by the festive Day of the Madonna. As events come to a boil, reports filter in about a potential war in the Middle East. But the people of La Goulette are captivated by more immediate news -- the nation's most treasured daughter, the celestial Claudia Cardinale (playing herself), is returning from Europe for a triumphant visit.

MACADAM TRIBE (MACADAM TRIBU)

Director: Jose Laplaine, France/Zaire/Mali, 1996 Laplaine's lively, comic first feature weaves unemployment, lust and family commitments into a series of scenes-from-the-quarter. Mike is an ex-con and layabout, while his brother Kapa spends his time boxing with his amateur-fighter friend Duka. The brothers are deeply concerned about their mother, Mother Bavusi, a former market woman who now spends her days quietly getting drunk. When Duka is knocked into a coma, the whole neighborhood of strivers, whores and amateur philosophers rallies together.

THE WATERMELON WOMAN

Director: Cheryl Dunye, USA, 1996

This debut feature from one of America's leading indie media stars, is fierce, funny and genuinely romantic. Dunye plays Cheryl, whose main passion is a forgotten black act or credited only as the Watermelon Woman. Frustrated by slim pickings on the dating front, Cheryl puts her energy into tracking down her mystery mammy. Moving effortlessly between fiction and mock documentary, Dunye reclaims the history of black-cast movies as she affectionately skewers the coupling habits of downtown Philadelphia lesbians. Meanwhile, Cheryl falls for a flirty white girl named Diana, (GO FISH discovery Guin Turner). Cameo by legendary motormouth and lesbian icon Camille Paglia.

W.E.B. DU BOIS: A BIOGRAPHY IN FOUR VOICES

Direcotr: Louis Massiah, USA, 1996. Dr. William Edward Burghardt Du Bois (1868 - 1963) stands as one of America's greatest scholars and political activists. His life story, spanning the post-Civil War Reconstruction period, the rise of Communism and Pan-Africanism, and the Civil Rights Movement, is chronicled by four leading African-American writers: Toni Cade Bambara, Amiri Baraka, Wesley Brown, and Thulani Davis. This richly woven visual history explores the major strategies for African-American empowerment during the 20th Century.

PLANET AFRICA SHORT FILM PROGRAMMES

PROGRAMME 1: Three stories from the playing fields of sex and race. From Britain to Burkina Faso, the rules between men and women are eternally fluid.

I BRING YOU FRANKINCENSE, Ngozi Onwurah, UK, 1996, 35 min. World Premiere

Sunshine Brown, the only bi-racial boy in Guildford, suffers at school both for his cocoa complexion and his hippie mother. Sunshine's only break comes each Christmas, when as one of the three wise men in the annual pageant he delivers exactly one line: "I bring you frankincense."

PUK NINI, Fanta Nacro, Burkina Faso, 1995, 30 min.

Salif and Isa are an average bourgeois couple, but when a Senegalese bombshell comes to town, Salif drops his pants in a minute. Isa embarks on exquisitely planned revenge.

SPIDERS AND FLIES, Danny Thompson, UK, 1996, 30 min. World Premiere

Lena meets the man of her dreams, only to realize she's just a stand-in for his one true passion. Same hair, same everything. She launches a plan that would make Machiavelli step back.

PROGRAMME 2: Their subjects may be different, but this pair of critically intelligent films sums up two poles of African experience -- the past in slavery and the future in dub science.

ASIENTOS, Francois Woukoache, Senegal/Belgium, 1995, 52 min.

On Goree Island off the coast of Senegal, a young man seeks refuge from present-day strife through a journey into history. Though no pictures captured the brutality of Goree Island's slave trade, the island retains memories of profound horror and strength.

THE LAST ANGEL OF HISTORY, John Akomfrah, UK, 1996, 45 min. North American Premiere

What do George Clinton's funkadelic Mothership, Sun Ra's jazz Arkestra and Lee Scratch Perry's Black Ark have in common? Weaving an impressive mix of interviews and analysis, Akomfrah reveals an alternate path in black culture

PLANET AFRICA FILMS CONFIRMED TO DATE

ARISTOTLE'S PLOT, Jean-Pierre Bekolo, Zimbabwe/France, 1996 ASIENTOS, Francois Woukoache, Senegal/Belgium, 1995 EVERYONE'S CHILD, Tsitsi Dangarembga, Zimbabwe, 1996 I BRING YOU FRANKINCENSE, Ngozi Onwurah, UK, 1996 JOHN HENRIK CLARKE: A GREAT AND MIGHTY WALK, St. Clair Bourne, USA, 1996 THE LAST ANGEL OF HISTORY, John Akomfrah, UK, 1996 MACADAM TRIBE (MACADAM TRIBU), Jose 82 Laplaine, France/Zaire/Mali, 1996, A SUMMER IN LA GOULETTE (UN ETE A LA GOULETTE), Ferid Boughedir, Tunisia/France/Belgium, 1995, PUK NINI, Fanta Nacro, Burkina Faso, 1995 SPIDERS AND FLIES, Danny Thompson, UK, 1996 W.E.B. DU BOIS: A BIOGRAPHY IN FOUR VOICES, Louis Massiah, USA, 1996, THE WATERMELON WOMAN, Cheryl Dunye, USA, 1996 WHEN THE STARS MEET THE SEA (QUAND LES 90 TILES RENCONTRENT LA MER), Raymond Rajaonarivelo, Madagascar/France, 1996.

Planet Africa is sponsored by Conros Corporation/Northland Firelogs and OXFAM Canada.

Special thanks to Black Film and Video Network.

The 21st Toronto International Film Festival runs September 5 - 14, 1996.

For further information contact Valerie Wint (416) 967-7371.

The website address for the Toronto Film Festival is: http://www.bell. ca/toronto/filmfest/ The schedule of "Planet Africa" films will be available on the Bell website at the end of August.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

308 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


Ethiopia and Eritrea;
Ethiopia, Eritrea Agree To Intensify Cooperation


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopia and Eritrea agreed to intensify with vigour and renewed impetus the cooperation existing between the two countries in the economic, cultural, political and diplomatic fields for the mutual benefit of the peoples of the two countries.

the joint communique issued yesterday by the fourth session of the Ethio- Eritrean joint high ministerial commission said the two sides, having reviewed the progress made in the implementation of the agreements in the economic fields, expressed satisfaction at the achievements and progress made in a number of sectors.

The joint ministerial commission, following the identification of certain impediments in the implementation of the agreements on trade, finance and investment and especially on the establishment of the free trade area and on transport and communication has agreed to establish a joint committee to review the efforts made so far and identify the problems encountered in the implementation process and submit a report to the commission within three months, according to the communique. 

The two sides, it said, commended the progress made in the social sector and expressed determination to further promote the activities in these areas with the view to bringing their two peoples even closer.

With regard to the political sphere, the two sides expressed satisfaction on the closes collaboration and coordination attained through the successful and effective implementation of the agreements, it indicated.

Both sides have recognized the need for establishing an effective follow-up mechanism so as to ensure the full and speedy implementation of the agreements signed in various areas of cooperation, according to the communique.

The joint ministerial commission in this regard, has also agreed to set up a unit in each country accountable to the respective chairman of the high commission to serve as focal points.

The communique further said the commission urged all relevant authorities and institutions of the two countries to redouble their efforts in expediting the actual implementation of all agreements and protocols signed between the two parties in the spirit of the prevailing fraternal relations existing between the peoples and governments of Ethiopia and Eritrea.

It added that both sides expressed conviction that the promotion of close exemplary relations between the two countries will have a vital contribution to the well-being of their peoples and to the enhancement of peace, stability and eventual economic integration of the sub-region.

The two parties reviewed the multifaceted relations between the two countries in various areas and held extensive discussions.

Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and Atom Mahmud Ahmed Sherifo, Minister of Local Government of the State of Eritrea led their respective high level delegations to the meeting.

The fourth Ethio-Eritrea joint ministerial commission has decided to hold its next meeting in December 1996, in Asmara.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 21, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia, Eritrea agree to intensify cooperation


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Ethiopia and Eritrea agreed to intensify with vigour and renewed impetus the cooperation existing between the two countries in the economic, cultural, political and diplomatic fields for the mutual benefit of the peoples of the two countries.

the joint communique issued yesterday by the fourth session of the Ethio- Eritrean joint high ministerial commission said the two sides, having reviewed the progress made in the implementation of the agreements in the economic fields, expressed satisfaction at the achievements and progress made in a number of sectors.

The joint ministerial commission, following the identification of certain impediments in the implementation of the agreements on trade, finance and investment and especially on the establishment of the free trade area and on transport and communication has agreed to establish a joint committee to review the efforts made so far and identify the problems encountered in the implementation process and submit a report to the commission within three months, according to the communique. 

The two sides, it said, commended the progress made in the social sector and expressed determination to further promote the activities in these areas with the view to bringing their two peoples even closer.

With regard to the political sphere, the two sides expressed satisfaction on the closes collaboration and coordination attained through the successful and effective implementation of the agreements, it indicated.

Both sides have recognized the need for establishing an effective follow-up mechanism so as to ensure the full and speedy implementation of the agreements signed in various areas of cooperation, according to the communique.

The joint ministerial commission in this regard, has also agreed to set up a unit in each country accountable to the respective chairman of the high commission to serve as focal points.

The communique further said the commission urged all relevant authorities and institutions of the two countries to redouble their efforts in expediting the actual implementation of all agreements and protocols signed between the two parties in the spirit of the prevailing fraternal relations existing between the peoples and governments of Ethiopia and Eritrea.

It added that both sides expressed conviction that the promotion of close exemplary relations between the two countries will have a vital contribution to the well-being of their peoples and to the enhancement of peace, stability and eventual economic integration of the sub-region.

The two parties reviewed the multifaceted relations between the two countries in various areas and held extensive discussions.

Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and Atom Mahmud Ahmed Sherifo, Minister of Local Government of the State of Eritrea led their respective high level delegations to the meeting.

The fourth Ethio-Eritrea joint ministerial commission has decided to hold its next meeting in December 1996, in Asmara.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

310 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Zambia-Treason Police Boss Commits Perjury


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Defence lawyers on Thursday asked a Lusaka Court trying eight opposition politicians for treason, to charge Zambia's Inspector- General of Police, Francis Ndhlovu, for perjury after it was proved he lied to the court.

Ndhlovu is a key state witness in the trial of the opposition leaders, for a spate of bombings which has rocked the southern African country in past months.

The defence lawyers asked that the police boss be charged with perjury after it was found that he lied when he said on oath he had no knowledge of a group which called itself 'Mad-Max, Dogs of the War' which claimed it planted bombs. 

Ndhlovu was giving evidence in the continued treason trial of the eight members of the United National Independence Party (UNIP), who have been charged with treason and murder, following their alleged link with the 'Black Mamba' group, accused of being responsible for the bomb explosions.

The police chief had earlier during cross-examination claimed the Mad-Max group were fictitious. So he had been unable to make any arrests which linked them to the bombs, he said.

However, he was proved to have lied when a defence lawyer, Sakwiba Sikota, produced a deposition of a former intelligent officer, Christopher Mukoka, from the mad-max group, that Ndhlovu agreed that he knew Mukoka personally.

"I pray to this court that the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), who is right here in court, representing the state, issue instruction to charge the Inspector-General of Police with perjury since, under oath, he has told the court lies," Sikota said.

When high court judge Peter Chitengi asked the DPP, Gregory Phiri, whether he had reactions to Sikota's request, Phiri replied: "No Reactions, My Lord."

The defence argued that the state was aware of the Mad-Max group, because it employed the group to plant bombs in order to frame the opposition leaders.

It also said the Mad-Max comes under the Central Joined Operations Committee (CJOC) comprising the police inspector general, army and air force commanders, Zambia National Service commander and director of the intelligence unit under the ministry of defence.

Ndhlovu, who later admitted that CJOC exists, sought the protection of the DPP not to allow him reveal secret operations in court.

Sikota also asked Ndhlovu to immediately resign as Zambia's Inspector- General of Police for committing a crime during the investigations on the Black Mamba.

The police chief admitted that he committed a crime by issuing instructions that the telephone lines of the private 'Post' newspaper be tapped, contrary to existing laws.

Only the Zambia Intelligence Service and Drug Enforcement Commission were supposed to bug telephones under the law.

Ndhlovu was later advised by the judge to remain silent if he did not wish to incriminate himself, after he was cross-examined for almost seven hours on Wednesday and Thursday.

The police boss ducked prying questions, saying he merely issues orders and directives, and so was not fully aware of the scenario of the treason case. The trial continues.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


311 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Liberia;
New Ecomog Commander Says He Will Deploy in Trouble Spots


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The new commander of Ecomog, the ECOWAS peace keeping force in Liberia, has said the deployment of soldiers to trouble spots will be his top priority.

Maj. Gen. Victor Malu, however, warned that the success of the mission would depend on the cooperation of the warring factions and the fulfillment of the pledge by leaders of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) to raise more troops. 

"I hope by the time I get to Monrovia to consolidate earlier gains made by my predecessors, the additional troops we are expecting would have started arriving to aid our peace keeping operation," Malu told journalists Wednesday.

At the recent summit of ECOWAS Committee of Nine on Liberia, in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, it was agreed to increase ECOMOG's strength from the current 8,500 to around 18,000 troops.

Malu said the deployment of ECOMOG troops would stem incessant clashes between the warring factions.

He takes over command from another Nigerian, Maj. Gen. John Mark Inienger, who headed ECOMOG for the past three years.

ECOMOG was sent to Monrovia in August 1990 to try and stop the civil war in Africa's oldest republic.

The war, started in 1989 as a rebellion by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia, has killed at least 150,000 people, defying costly peace initiatives by ECOWAS and the international community.

At the Abuja summit, the Liberian warring factions signed a revised peace plan, beginning with a cease-fire last Tuesday.

This is to be followed by deployment of ECOMOG troops to safe havens, disarmament of Liberia's estimated 60,000 combatants, and then national election in May 1997.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


312 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


South Africa;
De Klerk Apologizes For Apartheid


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Former President F.W. de Klerk has apologized publicly for the misery of the apartheid era in South Africa.

Delivering his National Party's submission to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in Cape Town Wednesday, de Klerk admitted that apartheid had caused what he described as "immeasurable pain and suffering to many."

He accepted responsibility and apologized for the unacceptable things which occurred during his rule. He also claimed that certain elements in the security forces had used unauthorized actions in an attempt to derail the South African transformation from apartheid to democracy while he was president. 

But while he accepted responsibility for human rights abuses committed during the apartheid era under his presidency, he was adamant that his government had never sanctioned assassination, murder, rape or assault.

De Klerk said that the apartheid government -- in an effort to fight the perceived communist threat posed by the African National Congress and the South African Communist Party -- had instituted a national management system to co-ordinate its response.

Resultant far-reaching security legislation and the national state of emergency, he added, created circumstances conducive to many abuses and transgressions against human rights.

There was a perceived need for unconventional counter-strategies, said de Klerk, but he had never been part of any decision by cabinet, the state security council or any other committee authorizing gross violation of human rights.

He admitted, however, that he had authorized cross-border raids aimed at legitimate military targets which specifically excluded civilians.

The former state president expressed his deepest sympathy with those who suffered during the conflict and reiterated his apologies for the pain and suffering caused by the former policies of the National Party when it was in power in South Africa.

Meanwhile, a 23-member delegation -- led by deputy president Thabo Mbeki -- will make the African National Congress submission to the Human Rights Commission Thursday.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


313 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Kenya-;
Tourism In Kenya Drops By 20 Percent


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenya recorded a 20-percent decline in international tourist arrivals in 1995, amounting to a drop of over 150,000 tourists, the minister for tourism nd wildlife, Noah Katana Ngala, has said.

He said that the drop was as a result of the weakening of most of the world's industrialized economies and general poor performance in international tourism. 

"The slowed growth rate translated to a 20-percent decline in international arrivals falling by 150,000 tourists," Ngala said here Wednesday.

He, however, said that Kenya was not the only country whose tourist industry declined in 1995, observing that growth of international tourism was short of expectations.

Ngala, who was launching a book on the 50th anniversary of the Intercontinental Hotel and Resorts, said tourists arrival worldwide totalled 561 million in 1995, reflecting a growth rate of 2.8 percent compared with 5. 5 percent growth rate in 1994.

He said tourism will continue to be a major generator of foreign exchange for most countries and appealed to Kenyan hotels to recognize the tight competition they will be expected to face.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


314 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Burundi;
Medical Supply Plane For Bujumbura


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The French-based organization, Medecins Sans Frontieres (Doctors Without Borders), is sending a cargo plane with drugs, medical and surgical equipment to four provinces in Burundi, according to a statement from the organisation released to PANA Thursday.

The plane left Bordeaux, France, Wednesday and stops over in Nairobi before landing in Bujumbura Thursday.

The 25 tons of drugs on board the plane will supply health centers and hospitals in Kirundo, Makamba, Gitega and Gankuzo, as well as one of the Bujumbura hospitals, for three months, the statement said.

Because of the embargo which has been imposed on Burundi for a week now, certain drugs are becoming hard to find, especially anti-malaria drugs, while the disease is endemic in the region. 

Currently, following the meeting of foreign ministers from the countries which imposed the embargo AuGust 16 in Kampala, only food aid for refugees and drugs are allowed through the borders by Burundi's neighboring countries.

Meanwhile, senior political leaders from Burundi have called for international sanctions to force new military strongman, Maj Pierre Buyoya, to give up power.

Speaking at a press conference in New York Wednesday after meeting with the UN Security Council, the leaders said the sanctions were necessary to put pressure on the new administration, which came to power through a military coup on July 25.

The leaders, from the two political parties represented in the country's parliament -- FRODEBU and UPRONA -- said that such an action by the international community would reinforce the efforts of the countries in the sub-region, which have already announced sanctions against Burundi.

"If the coup was allowed to stand, it would harm the interest of the countries around the world," said Jean Minani, president of FRODEBU and a former minister of health.

He said, "it (the coup) would open the door for all those eager to take power through their weapons. This should not be tolerated in Burundi or anywhere else."

Another FRODEBU official, Jean-Marie Ngendahayo, said the coup, which toppled president Sylvestre Ntibantungaya's government, should be condemned by everybody.

"The embargo set on Burundi must be tougher and be implemented by the rest of the world until Buyoya gives up power," said Ngendahayo, a former foreign minister. "That's why we are here, to tell it to the world, especially the Security Council. That's what we are going to do in the U.S. and Europe and the rest of the world."

However, not all the four leaders at the conference, organized by the New York-based Parliamentarians for Global Action -- an association of elected legislators from 96 countries -- agreed on the need for stronger sanctions against the country.

Adrien Sibomana, an UPRONA member, who was a prime minister under Buyoya, said that he was concerned at the effect that sanctions would have on Burundi.

"Burundi is a landlocked and poor country," he said, noting that international sanctions would hurt the people, especially children who might not have access to disease-preventing vaccinations.

"I am not convinced sanctions are the best way to go," Sibomana added.

The leaders all called on the international community to help initiate a process of political reconciliation in Burundi.

They asked that the report of the commission of inquiry into the 1993 failed coup, in which the country's first democratically-elected President (Melchior Ndadaye) was killed, be published.

"We believe that all those responsible for the series of killings and violence ought to be brought together irrespective of their party affiliations," said Anatole Kanyenkiko of UPRONA.

Kanyenkiko, also a former prime minister, said the international community had a role to play in terms of ensuring justice, adding: "We want the report of the commission to be made public."

The July 25 coup is the culmination of the violence which has racked Burundi since the 1993 coup attempt. An estimated 150,000 people have been killed in the violence.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


315 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Swaziland;
South Africa Moves Against Swazi Sugar


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland - South Africa has decided to take punitive measures against Swaziland in their ongoing controversy over cheap Swazi sugar exports to the country.

Relations between the two countries have soured following complaints that cheaper Swazi sugar presented unfair competition to the South African sugar industry.

Swaziland Sugar Association general manager, Andy Colhoun, told PANA Thursday, that Swaziland had explained its case to South Africa, justifying the sugar exports which help redress a considerable imbalance of total trade between the two countries in favour of South Africa. 

But in spite of that, the South African Sugar Association had decided to take punitive measures against Swaziland.

Colhoun said the South Africans have decided to withhold certain important services and facilities in the country used by the Swaziland Sugar Association for which it has been paying 3.5 million rand a year (about 800, 000 U.S.dollars).

The facilities to be withdrawn when the contracts between the two associations expire March 31, 1997 are the use of the South African Sugar Association facilities for exporting sugar via Durban harbour.

Access to the South African Sugar Association experimental station at Mount Edgecombe is to be withdrawn, thus denying Swaziland new varieties and other agronomic services from that station.

Access to the facilities of the Sugar Milling Research Institute used for various analysis and other essential services essential to the running of an efficient sugar milling industry is also to be withdrawn.

In addition, Swaziland will be denied access from November to the Mount Edgecombe Training Center where up to one third of the students trained come from Swaziland.

Colhoun said the Swaziland sugar industry could be damaged by these actions.

Swaziland's sugar industry has port facilities at Maputo, Mozambique, where the terminal is being upgraded and expanded and has offered the South African Sugar Association the use of the Maputo facilities when appropriate, he said.

Swaziland is currently urgently looking for suitable alternatives in Mauritius, Zimbabwe and Australia to replace the facilities and services to be withdraw by the South African Sugar Association.

Colhoun said the Swaziland sugar industry was equally concerned about misinformation and misconceptions about the industry resulting from recent South Africa press reports.

One of the reports stated Swaziland King Mswati owned over 50 percent of the country's sugar industry.

He said the true facts are that Tibiyo, the Swazi nation trust organization, owns 51 percent of Swaziland's sugar milling industry and 34 percent of the sugar growing industry which includes hundreds of small Swazi growers. The two industries are separate entities of which the king personally owns no part.

Colhoun said he understood top level discussions between the two associations were continuing in South Africa in an effort to resolve the dispute concerning Swaziland's sugar export.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


316 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe Civil Servants Continue With Strike


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Uncertainty surrounds negotiations scheduled to have started Thursday between the Zimbabwe government and civil servants to resolve a salary dispute which has paralysed government services.

The uncertainty comes in the wake of the decision by civil servants to spurn an order by their representative body to return to work.

A major pre-condition for the negotiations set by the government Wednesday was that the striking employees return to work by Thursday morning. 

The civil servants body, Public Service Association (PSA), Wednesday, ordered its members to return to work while it negotiates workers' grievances with the government.

But by early Thursday morning, government workers could be seen milling around the public service, labor and social welfare ministry head offices and the Africa Unity Square, as they persisted with their work boycott.

In Harare, the capital, the workers were addressed by some executive members of the PSA who castigated their colleagues who called off the strike Wednesday evening.

"You cannot be a leader if you dictate, the PSA should have consulted the workers if they agreed with the government's offer," said an irate worker from the ministry of higher education.

The strike action, which has forced the closure of most offices throughout the country and suspension of some service, has generally crippled the provision of essential service over which the government has a monopoly.

The business sector has moaned the absence of tax, immigration, industry and commerce and finance officers, saying the strike should be resolved to save investor confidence.

Civil servants are demanding 60 percent while the government in July awarded them increases of about 9 percent.

Public health workers who initiated the strike were Thursday adamant they would not relent until the government made a firm undertaking to review upward the increases.

Their job action has adversely affected the delivery of health services, with patients being attended to by army and Red Cross volunteers, who are evidently unable to cope.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


317 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Nigeria;
Abacha Swears In New Administrators


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian head of state Gen. Sani Abacha Wednesday administered the oath of office on military administrators (governors) for the nation's 30 states.

Twenty-seven of them are new faces while three old ones were redeployed following a surprise reshuffle announced last week, the first change of the state chief executives since Abacha seized power in November 1994.

He told the young military officers in Abuja, the federal capital, they should be servants and not bosses over the people. 

The new thinking is that "government is no more to be seen as a power above the people," but a veritable instrument for national development, he said.

"Government exists for the people and you must, therefore, go to the states as servants of the people. Since you do not have a fixed tenure, your daily undertakings must be guided by decorum, dedication, discipline, honesty and above all, patriotism."

The administrators are barred from obtaining foreign loans, and are to ensure continuity of programmes initiated by their predecessors.

Abacha also charged them to maintain the "momentum" of his administration's transition to democracy programme, planned to end in October 1998, with the inauguration of elected civilian government.

They are to exhibit absolute neutrality and fairness in which their "role must be transparently seen as that of an impartial umpire."

The Nigerian leader avoided any reference to suggestions in the local press, since the change was announced, that some of the old military administrators could face trial for alleged mismanagement.

Commenting on the reports, the defence spokesman, Brig. Gen. Fred Chijuka, said he could not confirm or deny that such trials would take place.

"It is the prerogative of the presidency," he added.

No official explanation was given for the change of the military administrators, whose tenure of some 32 months was considered long, going by past experiences.

Speculation is also rife that a cabinet reshuffle is likely.

But with silence and surprise as his greatest weapons, Abacha has managed to keep his trump cards close to his chest.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


318 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Zambia;
New Party Says World Bank Has Withheld Cash


BYLINE: Fred M'membe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Lusaka - The newly formed National Lima Party (NLP) yesterday added its voice to the call for political dialogue over the holding of the forthcoming presidential and general elections.

NLP co-chairman Guy Scott, in a press statement released in Lusaka yesterday, said his party's call for dialogue arises from economic concerns.

"Contrary to the impression given by the government media, even the World Bank has turned off the aid taps and this country is very tightly strapped for cash," Scott said, claiming: "A World Bank representative told President Chiluba on Thursday last week that the Bank could not release finance unless there was some prospect of the bilateral donors coming back into the picture after elections."

And the only way, according to Scott, of ensuring that the donors come back " is to conduct a dialogue that will result in some consensus over presidential qualifications, the voters roll, and other controversial matters" . 

"At the moment it is the farmers who are bearing most of the financial strain," the Lima Party co-chairman complained, adding: "There is no money out there for maize buying, and there is no money for inputs for the forthcoming season."

Scott advised that "it is far better for the government to start a constructive process of dialogue than to remain silent and hope that something will turn up".

"No miracle is going to take place," Scott warned. " Only our own common sense will save us from misery."

But a State House source was on Monday quoted by the state owned and government controlled Times of Zambia saying "the President has always been ready for dialogue"

Scott calls for talks and "it has always been the opposition who have torpedoed efforts for dialogue".

The State House spokesman was responding to accusations by the Zambia Democratic Congress that President Frederick Chiluba has closed all doors to dialogue with the opposition or the church - creating frustration and tension in the country.

NLP also demanded that rural dwellers who have not yet collected their voters cards should be given a chance to do so by extending the period of the collection exercise which the Elections Office says will only run up to September 2.

Scott, who co-chairs NLP with Zambia National Farmers Union president Ben Kapita, complained that "the publicity surrounding the collection of cards has been very poor, especially out on the farms".

"We feel government should take the exceptional measure of allocating more time for card collection," Scott said.

Scott said "right now, only some 20 per cent of those eligible can vote".

"It would appear that only half the eligible voters in areas such as Southern Province registered to vote in the first place," Scott carped. " Subsequently it appears that fewer than half of these have actually collected their cards."

And urging Ndola ruling MMD cadres to collect their cards in readiness for the "war", President Frederick Chiluba on Wednesday said the collection voters cards will continue but not indefinitely.

Scott also urged farmers to give their workers time to collect cards.

"While many commercial farmers have actively promoted the registration exercise, others have been unhelpful," Scott said. "One case has been reported to me of a farmer refusing his workers permission to collect cards - on pain of dismissal. This is outrageous."

Scott and Kapita yesterday called on the government to immediately release the K10 billion budgeted for the Food Reserve Agency in order to "restore some semblance of health" to the depressed maize market.

They pointed out that maize was selling in villages at K7,000 per 90 kg bag - considerably less than the production cost of over K10,000.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


319 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Ethiopia;
Rural Road Becomes Operational In Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

GOBA - a 78-kilometre road that links Dollo with Sebro-Jara Sheik town in Bale Zone becomes operational, zonal rural roads office said. 

Office head Ato Ahmed Abubakar said work on the construction of the road completed after a five year delay has been undertaken at a cost of 2 million birr.

The construction of the road is believed to speed up development activities in the area while solving problems of transport for Sheik Hussien pilgrims according to the office head.

He further said the road might be attended upto West Hararge to help promote trade and cultural relations between the people of Bale and West Hararge zones.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 22, 1996


Ethiopia;
Eritrean Delegation Concludes Working Visit


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - Eritrean delegation to the fourth Ethio-Eritrean Joint High Ministerial Commission Meeting headed by Ato Mohammed Sherifo, the country's interior minister returned to Asmara Yesterday.

The Eritrean official told reporters on departure at Bole International Airport that the implementation of cooperative agreements signed between the two government is in progress. 

The minister said a committee responsible for studying and creating conditions for promoting the bilateral relations between the two countries to the desired level has been established. He said the findings of the committee will be submitted to the joint ministerial meeting, he said.

Interior Minister Sherifo said except for some differences on detail provisions, the economic policies of both countries are similar and Eritrea is working to make the policies even more similar.

The minister said the joint ministerial meeting used to be held every six months has now been decided that it be told every four months to facilitate the implementation of the cooperation agreements.

The delegation was seen off by Dr. Kassu Illala, economic sector head with the rank of deputy prime minister and other senior government officials.

August 22, 1996


Ethiopia;
Wounded Minister Returns to Addis


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Minister of Transport and Communications, Dr. Abdulmejid Hussien, said here yesterday that destructive actions perpetrated by ill- disposed forces to derailing the nation-building process have been and will always remain an exercise in futility.

In a statement he gave on arrival from Jerusalem, where he had been receiving medical treatment following a foiled assassination attempt on his life, the fit-looking Dr. Abdulmejid said that those responsible for such vile act will not deter "me or other citizens from pursuing the path of development and peace we have embarked upon". 

He noted that except for some minor problems with his hands "which would be avoided after continued physiotherapeutic treatments," his health is in good condition and that he may get to work soon. He also expressed his heart-felt condolences for the families of the two men -- his body guard and a worker with the postal authority -- who were killed while engaged in saving his life.

On arrival at the airport, Dr. Abdulmejid Hussien was welcomed by the Israeli Ambassador Ato Abrham Granot, Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin and other senior government officials.
