Africa News


August 22, 1996


Ethiopia;
Eritrean delegation concludes working visit


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Eritrean delegation to the fourth Ethio-Eritrean Joint High Ministerial Commission Meeting headed by Ato Mohammed Sherifo, the country's interior minister returned to Asmara Yesterday.

The Eritrean official told reporters on departure at Bole International Airport that the implementation of cooperative agreements signed between the two government is in progress. 

The minister said a committee responsible for studying and creating conditions for promoting the bilateral relations between the two countries to the desired level has been established. He said the findings of the committee will be submitted to the joint ministerial meeting, he said.

Interior Minister Sherifo said except for some differences on detail provisions, the economic policies of both countries are similar and Eritrea is working to make the policies even more similar.

The minister said the joint ministerial meeting used to be held every six months has now been decided that it be told every four months to facilitate the implementation of the cooperation agreements.

The delegation was seen off by Dr. Kassu Illala, economic sector head with the rank of deputy prime minister and other senior government officials.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


324 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 22, 1996


Ethiopia;
Wounded Minister Returns to Addis


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Minister of Transport and Communications, Dr. Abdulmejid Hussien, said here yesterday that destructive actions perpetrated by ill-disposed forces to derailing the nation-building process have been and will always remain an exercise in futility.

In a statement he gave on arrival from Jerusalem, where he had been receiving medical treatment following a foiled assassination attempt on his life, the fit-looking Dr. Abdulmejid said that those responsible for such vile act will not deter "me or other citizens from pursuing the path of development and peace we have embarked upon". 

He noted that except for some minor problems with his hands "which would be avoided after continued physiotherapeutic treatments," his health is in good condition and that he may get to work soon. He also expressed his heart-felt condolences for the families of the two men -- his body guard and a worker with the postal authority -- who were killed while engaged in saving his life.

On arrival at the airport, Dr. Abdulmejid Hussien was welcomed by the Israeli Ambassador Ato Abrham Granot, Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin and other senior government officials.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


325 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Angola;
Unita Reports on Party Congress


BYLINE: Kwacha Unita Press


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Bailundo - The following are reports from Unita on the party congress taking place in central Angola.

23/08/96: The three commissions set up within the framework of the III Extra-ordinary Congress of UNITA, currently taking place in Bailundo since August 20, begun sitting today.

Issues related to the general policy of the Party, diplomacy and information are being debated within the Political Commission, while the Social and Economic Commission is discussing issues concerning the socio- economic life of the Party. Military issues are being debated in the Military Commission. 

In the meantime, journalists and other invited guests visited the Londuimbali quartering area in order to see the real situation in the area described by most observers as dramatic as far as the conditions in which UNITA soldiers and their families are living is concerned. It is worth noting that conditions in the quartering areas are among topics being debated in the Military Commission.

20/08/96: Representatives of Angolan political parties are in Bailundo to attend the UNITA Congress which got underway on August 20, 1996. Ngola Kabango of the FNLA, Andre Milton Kilandamoko of the PSD, Malungo Belo of PDP- ANA and Emanuel Kunzika of the CNDA arrived this morning, aboard a Government plane, accompanied by a group of nine foreign and local journalists based in Luanda.

According to Malungo Belo, their visit is intended to transmit their fraternal solidarity and good wishes for the success "of this most important event."

He said that the resolutions arising from the III Extra-ordinary Congress of UNITA will be decisive and give new life to UNITA and the country as a whole. He is the bearer of a verbal message from his party President for the UNITA President and a written message for UNITA congress delegates.

Ngola Kabango, who first visited Bailundo in 1975 as a member of the Transitional Government, expressed hope that the peace process does not derail and that it should involve all political parties in the country. Invited guests from Italy, Germany, Ivory Coast, Burkina Fasso and Zaire as well as more than 30 journalists from various news organisations around the world are already in Bailundo.

The entire town of Bailundo is covered with UNITA flags and photographs of the UNITA President and is proving to be too small to receive so many people anxious to accompany the UNITA Congress.

19/08/96: Portuguese political parties are present at UNITA's Extra- ordinary Congress. The Portuguese President, Dr Jorge Sampaio, is being represented by Laurentino Dias of the Socialist Party.

Upon arrival in Bailundo, Laurentino Dias said that Portugal is committed to the Angolan peace process and will continue to render its support to the process through its participation on the Joint Commission and any other possible way. According to him, the Portuguese people hope that Angolans will be able to find lasting peace national reconciliation. "Portugal maintains relations of trust and mutual respect with Angolan political parties," he added.

According to the Portuguese deputy, only through dialogue among all Angolans will it be possible to securely build a better country with solidarity. Laurentino Dias noted that the themes of the III Extra-ordinary Congress of UNITA reflects the Angolan political reality and corresponds to the expectations of all those who wish a prosperous future for Angola.

The Portuguese delegation to the III Extra-ordinary Congress of UNITA includes, among others, Commander Antonio Homem de Gouveia, former adviser to President Mario Soares and representatives from the PSD, CDS/PP (Portuguese political parties).


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


326 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Southern Africa;
SADC Prepares To Handle Trouble Spots


BYLINE: Elliot Mahende, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The end of apartheid in South Africa may have removed the greatest destabilizing factor in Southern Africa, but other factors have come into focus with a potential to create instability in some of the countries.

Authorities and non-governmental organizations in the region, cognizant of the lurking dangers, have gone on a peace offensive developing structures and building a capacity for peaceful resolution of disputes.

Like the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) which has set up a mechanism for conflict prevention, resolution and management amid increasing marginalization of the continent in the post-cold war era, Southern Africa has taken the initiative in securing its own peace within the context of the OAU and UN charters.

The Southern African Development Community (SADC) Organ on Politics, Defence and Security, launched in Gaborone, Bostwana, in July, is the crystallization of the various efforts that authorities in the region have been making to contain potentially explosive situations. 

However, South Africa's liberation, while eliminating the major source of instability, has exposed hitherto unseen or new factors in the politics of Southern Africa.

Analysts see these developments as having a potential to create instability in some of the countries.

These factors range from arms smuggling from Mozambique into the volatile Kwazulu-Natal province of South Africa and the border dispute between Botswana and Namibia over a small island on the Chobe river.

A potential right wing alliance involving the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) and other opposition parties in South Africa as well as the anti-democratic monarchies in Lesotho and Swaziland ranged against the ruling African National Congress (ANC) are also seen as possible causes of conflict.

Such an alignment would complicate the situation in Kwazulu-Natal, where over 14,000 people have died in the past 10 years in a low-intensity civil war between the ANC and the IFP.

Allegations of ANC involvement in the recent pro-democracy strikes and demonstrations, that paralysed Swaziland and forced King Mswati III to accede to democratic reforms, illustrate the new political land-scape in the post- apartheid era and its attendant dangers.

The fragility of peace in the region is also shown by the nervousness of the Namibian government over the recent arms purchases by Botswana and the war games that the Botswana army staged on the border with Namibia.

"The reality facing Southern Africa is that the structural and predisposing factors for violence and instability will endure for a long time," says Jakkie Cilliers, executive director of the Pretoria-based Institute for Defence Policy.

Therefore, the creation of peace structures and preventive diplomacy mechanisms is a welcome development for SADC member countries.

Chaired by Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe along with South Africa's President Nelson Mandela and Botswana's President Ketumile Masire, the SADC Organ on Politics, Defence and Security inherited the structures of the frontline states and the troika of the same leaders who in 1995 helped reverse the royal coup in Lesotho.

The new culture of peacekeeping and preventive diplomacy in Southern Africa is synergetic to the re-awakening in Africa about the need for the continent to take the lead in seeking solutions to its many internal conflicts.

"Africans themselves must first and foremost be seen to clean up their mess while the international community must continue to provide the logistics," says Chris Bakwesegha, who heads the OAU's division on conflict prevention, management and resolution.

While the Africans insist that the UN should never abdicate its peacekeeping responsibilities in the region because African countries are also members of the world body, the reality on the ground shows that after the Somalia debacle and the tragedy in Rwanda, Africa is being increasingly marginalized by the cash-strapped UN.

The UN peacekeeping budget has risen astronomically in the past five years to 3.6 billion U.S. dollars, a figure considered unsustainable given the state of finances of the world body.

"The trend is that unless one of the permanent members of the Security Council has an interest in a particular region, the UN is unlikely to be moved into undertaking an expensive peacekeeping operation," says Age Eknes of the Norwegian Institute for International Affairs.

Both Bakwesegha and Eknes spoke at the recent "training for peace" workshop at Kadoma 140 km (87.5 miles) south-west of Harare, attended by military and foreign affairs officers and representatives of non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

The workshop was organized by the Durban-based African Center for Constructive Resolution of Disputes and the Institute of Defence Policy. It was funded by the Norwegian Institute for International Affairs, an NGO to develop capacity for peaceful resolution of disputes as well as peacekeeping in the region.

The long-term objective of the NGO "contribute to regional confidence building and lay the foundations for mutual understanding and respect across cultural and geographical divides".

Hopefully, through such concerted local efforts, the tensions on the Chobe river or the carnage in Kwazulu-Natal will be eliminated leaving the region to concentrate on the task of economic development.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


327 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Zambia;
Anti-Polio Vaccination Of 2.3 Million Children


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia -- At least two million Zambian children under-five years old are expected to be immunized against polio during the country's second national vaccination campaign which started Friday.

Zambian health officials running the campaign said they hoped to immunize between 2.3 and three million children during the two-day effort. 

During the first phase, in July, close to two million children were vaccinated.

Officials estimated they needed to vaccinate just 1.6 million children but the figure has been revised by the National Statistics Office and health officials who say they had under-estimated the target child population.

The vaccination campaign is part of the World Health Organisation's global efforts to eradicate the debilitating disease by the year 2000.

Statistics provided by the Virology Laboratory in Lusaka shows a recurrence of the disease since 1992, when four cases were recorded. The figure doubled in 1993, and in 1995 45 cases were officially documented. There are six confirmed polio cases reported, so far, this year.

Polio, which normally causes paralysis of the limbs, is caused by what is medically termed the "wild polio virus."

Zambian medical authorities say there are 99 other people infected with the polio virus for every person with the paralytic symptoms of the disease.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


328 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


LIberia;
ECOWAS Wants Durable Peace In Liberia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana has assured the international community of the determination of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) to see durable peace return to Liberia and called for support to the peace plan.

"ECOWAS is determined this time around to effect the return of permanent and durable peace to Liberia, " Mohamed Ibn Chambas, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs and member of the Liberian Mediation team, told diplomats in Accra on Thursday.

Chambas, who was briefing the Diplomatic Corps on the just-ended ECOWAS Committee of Nine (C9) meeting on Liberia held in Abuja, appealed to the ambassadors to increase pressure on their governments to aid ECOWAS to keep the Abuja Agreement on track. 

A communique issued at the end of the C9 meeting reaffirmed and extended the Abuja Agreement for nine more months as the best framework for finding lasting peace in Liberia.

The meeting also spelt out a new schedule of implementation of the agreement for the return of democratic rule to the war-torn country next June.

The provision of adequate logistics for the West African Peace- keeping Force (ECOMOG) in addition to strengthening its capacity, form part of the crucial hurdle in the implementation process.

Apart from manpower requirements, about 132 million dollars is needed to make ECOMOG efficient and effective in its task of disarmament and demobilization.

Chambas said ECOMOG needs 18,000 troops in order to safeguard the peace process, adding that arrangements have been completed for additional contributions from member countries.

He said Ghana would contribute one more battalion of 850 men, while Niger, Burkina Faso, The Gambia and Cote d'Ivoire add troops ranging between a battalion and a company.

The level of troops from Benin and Togo would be determined in due course, he added.

Chambas said one major achievement of the Abuja meeting was the reconciliation of the members of the Liberian Council of State.

The Council of state, he said, held an official meeting in Abuja and deliberated on the General Roosevelt Johnson issue, agreeing to reinstate him as a minister in the transitional government, as stipulated in the Accra Mechanism.

Johnson, on the other hand, said he was determined to work with the Council and would return guns his forces seized from ECOMOG last December.

Chambas quoted news reports indicating that a cease-fire declared in Liberia was generally holding, while Johnson's ULIMO-J has returned the guns his troops captured from ECOMOG to the peacekeepers.

"These news reports confirm that the Liberian peace process has been energized and is being brought back on track," Chambas told the briefing, also attended by members of the Liberia Mediation team.

The officials hinted that Johnson was expected to leave for Monrovia, making a brief stop-over in Accra. They could, however, not tell when and how the faction leader who was at the center of bitter fighting last April, would reach home.

"We (have) left him in Abuja...he is expected to go to Monrovia. He may come over briefly to Accra before proceeding to Monrovia," Kwame Amoa-Awua, head of the Africa Bureau of the ministry of foreign affairs, told the Ghana News Agency (GNA).


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


329 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia To Set Up Burundi Sanctions Committee


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian government is to set up an inter-ministerial committee to monitor and coordinate implementation of the economic sanctions imposed on the Burundi military regime of Maj. Pierre Buyoya.

Zambia's deputy foreign affairs minister, Peter Machungwa, said Friday in a statement in Lusaka, that the country acknowledged that strict implementation of the sanctions by all concerned was bound to force the Buyoya regime to quickly restore democracy.

Zambia last week severed all contacts with Burundi, including water, land and air communication in protest against Buyoya's July 25 coup that removed the elected government of President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya. 

The sanctions followed similar ones by the Great Lakes and other African states which want Burundi to be returned to legality and constitutional order by reinstating that country's parliament.

The embargo is also intended to put pressure on the Buyoya regime to unban all political parties and initiate immediate unconditional negotiations with all concerned parties to restore stability and peace to Burundi.

Machungwa said government will impound all vessels and goods on Lake Tanganyika intended to bust the sanctions. Lake Tanganyika is Zambia's major trade link with Burundi.

In Kampala last week, a ministerial meeting of the Great Lakes states and others participating in the sanctions agreed to impose a travel ban on members of the Buyoya regime within the region, in addition to the sanctions. They, however, recommended to exempt medicines and emergency food from the trade ban.

The ministers had co-opted the office of United Nations Higher Commissioner for Refugees to ensure that only human medicines and food entered that country.

In order to effectively monitor the sanctions, the ministers established the regional sanctions coordination committee to be based in Nairobi and chaired by Tanzania.

Its functions will include harmonizing, monitoring and coordinating the activities of national sanctions committees, similar to the one being set up in Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


330 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Zimbabwe and Zambia;
Strike Closes Zambia-Zimbabwe Border


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Livingstone - The Zimbabwe-Zambia border post at Victoria falls crossing has been closed temporarily as a result of Zimbabwean Immigration and Customs officers downing tools in support of the civil servants' country wide strike.

Thousands of people wishing to cross to and from Zimbabwe have been marooned at the border post with most having attemted to jump over the fences. 

Immigration Officers and Zambia Revenue Authority officials from the Zambian side have expressed worry at the way things were being handled because there was no formal notification from their colleagues.

Foreign tourists from South African and abroad have failed to cross over to Zambia as they could not be attended to.

A survey showed that Zimbabwean civil servants on strike at the border have locked all gates and were not allowing any one to come near the border.

Police officers from Zimbabwe manning the place have threatened to shoot any Zambian or foreigners attempting to cross illegally.

A number of foreigners on connecting air flights have missed their planes and have been marooned at Musi-oa-Tunya Hotel Inter-Continental here.

The strike if prolonged would affect movements at borders of both sides and business would be paralysed.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZIS


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


331 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Zambia;
Party Sets Candidate Guidelines


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - Movement for Multi-Party Democracy (MMD) has announced that all aspiring parliamentary candidates must start submitting their applications to the consituency executive committees for consideration.

MMD national secretary, Mr. Michael Sata, made the announcement at a press conference held at his office today.

He said the aspiring candidates must submit their names with a non- refundable fee of K50,000 to the various constituency executive committees until 5th September. 

Mr. Sata said the government has decided to select candidates from the constituency level so that democracy is taken to the people in the constituencies as they will have a chance to choose representatives whom they want.

He said all aspiring candidates must show evidence that they have been paid up members of the MMD for at least two years.

Mr. Sata further charged that candidates must also produce evidence that they hold positions at branch, consituency, district or the national executive committtee (NEC).

Aspiring candidates are also required to show evidence that they hold positions as councillors, MPs, Cabinet Ministers or vice president.

Mr. Sata said candidates would also be considered if they once held political positions appointed by the president.

He also disclosed that the constituency executive committee would conduct interviews on the 6th and 7th for all applicants and thereafter select three applicants for each constituency in order of preference.

Mr. Sata said that only members of the national executive committee are exempted from the interviews adding that all MMD full time workers wishing to contest the elections must first resign from their positions.

The names of the three applicants would be handed over to the national executive committee panel for comments.

Mr. Sata also announced that with the release of the guidelines MPs can start campaigning adding that their campaign should be restricted to constituencies.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


332 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Zambia;
Labor Group: Zambian Women Still Disadvantaged


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - Zambian women have continued to be disadvantaged and discriminated against in various sectors of employment, says the International Labour Organisation(ILO).

ILO programme officer in Zambia, Adel Said Jashen, said this at a Zambia Congress of Trade Union (ZCTU) women's seminar in Lusaka yesterday. 

"Most women continue to be disadvantaged, to have unequal opportunities in what is occupational segregation," Jashen said.

ZCTU women's chairperson, Margaret Mukamba, speaking at the same function said "unless women understand their role they will continue to fight a losing battle."

"Women have to be in the forefront but they have to monitor the strategies they have set out," Mukamba said.

Mukamba said the country should soon have a woman heading ZCTU or indeed as president of Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


333 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Zambia;
President Happy With Company Working On Voters Roll


BYLINE: Masautso Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - Work done by Nikuv Computers (Israel) Limited on Zambia's voters roll has impressed President Frederick Chiluba.

Touring Nikuv Computers' facilities at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Centre yesterday President Chiluba said he could not understand why some politicians were critical of the company's work.

"I am satisfied with your work and I cannot understand those politicians who continue to criticise the work of Nikuv," said President Chiluba, naming Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika as one such critic. 

President Chiluba further challenged opposition politicians to visit the centre before making what he termed baseless attacks on the company.

"I cannot understand how someone can say this card fades within a day. Lewanika said this on television but this card is of high quality. It is designed for three presidential elections and it can last 15 years. It is better than the paper we had in 1991," President Chiluba said. "I appeal to my colleagues and friends to visit you."

Nikuv Computers programme manager, Gershon Korda, told the President his company, which has tested the card, was guaranteeing its quality.

"We guarantee the quality," Korda told the President. "Unfortunately none of the opposition leaders have visited us."

Korda also assured Zambians that voters whose names have been misplaced in the provisional register would be included in the final roll.

"We are waiting for the inspection period to finish we will correct all the mistakes," Korda assured.

National Party secretary general, Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika, in an interview on Wednesday, charged that the whole administration of the voters registration exercise was bad.

"An honest government would admit that the whole thing is a mess and does not give the sort of confidence that is required," Lewanika said.

And Lewanika maintained his earlier position that the quality of the voters cards was poor as the data was already erasing.

Lewanika was reacting to President Frederick Chiluba's claims in Ndola on Tuesday that the cards were of "high quality".

"Contrary to President Chiluba's assertions who has had his card for only two days, I have had mine for two weeks and seen that it rubs off and I will be handing it over to the electoral Commission as material proof," Lewanika said, displaying his partially erased card, advising:"When one makes a mistake of low quality and maladministration they should not seek to cover up through lies. They should come up with corrective action when these are brought to their attention."


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


334 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


Business;
Zambian Economy Grows By Five Per Cent


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has stabilised in that the economy had grown by about five to six per cent, said Bank of Zambia director of economics department, Felix Kani in Lusaka yesterday.

Kani, speaking at the ongoing International Banking Conference being held at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Centre, however, acknowledged that the Zambian economy had suffered some "shocks" in the mining sector over the low production and prices as well as the closure of some banks. 

Kani revealed that the major challenge experienced by the Bank of Zambia last year had been to maintain economic stability "with three banks in receivership and one in liquidation".

Kani advised that there was need for the Bank of Zambia to have a tight supervisory capacity over the country's financial institutions.

"Most important is the flow of information in a market economy," Kani said. "Inadequate information leads to speculation from businessmen which can upset the economy."

And Professor Lawrence Harris from the University of London, while recognising the progress made in the Zambian banking sector, noted that the country was still living with the effects of the liquidity injection which had characterised government's desperate efforts to rescue Meridien BIAO Bank.

"A 47 per cent increase in money supply is not benign and must be watched closely if the economic reform programme is to be kept on track," Professor Harris said, noting that the increase in money supply might be an indicator of spiralling inflation.

Professor Harris also urged the independence of the central bank as a factor in lowering the rate of inflation.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


335 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 23, 1996


South Africa;
Truth Panel Chiefs Meet Mandela


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - The following is a transcript of a statement made by Dr Alex Boraine at a news conference in Cape Town on August 22, after he and the Chairperson had seen President Mandela.

"Yesterday I received an invitation from the President to see him in relation to a discussion that has been raging throughout the country regarding General Bantu Holomisa and his initial appearance before the Commission.

"You will recall that after he was dismissed as Deputy Minister, I made a statement to the effect that we were anxious that the integrity of the Commission should be maintained. I wrote to the President at the time, and he has now received that letter, and has read the letter, and asked if we would go and see him in response to that situation. 

"He mentioned three specific points:

1. That he is totally committed to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission and its work and has never changed his mind on that;

2. That he believes that the Commission is independent and therefore it has the right to guard that independence; and

3. That it also has the responsibility to get to as much truth as possible and he personally as the leader of the ANC would encourage his people without let or hindrance, and without censorship, to appear before the Commission.

"This of course is very encouraging news as far as we are concerned. It doesn't come really as a surprise but nevertheless to have that affirmed is right. We, as you know, have asked Mr Mbeki to encourage members -- senior and other members of the ANC -- to appear before the Amnesty Committee where necessary, and to assist the Commission wherever possible. It's a request that we have made to every political party and we'll continue to make those requests."


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

337 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 24, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Global Coalition Discusses African Debt


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa - An international economic meeting is due to open tomorrow in Addis Ababa to discuss African debt alleviation and agricultural development, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced yesterday.

The ministry said the two-day meeting of the economic committee of the Global Coalition for Africa (GCA) will also deliberate on supply response to Africa's reform programmes, the subject which the coalition's annual conference due in October this year will deal with in depth. 

The meeting will consider ways to augment efforts being made at various fora by the World Bank, International Monetary Fund, Paris Club countries and the Group of Seven industrialised nations to reduce Africa's growing debt burden, the ministry said.

The meeting said in view of designing general agricultural strategies to boost productivity, it will give special attention in its deliberations to agricultural policies and strategies and review efforts made by participating African countries to implement such policies and strategies.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


338 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 24, 1996


Southern Africa;
Mandela Takes Over Leadership Of SADC


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Maseru - South African President, Nelson Mandela, has been elected chairman of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) while Mozambican President Joachim Chissano has been elected vice-chairman.

The results were announced by outgoing chairman Sir Ketumile Masire who is also president for the Republic of Botswana at the closure of the SADC heads of state and government summit held in Maseru yesterday. 

Sir Ketumile whose three year term of office expired this month, thanked fellow leaders for the support they gave him while he was at the helm of the 12-nation regional economic grouping. He did not seek for re-election. So was his deputy, King Mswati III of Swaziland.

Accepting the post, Mr Mandela said his election was a clear demonstration of the confidence SADC leaders had in him and the people of South Africa.

He said it was a great honour to be given the opportunity to contribute in the best way he could towards fostering goodwill to the people of Southern Africa.

He said the offer had come at a time when South Africa was striving for a place to strengthen and entrench her democratic values.

Mr Mandela paid tribute to the outgoing chairman and his vice-chairman saying with their support he was sure to succeed in this new difficult task ahead of him.

He urged fellow leaders to emergy from the 16th summit more stronger than before. Men and women come and go but organisations such as SADC remain, he told leaders from Angola, Tanzania, Malawi, Botswana, Swaziland, Zimbabwe, Mauritius, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Zambia.

Mr Mandela also urged leaders to adhere to principles.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


339 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 25, 1996


Ethiopia;
Prime Minister Confident Of The Future


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1694 words


 

Addis Ababa - Prime Minister Meles Zenawi assured the nation here yesterday that the goal of attaining self-sufficiency in food, originally scheduled for between five and seven years, will definitely be reached by the next Ethiopian year.

At a press conference attended by local journalists, Ato Meles indicated that the country may even find it necessary to export some of its food grains since prices are expected to fall sharply because of the surplus. "Some had even speculated that food self-sufficiency would be attained during the year just ended but I was personally of the view that the 1989 E.C. harvest season was a safer bet," the Prime Minister pointed out.

He at the same time dismissed as mendacious allegations that the reported 7. 7 percent growth in the economy was cosmetic, saying: "The consumer public knows very well that there has lately been a near dramatic fall in the price of food grains; peasant farmers in much of the country have experienced substantial improvement in their livelihood: Coffee producers have even began introducing electronics equipment into their homes and offices."

The growth in the economy should not be assessed by rises in GDP only, according to Ato Meles. "Of equal significance is the overall stabilization of the economy, the substantial reduction in budget deficit as well as the notable success attained in bringing down the inflation rate to a mere 0.9 percent," he told the heavily attended press briefing. 

Asked of his view of why organized terrorism has as of recently targeted this country, Prime Minister Meles made it clear that Ethiopia is by no means alone in getting exposed to the menace which he described as "International." "The ideology of terrorism is the ideology of frustration," he stated, adding: "Those engaged in it whether here or anywhere else do so when emerging trends are not in their favour and thwart the fulfilment of their aspirations. "

He nevertheless felt that multinational terrorists had turned their attention to this country on account of two reasons in particular: The government's unflinching stand against organized terror following the abortive attempt on the life of Egyptian President Hosini Mubarak last year and the openly declared intention of certain hostile forces to stop and if possible reverse the peaceful and democratic process upon which the country has embarked. Ato Meles stressed nonetheless that military action alone is not enough in countering such conspiracy, adding that public vigilance and the readiness to defend the gains made in all areas of national endeavour were even more important.

Asked if the recent cross-border military counter-offensive was not a violation of Somalia's sovereignty, the Prime Minister said, "definitely not!. He recalled that the government had remained patient throughout much of last year when terrorists kept violating Ethiopian territory. He described the Federal government's choice not to retaliate in kind entirely on moral grounds since I having done so would have added to the suffering of the trouble-torn people of Somalia.

"We met no hostile response from the international community because the situation could no longer be tolerated and our action was 100% correct from the legal point of view," Ato meles pointed out.

In his exhaustive and detailed briefing, the Prime Minister touched on a whole range of issues socio-economic and political and the Herald informs its readers that these will be covered in depth in tomorrow's issue.

The Prime Minister Meles Zenawi was asked whether the multinational terrorist conspiracy was in any way connected with the present and future use of the Blue Nile, but said he hoped not. "It should not in any way be related to that since the accord reached between the signatory countries very specifically asserts Ethiopia's national interests in a way that is not detrimental to those of the other parties," Ato meles noted.

On the means of dealing with such a problem, the Prime Minister said that his government's ultimate goal is to get at the very source of the menace. He, however, stated that plans for defending possible future targets of organized banditry are already in place. Ato Meles didn't underestimate the difficulty of entirely controlling terrorism, nonetheless.

"The ultimate plan in thwarting the threat lies in exploiting the age-old Ethiopian tradition of denying refuge to criminals," the Prime Minister hinted, but warned that resort to terrorism is not connected with any particular community or religious group.

So far as counter-offensive actions are concerned, Ato meles vowed that the government will directly or indirectly hunt down the criminals right down to their lair.

Speaking of capacity building, which is a top the agenda of the government's five-year development strategy, Ato Meles stated that a lot has been done to raise the efficiency of the executive branch, particularly in the regional states. He said that in addition to intensive training programmes organized by the Civil service College, legal practitioners and woreda administrators have been offered short term courses. "The result proved encouraging from the outset," he pointed out.

Ato Meles disclosed the opening of new education faculties at Dilla, Alamaya and Bahir Dar, and engineering faculties at Bahir Dar and Makalle as well as health institutions in Dilla and other localities.

These will all begin operation as of the next academic year, according to the Prime Minister.

Ato Meles said that the Federal Government has been and remains committed to extending technical assistance to the various state governments, with priority to those lacking adequate skilled manpower. This, he said, was entirely inresponse to their request. "To bring about an equitable development in all regional states," says Ato Meles, "the Federal Government builds basic infrastructures in all, but cannot interfere in their internal affairs."

Asked about his government's reported "special relationship" with the People's Republic of China, the Prime Minister said: " We don't have any special relationship with any country. We have good relations with virtually all nations across the world and pursue a foreign policy which best serves Ethiopia's national interest."

Ato Meles saw no positive trend in Ethio-Sudan relationship. "We can't have good relations with Sudan until the government there gives us solid guarantee against terrorist incursions and extradites known criminals," he said with feeling.

The Prime Minister admitted that keeping under detention those implicated in the Derg's Red Terror for over five years without charges is no longer justifiable and pledged a swift measure. He nonetheless dismissed as mendacious allegations about clandestine arrest and imprisonment.

Asked if he lived up to his promise of "welcoming loyal opposition half-way, : Ato Meles said that none of them bothered to take any such step. He also said that he saw no improvement around the private press in particular but that he still remained hopeful of a positive response.

Speaking on ways of controlling corruption, Ato Meles said that the immediate strategy lies in "hunting down the corrupt." But the ultimate solution is to be found in creating a working atmosphere that would let no loophole for all such practices. The Prime Minister cited the outright dismissal of customs police as a case in point.

Asked to justify his original plans to send a peace keeping force to Burundi "when there are closer and relatively better-off nations," Ato Meles said that it's foolish to consider oneself safe when a sister nation is caught in total anarchy. "Besides it is justified on moral grounds for we have endured a similar fratricidal war."

According to the Prime Minister, the country couldn't attract the expected amount of foreign investment. This was partly because of policies that hampered such involvement and bureaucraticredtape and partly because "some investors don't see a good climate unless they are allowed to indulge in activities that would negatively affect our national interest," Ato Meles stated. He foresaw better progress in future, all the same.

Asked if he wields a mechanism for ready access to first-hand information on what is going on in the country, Ato Meles said: "I sometimes go to the rural areas to have my own observation on the agricultural front. I would have wished to do the same in many areas but cannot to do because of very tight working schedules."


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 25, 1996


Zambia and South Africa;
Presidents Chiluba And Mandela Hold Frank Discussions


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Pretoria - President Frederick Chiluba today held frank discussions, behind closed doors, with his South African counterpart Nelson Mandela on recent political changes in Zambian, including the amended Zambian constitution.

Afterwards Mr Chiluba described the talks as having been held in a frank and very friendly atmosphere and disclosed for the first time that he was in the process of meeting United National Independence Party president, Dr Kenneth Kaunda, soon to further dialogue on the recent developments in Zambia.

The meeting with Dr Kaunda was scheduled for last week but could not take place because Mr Chiluba was in Lesotho for the Southern African Development Community Summit. 

"I spoke to Dr Kaunda last week but the meeting did not take place due to the SADC meeting in Maseru. But we will continue the process of dialogue with him and all other opposition party leaders, " Mr Chiluba said.

The President said before departure for Lusaka in Pretoria that he met Mr Mandela to explain further the constituitional changes in Zambia and to correct the wrong media reports that former president, Dr Kaunda, is being harrassed by the ruling Movement for Multi-Party Democracy (MMD) government.

The President said his meeting with Mr Mandela was held under very warm and cordial relations and that the South African leader has now been given extra information on the developments in Zambia which were explained wrongly because of the constitutional changes.

Mr Chiluba and Mr Mandela have been planning to meet since November last year, to discuss other pressing issues, and they took this opportunity to also hold bilateral talks between their two states.

The announced meeting between President Chiluba and Dr Kaunda will go a long way in easing tension between the ruling party and opposition UNIP which, together with other political parties and politically active Non- Governmental Organisations have been calling for this kind of dialogue without seemingly much success.

The last time that President Chiluba attempted to meet opposition parties for dialogue in Lusaka was in April when the meeting floundered and ran aground after opposition leaders a defiant position over who should chair the meeting and they even went as far as refusing to acknowledge his presence when he entered the conference hall for delibertions.

Earlier in Pretoria, Zambian government officials led by Movement for Multi- party Democracy Chairman for International Relations, Vernon Mwaanga, met South African government officials to explain the recent constitutional changes in Zambia.

The team included Lands Minister Luminzu Shimaponda, and Deputy Minister for special duties at State House, Eric Silwamba.

President Chiluba returned home immediately after the talks with Mr Mandela.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

341 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 26, 1996


Business;
Zambian Farmers Union Warns Of Maize Shortages


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - Prospects of shortages of maize later this year were not unreal, Zambia National Farmers' Union (ZFNU) executive director, George Grey, warned at an International Banking Conference on Friday at the Mulungushi International Conference Centre.

Speaking during a panel discussion on the possibilities of economic growth, Grey also warned that Zambia is approaching a crisis in the agriculture industry due to lack of inputs for the next farming season.

"There is not enough money coming from the credit schemes and we have to know that the government has not received its money from the schemes...The government is relying on the private sector to provide inputs for this coming season and the private sector's capacity is severely limited," Grey said. 

Agriculture minister Suresh Desai last week announced that the government had stopped funding the three major farmers' lending institutions - Lima Bank, Credit Union and Savings Association and Zambia Cooperative Finance Limited.

Desai said the institutions would be expected to run like other business organisations without the aid of government grants.

Grey predicted that the credit squeeze would show farmers that they had to pay back whatever they borrowed to enable them borrow again.

"It will show them that they have to pay back because credit is not a right, " Desai said.

As for the reliance on the private sector to provide lending for inputs, Grey pointed out that already, commercial banks were not willing to lend to farmers given the government's tendency to manipulate prices like it has done twice before in the last six months.

On the shortage of maize, Grey said the 15.6 million bags harvest announced by the government was not correct because reality had proved that the national figures were less than 14 million bags of maize produced in the last season.

Grey said this was due to a number of factors including the non- availability of grain bags and government's inability to bring in the maize to the food reserves.

"I hope these lessons force us to diversify more. I believe we should only grow enough maize to feed ourselves," Grey said.

And Bank of Zambia economist, Danny Kalyalya, said the growth in the agricultural sector and the economy as a whole was likely to come from non- traditional exports.

Zambia has benefited from increased exports in flowers and vegetables in the last three years.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996

August 26, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Under-17 Team To Disband


BYLINE: Celani Shongwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambian Under 17 squad which was scheduled to play against their Namibian counterparts yesterday will be disbanded today, FAZ acting secretary general, Julio Chiluba said at the weekend.

Chiluba said the squad will be re-assembled for the second round clash against Ethiopia on February 10 next year. 

"It is not our fault, CAF will decide on what to do, whether to give us points or to order a replay," he said.

Namibia failed to honour the African Youth Championship game due what officials of the Namibian Football Association (NFA) termed 'logistical reasons.'

In a telephone interview from Namibia on Friday, NFA executive member, Dominique Chipanga said they encountered serious problems which forced them to pull out of the competition.

"For logistical reasons we are not going to honour that game," Chipanga said. He dismissed reports that they were scared of the Zambian squad.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


343 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 26, 1996


Business;
SADC Agrees To Remove Tariffs


BYLINE: Tabo Kobokoane, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - The 12-member SADC edged a step closer towards becoming a free trade area following the signing of a trade protocol agreement on Friday.

The protocol, which provides the legal framework for the removal of tariffs and other measures restricting free trade in the region, was supported by the 12 states at the community's 16th summit in Maseru, Lesotho.

The protocol shied away from details, but Alex Erwin, the South African Minister of Trade and Industry, says these will be worked out in the next six months. 

Many community member states, like Zambia, insist on speeding up the phasing out of tariffs, hoping it will open up South Africa's markets and address the huge trade imbalance within Southern Africa.

South Africa favours a longer phasing out period, but some community members see this as South Africa's attempt to maintain the status quo.

"The perception is that South Africa is a bully boy," says

Erwin, "but the fact is that the trade imbalance within the region is growing rapidly in our favour in spite of tariffs.

"If you remove these trade barriers faster, they will accelerate even further in our favour," he warns.

His Zambian counterpart, Dr Syamukayumbu Sya-mujaye, says South Africa has to "open up its markets to goods from other countries".

"We are losing out to South Africa because of our lower tariffs, while South Africa's tariffs remain high. It needs to move fast," he says.

The trade protocol - which binds Zimbabwe, Zambia, Lesotho, Swaziland, Tanzania, Angola, Botswana and Namibia - comes at a time when the community's members are pressing South Africa to open up its markets to goods from the region.

Earlier this month, South Africa and Zimbabwe resolved a four-year-long trade dispute, which will see tariffs on clothing and textiles from Zimbabwe lowered from over 70 percent to 20 percent by 2000.

The trade protocol signed on Friday also makes provision for existing arrangements, like the customs union and bilateral agreements.

The heads of state at the summit also signed protocols on energy co- operation, transport, communication and combating illicit drug trafficking.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


344 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 26, 1996


Burundi and Zambia;
Is Burundi A Sovereign Nation? (COLUMN)


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - So finally our government through foreign affairs minister Gen. Christon Tembo has decided to review our relations with the military government in Burundi in support of other east and southern African countries that have decided to impose economic sanctions against the military government in Burundi.

The question the Jury then turned and asked itself was, what about the concept of sovereignty, is Burundi not a sovereign state?

Only a few months ago, our government cried foul when foreign states threatened them with sanctions over the adoption and contents of the unpopular Constitutional Amendments. 

Our government cried that Zambia as a sovereign state had the right to freely choose and develop its political, social, economic and cultural systems and therefore foreigners had no business interfering.

The Jury then advised that the concept of sovereignty was by and large a myth in that no state was an island. Every state has a duty to comply and in good faith with its international obligations and respect conventions and treaties it had freely entered into and signed.

The Zambian government was still adamant about its sovereignty and that is why the Jury was shocked that it took a stance against Burundi which boils down to sovereignty. The principle of the action is okay, but it is this question of double standards.

The adoption and contents of the constitution was more or less popular among MMD and government leaders, a clear minority, equally the coup in Burundi is popular among the minority soldiers.

If the MMD government respects the principle that each state has the right freely to choose and develop its political, social, economic and cultural systems, why then shouldn't the Burundi people decide their political destiny?

Why shouldn't the soldiers rule if that is the wish of the people of Burundi, why should Zambia bother if Burundi people kill each other?

The answer is simply that, a military coup is an affront to democratic ideals and further that the interest of other nationals in Burundi is threatened if the Burundi people rise against the military.

Legally speaking, the Jury appreciates the stance taken against Burundi, obviously morally, innocent citizens will suffer. But the most important thing to note is that we should never use the concept of sovereignty to block foreign interference when we are infringing the rights of citizen.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


345 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 26, 1996


Burundi;
UNICEF Not Planning to Leave Burundi


BYLINE: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Nairobi - Contrary to media reports today (22 August), UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund, has no plans to suspend its operations in Burundi. UNICEF has eight international and 74 national staff members in Burundi and UNICEF programmes are continuing in health, water and sanitation, education, nutrition, psycho-social recovery and family tracing. 

UNICEF is concerned that children are already being affected by the sanctions recently imposed on the country, and that the situation will deteriorate unless steps are taken to ensure their special protection. There is particular concern at fuel shortages which are hampering cross-border reunification programmes for 20,000 unaccompanied children and may paralyze immunization activities. Burundi was on the verge of reaching 75% immunization of under one year-olds, or 190,000 children, but there are now no supplies of Polio or BCG vaccines in the country. Fuel shortages will also jeopardize the supplementary feeding programme which is currently reaching 30, 000 malnourished children who have been uprooted from their homes. UNICEF currently has only three to five days' supply of fuel.

UNICEF, together with other UN-agencies and non-governmental organizations, is advocating for protected supply routes, or so-called 'humanitarian corridors', to allow the continued flow of food, fuel, vaccines, medical supplies and other items essential for the well-being of children.

For further information contact Emily Booker, Chief Media Section Division of Communication UNICEF (212) 326 7259.

(This document is distributed via the UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs Integrated Regional Information Network. Tel: +254 2 441125; Fax: +254 2 448816; e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies.)


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

346 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 26, 1996


East Africa;
Weekly Roundup -- Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1827 words


 

Nairobi - Number 23 (19 - 25 August 1996) in a series of weekly reports from the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network (IRIN) on general developments in the Great Lakes region. Sources for the information below include UN agencies, NGOs, other international organisations and media reports. IRIN issues these reports for the benefit of the humanitarian community, but accepts no responsibility as to the accuracy of the original sources.

# Zaire and Rwanda agreed on Thursday to a speedy and total repatriation of the more than one million Rwandan refugees currently living in Kivu region of eastern Zaire. The announcement was made in a press conference organized by Zaire's Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo and Rwanda's Prime Minister Pierre- Celestin Rwigema. Kengo wa Dondo said the repatriation process would go ahead "rapidly" and would be "massive, organised and unconditional". The aim would be to ensure the return of all Rwandan refugees to Rwanda before Zaire's electoral process gets underway in May 1997. 

The full statement said that the Government of Zaire would begin "the progressive closure of the camps and ensure the rapid repatriation of Rwandan refugees" while the Rwandan Government would take measures to welcome and install them in Rwanda. The two Governments also agreed to organize visits to refugee camps and transit camps and to pursue operations "to separate intimidators from innocent people". It was later reported that Zaire had expelled 28 Rwandans to Rwanda on Wednesday, accusing them of being intimidators.

The UNHCR on Friday stated its opposition to any attempt to forcibly repatriate Rwandan refugees from Zaire. Fernando del Mundo, UNHCR's spokesman, said that UNHCR was "not going to be part of any forced repatriation" and that the agency had not been informed about the discussions between the two Governments. Mr del Mundo recalled that both Governments had committed themselves in the past to resolve the refugee issue on the basis of voluntary repatriation and not expulsions. "These are our standards", he said.

# Some 6,000 Rwandan refugees returned to Rwanda from Burundi on Thursday, leaving Magara camp and crossing the border during the night. This left only 220 refugees remaining in the camp. UNHCR planned to distribute a five day food ration to these people on Friday and had no plans to transfer these people to Rukuramigabo camp. This brings to over 50,000 the number of Rwandan refugees who have returned to Rwanda from Burundi since the beginning of August.

# By Sunday night there were only 10,720 Rwandan refugees remaining in Burundi, 10,500 of whom in Rukuramigabo camp. 2,100 refugees returned to Rwanda from Wednesday to Saturday. (UNHCR reports that up to 4,000 refugees left from Rukuramigabo on Monday, 26 August 1996.) As of Friday there were 17, 000 people living in the Butare transit camp. They are being transferred to their home communes on a daily basis.

# More than 6,000 people have been killed in Burundi since the July 25 coup, according to Amnesty International. Amnesty said that it had learnt that at least 4,050 civilians were extrajudicially executed between July 27 and August 10 by Burundi Government forces in Giheta district of Gitega province. "We are disturbed that as many people have been massacred since the coup as were reported killed in the previous three months", Amnesty said. The Amnesty figures are similar to claims by FRODEBU, made on August 16, that the Army had massacred 5,000 Hutu civilians since the coup.

# A spokesman for Burundi's leader Pierre Buyoya on Thursday denied the findings in the Amnesty report. According to Reuters, Jean-Luc Ndizeye said, " Amnesty International is either completely misguided or is falling into a propaganda trap. I am positive that they are misinformed and that these numbers are outrageous".

# A WFP convoy of four trucks arrived in Ngozi from Tanzania on Sunday carrying relief food (rice and nutritional biscuits) and medicines. A cargo plane carrying 24 tonnes of drugs and medical materials from MSF France arrived in Bujumbura from Nairobi on Thursday afternoon. The French relief agency plans to use the drugs to supply dispensaries in several locations around the country and says that these will assist more than one million people over the next three months. The MSF-chartered flight represents the first relief supplies to reach Burundi by air since the embargo imposed by Regional Governments was put in place. Rebel groups, meanwhile, were reported to be trying to impose a blockade in Bujumbura by dissuading peasant farmers from providing food. Aid workers said on Thursday that they had been told of death threats against farmers.

# Burundi's regime reiterated its opposition to UN proposals for a multinational force in Burundi on Tuesday, following a statement in support of the proposal by Dr Boutros-Ghali on Monday. Jean-Luc Ndizeye, spokesman for Pierre Buyoya said, "we are against the sending of foreign troops. We are not surprised by Boutros-Ghali's declaration but we are opposed to it." He added, "This approach does not take into account the reality in Burundi. It is up to we Burundians to take our destiny in hand."

# The comments come in the wake of the UN Secretary-General's latest report to the Security Council, in which Dr Boutros-Ghali stated that "the international community must allow for the possibility that the worst may happen and that genocide may occur in Burundi. In that case, whatever Governments may think now, military intervention to save lives might become an inescapable imperative."

The report acknowledged, however, that previous efforts to find countries willing to take the lead in mobilizing and organizing such a force had met with little response. Two proposals had been considered by UN Member States, a peace-keeping operation and a force for humanitarian intervention deployed under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations. Some 86 Member States had been approached regarding a contribution to the peacekeeping proposal, of which 20 had replied, 14 positively and 6 negatively. On the humanitarian intervention force proposal, nearly 50 countries were approached, of whom 21 replied, and 11 declined to participate. Of the 10 positive replies, only three member states offered troops.

Dr Boutros-Ghali was critical of the coup d'etat of July 25, stating that " the forceful overthrow of the legal Government will not solve the problems of Burundi. It will reinforce the fears of one side and strengthen extremists on both sides. It will increase violence and add to the suffering of the Burundian people. It thus makes political dialogue all the more imperative."

On sanctions, the report suggests that they "should not be seen as an instrument of punishment, nor should they be allowed to add to the hardship of the suffering people of Burundi. They are, as always, a means to an end. The end in this case is the opening of serious negotiations for a political settlement." Consultations on establishing humanitarian exemptions continue.

# UNICEF will suspend its operations in Burundi at the end of next week unless Regional Governments relax sanctions, according to a Reuters news report on Friday. The news agency quoted Michel Sidibe, UNICEF's Representative in Burundi, as saying that "at the end of next week... UNICEF will stop working for lack of of fuel and as a result our entire immunisation programme for the year will be wiped out".

# The UN Human Rights Field Office in Rwanda published a report on Thursday revealing that 365 people died in various armed incidents in Rwanda in July. The report said that 226 of these were caused by "agents of the state" including the RPA, which killed 182 people in operations against Hutu insurgents. 'Interahamwe' guerillas killed 45 people, while the responsibility for the deaths of the remaining 94 persons could not be established. Some 220 of these deaths occured in Gisenyi prefecture. The report also showed that the authorities had released 866 detainees last month and had arrested 2,769. Rwanda's total prison population at the end of July was 78,510, of whom 52,678 were in prisons and the rest in makeshift detention centres.

# Rebels from the Lord's Resistance Army abducted 89 young people in Uganda's Gulu district in two separate incidents last week. On Monday they took 39 students from a mixed secondary school in Gulu, while on Friday they abducted 50 young girls from three villages in the district. According to a report in the New Vision newspaper, the rebels had moved from village to village telling residents they wanted young girls to take back with them to their jungle bases.

# The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights will establish a UN Centre for Human Rights in Zaire in the near future. Two human rights experts will be based in Kinshasa with a brief to study developments in the country and advise officials there. The announcement follows an agreement signed in Geneva by Jose Ayala Lasso, UN High Commissioner for Human Rights and N'Singa Udjuu, Zaire's Justice Minister.

Distributed via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not be taken always to reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816. E-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


347 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 26, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe's Informal Sector Poised For Growth


BYLINE: Tambayi Nyika, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1662 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's informal sector, previously neglected by planners, is poised to become the engine for the country's economic growth if current initiatives by the government, local authorities and the private sector are implemented.

After 16 years of uncoordinated planning, the three parties agree that the current unemployment crisis, estimated at 40 percent of the labor force in a country of 10,5 million people, is a recipe for instability in the near future.

Intelligence analyses already indicate that unemployment remains the biggest threat to stability in the country.

Indigenous pressure groups like the Affirmative Action Group (AAG) and the Indigenous Business Development Center have threatened disruptive action if the situation continues. 

"Our observation is that there is a lot of resistance to empower the informal sector so that they move away from being consumers to producers," says Caleb Chihota of AAG.

Zimbabwe National Chamber of Commerce (ZNCC) president, Danny Meyer agrees. "We have been talking and talking, holding workshops and seminars on the need to come up with job-creating projects but we have never done something about it."

Experts now admit that reliance on foreign and multinational investment where work places cost in excess of 50 000 U.S. dollars each is no longer tenable and are experimenting with various projects aimed at developing the informal sector.

At a recent workshop in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city, representatives from the three sectors acknowledged the potential of the informal sector, which now employs 1,5 million people against the formal sector's two million.

"No matter what local authorities do they cannot afford to ignore the informal sector anymore. It is one of the fastest growing and vibrant sectors and should be taken into consideration during planning," says Godfrey Nhemachena, Gweru's town clerk.

"The formal sector has failed to create employment, leaving 300 000 new labor entrants every year with no prospects of jobs," observes Thenjiwe Lesabe, Zimbabwe's minister for national affairs, employment creation and co- operatives.

The advent of the world bank and international monetary fund-sponsored reform programme in 1991 triggered massive retrenchments of over 30 000 employees, most of whom find solace in the informal sector.

The activities, which are labor rather than capital intensive, include carpentry, furniture and clothing manufacturing, welding, metalwork and panel- beating. Others are spray-painting, shoe repairs, hairdressing, vending and retailing, carried out from backyard shops or on street corners.

Though some of them are flourishing, representatives of the sector still complain of outdated licensing and zoning laws, health regulations, income tax and companies legislation which discourage their existence alongside the formal sector.

Also, lack of capital and land means that no vibrant sector exists, at least for now.

It is against this background that Zimbabwe's local authorities are changing city and town by-laws to accommodate the informal sector while the private sector has initiated a sub-contracting and linkages programme designed to spread the benefits of the economy.

Bulawayo town clerk, Mike Ndubiwa, says in addition to business incubators, the local authority has allocated sites for the sector in line with the type of activity being engaged in.

ZNCC micro-business development corporation plans to build three incubator workshop sites in Harare and one in Kwekwe worth one million dollars.

The sites which are expected to create 100 000 new jobs by the turn of the century are expected to spread to rural areas to stem the drift to urban area by unemployed youths.

"The entrepreneurs that may use these sites will be engaged in a wide variety of activities. After two years they will be expected to graduate into the formal sector and move out to make way for others," says Frank Jackson of the ZNCC.

The chamber of commerce also plans to provide business management training. The Confederation of Zimbabwe Industries sub-contracting and linkages programme is beginning to bear fruit for the small enterprises.

Allen Dickie, director of the programme, says 35 large corporations and 50 small enterprises had already been registered since 1994. "Over 50 activities have been identified for linkages, three are already operational and 12 still under negotiations. it has been a win-win situation for both parties resulting in improved efficiency, competition and creation of wealth."

Minister Lesabe says apart from creating an enabling environment through affirmative legislation, government plans to establish incubators which also provide space, equipment and consultancy services.

"Government has also started an employment creation fund in which entrepreneurs borrow up to 30 000 (Zimdollars) to be paid back at 12 percent interest to offset the high interests of over 30 percent charged by commercial banks," she says.

With all these initiatives in the pipeline, experts say there is need for the three parties to co-ordinate their activities to avoid duplication, even competition against each other.

"There are too many players. Current programmes lack a common framework with regards to implementation," notes Witness Chinyama, an economist with the Zimbabwe development bank, whose 800 000-dollar factory shell programme in Harare has been relatively successful in creating employment.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 26, 1996


South Africa;
BMW To Unveil Details Of Multimillion Dollar Investment in SA


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Details of a multimillion-dollar investment deal in South Africa by German car manufacturer BMW are to be revealed here this week but amid fear that a further increase in crime would lead to a review of the company's investments in the country.

Officials announced in Johannesburg Sunday that the chairman of the Bavarian Motor Works, Bernd Pischetsrieder, will arrive in South Africa this week to detail the luxury car maker's planned 220 million-U.S.-dollar four- year expansion programme in South Africa.

While successful implementation of the investment could result in BMW South Africa becoming the sole global manufacturer of the company's right-hand- drive vehicles, Pischetsrieder is expected to issue a strong warning of contingency plans to switch production to plants in other countries should the local subsidiary fail to meet export targets. Industry sources say that if this happens, it is unlikely that South Africa would ever regain the investments. 

Pischetsrieder's visit is expected to ease tensions, following warnings by BMW and arch-rival Mercedes Benz that the increase in crime in South Africa was compelling them to re-assess their operations in the country.

South African media report that the government's tame response to the unceasing crime wave has angered local and overseas businessmen, who view the situation as a major threat to new investments and economic confidence.

Violent crime in South Africa is regarded as a more significant deterrent to investment than the government's passive handling of the economy.

BMW spokesman Chris Moerdyk said the success of the planned expansion programme would be dependent on persuading car component suppliers to open in South Africa. This would be difficult, he added, if crime is not controlled.

BMW is South Africa's leading exporter of cars and components, with earnings of at least 200 million dollars forecast for 1996.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 26, 1996


United States and Africa;
Nigeria Accuses U.S. Of Supporting Pirate Radio


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's special duties minister, Wada Nas, has accused the Untied States Information Service of supporting a pirate opposition radio, which has been transmitting anti-government programmes since June.

"Nigeria is dismayed that a United States agency could provide logistic support to an illegal radio station, carrying out destabilization acts against the government of Nigeria," he said in an interview widely published Sunday by Nigerian newspapers.

The location of the pirate radio, which calls itself Radio Democratic International Nigeria, has been a mystery since it began broadcasting June 12, the third anniversary of the country's 1993 presidential election annulled by the last military regime. 

Exiled Nigerian opposition officials -- including Anthony Enahoro, of the National Democratic Coalition, and Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka, leader of the National Liberation Council of Nigeria -- have featured on the radio programs critical of the administration of Gen. Sani Abacha.

Nas claimed that the Nigerian government had discovered involvement of the U.S. agency in the recruitment of staff for the foreign based opposition radio station.

He alleged that a Nigerian journalist had been interviewed for a job with the radio by Bruse Copohed, a public affairs staff of the U.S. agency, in Nigeria's northern city of Kaduna.

Nas claimed that the journalist was interviewed July 14, as an Hausa language broadcaster for the pirate radio.

Nas said that the U.S. agency in Kaduna was already preparing travel documents for the unnamed journalist to join the pirate radio abroad.

Nigeria, Nas said, would protest to the appropriate quarters, adding that " government would not tolerate any act by foreign agencies directed at destablization the country."

Neither the agency nor the United States Embassy in Lagos was open for business Sunday and so could not comment immediately on the Nas' allegation.

Diplomatic relations between the Nigeria and the United States have been strained since the cancellation of the 1993 presidential election, prompting Washington to impose limited sanctions on the West African country.

Diplomats in Lagos had interpreted recent comments by President Bill Clinton, when he received the credentials of Nigeria's new envoy to the United States, as a sign of possible improvement in the troubled diplomatic relations between the two countries. They still enjoy good economic links.

The U.S. buys some 50 percent of Nigeria's crude oil, while multinational firms have managed to block attempts by American and European politicians to impose economic sanctions on Nigeria, because of their vested interests.

The Abacha government has also said that it abhors foreign interference to its plan to return Nigeria to democracy in October 1998.

LANGUAGE: English
