August 27, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Denies Nigerian Minister's Allegation


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - A United States Embassy official in Lagos denied on Monday allegations by Nigeria's special duties minister, who accused the U.S. Information Service of supporting a pirate radio opposed to the military government of the West African country.

Minister Wada Nas, in an interview published by Nigerian newspapers Sunday, claimed that the U.S. Agency's office in Kaduna, northern Nigeria, had interviewed and was preparing travel documents for a Nigerian journalist being recruited for the opposition station, which calls itself Radio Democratic International Nigeria. 

"The U.S. government does not fund the radio," the embassy official told PANA.

The diplomat, who asked not to be named also denied the existence of Bruse Copohed, the official, whom Nas alleged had interviewed the Nigerian journalist for a job with the pirate radio.

The radio, whose base is unknown, has been broadcasting anti-government programmes since June 12, the third anniversary of the country's 1993 presidential election cancelled by the last military regime of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida.

Diplomatic relations between Nigeria and the United States have been strained since the annulment of that presidential poll, with Washington imposing limited sanctions on the West African country.

But diplomatic sources in Lagos said that despite the disagreements over democracy and human rights, the U.S. and European countries have avoided imposing oil sanctions on Nigeria, mainly because of their own economic interests.

The U.S. buys some 50 per cent of Nigeria's total crude oil, with North American and European multinationals playing a major part in the production.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


404 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi Envoy Opposes UN Sanctions


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations - Burundi's permanent representative to the United Nations, Terence Nsanze, says any attempt by the UN Security Council to impose sanctions on the country will be "unjust, illegal and contrary to the UN charter."

Nsanze told UN correspondents in New York Tuesday the Burundi government " categorically rejects" the arms embargo being proposed by the security council against Burundi, over the recent military coup in the country.

"It (the embargo) has no grounds in view of the impressive initiatives already taken by the new regime," the envoy said, adding that the Security Council should wait until the new regime, led by Maj. Pierre Buyoya, had proven to be "incompetent, unqualified or engage in any atrocities." 

He said that since Buyoya came into office on July 25, he had expressed his commitment to ending the massacres and all forms of violence in the country as well as to launch a new democratic process and to encourage the mediation efforts by the former Tanzanian president, Julius Nyerere.

According to Nsanze, the government also plans to hold a national debate, to bring all ethnic groups together, in November and to engage in dialogue with the armed factions, if they lay down their arms and renounce violence.

He said instead of imposing sanctions on Burundi, the Security Council should resort to a "more-constructive, productive and beneficial diplomatic dynamics."

Nsanze said Burundi has proposed the establishment of an ad-hoc security council mission to be despatched to the great lakes region, whose countries have imposed economic sanctions to force out the new government.

"This fact-finding mission would allow the Security Council to take into account the current realities and the disastrous consequences which have been produced by this economic embargo," the permanent representative added.

He said the regional sanctions had further worsened Burundi's economy, paralysed infrastructure, affected the populace, particularly women and children, and threatened to precipitate a food crisis.

"What difference is there between a genocide by firearms and genocide by mass starvation and generalized diseases?" the envoy asked.

A draft security council resolution introduced by the non-aligned movement caucus urges imposition of an arms embargo on Burundi and, after 60 days, lead to the consideration of tougher measures unless the new government initiated efforts to reach a comprehensive political settlement.

In a related development, nsanze has accused the countries which imposed sanctions on Burundi of having hidden motives rather than acting in the interest of peace and security in the region.

He said apart from the fact that there was no precedent to the sanctioning of any country in the great lakes region over military coups, the sanctions violated the charters of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) and the UN.

"As a prerequisite, the security council should have been seized, in the interest of all concerned parties, of any possible measures to be taken," the ambassador said, adding that the council was not consulted before the sanctions were imposed.

Meanwhile, the president of the UN security council, Tono Eitel of Germany, has said there is a possibility that the council will send a fact-finding mission to Burundi.

"I would not exclude that but we are far from having discussed it, and we are far from having decided upon it," Eitel said, adding: "but in the course of events, it is one measure that may be discussed in the council."

According to a letter sent to the council by Burundi's permanent representative, the proposed mission will look into the economic, political and security conditions in Burundi since the coup, and also investigate the alleged massacre of 6,000 Hutus since July 25.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Liberia;
More West African Troops Set For Liberia


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Six countries, including four that already have troops in Liberia, have indicated their readiness to send forces to beef up ECOMOG, the West African Peace-Monitoring Force in the war-torn west African country.

Sources at the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) in Lagos, have said that two countries, Cote d'Ivoire and Burkina Faso, will be deploying troops for the first time since ECOMOG was sent to Liberia in 1990. 

The force is currently estimated at 8,500 soldiers, with Nigeria contributing the bulk of the troops, followed by Ghana. Gambia, Benin and Mali are the other contributors.

The sources said these countries were expected to increase the number of their troops, in line with the decision of the recent meeting in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, by west African leaders, who agreed to raise ECOMOG strength to 18,000 troops.

Commenting on the Liberian crisis Tuesday, Brig.Gen. Fred Chijuka, Nigeria's director of defence information, confirmed that "some countries have promised to contribute troops" to strengthen ECOMOG.

If "all the countries can contribute 1,000 troops each, the problem would be solved," he added.

Contributing countries, including Nigeria and Ghana, have had to scale down the strength of their soldiers in ECOMOG in the past out of frustration at the lack of progress in the Liberian peace process.

But the ECOWAS Committee of Nine, which met recently in Abuja adopted several sactions, including possible trial of leaders of any faction that violates the revised peace plan, for war crimes.

The plan provides for a new cease-fire, deployment of ECOMOG troops and disarming of Liberian warriors to pave way for national election on May 30, 1997.

The six-year-old Liberian civil war has killed at least 150,000 people and defied a dozen previous peace accords brokered by the 16-nation ECOWAS.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


406 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Nigeria;
British Bank Divests From Nigeria


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The British Standard Chartered Bank is selling off its 66. 6 million shares to the public from Sept. 2, to complete a phased divestment from Nigeria.

Bill Moore, regional coordinator of Standard Chartered Africa, said at a ceremony in Lagos Monday the divestment, which followed the 1993 collapse of Barings Bank of England, would fetch foreign stake holders some 499,328 U.S. dollars. 

The 50 kobo shares are being sold at a unit price of six naira to the public (80 naira = 1USD, and 100 kobo = one naira).

Moore denied that the pull-out from First Bank Nigeria Plc, was politically motivated.

He said Standard Chartered management decided to divest its 57 foreign investments where it did not have management or majority control given the group's experience with Barings.

"We are reviewing the scope of our activities worldwide," Moore said, adding: "we have over 50 countries like Mozambique and Malawi, where we do not have management or majority control, including Europe and America where we sold our hotel."

The divestment would make First Bank fully Nigerian owned.

Corroborating Moore's argument, First Bank's Managing Director, Joseph Sanisu, said the technical partners were acting in line with the laws of the European Union and the British government.

He said the divestment would not adversely affect the cordial relationship, spanning 102 years, between First Bank and Standard Chartered.

First Bank is Nigeria's leading financial institution in terms of its deposit and asset holding.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


407 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Angola;
Malaria Kills Over 500 In Angola's Kwanza South


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

SUMBE, Angola - Some 5,826 people died of malaria in the central-west Angolan Kwanza South province during the first half of 1996.

According to Teresa Joaquim, who heads the epidemiological surveillance section in the province's health department, the death toll was 190 people higher than those registered over the same period in 1995. 

She added that 31,594 cases were diagnosed during the said period. Out of the cases, 18,405 were infants below the age of four, 6,541 of children between five and 14 years, while 6,648 others were found among adolescents aged 15.

She attributed the high increase in malaria cases in Kwanza south to the existence of a very weak primary health care system, lack of insecticide, the high cost of living and medicine.

Meanwhile, 121 cases of biennorrhagia (a copious mucus discharge) were diagnosed over the period, 10 more than in 1995 over the same period.

Concerning the incurable AIDS, Teresa Joaquim could not give actual figures because Kwanza south lacks laboratory equipment to carry out tests.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Global Coalition Urges Reduction of Africa's Debt


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - A two-day economic meeting of the Global Coalition for Africa has ended in Addis Ababa with a call for additional reduction of debt owed multilateral institutions and bilateral creditors by 33 sub-Sahara Africa countries.

The decision was reached by the consensus of debtors and creditors attending the meeting, the chairman of the Economic Committee, Kwesi Botchwey, told journalists Tuesday at the end of the meeting.

He said the magnitude of the debt of these highly indebted poor countries of Africa had resulted from the combined effects of sizeable external inflows and low growth rates of their exports over the last decade. 

The meeting was attended by representatives from 16 African countries, 16 donor states and leading international financial institutions, including the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, and the African Development Bank.

The amount of the debt to be reduced for each of the 33 countries is to be decided at the annual meeting of the World Bank and the Fund to be held in October in Washington D.C.

Total stock aggregate debt of the 33 countries stood at 164 billion U.S. dollars in present value terms at the end of 1994 Botchwey, Ghana's former finance minister, said

Of the total amount, 64 per cent is owed to official bilateral creditors, 19 per cent to multilateral creditors and the remaining 17 per cent to private creditors.

Of the total multilateral debt of African states, 25 per cent concerns the International Development Association, 22 per cent the World Bank, 13 per cent the African Development Bank, 13 per cent European and Arab development finance institutions, and the remaining to other creditors, the Global Coalition says.

Botchwey said that the Coalition would further deliberate on debt reduction at its political forum gathering October 30-31 in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, with the view of contributing to the build-up of consensus for resolving the debt problems.

He said that the Addis Ababa meeting also recommended ways for improving the efficiency of agriculture production in Africa and ensuring food security in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


409 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Becoming A Priority In Mining Exploration


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Africa is poised to become the third largest area of international mining exploration in the world, according to a senior executive of the South African mining group JCI Limited.

Frank Gregory, JCI's general manager, said that as foreign companies intensify their surveys into the potential of Africa's mineral wealth, spending on exploration on the continent increased by 60 percent from 199 million U.S. dollars in 1994 to 320 million dollars in 1995. 

Addressing delegates at a mining investment conference in Johannesburg, he said this growth was the largest of any regional exploration budget in the world.

"Given this trend," he added, "exploration expenditure in Africa could overtake Canada in 1996, placing this continent third after Latin America and Australia."

And all indications were, he said, that this upward trend would be maintained.

The factors making mining in Africa a more viable included the change in attitude of many African governments towards foreign investment, the fact that Africa was still mainly under-explored as a result of its history of instability, and the expected international increase in metals consumption as more developing countries moved toward industrialization, said Gregory.

However, he said that exploration in Africa still faced such stumbling blocks as inadequate infrastructure, health and safety hazards, inefficient administration and corruption.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


410 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Zimbabwe;
AIDS Figures Boomerang On Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Innocent Madawo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe - One method authorities all over the world have used to control the HIV/AIDS pandemic has been to constantly release statistics of its spread.

Since reporting its first AIDS case in 1987, Zimbabwe has been at the forefront in releasing statistics on the incurable disease's whose cumulative estimates show that 10 per cent of the country's 10.5 million people are HIV- positive, at least 200,000 people have developed AIDS and are dying at the rate of 300 every week.

The figures show that the southern African nation has the highest AIDS cases in sub-Saharan Africa. The figures have contributed significantly to the 90 per cent awareness rate of AIDS in the country but they have also contributed negatively to the country's image abroad. 

In 1994, Zimbabwean delegates at the World Population Summit in Cairo, Egypt, had to fend off questions stemming from a British newspaper report that labelled the country as an AIDS haven.

During the July 1996 Olympic Games in the United States, boxing officials from some countries were reportedly uncomfortable with their boxers fighting Africans, particularly those from Zimbabwe and Kenya where high rates of HIV/AIDS infection were quoted.

At a recent AIDS workshop for Zimbabwe army officers a captain, who had just been on United Nations peacekeeping duty in Angola, said authorities in that country warned women against fraternizing with Zimbabwean soldiers because they were "full of AIDS."

Such taunts have compelled people to ask such fundamental questions as to whether the situation is really that bad in Zimbabwe as compared with other countries. And if known statistics are just estimates, what are the actual reported statistics and, also, is the government aware of the consequences of releasing the high estimates?

Ironically, actual recorded statistics for cumulative cases from 1987 to September 1995, released recently by the Ministry of Health, do not talk about the 10 per cent of the population being HIV positive or even the estimated 200,000 full-blown AIDS cases.

Instead, the figures show 48,882 actual tested cases by September 1995 and that up to 70,000 might develop full-blown AIDS by the end of 1996.

Why then is there such a big disparity between estimates and real figures?

The Zimbabwe National Family Planning Council technical director, Dr. Buhle Ncube, who recently resigned from the ministry of health's epidemiology and disease control department, said the high estimates were closer to reality than the actual tested cases.

"Reasons for the big gap are that testing in Zimbabwe is not compulsory and there is gross under-reporting of HIV/AIDS infections," he said, "as a result many people are classified as suffering from such AIDS-related illnesses as tuberculosis, hence the low figures of actual tested cases."

However, she said that because Zimbabwe's health delivery system was more advanced than most developing countries, it was easy to make near accurate estimates of the trend of the disease from general visits to health institutions.

An information and education officer in the ministry's Reproductive Department, Eunice Takawira, said that Zimbabwe's open reporting system made it appear like it had a worse HIV/AIDS problem than other countries yet, it probably was among the least affected.

"Some countries with low reported figures either have genuinely ineffective data collection systems or deliberately under-report their cases," she said.

However, Ncube and Takawira could not say whether government realized the consequences of its truthfulness, particularly the way Zimbabweans are being treated abroad.

But the health and child welfare minister, Dr. Timothy Stamps, has often said government has an obligation to inform the people truthfully as a way to control the disease.

Furthermore, the medical profession is convinced that the constant hype of the high statistics could have been a major contributor to the drop in sexually transmitted infections and cases of tuberculosis which have been noticed lately in Zimbabwe.

According to statistics, cases of sexually transmitted infections rose from 686,500 in 1986 to 1.24 million in 1991. Then there was a sudden drop to about 879,000 in 1992 and 1993 and again down to 694,428 by September 1995.

"This could be a good indication of positive sexual behavioral change among Zimbabweans," said Lt. Col. Alexander Musoko, the director of medical services of the Zimbabwe army.

Also showing a decline are reported cases of Tuberculosis which peaked at 25,956 in 1994 before dropping to 22,200 by September 1996 and are expected to drop further in 1996 and beyond.

However, it is not lost to the medical experts that the drop in sexually transmitted infections and tuberculosis could be a result of people not reporting their illnesses and so they expect new AIDS cases to rise by a yearly rate of 10,000 until the year 2000.

But the question remains, should the government continue releasing the high estimates and increase Zimbabweans' discrimination abroad or should it take other countries' lead and stick to reported cases only which apparently are much lower than in other countries?


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


411 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Swaziland;
Shake Up In Swaziland's Police Force


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland - After allegations of police involvement with drugs racketeers, there has been a shake up in Swaziland's police force.

Mass transfers of officers at various stations around the country, especially the stations in the vicinity of the borders with South Africa and Mozambique, are underway.

A long list of police officers are in the process of being transferred to other stations following information concerning large numbers of police involved in drugs smuggling. 

It is understood the mass transfers follow the arrests in July of two South African men by Swazi police after the men's van was found to be loaded with bales of dagga as they were driving to the Oshoek border on the Mbabane- Motshane-Oshded main road.

The occupants told the police they had bought the dagga from Swazis in the Piggs Peak area and were on their way to deliver it to buyers in South Africa.

According to informants, several Piggs Peak police officers, including senior officers at the Piggs Peak police station, except the station commander, have been working in league with the dagga farmers along the Swazi/South African border in northwest Swaziland and dagga smugglers. For this reason, the smugglers were not bothered by police in the areas under the jurisdiction of the Piggs Peak police.

The involvement of the police in the dagga smuggling was exposed by angry members of the Piggs Peak community who lodged complaints at the police headquarters in Mbabane, demanding the police commissioner take disciplinary action against those involved.

The Piggs Peak magistrate has also announced that from now on, consignments of confiscated drugs of various types in northwest Swaziland will no longer be sent to the Piggs Peak police station for safe keeping pending the destruction of the drugs.

Swaziland drugs squad police has been working in cooperation with INTERPOL, the international police, to curb the smuggling of drugs by international syndicates using Swaziland as a soft transit route to smuggle hard drugs like mandrax into South Africa - and as a plentiful source of Swazi grown dagga consignments some of which have been intercepted by police in Germany.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


412 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


United States and Africa;
Frontline Feminisms Conference Information


BYLINE: The Center For Women In Coalition


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Riverside - The Center for Women in Coalition at the University of California, Riverside is organizing a conference, "Frontline Feminisms: Women, War, and Resistance" to take place on campus January 16-18, 1997. Participants will discuss the forging of new feminisms in the context of militarized situations around the world.

The conference aims to link feminist activist and grass-roots organizers engaged in innovative feminist praxes with a gathering of scholars and policy- makers engaged in theorizing conflict and promoting cooperation.

Featured participants will include women from the Balkans, the Middle East, Central America, South Asia, the Philippines, Africa, and the United States. 

Workshop, film/video, visual art, creative writing and paper proposals are due August 1. All scholars and activists interested in attending are invited to send their mailing and/or e-mail addresses to the organizers for inclusion on the mailing list.

Conference registration will be $30 ($15 for students) and modestly-priced lodging will be available. (Registration and lodging can be waived in case of need.)

1. The conference is international in scope and we are interested in flying activists from different parts of the world. This is of course dependent on funding. We have invited women associated with the politics of the Balkans, South Asia, Central America/Mexico, Israel and Palestine, Iran, and hope to expand our contacts in sub-Saharan Africa, East Asia and South America. However, we are particularly interested in creating linkages between local and national activists and scholars with women from other parts of the world. In southern California, there is a richness of activism among Mexican- American, Native American Asian- American communities and we will be tapping into these regional networks.

Confirmed speakers include: Vasanthi Raman, Senior Fellow, Center for Women's Development Studies, New Delhi; Soona Samsami, Member Foreign Affairs Committee, National Council of Iran; Gila Svirsky, Member and Founder, Women in Black Advisory Council, Israel Women's Network; Rachel Wareham, Activist and Trainer; Motrat Qiriazi-Rural women activists; Kosovo Kemi Oyarzun, Founder, Center for Women's Studies, Santiago, Chile. This list does not include the many academic scholars who have either committed themselves to, or expressed interest in, participating. Also, we are working with the rich network of activist groups in Southern California that are addressing issues such as immigration, political asylum, and labor, which are closely linked with struggles elsewhere.

2. The conversations will not only connect the "global" and the "local" they will also connect the "academic" with the "practical". As such, we are welcoming all sorts of texts and discourses -- papers can follow the conventions of academic conferencing, but they can also include creative writing, photodocumentary essays, installations, film/video. They can and will be bi or tri-lingual and interpreters will be on hand! We hope that conversations are multiple, linking scholars with activists, poets, artists and whatever intersections and permutations of both. There will be panel presentations, workshops and films.

3. We remain open -- in policy -- to any ideas and creative possibilities which we can accomodate within the constraints we have: time and money. So please do get in touch with us -- about people both here and internationally who we could contact. We are already heartened by the enthusiasm which is seeping in from all quarters of global cyber-space and will follow any "lead" you suggest. Please note again that our funding IS limited in terms of being able to pay for air-tickets but we are going to be creative about good but cheap accommodation in Riverside -- and transportation within the area (to and from airports etc).

4. We are also committed to trying to financially assist women who are not connected to any sources of conventional funding (university, foundations etc) and who will be prohibited because of financial inability to pay for train/plane tickets, housing etc.

5. We are also planning to put together an anthology of writing about these issues (again both academic and other kinds of work) which will be published. We intend to archive (both in text and video) the conference.

For more information, write, fax, or e-mail: Piya Chatterjee and Marguerite Waller, Department of Women's Studies, UC Riverside, Riverside, CA 92521. FAX: (909) 787-6386. EMAIL: mwaller@ucrac1.ucr.edu or piya@ucrac1.ucr.edu


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


413 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Arts;
Planet Africa 1996


BYLINE: Toronto International Film Festival


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2000 words


 

Toronto - Inaugurated in 1995 to both critical and audience acclaim, Planet Africa returns as a regular part of the 1996 Toronto International Film Festival, presenting films from Africa and the African diaspora. Programmed by Cameron Bailey, Planet Africa includes six world premieres in a programme of eight features and five short films.

"We generated a lot of enthusiasm last year with a modest slate of films," says Bailey. "This year we're back with a larger programme including several world premieres and more films from more of the African world. We've covered the continent more broadly with films from southern, northern and western Africa, as well as other parts of the Diaspora. This year establishes Toronto as the place in North America to see new African film each year."

The following are the films featured in this year's Planet Africa. 

WHEN THE STARS MEET THE SEA (QUAND LES ETOILES RENCONTRENT LA MER) - World Premiere

Director: Raymond Rajaonarivelo, Madagascar/France, 1996 Madagascar's pre- eminent filmmaker establishes his place at the forefront of African cinema with this majestic film taking his story from a particularly resonant Malagasy myth. A boy, born on the day of an eclipse in a small village, is believed to possess great and dangerous powers. As a test, he must endure one night alone among the cattle. But a childless young woman rescues him, forever changing his fate. This startlingly beautiful film reveals Madagascar as one of the last magical places on earth.

ARISTOTLE'S PLOT - World Premiere

Director: Jean-Pierre Bekolo, Zimbabwe/France, 1996 ARISTOTLE'S PLOT began as the African entry in the British Film Institute's commemoration of the centenary of cinema. Instead of a respectful documentary like Martin Scorsese's US contribution, Bekolo serves up a wild hybrid that's half meditation on the trials of African moviemaking, half action movie send-up. In a southern African town, a group of wannabe gangsters hangs out at the Cinema Africa, megadosing on the latest actionfest while assuming the names of their screen gods: Van Damme, Bruce Lee, Nikita, Saddam, and the leader, Cinema. Enter an earnest cineaste, trying in vain to enlist the government's help in cleansing the Cinema Africa of Hollywood contamination, replacing Schwarzenegger with Ousmane Sembene. Taking matters into his own hands, he becomes a vigilante for a home-grown film culture.

EVERYONE'S CHILD - World Premiere

Director: Tsitsi Dangarembga, Zimbabwe, 1996. In her debut feature, Commonwealth Writer's Prize-winning playwright and novelist Tsitsi Dangarembga distills the statistics of the millions of African children orphaned because of AIDS. When their parents die suddenly, Tamari and her brother Itai must fend for both themselves and their younger siblings. Itai heads to Harare, where local hoods take him in and train him in the ways of the street. Back in the village, Tamari accepts the advances of a lecherous shopkeeper. As she tries to use his gifts to pay for her siblings' schooling, the village women suggest she leave, to keep the village safe for their husbands.

JOHN HENRIK CLARKE: A GREAT AND MIGHTY WALK - World Premiere

Director: St. Clair Bourne, USA, 1996. African-American historian John Henrik Clarke is a legend among scholars. Born into sharecropping, self- taught long before he entered academia, he possesses an astounding knowledge of the roots and branches of African history. He's also a great talker. Veteran documentarian St. Clair Bourne (MAKING DO THE RIGHT THING) lets the man do just that in this remarkable documentary, weaving Clarke's words into a mix of archival treasures and image manipulation. From ancient Egypt, we move through the Mediterranean, Africa's great empires, the slave trade, and African American history right up to the Million Man March. Though now blind, Clarke has lost none of his razor-sharp edge. "If you lose your eyesight," he says, "increase your insight." Narrated and executive produced by Wesley Snipes.

A SUMMER IN LA GOULETTE (UN ETE A LA GOULETTE) - North American Premiere

Director: Ferid Boughedir, Tunisia/France/Belgium, 1995 Ferid Boughedir's first film since his acclaimed HALFAOUINE is a sly comedy full of warmth, wit and exuberance, as he crafts a glorious portrait of a Tunisian resort neighbourhood where Muslims, Christians and Jews live side by side. It's the summer of 1967, and three teenage girls vow to lose their virginity by the festive Day of the Madonna. As events come to a boil, reports filter in about a potential war in the Middle East. But the people of La Goulette are captivated by more immediate news -- the nation's most treasured daughter, the celestial Claudia Cardinale (playing herself), is returning from Europe for a triumphant visit.

MACADAM TRIBE (MACADAM TRIBU)

Director: Jose Laplaine, France/Zaire/Mali, 1996 Laplaine's lively, comic first feature weaves unemployment, lust and family commitments into a series of scenes-from-the-quarter. Mike is an ex-con and layabout, while his brother Kapa spends his time boxing with his amateur-fighter friend Duka. The brothers are deeply concerned about their mother, Mother Bavusi, a former market woman who now spends her days quietly getting drunk. When Duka is knocked into a coma, the whole neighborhood of strivers, whores and amateur philosophers rallies together.

THE WATERMELON WOMAN

Director: Cheryl Dunye, USA, 1996

This debut feature from one of America's leading indie media stars, is fierce, funny and genuinely romantic. Dunye plays Cheryl, whose main passion is a forgotten black act or credited only as the Watermelon Woman. Frustrated by slim pickings on the dating front, Cheryl puts her energy into tracking down her mystery mammy. Moving effortlessly between fiction and mock documentary, Dunye reclaims the history of black-cast movies as she affectionately skewers the coupling habits of downtown Philadelphia lesbians. Meanwhile, Cheryl falls for a flirty white girl named Diana, (GO FISH discovery Guin Turner). Cameo by legendary motormouth and lesbian icon Camille Paglia.

W.E.B. DU BOIS: A BIOGRAPHY IN FOUR VOICES

Direcotr: Louis Massiah, USA, 1996. Dr. William Edward Burghardt Du Bois (1868 - 1963) stands as one of America's greatest scholars and political activists. His life story, spanning the post-Civil War Reconstruction period, the rise of Communism and Pan-Africanism, and the Civil Rights Movement, is chronicled by four leading African-American writers: Toni Cade Bambara, Amiri Baraka, Wesley Brown, and Thulani Davis. This richly woven visual history explores the major strategies for African-American empowerment during the 20th Century.

PLANET AFRICA SHORT FILM PROGRAMMES

PROGRAMME 1: Three stories from the playing fields of sex and race. From Britain to Burkina Faso, the rules between men and women are eternally fluid.

I BRING YOU FRANKINCENSE, Ngozi Onwurah, UK, 1996, 35 min. World Premiere

Sunshine Brown, the only bi-racial boy in Guildford, suffers at school both for his cocoa complexion and his hippie mother. Sunshine's only break comes each Christmas, when as one of the three wise men in the annual pageant he delivers exactly one line: "I bring you frankincense."

PUK NINI, Fanta Nacro, Burkina Faso, 1995, 30 min.

Salif and Isa are an average bourgeois couple, but when a Senegalese bombshell comes to town, Salif drops his pants in a minute. Isa embarks on exquisitely planned revenge.

SPIDERS AND FLIES, Danny Thompson, UK, 1996, 30 min. World Premiere

Lena meets the man of her dreams, only to realize she's just a stand-in for his one true passion. Same hair, same everything. She launches a plan that would make Machiavelli step back.

PROGRAMME 2: Their subjects may be different, but this pair of critically intelligent films sums up two poles of African experience -- the past in slavery and the future in dub science.

ASIENTOS, Francois Woukoache, Senegal/Belgium, 1995, 52 min.

On Goree Island off the coast of Senegal, a young man seeks refuge from present-day strife through a journey into history. Though no pictures captured the brutality of Goree Island's slave trade, the island retains memories of profound horror and strength.

THE LAST ANGEL OF HISTORY, John Akomfrah, UK, 1996, 45 min. North American Premiere

What do George Clinton's funkadelic Mothership, Sun Ra's jazz Arkestra and Lee Scratch Perry's Black Ark have in common? Weaving an impressive mix of interviews and analysis, Akomfrah reveals an alternate path in black culture

PLANET AFRICA FILMS CONFIRMED TO DATE

ARISTOTLE'S PLOT, Jean-Pierre Bekolo, Zimbabwe/France, 1996 ASIENTOS, Francois Woukoache, Senegal/Belgium, 1995 EVERYONE'S CHILD, Tsitsi Dangarembga, Zimbabwe, 1996 I BRING YOU FRANKINCENSE, Ngozi Onwurah, UK, 1996 JOHN HENRIK CLARKE: A GREAT AND MIGHTY WALK, St. Clair Bourne, USA, 1996 THE LAST ANGEL OF HISTORY, John Akomfrah, UK, 1996 MACADAM TRIBE (MACADAM TRIBU), Jose 82 Laplaine, France/Zaire/Mali, 1996, A SUMMER IN LA GOULETTE (UN ETE A LA GOULETTE), Ferid Boughedir, Tunisia/France/Belgium, 1995, PUK NINI, Fanta Nacro, Burkina Faso, 1995 SPIDERS AND FLIES, Danny Thompson, UK, 1996 W.E.B. DU BOIS: A BIOGRAPHY IN FOUR VOICES, Louis Massiah, USA, 1996, THE WATERMELON WOMAN, Cheryl Dunye, USA, 1996 WHEN THE STARS MEET THE SEA (QUAND LES 90 TILES RENCONTRENT LA MER), Raymond Rajaonarivelo, Madagascar/France, 1996.

Planet Africa is sponsored by Conros Corporation/Northland Firelogs and OXFAM Canada.

Special thanks to Black Film and Video Network.

The 21st Toronto International Film Festival runs September 5 - 14, 1996.

For further information contact Valerie Wint (416) 967-7371.

The website address for the Toronto Film Festival is: http://www.bell. ca/toronto/filmfest/ The schedule of "Planet Africa" films will be available on the Bell website at the end of August.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996

414 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Business;
Phelps Dodge Buys 51 Per Cent Of Zambian Company


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - Phelps Dodge, a United States mining company and manufacturer of electrical wire and cables, carbon black, and tyres, has acquired 51 per cent majority shareholding in Zambia Metal Fabricators Limited (ZAMEFA).

Introducing the new ZAMEFA management in Lusaka on Wednesday, United States ambassador to Zambia, Roland Kuchel, said Zambia had acquired another world class leader in business.

"The Zambian worker will benefit by working in a company which looks at the worker as a partner," Ambassador Kuchel assured. 

Ambassador Kuchel said "in dealing with raw materials, the company creates an opportunity for growth and export in the manufacturing industry".

According to a Zambia Privatisation Agency (ZPA) press statement released in Lusaka on Wednesday, other ZAMEFA shareholders are Bikana International Limited and the Zambia Privatisation Trust Fund (ZPTF).

And from the balance of shares formerly owned by the government, through ZIMCO (in liquidation), ZPTF will own 18 per cent shares for onward sale to the general public in Zambia through public floatation on the Lusaka Stock Exchange at a later stage.

And speaking at the same function ZPA chief executive, Valentine Chitalu, said "ZAMEFA is an important company in the matter of pursuing foreign markets, also taking into account that it holds great significance on the amount of local business it attracts".

A ZAMEFA executive confirmed that the company's business has undergone a lot of change, especially on the local market, from enjoying a virtual monopoly in local supply of copper wire and cable, it now faces stiff competition from international suppliers.

In particular, ZAMEFA's two major customers, ZAMTEL and ZESCO, have put out to tender their wire and cable supplies as a way of cutting down costs.

As there are no other wire and cable producers in Zambia, all copper rods are exported - mostly outside the southern African region.

Copper rods sales account for between 60 and 75 per cent of ZAMEFA's total sales in the last five years.

Issue Date: August 23, 1996


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


415 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
SADC Editors Urged To Expose All Violations


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Blantyre, Malawi - Journalists should expose all human rights violations, regardless of who is involved, a Dutch international human rights professor told more than forty editors from 12 SADC countries meeting in Blantyre yesterday.

Professor Cees Hamelink, of University of Amsterdam in Holland, yesterday said journalists must take keen interest in reporting and exposing all cases of human rights violations taking place in their countries.

Professor Hamelink said that all countries are, in one way or another, involved in violations of human rights and that these incidents must be brought out for the public to know. 

"Its the duty of the media to defend human rights and fight their abuse regardless of whether the government, or whoever are involved, may not like it," Professor Hamelink said.

Professor Hamelink, who addressed editors on professional claims and practices on human rights reporting, said that most governments find it difficult to accept many important issues on international human rights.

Amnesty international, a human rights organisation, he said continuously highlighted the abuses but few countries seem to respond.

Professor Hamelink noted that for good reportage of human rights issues it was important that there was independence, compassionate, fairness and accuracy in the media.

"Accuracy in reporting human rights is important because journalists are teachers on whom so many people depend on," Professor Hamelink said.

Professor Hamelink emphasised that every individual had a right to dignity, liberty and integrity.

"Individuals are more important than their government," Professor Hamelink said.

He said most human rights abuses go unpunished and very few people, including journalists, follow up such crucial issues although they are prevalent in their communities.

Professor Hamelink urged journalists to make a difference and turn a new leaf in the field of human rights.

He said that while constant reportage of human rights abuses would not guarantee an overnight improvement of the situation, the action would make a difference.

Issue Date: August 22, 1996


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


416 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Business;
Zambian Economy Grows By Five Per Cent


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has stabilised in that the economy had grown by about five to six per cent, said Bank of Zambia director of economics department, Felix Kani in Lusaka yesterday.

Kani, speaking at the ongoing International Banking Conference being held at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Centre, however, acknowledged that the Zambian economy had suffered some "shocks" in the mining sector over the low production and prices as well as the closure of some banks. 

Kani revealed that the major challenge experienced by the Bank of Zambia last year had been to maintain economic stability "with three banks in receivership and one in liquidation".

Kani advised that there was need for the Bank of Zambia to have a tight supervisory capacity over the country's financial institutions.

"Most important is the flow of information in a market economy," Kani said. "Inadequate information leads to speculation from businessmen which can upset the economy."

And Professor Lawrence Harris from the University of London, while recognising the progress made in the Zambian banking sector, noted that the country was still living with the effects of the liquidity injection which had characterised government's desperate efforts to rescue Meridien BIAO Bank.

"A 47 per cent increase in money supply is not benign and must be watched closely if the economic reform programme is to be kept on track," Professor Harris said, noting that the increase in money supply might be an indicator of spiralling inflation.

Professor Harris also urged the independence of the central bank as a factor in lowering the rate of inflation.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 28, 1996


Business;
Economic Liberalisation Needs Good Management


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Lusaka - Economic liberalisation needs good management if it is to benefit the country in which it is implemented, said former Bank of Zambia governor, Dominic Mulaisho, in Lusaka yesterday.

Mulaisho, participating in a panel discussion at the International Banking Conference which started yesterday at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Centre, said liberalisation which does not take in the human capacity can be chaotic and destructive.

"There is need for human resources to manage libera-lisation otherwise liberalisation turns into a monster you cannot control," Mulaisho said. 

Mulaisho encouraged investment in human resources as a factor towards growth in a liberalised economy.

University of Zambia's Professor Venkatesh Seshamani, speaking at the same conference, said growth without development has been a frequent experience in developing countries, being recorded only in figures but not visibly experienced.

Seshamani said apart from the usual measure of the implementation and the impact of the economic reforms, the success of economic policies could also depend on errant factors such as the terms of trade, both internationally and locally.

But Dr Mohsin Kahn, deputy director of research at the International Monetary Fund, argued that there can be no growth without development.

"Financial liberalisation leads to development and then leads to growth," Dr Kahn said.

Dr Kahn maintained that due to liberalisation, an environment would be created where growth could begin to take place though it should not be expected to happen overnight.

The conference sponsored by the Bank of Zambia, among others, is being attended by some African countries and representatives of the major business organisations in the country.

The theme of the conference, "Economic Liberalisation", dominates all the topics of the three-day meeting which is also being attended by university professors from the United Kingdom, United States, some officers of United Nations organisations, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

Chairman of the meeting yesterday, Bank of Zambia deputy governor, Situmbeko Muso-kotwane, said studies had shown that countries which had undertaken structural reforms around the world performed better economically than the ones which hadn't.

"Liberalisation is not an end in itself but the means to achieving the end," Musokotwane said.

Finance minister Ronald Penza, who officially opened the meeting, said the year of 1995 had been an important challenge to the government in light of the banking crisis brought about by the collapse of Meridien BIAO Bank, Africa Commercial Bank, and Commerce Bank.

"This seriously threatened to undermine the economy...1996 also poses serious challenges. Restoring macro-economic stability remains high on the agenda," Penza said.

Penza said it was time that southern Africa concentrated on restructuring its economies in view of the nominal growth recorded by all the members.

In a vote of thanks to the minister's speech, Zambia Association of Chambers of Commerce and Industry (ZACCI) member, Murray Sanderson, cynically said the business community was grateful that the government had set in motion various initiatives such as the expedient privatisation of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM).

"We are also extending our gratitude to the government for the flexibility in the matter of dealing with the bilateral donors, considering the importance of donor aid to economic stability," Sanderson said in closing.

Issue Date: August 22, 1996


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


418 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Ethiopia;
Economist Favors Private Ownership of Land in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Addis Ababa - Dr. Befekadu Degeufe, one of the most prominent Ethiopian economists and perhaps the most vocal of those still residing in Ethiopia, says in unequivocal terms that land in Ethiopia should be freely bought and sold ("Tobia" Magazine, 4th year, No.9). He goes on to say:

"Let priority be given to those who sell their land if there is such a need. Unless land is bought and sold on a purely commercial basis, the free movement of investors from region to region will be severely restricted in the short term".

"But there is a greater force that compels people to move from one region to another and this is the relentless population growth. People are forced to migrate to other regions as a result of land shortage and soil depletion. The barrier to inter-regional movement of people that may be temporarily erected by ethnicity-based regionalization and language policy will be broken asunder by the implacable growth of population". 

"The EPRDF is opposed to private ownership of land for fear that peasants would sell their land and migrate to towns only to swell the ranks of the unemployed. This may sound a legitimate fear, but the policy will not stop migration caused by population pressures and as such can only be thought of as a short-term solution".

"With respect to urban land and housing construction, a very amazing and deplorable situation has been created. Where the Derg regime encouraged individuals to build homes by educating mortgage rates, the EPRDF has gone two steps backwards to resurrect the condition prevalent under feudal land monopoly".

It is gratifying to note that as knowledgeable and experienced a scholar as Dr. Befekadu is in favor of private ownership of land with undiminished property rights, including the right of sale and purchase. However, we would like to indicate that arguments in favor of private ownership of land should be strongly presented by detailing the following additional major points:

Private ownership of land does not exclude the existence of other forms of land tenure such as public domain, cooperative and communal ownership;

. The reason why land ownership has become such a burning development issue is because the current mechanism for the supply of land under state ownership is grossly inefficient and because state monopoly on land and the resulting inefficient mode of its disposition have sent land prices sky-high;

Unwarranted restrictions on land use resulting from state ownership of land have adversely affected efficiency in its utilization;

. Private ownership of rural peasant plots would enable smallholder farmers to use land as collateral for small rural credits;

The assumption that peasants would sell their land and migrate to town en masse is not supported by historical and traditional evidence and experience and underestimates the farmer's rational decision-making behavior.

Would farmers continue to sell their lands and flock to towns even after feedback information that such behavior is met with wretched urban unemployment?

On the question of economic growth, or the lack of it, under EPRDF's rule, Dr. Befekadu has put forward some rather convincing and officially authoritative statistics. These show that at the end of 1993/94, i.e. more than three years after the seizure of power by the EPRDF, Ethiopia's real GDP (12.05 billion birr) was lower than in 1989/90 (12.09 billion birr) when the Derg was still in power. Further, Dr. Befekadu convincingly concludes that compared to the level of real GDP in 1989/90, there was no economic growth from 1990/91 to 1993/94, i.e. three full years and three months of EPRDF's rule.

According to the statistics presented, it was only in 1994/95 that there was some growth (4.8 percent) over the 1989/90 level (figures for 1995/96 are not given in his analysis). He concludes that year-on-year growth registered from 1991/92 to 1993/94 was due to the low-base factor, representing recovery rather than growth in the real sense of the word.

Factoring population growth into his calculations, Dr. Befekadu derives the very sobering conclusion that in fact daily per capita income declined from 59 cents in 1989/90 (the last full year of the Derg regime) to 57 cents in 1993/94.

On other facets of the national economy, Dr. Befekadu establishes the following facts on the basis of the government's own official statistics: That, although some of it is accounted for by birr devaluation, the country's annual resource gap increased from 822 million birr in 1989/90 to nearly 2.8 billion birr in 1993.94, indicating unabated heavy dependence on external loans and grants;

That the country's external debt burden burgeoned from 6 billion birr in 1989/90 to 28.7 billion birr in 1994/95;

That, similarly, the government's domestic debt went up from 6 billion in 1989/90 to 12.3 billion birr in 1994/95;

That the government's budget deficit had soared from 2.1 billion birr in 1989/90 to 4.1 billion in 1993/94, although in 1994/95 it did decrease precipitously to about 2.4 billion birr;

That the total volume of money expanded significantly from 6.7 billion birr in 1990/91 to 14.0 billion birr in 1994/95;

That overall inflation accelerated by 36 percent between 1990/91 and 1994/95.

Even assuming that the government's own official statistics are free of " political doctoring", Dr. Befekadu has credibly established that all the euphoria in government circles and on the government-controlled mass media about year-on-year economic growth in the past few years is misplaced and unwarranted and that per capita income has in fact declined over those years, implying the further impoverishment of the broad masses.

He also implicitly indicated that the illusion of growth has been created by the folly of making statistical comparisons within short spans of time rather than viewing developments in their proper long-term perspective. What do government bureaucrats have to say to such rather startling revelations? Or would they rather continue toeing the futile official line of trying to " create reality" with dodgy official statistics and specious statistical comparisons?

Issue cover date: August 23


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 28, 1996


Ethiopia;
All Taxis Should Be Insured


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele, Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Addis Ababa - No-one who has been in Addis Ababa longer than a few hours needs to be told that motorists' respect for traffic regulations - in particular taxis - leaves a lot to be desired. The soaring number of vehicles seen in the capital, combined with carelessness, is showing a rise in property damage and loss of life. 

In most cases, when someone is in an accident involving a taxi, the owner of that taxi is unable to pay for the damage due to lack of insurance. If you are unfortunate enough to be a pedestrian or passenger injured by a taxi, who is going to foot the medical costs?

There is no doubt that taxis are an invaluable service in our city. They transport thousands of commuters to and from work and personal business every day. It is also unquestionable that the majority of people who use taxis are in the low income bracket - in no position to pay heavy bills. To protect citizens, compulsory insurance for taxis needs to be enforced.

The government should look into this legal oversight. We have learned that some insurance companies refuse to insure taxis no matter how high the price. Stricter measures against traffic offenders, intoxicated drivers etc., is another important step. We can recognize and reward safe taxi drivers (say, with car stickers), to encourage others to follow their example .

In actual fact it is time every vehicle in Ethiopia was required to have compulsory insurance.

Issue cover date: August 23


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


420 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Business;
Rents for Ethiopia Business Premises Increase


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Addis Ababa - Tenants in Addis Ababa of some 27,100 houses and other such structures administered by Region 14 (i.e. Addis Ababa) and being used as business premises will reportedly be subject to stiff rent increases of up to 34 birr per square meter effective as of the beginning of the third week of August 1996 ("Addis Lisan", Nehase 11, 1988 E.C.)

For the purpose of the rent hikes, the Administration of Region 14 (or Addis Ababa) has ranked "Kebeles" (districts) and houses in Addis Ababa in three grades, namely first, second and third grades. The "Kebeles" are graded on the basis of location while houses are ranked according to the building materials of which they are made. Rent increases are also correlated with the grades assigned to roads. For example, houses located along main arteries are charged higher rents than those situated along feeder (inner) roads. 

The newly announced rents range from a high of 34 birr per square meter for grade-one houses located in "Kebeles" designated "grade one" and along main arteries, to 6 birr per square meter for grade-three houses situated in " Kebeles" designated "grade three" and along feeder (inner) roads.

Following is a sample of the newly announced rent list:

House Ranks Rent Per Square Meter in Birr

1 Grade one "Kebeles"

1.1 Main arteries

1.1.1 Grade-one houses 34

1.1.2 Grade-two houses 33

1.1.3 Grade-three houses 31

1.2 Feeder (inner) roads

1.2.1 Grade-one houses 31

1.2.2 Grade-two houses 30

1.2.3 Grade-three houses 28

2 Grade two "Kebeles"

2.1 Main roads

2.1.1 Grade-one houses 26

2.1.2 Grade-two houses 24

2.1.3 Grade-three houses 23

Hence, a tenant in the area of whose premises is thirty square meters and whose premises are located along one of the roads designated "highway" in one of the grade-one "kebeles", and which premises are made of stone, will have to fork out a monthly rent of 1020 birr. Would this be considered high? Compared to the previous rent, it is extremely high. The same house would not have rented for more than 70 - 80 birr on the basis of the old rent rates.

On the other hand, compared to average current free-market rates, 1020 birr might just be a little bit on the high side, but not all that much higher.

The rent increases have already created a public outcry, and not just among business people who are going to be directly affected by them, but also among tenants of government-owned houses at large, the latter thinking that it would be their turn next time around! The rent hikes would hurt user-tenants (those who have not sublet their tenements) more than sublessees (those occupying sublet premises).

Sublessors are going to be hurt most because they have lost their rent contracts with the Administration of Region 14 altogether! On the sidelines, previous owners of all these government-owned houses confiscated by the Derg may just muster enough enthusiasm about it all to snicker with some glee over the scramble for the properties which by rights are theirs and over the apparent appreciation of "their" assets!

Is the Administration of Region 14 wrong in making the rent increases? This in fact is not the first question to ask. What should first be questioned is whether the government in general is right in continuing to be in possession of properties which legally belong to some private citizens of Ethiopia? One may start yawning at the very idea of raising the question yet one more time, but the fact is that a wrong will endure unless righted or somehow redressed. The ranking thought of having been dispossessed in the present context of the transition to the restoration of the rights of private property is making a lot more bad blood than during the days of the Derg when private property was at any rate almost wholly proscribed.

On a more practical plane, the question raised earlier on may now be put forward: Is the Administration of Region 14 right in raising rents? Here the magnitude of the increase is the most important debating point. The Administration may well be criticized for increasing rents so steeply.

The increases should have been moderate, phased over a reasonably long period of time. Further, the termination of rent contracts with sublessors without due warning and without giving them a chance to renew their contracts does not appear to be an act done in good faith. Another question is: has some sort of comparison been made between the increased rents and the incomes of those affected by them?

On the issue of the probable consequences of the rent increases, the following may be underscored:

* Continued strife between sublessors and sublessees;

* Attempts by those remaining in their tenements after the rent increases to recoup some of their loss of income by raising prices;

* Vacating of tenements by those who cannot afford to pay the new rents, thereby possibly joining the ranks of the unemployed;

* Making the possibility of returning confiscated properties to previous owners or paying them adequate compensation more remote, because of the high revenue and valuation implications of the increased rents;

Well, finally one can only insinuate that two wrongs don't make a right! There is plenty of time to reconsider the decision to increase rents so steeply.

Issue cover date: August 23


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 28, 1996


Ethiopia;
Wounded Ethiopian Minister Returns Home


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Ethiopian Minister of Transport and Communication, Dr. Abdulmejid Hussien returned to Addis Ababa on Wednesday after receiving treatment in Israel. Dr. Abdulmejid was shot six times as he was going into his office 8 July. Apart from his hands, which further physiotherapy should put right, he is reported to be in good health. 

Two men, a postal agency guard and a police security guard were killed during the shoot-out with the unidentified gunmen. The Somali based Al-Itahad AL-Islamia have claimed responsibility for the attempted assassination on the minister.

In an interview with Efoyta an EPRDF magazine, Dr. Abdulmejid dismissed the group's claim saying that they had taken responsibility for the death of Major General Hailom. He is reported to have told Efoyta that the attempt on his life had been made because he was one of the leading figures in the country's development and peace endeavors.

On his arrival at Bole International Airport, he said: " We shall never kneel down to such terrorist acts."

Africa News


August 28, 1996


United States and Africa;
US Africa Aid Decision Nears


BYLINE: Washington Office on Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Washington, DC - Congress is now deciding how much it will spend next year to help the poor abroad. Last year, the US dropped to fourth place in total dollars spent on development and humanitarian aid. Of 21 industrialized countries, the US spends the smallest proportion of its national wealth on aid--just 0.1 percent of GNP. While the total amount allocated to foreign assistance in fiscal year 1997 year looks likely to be around $12 billion, Congress has already voted to spend $276.7 billion on defense next year--$11. 2 billion more than the Pentagon requested. 

Two different versions of the FY97 Foreign Operations Appropriations bill (H.R. 3540) have passed in the House and the Senate. Soon after Congress returns from the August recess, members of both houses will meet in the Foreign Operations Appropriations conference committee to reconcile differences between the two bills.

The Senate bill allocates more money for foreign assistance: a total of $12. 2 billion, as opposed to $11.9 billion in the House version. It also reestablishes the Development Fund for Africa (DFA), which was eliminated in last year's bill. The DFA was created by Congress in 1987 to direct US aid to Africa's poor majority. The Senate language holds US contributions to the International Development Association (IDA), the interest-free lending facility of the World Bank, at $700 million. This is not sufficient to fulfill US commitments, but is higher than the House version. Finally, the Senate allocates $27 million for debt reduction programs which would benefit many highly-indebted African nations.

The House version offers stronger support for the African Development Foundation (ADF). Although it keeps the ADF's funding at last year's level ($11.5 million), it protects these funds by preserving the ADF's separate budget line.

For additional information: Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E- mail: woa@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 28, 1996


Sudan;
Roman Catholics Held Prisoners by the SPLA


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Washington, DC - A delegation composed of Andrea A. Maketh, newly appointed by the SPLA as Commissioner for Yirol County, Msgr. Caesar Mazzolari, Apostolic Administrator Diocese of Rumbek and Fr. Kizito Sesana, responsible for the SCIO, flew from Nairobi to Akot in order to witness the release of six missionaries. Rumors had reached Nairobi that the missionaries had been under house arrest since 17 August.

The Nairobi SPLA office attributed this to the action of a local commander and told the press they would be freed by noon of the same 23 August. When the delegation arrived in Akot the missionaries were not at the airstrip, as expected. 

The delegation asked to proceed to Mapourdit, the actual mission station, at about 35 km from Akot, where the six missionaries are running a parish, a primary school with 1,500 students and a dispensary. The delegation was able to proceed to Agany, in the vicinity of Mapourdit, at the office of the Commissioner. When the local military commander arrived, it was negotiated that the delegation could see and speak first with the four missionaries held in Row Prison, also in the vicinity, and see the other two, still held in the compound of Mapourdit Mission.

The four in prison were: Sr. Moira Lynch, 73, Australian; Sr. Mary Batchelor, 68, Australian; Fr. Michael Barton, 48, American; Fr. Raphael Riel, 48, Sudanese and Vicar General of Rumbek Diocese. Sr. Maureen Carey, 52, Australian and Brother Raniero Iacomella, 26, Italian, were said to be free, but held in the compound of the Mission for "their own security".

In the afternoon the delegation was able to see the four prisoners for few minutes, and they appeared to be in good physical conditions. At the later meeting with the military commander of Rumbek and Yirol Counties, Daniel Deng Manydit, the delegation learned that the local commander had acted with his knowledge and consent; that no instructions to release the prisoners had been received and that they will be held until investigations are completed.

The charges against the four missionaries were stated as: "hindering SPLA recruitment, being found in possession of documents proving that they are spies from foreign countries, working for the spread of Islam under the disguise of the Cross". In the meantime Msgr. Mazzolari was able to put together from morsels of information collected from people what had happened. Saturday 17 at 5.30 a.m. the mission was surrounded and seal off. The evening of the same day the missionaries were put in prison or in isolation. Later the mission was looted. Several Christians as well as the Commissioner expressed to Msgr. Mazzolari their conviction that the action was a mistake condemned by the majority of civilians, and pleaded with him to organize for a quick restart the school as soon as the situation will normalize. Sunday 25 in the morning at 11 am Msgr. Mazzolari and Fr. Kizito decided to go back to Nairobi to inform the embassies of the concerned people and the media on the real situation in Mapourdit, an to intensify contacts with the SPLA leadership. Msgr. Mazzolari appeals to the SPLA leadership the guarantee the well-being of the missionaries while the investigations take their course, and, certain that the missionaries will prove to be totally innocent, is on his side more than willing to continue humanitarian, educational and religious work at the service of the civilians in Mapourdit area.

For more information, contact Mgr. Mazzolari / Fr. Kizito SCIO - Nairobi - Tel 569130 or 562247, fax 566668. Sudan Catholic Information Office Bethany House - P. O. Box 21102 - Nairobi - Kenya tel. +254.2.562247 or 569130 fax: +254.2.566668 Internet: scio@tt.gn.apc.org or scio@tt.sasa.unep.no


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 28, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia Fights New Floods


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission announced here yesterday that the task of transporting people encircled by floods in Alem Tena, Ejere and Illu woredas of West Shoa Zone, Oromiya to the Tefki Encampment has continued with vigour.

About 300 persons, domestic animals and household utensils have successfully been transported thorough efforts being carried out in ten seriously affected peasant associations since Thursday, the commission said, adding plastic and motor boats and amphibians obtained from the Defence Force and the Ministry of Agriculture were employed for the purpose.

The effort of rescuing life still continues, the commission said and added that the flood affected citizens are being provided with food and clothings. 

It said a consolidated life-saving effort is being made with the support of members of the Defence Force to help citizens stranded by a road blocked in Wonji Kuriftu caused by the route diversion of the Awash River to reach Nazareth on foot along the main road.

Of the 11 water wells sunk near the Awash Basin to supply water to Nazareth town, three have been flooded whereas the remaining for which flood protection has been made are functioning normally, according to the commission.

Similarly, in Wonji, the commission said, 17,000 flood affected persons are being assisted in the six temporary camps prepared until Sunday in Wonji Shoa, Alem Tena, Chaka, Mekonnen Boka, Gefersa, Dedemtu and School Number Four.

In addition to the assistance being made to the displaced, the process of searching for individuals to prove that no one has been left behind, with the help of motor boats some of which were secured from the Ministry of Defence, it s still under way, the commission said. No reports of human casualties so far, it added.

The Federal Government which has set up various committees for the purpose is doing all in its capacity to assist the displaced in temporary camps with the help of helicopters, vehicles and amphibians, according to the commission.

It said no damage has been caused to the Wonji Shoa Sugar Factory, adding the Defence Force and the factory's armed squad are making joint efforts to protect the factory from robbers and flooding.

About 8,000 of the workers of the Metahara Sugar Factory have been sheltered in temporary camps for caution, the commission reported, disclosing that the necessary assistance has been transported by helicopters to flood prone areas in Amibara, Gewane and Dubti as well as the Awash Basin.

The responsible committee urged citizens in flood-prone areas to stay on the alert and move to dry, safe areas before being caught by the floods.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


425 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Ethiopia;
Premier Stresses Need For Action Against Poverty


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Addis Ababa - Prime Minister Meles Zenawi has said that the ever increasing level of poverty would have incalculable political and social consequences if it is not arrested and reversed in time.

Opening the two day Economic Committee meeting of the Global Coalition for Africa (GCA), Ato Meles said, "the remedy for what ills Africa has whether it is its poverty that pricks one's conscience or whether it is its instability that arouses one's concern, lies in removing the obstacles to Africa's economic and social regeneration and to its development." he noted that "if Africa fails to do so, it would remain to wallow in its poverty with all it consequences and the achievement of peace and stability in the continent would remain a distant dream."

He emphasized that the unique partnership for which the Global Coalition is a vehicle is also based on the firm realization that a speeded up and accelerated economic development of Africa is not only in the interest of the continent but also in the interest of others. 

He also expressed his belief that the exchange of views and sharing of experiences are vital in availing the forum of "building consensus on the appropriate steps that need to be taken and on ways and means to pull Africa out of economic quagmire.

Mr. Ahmadou Adbulla, Executive Secretary of GCA, said on his part that it has to be understood that a great deal has been achieved by most African countries. Problems in leadership commitment for development and transparency still happen to be challenges for progress throughout the continent.

According to ENA reports the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) Director General, Jacques Diouf says Ethiopia's effort to achieve food self- sufficiency within a short period of time would be worth emulation by other African countries.

During talks with Prime Minister Meles Zenawi yesterday, Mr.Diouf expressed his conviction that Ethiopia would sometime be able to assist other countries particularly in the area of agricultural expertise.

Promoting irrigation in areas characterised by water shortage is vital to improve agricultural productivity and guarantee food self sufficiency, he said.

Mr. Diouf expressed his organisation's appreciation of the dedication exhibited by Ethiopia, particularly of Prime Minister Meles, who in his capacity as chairman of the OAU last year made great effort to make the World Food Summit scheduled to be held in Rome in mid November a success.

Some 90 heads of state and non governmental organisations are expected to participate in the summit from which Africa hopes to benefit.

Prime Minister Meles on his part briefed the director general on the activities undertaken by the Ethiopian government in the agricultural sector to achieve food self sufficiency.

He commended the assistance the World Food Organisation has made to date to promote agricultural productivity in Ethiopia.

Mr. Jackques Diouf arrived Sunday to attend the ongoing economic meeting of the global Coalition for Africa under way here in Addis.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

426 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 28, 1996


Ethiopia;
Efforts To Prevent Ethiopian Flooding


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Addis Ababa - Water Resources Minister Ato Shiferaw Jarso said there is no fear that the overflowing of Awash River would flood areas neighbouring Wonji.

The minister, member of the National Committee in charge of Disaster Prevention said strengthened efforts are being undertaken to prevent floods from damaging standing crops in Amibara, Metehara, Dubti and Assayta.

Ato Shiferaw said preventive activities would be undertaken in a consolidated manner as there would not be heavy rainfalls until Wednesday (today), according to meteorological predictions. 

He said about 30,000 people have so far been evacuated from the flooded areas including Wonji in a life-saving campaign since the Awash River burst its bank.

Only standing crops of two peasant localities and sugar-cane plantation on 400 hectares have so far been damaged by the floods caused by the overflow of the river, Ato Shiferaw said, adding there was no other damage or human casualty except one person whose body was found afloat on the flood.

The victims of the floods were evacuated and were settled in a temporary shelter in Metehara town.

The amount of water released through Koka gates Sunday was 600 cubic metre and that maximum efforts are being exerted to prevent a bridge which leads to the Metehara Sugar Factory from being damaged by floods.

Numerous members of the national Defence Force in Awash Arba locality are making dikes to help prevent the overflow of the river, according to the minister.

Meanwhile, all the remaining people who have not been evacuated from areas engulfed by floods were rescued last Sunday.

In a related news from Nazareth, residents of Nazareth town are building dikes around a water pump in Wonji in a bid to prevent water shortage that may result from overflow of Awash River.

The Oromiya Water, Mines and Energy Bureau head, Ato Jundi Sado said the residents saved the main water pump from being damaged by floods by building protective dikes around it.

He further said presently the residents of the town are being supplied with adequate water and added preventive action would be undertaken round the clock.

Ato Jundi said the Ethiopian Roads Authority, the Fuel Wood Project and the Municipality of Nazareth town have made great contributions to the preventive activities by providing manpower and materials.

LANGUAGE: English
