Africa News


August 29, 1996


Zambia;
Kaunda Welcomes Donor Sanctions On Zambia


BYLINE: M. Mulenga and M. Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondents, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Opposition UNIP leader, Kenneth Kaunda, Thursday welcomed the donor economic squeeze on President Frederick Chiluba's government and urged the international community to keep up the sanctions pressure to force the government resolve the current constitutional and political impasse.

"We are where we are now (peaceful) because of the donors who have withheld aid which continues to give hope to Zambians for a peaceful resolution of the present political and constitutional crises," Kaunda told local journalists here.

He said that he was ready to contribute to the search for a solution to the crises through the proposed inter-party dialogue between the opposition parties and the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy. 

President Chiluba, he revealed, had been in touch with him to arrange the proposed inter-party reconciliatory talks which, he said, should revolve on the constitution and the 1996 scheduled presidential and parliamentary elections. His only condition for attending the talks would be that they be held at a neutral venue under neutral chairman.

"I am ready and willing to come (for the talks)...I am not asking any more than what Mr. Chiluba had himself asked for in 1991...it's a matter of do unto others as you would have them do unto you," said Kaunda.

He was referring to Chiluba's refusal to attend the 1991 constitutional talks at state house under his chairmanship. Kaunda gave in and allowed the church to preside at venues outside the seat of power.

Kaunda again reiterated that he would defy the new constitutional clause which bars him from standing.

"I want to say again that I will break the law and go to prison over this apartheid constitution. We fought similar constitutions in Angola, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe and South Africa as a matter of principle...I will never compromise with evil," warned Kaunda.

Meanwhile, Kaunda has asked President Chiluba to dismiss Francis Ndhlovu, the inspector general of police, who he said, comprised the integrity of the police service by admitting that he had deployed unorthodox means to investigate members of UNIP who are currently charged with treason and murder.

Ndhlovu last week told the court that he had ordered illegal tapping of " Post" newspaper telephone lines during investigations of the treason case.

Kaunda claimed that the opposition members had been charged with "fake" offenses as political vendetta against UNIP.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 29, 1996


United States and Africa;
Boutros Ghali To Address Washington Forum


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and veteran South African freedom fighter Walter Sisulu are expected to be main speakers at a five-day forum starting September 9, in Washington, D.C.

The forum, organized by an African-American organisation, "Constituency for Africa" or CFA, will be officially named the 'Ronald H. Brown African Affairs Series' in honor of the late U.S. Secretary of Commerce, who died in a plane crash in Croatia earlier this year.

The organizers said in a dispatch to PANA in Dakar Thursday the UN secretary general will give a keynote address on September 13, on 'conflict Resolution in Africa'.

Issues to be discussed under the subject will include the 1994 genocide in Rwanda and the current situation in Burundi, where a military takeover occurred July 25. Trade and human rights in Nigeria, modern slavery in Africa, the US/UN intervention in Liberia and African human rights efforts will also be discussed. 

Walter Sisulu will participate in a discussion on the state of democracy and status of human rights in Africa. The topic will be part of the discussion on Democracy, Human Rights and U.S Policy towards Africa with the U.S Assistant Secretary of State George Moose as one of the keynote speakers.

The CFA Executive Director, Melvin Foote, said the forum will also discuss diverse issues as doing business in Africa, the culture of the African Diaspora and the modern world and the role of science and technology in African development.

The forum will be the second of its kind and is to be held during and in conjunction with the "Congressional Black Caucus Annual Legislative week."

"The goal of this series is to keep African issues and concerns on the front burner of the agenda of this country because they are as important as their domestic counterpart, particularly for African-American progress," Foote notes in the dispatch.

"While the past twenty five years have witnessed unprecedented progress in the area of African African-American cooperation, more needs to be done to strengthen the links and to demonstrate how intertwined are the destinies of both peoples."

Participants will witness the inauguration of an award called "The Constituent of the Year Award" to be presented to an individual who has provided exemplary leadership and service "in creating support for Africa in the United States."

CFA's focus since the organisation was founded in 1990 has been "to educate the American public about Africa and African issues and to improve cooperation and coordination among a variety of organizations, groups and individuals with interest in Africa."

Africa News


August 29, 1996


Libya;
Six African Leaders To Attend Libya's Revolution Day


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - Six African presidents are expected in Tripoli within the next two days, to attend the 27th anniversary of the Libyan revolution which falls on September 1.

Officials in the Libyan capital said they are expecting presidents Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso, Idriss Deby of Chad, Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Alpha Konare of Mali, Gen. Ibrahim Mainassara Bare of Niger, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Syria's Hafez Al Assad.

Highlights of the celebration, marking the accession to power of Col. Moammar Kadhafi in 1969, will include the launching of the second phase of Libya's water supply project known as the "Great Artificial River." 

Libyan officials said Mubarak and Assad would be visiting their country again for the first time in five years.

The officials have been engaged in spirited public works which include rehabilitation of the water supply system in Tripoli. Extensive work is also being carried out at the Sidi Yayah water depot, 30 km from the capital, which will be used to stock fresh water tapped from underground streams in Southern Libya, close to the border with Sudan.

Tripoli airport is also undergoing a facelift, particularly its VIP lounge, suggesting that some of the invited leaders might arrive here by plane, despite the embargo imposed on Libya by the United Nations on April 15, 1995.

The world body alleged that Libyan secret agents were implicated in the mid- air explosion of a passenger plane over the Scottish town of Lockerbie in 1988, and in a similar incident involving a French carrier, UTA, over Niger in 1989.

Three western countries -- Britain, France and the United States -- convinced the United Nations to impose sanctions against Libya to force it to surrender the suspected bombers for trial in London or Washington.

Libya has violated the embargo on a number of occasions. In 1995 and earlier this year, its planes flew pilgrims to Jeddah in Saudi Arabia. In June this year, Col. Kadhafi flew to an Arab summit in Cairo in a Libyan aircraft.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


August 29, 1996


West Africa;
West African Experts Discuss Gas Project


BYLINE: Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Four West African countries - Benin, Ghana, Nigeria and Togo - have commissioned two teams of experts to speed up the execution of a 260-million-dollar gas pipeline project.

The Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation said in a statement Wednesday the "teams were set up with specific tasks." It did not elaborate.

The creation of the two standing teams was decided Tuesday in Cotonou, Benin, by oil and energy ministers of the four countries, at a meeting held to review the project launched in 1995.

The ministers requested the headquarters of the Lagos-based Economic Community of West African States to serve as the project's permanent secretariat.

The teams have been asked to give a report at the next extraordinary meeting of the ministers scheduled for October in Accra, Ghana.

Nigeria's petroleum resources minister, Dan Etete, was elected chairman of the standing committees of the project designed to commercialize, within the West African sub-region, his country's surplus gas currently being flared.

Nigeria is expected to generate about 500 million dollars over a period of 20 years from gas sale to a number of West African countries.

Some 50 million standard cubic feet of Nigerian gas is to be supplied daily through the pipeline to solve the energy problems being faced by some countries in the sub-region.

August 29, 1996


Libya;
Libya Grants Amnesty To Prisoners


BYLINE: Ali Dellali, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - The Libyan High Judicial Council has granted amnesty to all criminals who have served two thirds of their sentences. 

The council said Wednesday in Tripoli that it had also commuted to life imprisonment the death penalty passed on some prisoners.

The Council did not give any details regarding the number of prisoners benefiting from the amnesty, saying only that their names will be listed in the prisons.

Libyan leader Moammar Khadafi has proposed the abolition of the death penalty, but the Libyan Popular Congresses, the country's highest legislative body, have twice rejected the proposal.

August 29, 1996


Sudan;
Iraqi Embassy Denies Involvement In Sudan Plane Hijack


BYLINE: Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - The Iraqi Embassy in Khartoum has denied that its diplomats were involved in the hijacking of a Sudanese jetliner Monday, while on a scheduled flight from Khartoum to Amman, Jordan.

Iraqi Ambassador, Abdul Samad Humaid, condemned the incident as "a terrorist operation" which ran against "the values and morals of the honorable Iraqis." 

It has been widely reported in the international media that Iraqi diplomats were involved in the hijacking. The drama of Sudan Airways Flight 150 ended with the freeing of all 13 crew and 186 passengers, unharmed, at London's Stansted Airport.

News reports described the hijackers as six armed Iraqi diplomats. On Wednesday, the International Herald Tribune, Published in Paris, cited a London police official, John Burrow, as saying that there might have been up to eight Iraqi hijackers involved.

"Those who have circulated such lies should have referred to the list of passengers of the said flight to get the proper information on the names and profession of the passengers," Humaid said.

The jet, an A300, was hijacked over Egyptian airspace. Some 142 of the passengers were Sudanese and the rest Arab nationals, the official Sudan News Agency reported Tuesday.

433 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Civil Servants Strike Continues, Govt. Softens Position


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Civil servants in Zimbabwe continued with their strike for higher salaries Thursday as their leaders tried to squeeze more concessions from the government which has been forced to soften its hardline stance by the 10-day work stoppage.

Thousands of workers, sensing victory after the government announced it would award them a 20-percent increase, converged in larger numbers at their usual assembly points in the main cities awaiting orders from their leaders who were negotiating with the minister of the public service, labor and social welfare, Florence Chitauro.

The few civil servants who had succumbed to threats of dismissal and returned to work rejoined the strike after the government softened its position, acknowledging that mistakes had been made when the majority of the civil servants got less than 10 percent in salary increases. 

Chitauro announced Wednesday that the 161 000 civil servants would be awarded an extra 20 percent back-dated to July, saying this was part of the package the government had earlier committed itself to but which had not been effected.

The government climb-down came after the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions threatened a nationwide strike unless the government resolved its dispute with the civil servants by Friday.

Union leaders representing the striking workers told ZIANA Thursday morning that they had begun negotiations with Chitauro to formally present their grievances.

A public sector job evaluation exercise conducted by government in 1995 found that on average, civil servants earned 172 percent less than their counterparts in the private sector, and 82 percent less than those in the country's public-owned companies.

"We are now commencing negotiations...with a view to having the salary gap between us and our counterparts in parastatals narrowed," said one of the representatives.

He said it was hoped they would strike a deal to ensure that the lowest paid civil servant would get a 60-percent salary hike.

Meanwhile, they said the strike would continue.

The fate of the 7,000 workers whom the government had said it had fired for taking part in the strike was one of the issues to be resolved before they could return to work, they said.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


434 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Backs African Sanctions Against Burundi


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

United Nations -- The United States "strongly supports" the economic sanctions imposed on Burundi by African nations, U.S. Ambassador Karl Inderfurth said in a speech to the Security Council August 28.

The sanctions, which include cutting air links and closing borders, were imposed on July 31 by East African nations in response to a July 25 coup which replaced the elected president, Sylvestre Ntibantunganya.

Following is the text of Inderfurth's statement:

On July 29 the Council called on the military leaders in Bujumbura "to restore constitutional government and processes, including the continuation of the elected National Assembly and civil institutions and respect for human rights." Regrettably, there has been no progress toward these objectives. The leaders of the July 25 military coup d'etat in Bujumbura have taken no apparent steps to restore democracy, and the indiscriminate killings on both sides have continued. 

The most recent report of the Secretary-General points alarmingly to the further worsening of the situation in Burundi and to the failure of both the civilian and military leaders either to resolve their differences or to heed clear warnings given by the Secretary-General, the Security Council, and numerous world leaders.

The United States applauds the efforts of the states of the region to bring pressure to bear on the coup leaders. We will seek above all to support the objectives of Arusha in calling on the new regime to undertake immediate and unconditional negotiations with all parties inside and outside the country, to return to constitutional order and legality, to restore the National Assembly, and to unban all political parties. We also strongly support the stated intention of these states to cooperate fully with the United Nations and work toward measures aimed at avoiding a humanitarian catastrophe in Burundi.

The Arusha states have also imposed economic sanctions on Burundi. We strongly support this step and believe it indicates the determination of the regional states to achieve the goals I mentioned above. We hope these sanctions will convince the coup leaders that they have no alternative but to halt the fighting and initiate a political dialogue. If this does not work, the Security Council is willing to consider further action in support of cessation of hostilities, or to compel cessation of hostilities. Such action could include an arms embargo or targeted sanctions against faction leaders, as the situation warrants. All sanctions must be carefully implemented to permit continued humanitarian relief so that they do not injure the already- suffering innocent civilians in this crisis-torn country. And, of course, we should stand ready to support any genuine opening to peace and dialogue.

Future measures both at the United Nations and in the region must be carefully calibrated to events in Burundi. The fate of Burundi is today, more than ever, in the hands of the Burundians. We are sending a very strong message to both the present regime and insurgents inside and outside Burundi that the international community will not tolerate genocide and the threat this poses to peace and security of the Great Lakes region as a whole. All parties must commit themselves to a cessation of hostilities and a dialogue aimed at establishing a lasting cease-fire, an end to killing, and a comprehensive political settlement.

The Secretary-General's report correctly observes that the conflict in Burundi is not susceptible to a military solution. The factions in Burundi must overcome their deep-seated distrust and fears in order to identify and establish an effective political mechanism for themselves.

The U.S. commends with great appreciation the efforts of the Secretary- General and his staff; the Organization of African Unity and its Secretary- General, Salim Salim; former President Nyerere of Tanzania; the regional leaders from Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zaire, who met in Arusha on July 31; and other representatives of the international community who have worked tirelessly to avert a further worsening of the situation in Burundi.

The Secretary-General's report notes that the Secretariat has continued to facilitate contingency planning for a rapid humanitarian response to a crisis in Burundi. While we will continue to place our highest priority on promoting a peaceful solution based on political dialogue, my government welcomes finalization of the Emergency Operations Plan for Burundi, which ensures that U.N. agencies can function together to provide the maximum level of emergency assistance in the event of a serious escalation of the conflict. The United States has worked closely with the United Nations Secretariat in its two- track approach to military contingency planning, and continues to urge that other government support this effort. The international community must always allow for the possibility that the worst may happen in Burundi. The international community must avoid a replay of the horrors that befell Rwanda. The international community must do all that it can to be ready to act if the need arises.

The Security Council must, therefore, take further action. To that end, we will be working with other members of the Council this week to produce a resolution that sends an unmistakable and frank message to leaders of the Burundian factions: stop the killing now and initiate an immediate dialogue. Without timely progress toward these goals, it will be difficult to avoid a humanitarian crisis. But with progress can come a return of international support.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


435 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Uganda;
Formidable Task For Caretaker Of Uganda's Anglican See


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Nairobi - Early this year, Pope John Paul II appointed a Canadian, Monsignor Gray, Superior General of the White Fathers as bishop of the trouble-torn Kabale Diocese in south-western Uganda, and succeeded in restoring peace to the diocese. Recently, the Anglican Archbishop of Uganda, the Most Rev. Mpalanyi Nkoyooyo appointed an American padre and medical volunteer, the Rev. Dr. Christopher George Palacas as Vicar-General of the troubled eastern diocese of Busoga, a move that has been welcomed by antagonists in the see.

There are strong indications that peace could finally be restored to the trouble-torn Anglican diocese of Busoga after rival factions agreed to bury the hatchet and end a four-year rift that has paralysed pastoral and welfare activities of the Church of the Province of Uganda in this diocese.

This follows the induction on August 14, of an American padre and medical volunteer, the Rev. Dr. Christopher George Palacas as the Vicar General of Busoga Diocese. 

The bishop of the diocese, the Rt.Rev. Cyprian Bamwoze who has been on sabbatical leave will retire on February 7, 1997.

The Rev. Palacas, a native of Massachussetss, United States of America, came to Uganda with his wife Jane five years ago and has been working as a volunteer with the Community Health Project of the Anglican Church in Uganda.

The diocese encompasses the regional home of the Busoga, Uganda's second largest ethnic group after the Baganda in a country of some 18 million people.

Observers say members of the House of Bishops of the Church of the Province of Uganda have taken a balanced decision regarding the two rival factions. First they ordered Bishop Bamwoze, the man at the centre of the controversy to proceed on early retirement. He should have retired in 1999 on attaining age 65. Then they ordered Rev. Canon Samuel Lubogo, the self-installed bishop of the anti-Bamwoze faction, to vacate the bishop's house at Christ's Cathedral Bugembe, the headquarters of the troubled diocese. Lubogo was previously a prison chaplain and was installed by the rival group at the height of the crisis in 1974.

Furthermore, observers say by choosing a foreigner as caretaker, the archbishop has helped diffuse the seemingly endless problem, partly because each group's pride has not been violated.

In the three-hour service to induct the Rev. Dr. Palacas, former bitter rivals hugged and pledged to forgive each other for the many years of hatred, violence and antagonism that had characterized the upheavals in Busoga. The service was conducted by Archbishop Nkoyooyo who has been acting bishop of Busoga since the House of Bishops sent Bamwoze on sabbatical leave last year. "This is God's intervention, not human achievement," said Canon William Magambo, the Church of Uganda provincial secretary.

But despite the unprecedented return to the spirit of reconciliation, there is still simmering tension beneath. For example, during the induction service, the archbishop stated that Bishop Bamwoze was still free to confer sacraments of his church but a section of the congregation booed this suggestion.

In the meantime as Bishop Bamwoze prepares for full retirement, Rev. Canon Lubogo has already vacated the bishop's house and relocated to a furnished flat in the Ugandan capital, Kampala. He is officially on leave pending a decision about his fate.

The lay leaders whom he purported to ordain deacons will be defrocked since Lubogo was not an ordained bishop in conformity with the practice of Anglicans.

The four-year crisis in Busoga was a sorry chapter for the whole Anglican Church in Uganda. Rival factions threatened to secede a number of times in the hope of swaying the House of Bishops to their line of thought. Indeed, former Archbishop Yona Okoth angrily told the anti-Bamwoze faction: "You can secede if you wish since you have failed to operate within the accepted practice of your church."

The problem in Busoga reached a climax in August 1992 when the influential Dean of Busoga the Rev. Canon James Zikusooka, tendered his resignation to Bishop Bamwoze, stating a number of reasons for his actions, including accusations of financial mismanagement and poor pastoral management of diocesan affairs. Others charged the bishop had very poor communication skills.

Matters took a new turn by September when 1,500 anti-Bamwoze Christians passed a constitutionally invalid "vote of no confidence" in their bishop. They then proceeded to lock out the bishop from Christ's Cathedral in Bugembe and a number of other parishes. Bishop Bamwoze was out of the country at the time.

This state of affairs did not please the House of Bishops who in February 1993 issued a statement affirming that Cyprian Bamwoze "is the rightful Bishop of Busoga Diocese." The House of Bishops established a four-man committee to look into the affairs of the troubled diocese.

Unfortunately, as matters deteriorated, Bishop Bamwoze was not ready for reconciliation. Previously accused of arrogance by his detractors, Bamwoze issued a statement in January 1993, scoffing at moves to dethrone him.

He said he had no time for "such minor issues as his was a busy office." He would not defend himself under duress. He was quoted saying that as a bishop, he was "not desperate for support from those below or above him." Not surprisingly, a member of the steering committee against Bishop Bamwoze, a Mr. Naigere commented: "the bishop has fanned his current predicament."

Clearly, by belittling very influential people from his own Basoga community, he was only helping to fan the fire against him.

The Rev. Canon James Zikusooka, whose resignation as dean sparked the crisis, is a retired engineer and a former cabinet minister. He is currently head of Uganda's Public Service Commission. The late D.K. Nabeta, a former Ugandan ambassador to France, also worked ceaselessly for Bishop Bamwoze's downfall. His own brother, the Rev. T.T.T. Nabeta, should have been bishop but turned down the offer of appointment, citing lack of sufficient experience to manage the affairs of the diocese.

Paul Waibale Senior, a Ugandan journalist whose own father was a churchman in Busoga for many years, says the task ahead for a peacemaker like Rev. Dr. Palacas "is a formidable one" that demands patience, courage, determination and prayers.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


436 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Kenya;
A Story Of "Sour-Sugar" For Kenya's Cane Farmers


BYLINE: Robert Otani, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Nairobi - Nearly two decades ago, the people of a fertile region in south- western Kenya celebrated the government's promise of bringing them instant wealth through a factory and money minting cash crop, sugar-cane. But today, the eldorado has turned into a mirage as residents helplessly watch their unharvested cane go to waste, not to mention the environmental disaster and economic nightmare they have had to cope with over the years.

Seated under a giant mango tree in the middle of his homestead, retired civil servant Ogola Omolo reflects on his glorious past, hostile present and uncertain future.

His two grandchildren are playing lethargically nearby. They are hardly eight years but old enough to go to school although they are not doing so. With a sigh of frustration and despondency, he looks at his ten acres of over- mature sugar-cane crop. "I invested all my worldly wealth in this cane, but it is now going to waste," laments Omolo. 

The withering cane is almost six months past harvesting time. On the other side of the river overlooking Omolo's homestead stands the imposing South Nyanza (SONY) sugar factory. "This monster is my undoing. Before its arrival here I was a respectable man easily managing my affairs. But look what it has reduced me to."

Ogola Omolo is one of the hundreds of thousands of farmers who subscribe to the Sony sugar company at Awendo, a fast-growing township in the fertile south-western region of Kenya, some 600 kilometres west of the capital, Nairobi.

Before 1977, the half-a-million residents of this extremely arable land of 50,000 square kilometres were a happy and complacent lot. They enjoyed ample rainfall almost throughout the year owing to the relief and rich natural vegetation, most of it indigenous forests. They therefore grew enough crops, some of which doubled as cash crops, for food and other requirements.

They must have been overjoyed when the government announced just before 1977 the introduction of another crop that would instantly change their lives -- sugar cane. The sugar factory would be a fountain of cash to them, they were promised, and it would employ all their children after school.

The residents therefore welcomed the development project with open arms. Those affected by the project's nucleus estate willingly accepted to be moved out, although the government was despicably skimpy in its compensation for the acquired land and any development on it.

The people who had hitherto lived in tightly knit community set-ups were displaced. To minimize scattering, they were absorbed by their kinsfolk who were lucky enough to escape the nucleus dragnet. The land shrank considerably for those who would be the factory's out- growers to supplement its nucleus estate.

The monetary compensation was really not much but it was enough to send a good number of the beneficiaries mad, as most of them had not handled so much money before. It further enriched those who were already rich and further impoverished the less well-to-do. Most of the beneficiaries went into

unnecessary spending sprees and spared no money for alternative land. Such people now live in Awendo either as squatters or at the Sony labour camps.

It is two decades since and the local people from the project have to bear the brunt of the side-effects of a poorly conceived and executed development undertaking.

Says David Okeyo, an out-grower like Omolo; "If this is what development is, then let the government keep it to the urban centres and leave the rural folks alone."

Before the establishment of Sony, the people lived in primitive bliss. Although they did not have so much money, they eked a living out of the many acres of land each owned. The land provided their daily food needs, pasture for their cattle, cooking fuel and a home. The women's search for fuelwood only ended a short distance from the homestead, thanks to the rich natural forest cover.

But today, cooking and house heating fuel is a thorny issue for the residents of Awendo. Years back, they were sweet-talked into clearing these forests to give way to the sugar-cane plantations. But today, firewood is a scarce commodity, notwithstanding the concerted agro-forestry efforts of the Ministries of Environment and Natural Resources, Culture and Social Services and the work of many women's groups and non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

The fuel problem is compounded by the high costs of such alternatives as kerosene which sells for Shs.25 (about 50 US cents) per litre, yet an average household uses about two litres a day. An average Sony worker earns Shs.2,500 (US dollars 50) per month. Alternatives like petroleum gas or electricity are out of reach for these people.

The agro-forestry efforts would have achieved some success, had it not been for a recent phenomenon -- the arrival of the multi- national, British- American Tobacco Company (BAT) on the scene. Apart from competing for land with the sugar industry, tobacco consumes a lot of fuelwood during its smoke- drying stage.

Although a BAT leaf officer recently told a farmers' meeting that his company would do everything in its powers to promote agro- forestry alongside tobacco, the situation continues to deteriorate.

The residents' hopes for their children's employment have not been fulfilled either. Sony has a permanent workforce of about 2,000 and about 3, 000 casuals. But of the permanent staff, only about a tenth come from Awendo. Most of the casuals are transported in trucks from far-flung places in the morning and back in the evening.

Says George Bolo, the supervisor of one of the many weeding groups; "We prefer those from faraway places because they demand less pay. The locals gripe that they were short-changed during displacement and therefore deserve better payment for their labour.

But a factory personnel official argues; "We employ purely on merit and not according to where the applicant comes from. Giving the locals the priority is against government policy. We have no quota system."

The executive chairman who hails from the Awendo area laments: "The local people prefer to work in faraway places to avoid constant pestering by their extended families for cash assistance."

Most of the inputs during cultivation are provided by the company because of the farmers' poverty. Sony also accesses to the farmer transportation of the harvested cane to the factory and cash advances

for labour. But the bills charged for the services mean that the farmer ends up earning very little at the first harvest. Occasionally, one ends up with a heavy debt which can be recovered at the harvest of the first ratoon (regrowth).

But the situation has now become desperate for the farmers. Owing to rampant corruption and mismanagement on the part of the company and the effects of liberalization as prescribed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF), cane is hardly ever harvested.

Kenya's economic liberalization policy has brought about uncontrolled importation of sugar by well connected businessmen. Since the import is cheaper, the locally produced sugar hardly moves. Thus, as is the case with the other half-a-dozen sugar factories in the country, Sony stores are choking with stagnant stock. The factory's frustration is passed onto the farmer whose crop has to vegetate and rot.

Despite the factories' hue and cry over the unrestrained importation of sugar and representations to the government for action, the situation is far from improved. This is why sometimes Sony cannot afford to harvest ready cane, and the farmer has to watch in utter disgust and frustration as his crop goes to waste.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


437 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


South Africa;
Islamic Fundamentalism Threatens South African Security


BYLINE: APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2080 words


 

Nairobi - A major stand-off has developed in South Africa between the country's security forces and a Muslim fundamentalist group following the murder by the militants of a feared gang leader.

The murder has been condemned by the government, including President Nelson Mandela himself and retired Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, but other groups and the Muslims blame it on impatience with police and judicial inability to combat crime.

The Muslims have since threatened to declare a Jihad over the issue.

The incident was sparked when about 2,000 members of the militant Muslim group, People Against Gangs and Drugs (PAGAD) arrived at the house of Hard Living gang leader Rashaad Staggie in Salt River mixed race township near Cape Town on the night of August 4 in a motorcade of at least 500 vehicles, witnesses said

Hard Living gang is regarded as the most vicious of the drug-dealing gangs in the Cape Flats area, where most of Cape Town's mixed-race and black townships are situated.

Witnesses said that Staggie arrived home to find his house surrounded. Sitting in his vehicle, he raised his hands to show he was not armed, but someone shot him in the head at point blank range and dragged him out. 

As paramedics tried to attend to him, someone threw a petrol bomb which exploded and set him alight, driving the paramedics back.

He then managed to stagger to his feet and run a few paces before others in the mob pushed him over and emptied more bullets into him. Some PAGAD members kicked his corpse as he lay in the gutter, witnesses said.

The attack and subsequent murder of Staggie, the well-known drug and gang leader, was committed in front of police and a large crowd of residents. At lease 18 people, including a journalist, were also injured during the attack.

Condemning the killing, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, former head of the Anglican Church in South Africa, said citizens should not take the law into their own hands. "That way lies chaos and anarchy. It reinforces the old adage: 'Two wrongs do not make a right,'" he said.

South African President Nelson Mandela and Justice Minister Dullah Omar also lashed out the next day at the militant Muslim vigilante group, warning that problems linked to crime, drug trafficking and gangs could not be solved by people taking the law into their own hands.

"Arresting criminals, investigating their cases and bringing them in court is the function and responsibility of the police," Omar said.

On the other hand, Western Cape provincial premier Hernus Kriel called for an inquiry into the killing, saying he had sympathy and understanding with the people's frustration which, he said "followed on the obvious inability of the judicial and police system to handle such problems."

Political opposition parties and human rights groups, meanwhile, said the mob execution was an indictment of the inability of the police and the justice system to deal effectively with South Africa's runaway crime rate.

The liberal Democratic Party (DP) also condemned the killing, but pointed out that it was an indication that the community was sick of rampant crime, gangsterism, police inability to nail criminals and ineffective courts.

The independent Lawyers for Human Rights (LHR) condemned the vigilantism but said it was an expression of a much larger problem. "That the frustrations of these communities have boiled over into violence is not unexpected, in view of the commonly-held perception that gangsters operate with impunity," LHR said in a statement.

Police spokesman Senior Superintendent John Sterrenberg predicted an all- out war between PAGAD and the gangsters. "I shudder to think of the repercussions of this thing," he added.

Police had been at the scene of the mob execution but were unable to prevent the killing because when they tried to take action, they were cut off by the crowd, Sterrenberg said, adding that even if there had been 14,000 policemen at the scene "we could not have done anything."

But the Muslim leaders remained defiant, and instead warned of suicide bombings and a "holy war" against drug dealers and gangsters following the weekend mob execution of the feared Cape Town gang leader.

Mohammed Ali Parker, military leader of the PAGAD militant group which carried out the execution, was reported saying that he had no regrets about the operation. "The blood-letting was actually very helpful. In my mind it strengthens our cause. The war will be intensified. It marked the start of a Jihad (holy war)," said Parker, who was shot in the chest during the fire fight.

"All the signs are there. Each soldier of Allah is equivalent to 5,000 gangsters. "We are clean, God-loving people, and we are not afraid to die," vowed Parker, warning gangsters and drug dealers: "If they are not going to listen then I will pack myself full of explosives and pay somebody a visit. Then they will know."

On the other hand, residents of Salt River also spoke fearfully of the killings, telling journalists that Staggie was a Robin Hood figure in the area, and often gave money to poor people.

"He gave us money for sweets or anything," said a 10-year-old boy, recalling that shortly before he was killed, Staggie gave him a ten rand note (about 2 dollars.)

According to Prof. Wildred Scharf, director of the University of Cape Town's Institute of Criminology, the deceased gangster and his twin brother, Rashied, used generosity to buy silence from the community. "All gangs have to buy silence, and the Staggies were particularly creative in this," Scharf added.

One woman said the Muslim vigilantes had killed the less evil of the Staggie twins: "Rashied is the dangerous one, Rashaad was a gentleman," she observed.

Rashaad himself told a British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) interviewer in 1993 that Rashied was the violent one. "He likes the power. I like the money," he was quoted saying.

"I am the only one who can get into Rashied's mind," he said. "He is a psychopath, a real killer. If I go away, Rashied is in big trouble."

The clashes followed recent reports of growing secret cells of foreign- trained Muslim militants operating in South Africa's Western Cape province and in the eastern city of Durban.

The clashes followed recent reports of growing secret cells of foreign- trained Muslim militants operating in South Africa's Western Cape province and in the eastern city of Durban.

A senior government source said on August 6 that the cells were discovered by South Africa's secret service after an Israeli newspaper claimed in April that fundamentalists of the Muslim Hizbollah movement were training militants at five bases inside South Africa.

Public South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC) radio quoted an unnamed PAGAD leader as saying some members of the group had received military training in Middle Eastern countries, especially Libya, but the Libyan ambassador to South Africa, Abdullah al- Zubeida, denied his country's link with PAGAD.

Despite the efforts to contain the looming struggle, security officials still believe that Muslim extremists remained the biggest threat to internal security, with police spokesman Reg Crewe confirming that militant Islamic extremist cells had been set up in various parts of the country.

He said police investigations have reportedly revealed the existence of Islamic cells in several major cities, including Cape Town, Johannesburg, Durban and Port Elizabeth and also identified names of cell leaders, where military training is being given, where they got their weapons from and what contact they have had with international groups.

He named Qibla, an organization operating in Western Cape province, as the most extreme of the groups, saying that some of its members have been trained in Libya and Pakistan while others fought alongside the Hizbollah movement in Lebanon against Israel.

A Muslim analyst Lqbal Jhazbhay pointed out, however, that although the recent emergence of a popular and well-armed Muslim-based movement threatening religious war on crime in Western Cape province has surprised most South Africans, Islamic militancy has been around in the country for some time.

The majority of South African Muslims, believed to number between 500,000 and a million, live in Cape Town with smaller communities in the eastern port of Durban and the commercial centre of Johannesburg.

PAGAD's Cape Town support base consists mainly of descendants of Malaysian and Indonesian slaves who were brought to the Cape colony in the 18th century.

Under the segregationist policies of the apartheid regime, they were designated "coloureds" -- people of mixed race origin -- and denied significant political representation.

This, along with the former white minority government's restrictive Protestant doctrine that tolerated but did not encourage the growth of other faiths, drove many Muslim leaders to the anti-apartheid struggle.

Having played a key role in the overthrow of apartheid, particularly as intellectuals and strategists in the African National Congress (ANC) and the radical Pan-Africanist Congress (PAC), Muslim political figures were rewarded in the new democratic era.

Their presence in parliament, where they constitute 16 per cent of the members, is out of all proportion to the Muslim population of a little over one per cent of the 42 million South Africans.

Four members of government are Muslims, three of them in President Mandela's 25-member cabinet, including Dullah Omar who is responsible for the key Justice portfolio.

Ebrahim Rasool, who is now an ANC member and the provincial Minister for Health in the Western Cape, founded the "Call to Islam" in 1994.

Ahmed Cassim, a former PAC activist who spent time in the notorious Robben Island prison for his anti-apartheid efforts, founded "Al Qibla" a more radical group that recruited South African Muslims to fight in the civil war in Bosnia.

More recently, Al Quibla hosted the controversial visit to South Africa of d'Anouar Haddam, a leader of Algeria's banned Islamic Salvation Front (FIS), which provoked a mini-diplomatic crisis with some Arab states.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


438 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Churches Told To Work For Peace And Reconciliation


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Nairobi - The new head of the International Affairs Desk of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) has challenged churches in Africa to continue to work for peace and reconciliation, stressing that issues pertaining to lack of respect for human rights and democracy continue to affect the continent.

The Zairean clergy, Rev. Daniel Ngoy-Mulunda said the situation prevailing in Africa should encourage churches there to redouble their efforts towards peace and reconciliation.

"Issues pertaining to lack of human rights, democracy and civil strife, among others that are currently affecting thousands of people on the continent, should encourage us as churches to continue with our mission of reconciliation and peace promotion," Rev. Mulunda told APS in an interview here on August 22. 

In a document, put out by the International Affairs desk entitled, Proposed Initiatives, Rev. Ngoy, says a major problem confronting the aspiring democratic society centres on the tension between conflict and consent.

"When national political leaders fail to reach an agreement when all institutional channels are incapacitated, the churches will be called upon to offer conflict resolution strategies," observes Rev. Mulunda.

The changing situation in Africa calls for the AACC and in particular, the International Affairs Desk, to play a sentinel role, reading the signs of the time, warning the churches--as in the days of Ezekiel (33:1-9), equipping them and working with them for the establishment of God's kingdom on the continent of Africa, says the document.

In the peacemaking and conflict resolution, the promotion of forgiveness and reconciliation constitutes the primary challenge confronting the African church, Rev. Mulunda stressed, adding..."the achievement of forgiveness and reconciliation remains the central challenge in the context of the Rwanda genocide."

The AACC describes both forgiveness and reconciliation as theological concepts, whose common sharing and understanding is critical to their effective deployment by the church. If misunderstood, such concepts can by themselves become the source of conflict.

On injustice and justice, the desk's document says the church will increasingly be engaged with people who are accused of meting out injustice, fostering oppression and abusing human rights.

On ethnicity and nationalism, the document says ethnic conflict has been identified as one of the most destructive elements on the African continent. "In this regard, Christian churches are not immune. In many situations across the continent, churches and political parties work from some ethnic base. It is precisely under these circumstances that the church is called upon to promote peace and reconciliation," it explains.

On peace and reconciliation, the desk in its efforts to provide an ecumenical umbrella for conflict resolution in Africa, will engage the collaboration, cooperation and support of the Geneva-based World Council of Churches (WCC).

Regarding the resolution of existing conflicts, the AACC desk intends to organize various programmes and priority countries will include Rwanda, Burundi, Zaire, Sudan, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Senegal.

And on skills in conflict resolution, the department will organize training for church leaders in countries of conflict "so that they can be equipped to deal with conflicts."

Human rights, says the AACC International Affairs desk, will be part of the church curriculum, it must become part of Christian education programmes. The training of Christian educators must be linked to Christian faith, thus emphasizing the theological basis for human rights.

Rev. Mulunda, first joined the AACC in September 1988 as a Youth Programme Secretary. He recently graduated from the Wesley Theological Seminary and School of International Service of the American University, United States where he majored in Theological Studies and International Peace and Conflict Resolution respectively.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


439 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Angola;
Ecumenical Body Sounds Appeal For Angola


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Nairobi - As the unfolding peace process takes shape in Angola, the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), acknowledging Angolans' hope for a better tomorrow, has appealed to international ecumenical partners, donors and churches in Africa, to help the people of this war torn country realise the opportunity for peace that God has granted them.

The AACC appeal comes following a visit to Angola by the Executive Secretary for the organization's Youth Department, Mr. Khepi Shole. The officer was hosted by the Council of Churches in Angola from July 29 to August 6 this year.

And as the continental umbrella of churches reported on the situation of Angola, torn apart by more than two decades of civil war, former Angolan rebel movement, the Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA), on August 20 opened a special congress in the central town of Bailundo which will among other things decide the future of its leader, Jonas Savimbi. 

Among the new problems of the post-civil war (post-1992) period that last week's meeting was expected to resolve, is whether the UNITA leader should accept Luanda's offer for vice-presidency in a government of unity and reconciliation to be formed under the November 1994 Lusaka Peace Accord.

The AACC visit to Angola, which Mr. Shole described as both heartbreaking and educating, exposes human beings who have been reduced to endangered wild life in the middle of a devastating drought.

"It is only in Angola that I witnessed the total destruction of social fabrics of communities, which now have to start with absolute-nothing to bring new meaning of life," Shole said in a statement issued here.

Saying that the destruction of the Angolan community reflects very clearly that the civil war was sufficiently sponsored by the world's richest countries, the AACC Youth Secretary highlights problems facing the youth, most of whom were born within the war period.

He notes that while young people are on waiting lists in Luanda for further tertiary studies, most families do not have any kind of income to send their children to school.

Shole says of the rural areas, the learning environment is totally not conducive for any learning process, a reality that is well reflected in the shortage and conditions of schools, overcrowding, too many children out of school and inadequate learning material.

Angola faces one major headache---demobilised soldiers. The AACC youth secretary reports on demobilised soldiers flocking to churches for assistance in the hope of helping themselves in the future.

"Are we going to lose this generation of the youth....?"poses Shole. And adds, "our failure to provide any assistance to them will determine the undesirable future for Angola and will put the peace process on a very turbulent process."

Pointing out that most of the demobilised soldiers were born within the civil war period, the AACC staff underscores the fact that these young people have never known any situation outside the fighting. For them, a gun provides a job, security and status, and what they need is not hand-outs but self- sustaining assistance.

On leadership development, Mr. Shole compares the community of hatred, conflict and intolerance portrayed by the war situation to one of tolerance, reconciliation and trust, which must emerge if the healing process in Angola is to bear fruit.

Notes the AACC staffer, the war marginalised Angola for many years, denying the youth the opportunity to be part of the global, continental and even national ecumenical experiences that other youth in other countries benefitted so much from.

He says the Angolan youth are determined to learn from other young people's experiences and build their country.

Shole adds, although a large part of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) are providing hand-outs such as food and medicine, these, albeit really helpful, are not self-sustaining.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
