Africa News


August 29, 1996


Uganda;
Muslim Leader Warns Of Fundamentalist War


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Kampala - The Mufti of Uganda -- the leader of Muslims in the country -- has warned of a new plan by Islamic fundamentalists to wage war on the government.

Sheikh Saad Ibrahim Luwemba who is also Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni's personal friend, decried the misuse of religion by people "who are disguising themselves as missionaries, yet their real goal is politics."

He alerted the State saying he had received numerous reports that hundreds of fundamentalist-leaning Tabliq youths had been recruited and were receiving training in a country he did not disclose, but believed to be Iran or Sudan. Tabliqs are a militant ultra conservative Muslim sect. 

The Mufti reminded the people of Uganda of an incident in 1994 when hundreds of Tabliq youth were caught training in a forested area of north- western Uganda. Many were killed or captured when the Uganda People's Defence Force attacked their hideout. Some escaped across Lake Albert into Zaire and have formed the core of the West Nile Bank Front (WNBF), whose majority members are former President Idi Amin's supporters.

Said Sheikh Saad Luwemba: "I remember having warned the government that there were people poised to wage war here and you saw what happened in Buseruka (western Uganda). I therefore warn you that these people have reorganized to cause more chaos."

Sheikh Saad urged Muslims to give the government full support so that peace and development can continue in Uganda after years of civil strife. He made the comments at a mosque in Central Uganda on August 14, during prayers commemorating the reign of a Muslim King, Kabaka Noah Kalema of the Baganda people, Uganda's largest ethnic group.

King Noah Kalema's reign was short-lived but he is remembered for the promotion of Islam in Uganda. He died in the 1880s at the height of political and religious conflicts in Uganda.

Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni has previously warned the Tabliq sect to respect the laws of the land following the vicious killing of policemen outside a mosque in Kampala in the early 90s.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


441 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Governments Need Church's Help, Says President Mugabe


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Harare - In an impassioned appeal for peace in Burundi, Liberia, Somalia, Sudan, Rwanda, Western Sahara and other troubled spots in the world, Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe has called for a national political order that enables all individuals to enjoy full human rights, including the fundamental democratic right to chose and reject governments in power.

The Zimbabwean leader emphasized the government's need for the spiritual vision of churches to steer a straight course and called for solidarity between the Church and the State, saying governments alone cannot achieve any of their social targets.

He was speaking at the Catholic Bishops Conference on Social Thought and Action of the Church in English and Portuguese-speaking Africa which was held here at the beginning of August. 

The conference was attended by about 60 bishops and members from the outspoken and influential

Catholic justice and peace organizations and was hosted by the Pontifical Council for Justice and Peace together with the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace.

Pointing out that problems could be created by governments and dictatorships, President Mugabe said, if solidarity is to be realised between the Church and State, it is most important that the latter recognizes the former as an equal, if not superior partner.

"But we have to go beyond peace, and for its own survival and our own, create politically and economically sustainable environments that will outlaw, for all time, dictatorships, tyrannies and other politically oppressive systems, for the greater joy and hope of man in our society," President Mugabe advised.

He observed that governments are only a political creature with temporary authority, regulating the lives of citizens, including bishops and church followers, whom those authorities sometimes unjustly harassed, arrested and incarcerated.

President Mugabe said the power wielded by the government is however ephemeral and short-lived but the power and strength of the Church, being spiritual, is more enduring.

The Head of State voiced his conviction that governments should be guided by certain Christian or ethical and humanitarian principles as well as common societal interests.

He noted that a government whose policies are reinforced by Christian or moral values, is more enriched and a powerful force for the attainment of a society or nation whose members are bound by a system of moral values.

On social morals, Mugabe said the acceptance of the sanctity of marriage, bonds of love or true friendships in neighbourhoods and communities, reduce conflict and even thefts and robberies.

Both the government and Church should continually appraise the prevailing situation in society in order to assess the needs of the times. Common objectives mean that the two institutions should share strategies on problems that demand common programmes.

"The recognition of a common bond between them (Church and State) should thus enable the two partners to forge efficient and effective partnerships in the humanity of all to the greater glory of God...," he added.

President Mugabe also commended the youth for the important role they had played in the national liberation struggles of many African countries. In many political struggles for freedom from oppression and human rights, the youth had always been the forerunners of political movements.

Christian discipline of the youth through the teaching and example of the family, school and Church, would result in the uprightness of the young people, thereby lessening juvenile delinquency, drunkenness, drug addiction and crime, noted the Zimbabwean leader.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


442 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Kenya;
Nairobi Gets New Anglican Provost


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Nairobi - Newly appointed Anglican Provost of Nairobi's All Saints Cathedral has condemned land grabbing and corruption and urged Christians to set a good example in practising justice.

Giving his maiden sermon at the cathedral on August 18, Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) Ven. Canon Peter Njoka quoted the biblical prophet Amos who stood for justice that went beyond barriers. Justice he said, does not discriminate between the poor and the rich or the old and young. 

He wondered why the poor man should lose his land to the rich man just because the rich are capable of using the courts which also have become unfair dispensers of justice.

Everyone, he said, should receive what they deserve for their actions regardless of their station in life, and only then will justice flow like a never failing stream. He said the present day Kenya was not different from the eighth century BC Israel when Amos prophesied: "And the words of Amos are still speaking to us today, Kenya is peaceful and business can be done peacefully but we need to see God as overall head and submit to Him even as we express justice. Only then will justice roll down like a flood to us," noted the new provost.

The Ven. Canon Njoka was appointed the tenth provost of All Saints Cathedral on July 25, 1996, succeeding the Very Rev.Peter Njenga who was elevated to be the fourth Diocesan Bishop of Mt.Kenya South.

Born 51 years ago in Kagaari in Embu District, Eastern Province, the new provost attended local primary and secondary schools and trained as a teacher at St. Mark's College Embu. He taught in several primary schools upto 1975 when he resigned to study theology at the St. Paul's United Theological College, Limuru. He attained a Makerere University Diploma in Theology and a Licentiate in Theology in 1978.

He later on studied for a bachelor's degree in Bible and Christian Ministries specializing in biblical interpretation and application at the Daystar University. Between 1983 and 1984 he attained a certificate in ecumenical studies from the Bossey Institute in Switzerland.

Canon Njoka was made deacon on December 3, 1978 and served as a curate at St. Stephen's Church Jogoo Road, Nairobi. He became priest on December 9, 1979, serving in the same parish and later on at St. Mary's Kabete Parish. He has also served the parishes of St. Mark's Westlands, St. Barthlomew Church and St. John's Pumwani.

He has served as a canon of the diocese of Nairobi since 1982 and as a Rural Dean since 1987. In 1995, he was elevated to be Archdeacon of St. John's Pumwani.

Canon Njoka is married to Pauline Wanjiku and they have three children. He will be inducted to his new position on September 22, 1996.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


443 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Uganda To Host Girl-Child Education Conference


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Kampala - As a follow-up to the 1995 United Nations Women's Conference held in Beijing, China, Uganda will host the first African conference on the girl- child and the education of women from September 8 to 13 this year.

The theme of the conference in the Ugandan capital will be, Empowering women through functional literacy and the education of the girl-child.

The six-day meeting will attract national policy makers in the area of women's education and gender development programmes on the African continent. Some 300 participants are expected at the meeting sponsored by the Organization of African Unity (OAU), the Ugandan government and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). 

A key area of discussion will be gender sensitive curricula and teaching methods. Other aspects include the security and health of the girl-child and young women in the course of their education. For example, sanitary facilities which are lacking in many girls' schools in Africa will also be an item of concern for the conference participants.

Sam Onen, a technical consultant for the conference said the forum will serve as one of the many approaches to help sensitize communities and policy makers on the vital role of educating women in the development process of any nation.

The goal of the conference is to enhance the status of women in Africa through promotion of functional literacy and girls' education, thus achieving gender equity in development. The conference is expected to sign a "Kampala Declaration" on the advancement of women with viable and attainable commitments on girls' and womens' education.

Meanwhile, a recent survey in Kampala has shown that affirmative action and policies introduced in Uganda since 1990 have substantially increased the number of girls in schools and colleges of higher learning.

For example, girls now constitute 33 per cent of the enrolment at Makerere University up from 25 per cent six years ago.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


444 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Egypt;
69 Arrested After Coptic Christians Killed


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Cairo - Egyptian security forces have arrested a total of 69 people following a series of raids by suspected Muslim fundamentalists on jewelry shops in southern Egypt that left two Coptic

Christians dead, police sources announced here on August 18.

The arrests took place around the town of Tima, 455 kilometres south of Cairo, and five Islamic militants were seized in the town's cemetery after the raids on four jewellers in the nearby town of Tahta late August 17, they said.

Three armed groups of militants launched simultaneous raids against three jewellers' shops in the same road in Tahta, shooting dead two jewellers and injuring three other people, police said. 

They killed two Coptic Christians, Metri Atta Ateya and Safwat Shafiq, and injured three other people, including a six-year-old Coptic boy and a Muslim engineer, hit by bullets as the gang made their escape in a hijacked lorry.

The group then attacked a fourth jewellery shop in Tahta without causing casualties, police said.

Witnesses said that security guards hired to guard the main street in Tahta, which contains dozens of jewellery shops, fled when they heard gunfire from the militants.

Police said the attackers were from Egypt's main armed Islamic militant group, the Jamaa Islamiyya, and that they escaped with 10 kilogrammes of gold and 15,000 Egyptian pounds ($4,500).

According to police officials, Islamic militants had now turned to armed robbery to fill their depleted coffers and buy weapons after the government successfully cut off their flow of funds from abroad.

The Jamaa Islamiyya, has recently struck repeatedly against jewellery shops and banks in southern Egypt over the past month, leaving behind a trail of bloodshed.

On August 5, two people including a bank employee were killed and three others were seriously wounded in a raid against a branch of the state-run Misr Bank in the village of Aayat, 50 kilometres south of Cairo, with the attackers walking away with 400,000 pounds ($118,000).

"The Ministry of the Interior has almost succeeded in stopping funds from reaching the fundamentalists from abroad, thanks to a string of accords struck with several countries," a police official, who requested anonymity said.

"Deprived of funds, the armed fundamentalists have launched a campaign of robberies to buy weapons and they have carried out their raids in several regions to weaken the efficiency of the security services," the official said.

Two groups of commandos, comprising six militants each, have been set up to carry out hold-ups, with one group working in the northern region of south Egypt (Minya and Beni Suef), while the other group was in charge of armed robberies in Assyut and Sohag, further south, the official said.

Islamic militants have committed five armed robberies since April in banks and jewellery shops in the regions of Minya and Beni Suef, during which six people including four Coptic Christians were killed.

"The latest robberies have shown a serious gap in the security systems of banks and jewellery shops in some areas of southern Egypt, despite measures taken to face such situations," the police official added.

In Minya and Beni Suef, measures have included banning traffic in streets where banks and jewellery shops are located and ordering these establishments to close one hour before sunset.

The Jamaa militants raid jewellery shops owned by Coptic Christians because they consider them

"impious" and therefore believe that robbing them is legal.

The latest deaths brought to 1,047 the number of people killed since a wave of Islamic militant violence was unleashed in Egypt in March 1992, according to data compiled from police statements.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


445 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Algeria;
Algeria Says Extremists Didn't Massacre Civilians


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Algiers - The Algerian government has strongly denied a press report alleging that Islamic fundamentalists had slit the throats of 63 civilians, including pensioners and children, saying the Arab newspaper that carried it was trying to spread anxiety and support terrorism.

The London-based Arab daily Al-Hayat reported on August 19 that armed Islamic militants had cut the throats of 63 people including women, old people and children, in the worst attack on civilians since political violence erupted in Algeria in 1992.

The claim was "devoid of all basis in fact," the Algerian Interior Ministry said and accused the newspaper, distributed in Arab and Western capitals, of " seeking to sow strife and spread anxiety among public opinion." 

The newspaper had "but one objective: to support avowed terrorism come what may," the ministry statement charged.

The report had claimed that the massacre occurred on August 17 south-east of Algiers on a road between M'Sila and Batna. Batna is the birthplace of Algerian President Liamine Zeroual, whose regime the fundamentalists want to overthrow.

The mountainous region, where several Islamic underground forces are based, voted overwhelmingly in favour of Zeroual in the presidential polls in November.

The Algerian government has already reacted sharply to a report in Al-Hayat at the beginning of this month, claiming that French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette had escaped an assassination attempt during an official visit to Algiers.

Al-Hayat claimed that in the latest incident, some 100 militants armed with hunting rifles, daggers and axes, set up a false roadblock and stopped two buses packed with civilians, and after checking their identity cards, "they cut the throats of all the passengers from Batna, including women, the elderly and children."

Batna residents were earlier reported as having said that they had heard of a massacre, but it later turned out to refer to another incident elsewhere on August 15 when 17 young people were killed, 200 kilometres south of the capital.

Al-Hayat quoted Algerian sources as saying that the aim of the massacre was to target inhabitants from a specific region to provoke unrest between various tribes.

Civilians have been targeted in several attacks along Algeria's roads in the past months during the violence which first erupted in the country in January 1992 after the cancellation of elections which the banned Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) was poised to win, and has since left up to 50,000 people dead.

Zeroual has opened negotiations with most of the political parties ahead of a national conference to resolve the country's political future. The conference, from which FIS has been excluded, is due to take place by the end of the summer.

Algerian authorities have repeatedly insisted that they have tracked the problem of terrorism and that the militants are on the run and stripped of popular support.

Late on August 18, state television broadcast a list of telephone numbers and a plea to denounce those belonging to armed groups, showing a series of images of militant violence and attacks.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


446 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Women Pastors Challenge Gender Bias In The Church


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Kisumu, Kenya - The gender imbalance in the church leadership the world over will soon be a thing of the past, if a recent church convention here is anything to go by.

Participants at an international convention of women pastors at Kisumu Polytechnic here, some 360 kilometres north-west of the capital, Nairobi resolved that the higher ratio of men to their women counterparts in church leadership must be rectified.

The participants, all women pastors, called on the leaderships of all church organizations in the world to ordain more women priests, arguing that women can make as good ministers as their male counterparts. 

At the climax of the August 14 to 17 convention, over 5,000 faithful witnessed the ordination of 100 women priests at Kisumu's Moi Stadium. The function was presided over by church leaders from the United States and brought together women priests and clerics from the US, Russia, Australia, Ghana, Nigeria, Tanzania, Uganda and Kenya.

The convention was organized by women from the Voice of Salvation and Healing Church in Eastern Africa in collaboration with the US- based International Gospel Centre (IGC). The ordination ceremony was conducted by the head of the church, the Rev. Silas Owiti, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Ladonna Osborne and the Rev. Dr. Chyama Anthony, both from the International Gospel Centre. Dr. Osborne is a daughter of Dr. T.L. Osborne, also of the IGC.

During the ordination ceremony, Dr. Ladonna Osborne told the gathering: " Discrimination against women in the church must be a thing of the past," and called for a proper interpretation of the Bible. She said the Bible is "the foundation of our faith, but tradition and culture are not always Bible-based and should not be a basis for the discrimination against women.

"Kenya needs strong women in the church, politics and education to get rid of such vices as prostitution which come about because of the bias." Dr. Osborne noted that from the first century, church tradition has placed women below men, "but this is against God's will. The world is shrinking apace due to technological development, so once one country starts discussing one issue, the others will follow suit: change is thus inevitable."

The secretary-general of the Voice of Salvation and Healing church, Mrs Winnie Owiti, said women are the best soul winners and should be given a chance.

Earlier in the previous sessions of the convention, Mrs. Owiti had told the participants that it is unbelievable that a male priest is expected to lead a congregation of over 4,00 women, none of whom is a priest.

During one of the sessions, the participants called on the church leaders to step up the war against evil in society. They called upon the Church to exploit the freedom of worship, as guaranteed by the Kenyan constitution to fight evil without fear.

Said the pastors: "The world is currently reeling under the weight of immorality, and this must be curbed spiritually." And they warned political leaders against oppressing the weak in society. "When the weak are oppressed, God will always avenge this."

Dr. Osborne called upon mothers not to leave all the household chores to the girls, arguing that this makes girls feel inferior and the boys superior.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


447 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Arts;
Gallery Bids To Stop Transfer Of Zimbabwean Art


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Harare - The National Gallery of Zimbabwe will submit recommendations to the government to prevent works of art leaving the country before they have been referred to the gallery or before it has been given the right of first refusal.

The move is meant to curb the loss of some of the best cultural and artistic works from being siphoned out of the country.

"We would want to see a situation like that in the United Kingdom, where there is an act which forbids works of art from leaving the country before they are shown to the institution charged with preservation of the finest examples of their culture and heritage," says the executive director of the National Gallery, historian Prof. George Kahari. 

It is part of the work of the National Gallery to delve into the past, collect and preserve the finest examples of Zimbabwe's cultural heritage, enabling the institution to display the artistic and cultural soul of the nation.

Prof. Kahari said in an interview recently that the National Gallery was also concerned about what artists were being paid for their work. "The prices are low, but a contract between the buyer and seller (artist) at the moment prevents us from intervening."

The gallery, he adds, was "concerned and we are in the midst of formulating some guidelines to protect artists, especially those in the rural areas..."

As a historian, Prof. Kahari's concerns stem from knowledge of how art and sculpture in particular, has helped put Zimbabwe on the world map. There is also cognisance of the important role art plays in recording, embodying and anticipating the national aspirations and the need to be able to mirror these to the world.

The other cause for concern is driven by realisation of the potential loss to the nation if the situation continues without adoption of the proposals being formulated by the gallery.

The issue of the impact of airport art on fine art and the difference between the two is less of a problem, largely because of the existence of structures that distinguishes these, but also there is acceptance that even within airport art as in airport books, there are some gems of artistic brilliance.

President Robert Mugabe is scheduled to be the official guest at the opening of the prestigious Heritage Exhibition set for November this year.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


448 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 29, 1996


Burundi;
Human Rights Watch Appeals for Humanitarian Exemption


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

New York -- The following is a letter by Human Rights Watch urging the exemption of humanitarian aid and assistance from the economic sanctions imposed against Burundi. The letter was sent on August 28, 1996 to the presidents of Burundi, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, Zaire, and Zambia, to the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, and the secretary general of the Organization of African Unity.

In the letter, HRW also calls upon Burundi's new government to bring to trial those who have presided over the last three years of bloodshed.

Human Rights Watch is a nongovernmental organization established in 1978 to monitor and promote the observance of internationally recognized human rights in Africa, the Americas, Asia, the Middle East and among the signatories of the Helsinki accords. It is supported by contributions from private individuals and foundations worldwide. It accepts no government funds, directly or indirectly. 

The text of the letter:

On July 31,1996, in response to the coup d'etat that led to the installation of Major Pierre Buyoya as head of state, members of the Arusha " Emergency African Summit" imposed full economic sanctions upon Burundi including the cutting off of air links. Between August 2 and 10, 1996 all its neighbors implemented an economic embargo against Burundi. On August 16, 1996, regional foreign ministers decreed that only medicines and "emergency basic food aid for Rwandan refugees in Burundi" would be exempt from sanctions imposed at Arusha.

Although Human Rights Watch has serious concerns about the nature of the embargo imposed on Burundi, as outlined below, we share the sentiments that led Burundi's neighbors to act firmly in opposition to the coup. While we welcome the new government's pledge to stop the killing, we cannot help but note that the same military officers who launched the coup have been responsible for the terrible bloodshed at the hands of the Burundi army and allied militia for the past three years. A vow, in such circumstances, to stop the killing is hardly justification for abandoning the last elements of power sharing with the Hutu majority that remain from the June 1993 elections. Rather, a test of the new government's commitment to democracy and rule of law should not only be its willingness to begin immediate discussions about a return to constitutional rule, as neighboring countries are demanding, but also its willingness to bring to justice those who have presided over the last three years of slaughter. Among those who certainly should be brought to justice are the former army chief of staff, Col. Jean Bikomagu, and the head of the gendarmerie, Col. Pascal Simbanduka: they are both, according to Human Rights Watch's own investigations, responsible for serious, violent abuses of human rights.

Human Rights Watch is also profoundly troubled by the scope of the sanctions regime imposed on Burundi. We have received reports that the sanctions are severely constraining the efforts of humanitarian organizations to deliver assistance to the civilian population of Burundi. Little, if any humanitarian aid appears to be reaching an increasingly needy population. International humanitarian law prohibits the employment of starvation as a method of warfare. Parties to a conflict are enjoined from acts which might hinder the availability of commodities and services that are indispensable to the survival of the civilian population. By the same token, economic sanctions should not be applied in a manner that substantially risks denying Burundi's civilian population foodstuffs, medicines and other humanitarian supplies that are vital to its subsistence.

Humanitarian assistance should be entirely excluded from the sanctions regime imposed upon Burundi in order to enable non-governmental organizations to dispense aid to all sectors of Burundi's vulnerable civilian population. We therefore urge that at its inaugural meeting in Nairobi on August 31, the Regional Sanctions Committee should formally and unambiguously exempt all humanitarian cargo and personnel from the sanctions regime imposed upon Burundi at the July 31, 1996 Arusha summit.

In addition to an exemption for humanitarian assistance, steps should be taken to ensure that the aid is distributed among the civilian population on the basis of need alone rather than on grounds of ethnicity or political affiliation. Further, steps should be taken to ensure that humanitarian aid not go to any military force, and that military forces inside Burundi do not obstruct the delivery of this aid to its intended recipients. Humanitarian aid should be distributed by nongovernmental organizations, a United Nations agency, or a combination of these and coordinated by a mutually agreed upon UN or NGO body. There should also be established an effective mechanism for monitoring the impacts of the current embargo, even with these necessary humanitarian exemptions. Given the growing need for humanitarian assistance on the part of Burundi's civilian population, Human Rights Watch believes that the quest for guarantees against misuse of humanitarian aid should not be permitted to delay unduly the actual delivery of humanitarian supplies.

For more information, contact Human Rights Watch at 485 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10017-6104 , Tel: 212/972-8400. Fax: 212/972-0905. E-mail: hrwnyc@hrw.org.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 30, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Strike Puts Government In Hard Spot


BYLINE: Elliot Mahende, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1828 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The strike by civil servants in Zimbabwe has exposed divisions within the ruling ZANU PF (Zimbabwean African National Patriotic Front Party), the top leadership in government and civil servants.

It has also shown that while the ruling party has for the past five years liberalized the economy, a part of its leadership has not been able to liberalize its own mindset and still believes in media manipulation to achieve political goals.

These contradictions created a situation during the current strike by the civil servants in which the strikers won public sympathy and covert support from the police and the armed forces, who anticipated higher salaries should the government meet the demands of the strikers.

During the strike, the government, notably the minister of the public service, labor and social welfare, Florence Chitauro, made decisions which to many, including the strikers, were obviously unsustainable. 

Those on strike saw the hollowness of the threat to fire 90 percent of the civil service, including doctors, nurses, airport fire-fighters and technicians. How can the country be ran normally?

"Let them fire all of us and let's see how they hope to run the country. In fact we can grind the country to a halt if they continue along those lines," boasted Givemore Masongorere, president of the Public Services Association (PSA), when Chitauro announced the mass dismissal of civil servants on Monday.

Analysts sympathetic to the government have concluded that the cabinet decision to fire and shut all lines of communication with the strikers was based on wrong information.

The situation was compounded by a news black-out on the strike in the dominant state media. The origin and legality of that order remains unclear.

The acting director-general of the Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC), Victor Mhizha-Murira, acknowledging the black-out, saying it was a local decision by departmental heads.

The result, however, was that decision-makers found themselves in the dark as to the thinking of the strikers. On the other hand, the civil servants had scant regard to government statements coming out in the state media and ridiculed the newspapers.

An honest analysis based on accurate information might have predicted a lengthy industrial action given that the civil servants grievances were genuine and deep-seated.

The support rendered by the teachers, nurses and doctors who have had experience in such strikes could also have been seen as a factor that would bolster the resolve of the strikers.

The support the strikers received from members of parliament, some of them senior members of the ruling party, though initially suppressed from publication, also demonstrated the complexity of the civil servants strike and the level of support they had.

That the cabinet, and later the president, were acting on wrong information, came to light when Chitauro acknowledged what everybody else had known all along that the Public Service Commission had erred in awarding the majority of civil servants less than 10 percent salary increases when the original government commitment was at least 20 percent.

This was starkly illustrated when President Robert Mugabe, returning from South Africa, told journalists that he was not aware of the civil servants grievances and that as far as he knew, they had been awarded a 20 percent salary hike.

As a result, the apparent misrepresentation to cabinet and the president took center-stage for a long time resulting in the strike perhaps running longer than was necessary at the expense of the economy and the ordinary people who saw many of their relatives die in hospitals due to lack of care.

When the truth came out - that the civil servants had not been given what they had been promised and therefore had a genuine grievance - Chitauro found herself on quicksand, politically.

This, coming out at a time the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) had threatened a nationwide strike in support of the civil servants, could have made the task even more difficult for Chitauro to explain to her colleagues in cabinet.

An impression was created that the blunder was simply an oversight on the part of the government. It was a small issue that could be rectified (ratified, as Chitauro put it) and needed no negotiation with the civil servants but simply implementation.

What about the order dismissing all civil servants who had refused to go back to work before the new deal was struck?, asked members of the unified civil servants negotiating committee.

They stood to negotiate themselves out of work if that order was not rescinded.

Moreover, there was also the question of whether there would be any other victimization of the strikers, such as the withholding of pay for the time they have been on strike.

Chitauro, in a response which she repeated in writing on Friday, said that the order could only be rescinded by cabinet.

But her situation became invidious in that the same cabinet and president had acted on wrong information emanating from her office and the public service commission.

Some of her colleagues in cabinet, reportedly divided over the issue because of the misleading information, may want to know how that misinformation came about, whether it was deliberate, who was responsible and what agenda they were pushing.

There are political costs to be borne given that elections for the mayor for Harare are due early September.

The independent candidate, Kempton Makamure, challenging ZANU PF's Solomon Tawengwa, is putting up a spirited campaign while Tawengwa's campaign seems to be flagging despite being backed by the most powerful political machine in the land.

In Harare's satellite town of Chitungwiza, elections are also on for the mayor and the ruling party's candidate, Andrew Jiri, is facing a stiff challenge from the party's rebel, who chose to stand as an independent, George Mhashu.

In such a scenario, blunders by the PSC and Chitauro which tend to chip away at the party's popularity base, would inevitably be irksome to the party's old guard.

A former trade unionist who was co-opted into ZANU PF in 1990, when the party needed a representative from the ZCTU, Chitauro, despite her grave responsibilities in matters of state, is a lightweight in ZANU PF when the liberationists ponder their tenure of power.

While publicly Chitauro and her colleagues in cabinet will have to wriggle their way out of the current impasse, with a decision next Tuesday on whether the dismissed civil would be allowed back at work, somebody might have to bear the consequences of putting the party and government in such an invidious position.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


450 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 30, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia Rushes Assistance To Flooded Areas


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopian health authorities said here they have sent sufficient drugs, equipment and medical staff for victims of flooded areas in the eastern part of the country to control possible outbreak of malaria and water-borne diseases.

The country's health minister, Dr. Ahmed Ibrahim, said on television Thursday night a task force of health staff had been dispatched earlier this week to localities along the flooded middle and lower Awash river.

Following heavy flooding the previous week that completely inundated the sugar estate and factory town of Wonji, 125 km (78 miles) east of Addis Ababa, the government had to evacuate all of the town's 25,000 residents to higher grounds in the nearby town of Nazareth by the weekend. 

The minister said those who were evacuated have been getting sufficient medical attention.

He said a medical team with medicine and equipment had also been sent to the hamlet of Fogera on the northern shore of Lake Tana in north-western Ethiopia, which was partially flooded early this week.

Ethiopian television also reported that construction and reinforcement of protective bunkers was underway on the banks of Awash river to protect Dubti town from imminent floods.

It said a total of 20 km (12.5 miles) of dykes had been built, with the heights of the bunkers raised to 1.5 meters (5 feet), to protect Dubti, which is located in the lower Awash.

Flood water from the Awash has also invaded the hot-spring resort center at Sodere, 135 km ( 85 miles) east of the Ethiopian capital. The swollen Awash river has continued to wreck havoc on small towns, farm communities and large sugar and cotton plantations in the area since last week.

The one-square-kilometer (04.4 square mile) Sodere resort complex was flooded early Wednesday when its hot bath and swimming facilities were completely submerged by muddy waters from the Awash river.

According to press reports, close to 3,000 workers at the Sodere hotel and others from nearby banana, papaya and mango plantations have been evacuated to the town of Nazareth, 20 km (12.5 miles) west of Sodere.

Ethiopian authorities last night issued fresh warnings to the inhabitants along the middle and lower Awash river not be lulled by the stoppage of the rains during the last two days.

Sodere's flooding was caused by a discharge of waters Tuesday from the Koka dam, 35 km (22 miles) west of the sugar estate and factory town of Wonji that was totally flooded over the weekend.

The Koka dam was said to have been filled to the brim. Its floodgates were opened Tuesday as the water level of the dam passed the peak mark of 110 meters (363 feet) and started spilling over.

The only reported casualty so far has been an unidentified dead man whose body was found floating along the flooded Wonji-Nazareth road over the weekend.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


451 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 30, 1996


Burundi;
At Least 175 Rights Observers Needed in Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - A director from the Geneva-based United nations Human Rights center, Diabira Marufa, said Friday in Bujumbura that at least 175 international observers would be needed to monitor human rights in the 115 communes of Burundi.

Reacting to Thursday's request by the military regime in Bujumbura on the human rights commission to send observers to the civil-war torn country, he said up to 200 of such observers were necessary.

Marufa, who is Mauritanian, told PANA in Bujumbura the issue of sending observers to Bujumbura had been discussed with the previous administration of President Sylivestre Ntibantunganya, who was replaced by Maj. Pierre Buyoya in a Coup d'Etat on July 25. 

"A fund-raising campaign has been under way for the past one month among United Nations member countries," he said, without specifying the cost or duration of the proposed human rights observer mission.

He said, however, that some 950,000 US dollars was required to maintain 35 observers in Burundi for a month.

Since April, the European Union has been financing the activities of four human rights observers in Burundi. Last month, these observers wrote a critical report which angered the Tutsi-dominated Burundian army.

The report talked of "massive human rights violations" perpetrated against members of the Hutu majority ethnic group.

Marufa said the four observers had investigated "a certain number of major incidents" but were unable to travel to all parts of the country, particularly in the troubled north-eastern Burundi.

In its letter, the Burundi government asked the UN Human Rights High Commissioner to "substantially raise" the number of observers so as to " reinforce the government's efforts to end human rights violations in Burundi."

Bujumbura wrote the letter in the wake of a report by the London-based Amnesty International, which accused the Tutsi-dominated Burundian army of slaying up to 6,000 civilians between late July and early August.

The military regime in Bujumbura rejected the charge saying it was unrealistic.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


452 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 30, 1996


Kenya;
Kenya Airways Rated Fifth In Profitability Among Top Airlines


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenya Airways has been ranked the fifth most profitable airline in the world among 150 leading carriers in the 1995 category of best net margins.

Kenya Airways Public Relations Manager, Koome Mwambia, said the best net margins category, the indicator which measures profitability, was dominated by medium sized airlines where Kenya Airways was ranked fifth. 

"With a 13.8 percent margin KA is ranked closely behind Singapore Airlines in fourth position with 14.9 percent net category. Valujet tops the category with 18.4 percent," he said.

Mwambia said that the survey, published in the September edition of the aviation journal, Airline Business, also reported a steady trend of profitability in aviation business with 11.5 percent growth in sales for 1995 compared to 10.8 percent in 1994, among the top 100 airlines.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


453 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 30, 1996


Liberia;
Charles Taylor Arrives in Tripoli


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - Charles Taylor, a member of the Liberian Council of State, arrived in Tripoli on Thursday, to attend ceremonies marking the 27th anniversary of Col. Moammar Kadhafi's accession to power.

He said he was "very happy" to be in Libya ahead of Sunday's celebration of the "great African revolution which freed Libya and brought back its people's dignity." 

"We will take this opportunity to discuss with our Libyan friends the means of restoring peace and security in Liberia and relaunch economic and social development activities," he added.

This is Taylor's first visit to Libya. He arrived in Tripoli by land via the Tunisian island of Djerba, leading a strong delegation.

Meanwhile, President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana left Accra Friday for Libya, to participate in the celebration, at the invitation of Col. Gaddafi.

Libya is also using the occasion to show-case the successful completion of its Great Man-Made-River Project.

The project is designed to supply drinking water as well as irrigate vast semi-arid country for agriculture.

Rawlings is travelling with retired Capt. Kojo Tsikata, Council of State Member and Dr Mohamed Ibn Chambas, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


454 of 455 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 30, 1996


Kenya;
Opening Of Mombasa Airport Terminal Postponed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - The opening of Mombasa's new terminal, at Moi International Airport, has been put off until September 5, because of missing vital passenger equipment, Airport Manager Samson Nyole has said.

The terminal, which should have become operational Thursday, has remained non-operational since it was commissioned more than two months ago owing to lack of vital security and surveillance equipment. 

Nyole said that the missing equipment, which includes baggage X-Ray machines, scanners and surveillance cameras, had been installed.

Recently, there have been concerns about the airport's safety after vital landing equipment became non-functional. However, the management replaced the faulty equipment quickly.

Major features at the new terminal include a stand-by generator, air bridges, a first class lounge, escalators, a business center and an a-la- carte restaurant.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Libya;
Liberia's Charles Taylor Arrives in Tripoli


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - Charles Taylor, a member of the Liberian Council of State, arrived in Tripoli on Thursday, to attend ceremonies marking the 27th anniversary of Col. Moammar Kadhafi's accession to power.

He said he was "very happy" to be in Libya ahead of Sunday's celebration of the "great African revolution which freed Libya and brought back its people's dignity." 

"We will take this opportunity to discuss with our Libyan friends the means of restoring peace and security in Liberia and relaunch economic and social development activities," he added.

This is Taylor's first visit to Libya. He arrived in Tripoli by land via the Tunisian island of Djerba, leading a strong delegation.

Meanwhile, President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana left Accra Friday for Libya, to participate in the celebration, at the invitation of Col. Gaddafi.

Rawlings is travelling with retired Capt. Kojo Tsikata, Council of State Member and Dr Mohamed Ibn Chambas, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs.
